title: Research on Current-Based Torque Estimation for Robot Joint Parameter Identification Based on Recursive Least Squares
authors: Zepei Jiang, Guorong Zhu, Yihong Zheng, Jun Fan, Kui Xiang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Robotics and Automatic Control (IRAC)
abstract: With the rapid development of robotics, torque estimation technology in servo systems, as the foundation for achieving precise control, efficient operation, and intelligence of robot joints, has become one of the research hotspots in the field of servo control in recent years. Addressing the issues of mechanical structure design, installation dimensions, and equipment costs associated with traditional methods of obtaining torque measurements by installing torque sensors and attaching strain gauges to collect voltage signals, this paper analyzes the mechanical motion model of the servo system, identifies the mechanical parameters of the servo system based on the recursive least squares algorithm, realizes real-time estimation of the load torque of the servo system, builds a simulation model, and verifies the effectiveness of this torque estimation technology through simulation and experiments.

title: Improving Information Security of the Exchange of IoT Data with the Use of Lora-Based Encryption Methods
authors: Qobulova Zulakho, Irgasheva Durdona
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: The propagation of the Internet of Things (IoT) has resulted in greater demand for communication systems capable of being used effectively over a long distance but using minimum energy. LoRa (Long Range) is another technology that has become popular to support such requirements and its coverage and power consumption are quite good and can be used in large scale deployments of the IoT. In spite of these strengths, LoRa based networks are still prone to a networking range of security threats because of open wireless channels and unlicensed spectrum. The topic of the study is the improvement in data security in the context of LoRa networks that transmit the data. The research is aimed at eliminating the vulnerabilities in standard LoRaWAN protocol. We propose multi-layered, in which advanced encryption algorithms, integration of changes in the session key and energy-efficient inetrusion detection mechanism is made possible. It is shown, through experimental analysis, that the suggested frame-work increases resilience towards eavesdropping, replay attacks, and providing protection against device spoofing without sacrificing the low-power features that are central to IoT applications.

title: A Unified Energy Management System Framework for Active Distribution Networks with Hybrid Energy Storage and Decentralized Voltage Control
authors: Ahmed Bedawy, Yutaka Sasaki, Chiraz Krifa, Yoshifumi Zoka, Naoto Yorino
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: High penetration of renewable energy sources (RES) and inverter-based resources (IBRs) in active distribution networks presents two major operational challenges: maintaining voltage quality and managing the variability of distributed generation. This paper proposes a unified Energy Management System (EMS) framework that brings together several established methods into one conceptual platform. The first component is a neural network-based forecasting module for photovoltaic (PV) generation and load demand, which supports a two-stage storage management strategy, day-ahead mixed-integer linear programming (MILP) scheduling, and intraday model predictive control (MPC) corrections, for the coordinated operation of battery energy storage systems (BESS) and hydrogen energy storage systems (HESS). The second component is a sensitivity-based voltage control layer, implemented using a multi-agent system (MAS) to coordinate voltage regulators and inverter reactive power in real time. While the forecasting-based storage management and the decentralized voltage control operate as separate modules in the current study, the proposed framework outlines how they could be combined in future work. Each algorithm is validated individually through simulations on benchmark distribution test feeders, demonstrating reduced voltage deviations, minimized tap changes, improved energy scheduling, and enhanced state-of-charge (SOC) and level-of-hydrogen (LOH) tracking.

title: Design of an UWB Asymmetric Stripline Directional Coupler with Low Ripple
authors: Zexi Zhu, Zhiqiang Yu, Jianyi Zhou
abstract: An ultra-wideband directional coupler based on Chebyshev tapered transmission line is proposed. The offset parallel-coupled stripline structures are implemented. According to measured results, the operating frequency range is 1.6 GHz–10 GHz, reaching a relative bandwidth about 145%. The features of the proposed coupler include a coupling coefficient of 15 dB, return loss better than 10 dB, and isolation better than 20 dB. To reduce design and optimization complexity, the number of design parameters was minimized while maintaining performance. Parameter optimization was achieved using a particle swarm optimization algorithm within a MATLAB-HFSS co-simulation. Transition circuits were added at all four ports to facilitate integration with microstrip lines.

title: The Cultivation and Evaluation Model of College Students' Innovation Ability Based on the Concept of "Five-Education Integration"
authors: Rongchun Hu, Qiang Li, Juan Ma
abstract: The comprehensive development of morality, intelligence, physical fitness, aesthetics, and labor has become one of the core goals of higher education. The concept of "five-education integration" requires the integration of moral education, intellectual education, physical education, aesthetic education, and labor education to enhance students' comprehensive literacy. With the development of neural network and artificial intelligence (AI) technologies, their application in the field of education provides new perspectives for cultivating college students' innovative abilities. This paper discusses the cultivation and evaluation of innovation ability under the concept of 'five-education integration', establishes an innovation ability evaluation model by integrating the 'five-education' data, and applies the model in practice, achieving the expected results.

title: An AI-based Approach to 5G Networks' Dynamic Resource Allocation
authors: Ernazar N. Reypnazarov, Bairam K. Turumbetov, Gozzal B. Eshniyazova, Tazakhan M. Babazhanova, Aykerim O. Karimova
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: The paper refers to and compares dynamic plans of resource distribution in 5G networks under the patronage of artificial intelligence algorithms. A scheme of simulation in the Python programming environment based on the reinforcement learning schemes (DQN, PPO) and load forecasting schemes (LSTM) is put forward considering low-/peak-load and heterogenous users mobility. It is demonstrated that DQN outperforms always the fixed and proportionally fair schemes: reduces the average latency (in URLLC - to standard levels of <2 ms), increases QoE (including in peak load case - >4.0 on a five-point scale), enhances throughput and energy efficiency. The ensuing data bear witness to the viability of AI deployment for self-driving network evolution and open doors towards 6G.

title: Physics-Informed Neural Network for Sensorless Speed Prediction of Submersible Motors
authors: Haolei Shao, Lihua Zhou, Qi Liu, Siying Wang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: This paper presents a sensorless control method for submersible motors based on a physics-informed neural network (PINN). The proposed model predicts the stator currents and rotor angular speed directly from voltage control inputs, eliminating the need for traditional sensors. To evaluate its effectiveness, a standard data-driven neural network (NN) was trained under identical conditions for comparison. Simulation results demonstrate that the PINN achieves faster and smoother loss convergence on training data, and exhibits superior generalization on unseen operating conditions with different loads and target speeds. These findings confirm that embedding the motor's physical dynamics into the learning process effectively improves model stability, data efficiency, and robustness for submersible motor control.

title: Research on Model-Free Predictive Current Control Strategy for Axial Flux-Switching Shaftless Rim Driven Motor
authors: Chenxuan Zhang, Ziyi Tai, Haoyu Wang, Yifei Ren, Wei Zhang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: To solve the issue of parameter mismatch in the axial field flux-switching permanent magnet motor (AFFSPMM) caused by the complex and dynamic marine environment, which adversely affects the robustness of the control system, this paper proposes a model-free predictive current control (MFPCC) strategy based on an extended state observer (ESO). Firstly, the mathematical model of the AFFSPMM under MFPCC is established. Then, the ultra-local model and the extended state observer are designed to enable online estimation and compensation of lumped disturbances. Finally, the control system simulation model and experimental platform are developed to validate the proposed control strategy. The simulation and experimental results demonstrate that, compared with traditional model predictive current control (MPCC), the proposed strategy improves the stability and robustness of control system.

title: A Graph Neural Network-Based AC Microgrid Fault Diagnosis Model
authors: Mingjun He, Ke Fan, Song Zhang, Xinyu You, Yongxiang Cai
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: The stable operation of AC microgrids is crucial for power system reliability, and its fault diagnosis directly affects power supply security and system maintenance efficiency. However, traditional diagnostic methods perform poorly under dynamic microgrid topology conditions. This paper proposes a graph neural network-based fault diagnosis method for AC microgrids, leveraging the advantages of a multi-perspective feature extraction module, a feature coordination attention mechanism, and a fault feature generation module. First, the microgrid topology graph is constructed, and the multi-perspective feature extraction module is employed to capture high-level semantic features and shallow features of nodes. Subsequently, the feature coordination attention mechanism dynamically allocates feature weights to enhance useful information. Finally, the Transformer encoder and fault feature extraction attention mechanism in the fault feature generation module achieve accurate discrimination of three-phase faults. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method exhibits high diagnostic accuracy and adaptability under circuit breaker state changes and line impedance fluctuations.

title: Dual-Platform Comparative Study: Evaluating Generative AI for English Writing Errors Correction
authors: Yiding Liu, Yi Zhang
abstract: With the explosive growth of generative AI, the usage rate of generative AI by Chinese students when learning English is also increasing. This study presents a comparative assessment of DeepSeek and Doubao, two leading generative AI platforms in China, focusing on their efficacy in correcting English writing errors of Chinese learners. Adopting James’ error classification, the research evaluates 60 authentic errors from the iWrite corpus. The capabilities of the two generative AI platforms in English writing errors correction were evaluated by examining their performance on indicators such as accurate recognition and effective correction. Results indicate comparable ontology error correction for both platforms, with DeepSeek outperforming in text errors and Doubao excelling in discourse errors. In terms of judgment speed, Doubao is significantly superior to Deepseek. This research provides valuable insights for English learners to select a more appropriate generative AI platform tailored to their needs. Additionally, it facilitates developers in identifying the limitations of the platform and enhancing its performance.

title: AI-Powered Cybersecurity Framework: From Reactive Defense to Proactive, Resilient, and Autonomous Protection
authors: Richa Trivedi
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: As our world becomes more dependent on digital systems in areas like finance, healthcare, and government, cyber threats are growing rapidly in both scale and complexity. Global cybercrime damages are expected to cross $10.5 trillion annually by 2025, and traditional security methods that rely on signatures or fixed rules are no longer effective against new, unknown attacks. This paper presents an AI-powered cybersecurity framework that uses machine learning to detect unusual behavior, connect threat patterns in real time, and respond automatically with minimal human effort.Experiments using real datasets and enterprise logs show strong improvements—detection accuracy up to 96.8%, fewer false alerts, and a 96% faster incident response. These results suggest that artificial intelligence can transform cybersecurity from a reactive process (responding after an attack) into a proactive and self-learning system capable of preventing, adapting to, and recovering from threats automatically

title: AI-Assisted Resource Allocation in 5G/6G Networks
authors: Rahul Kumar, Ashok Kumar, Jitendra Kumar Chaudhary, Mahadev, Anil Kumar, Vikas Thada
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: The current generation of wireless communication systems is anticipated to provide ultra reliable connectivity, very low latency and brilliant automation in billions of devices. Nevertheless, to reach these high-aspirational objectives, there is the need to transform the status quo of resource allocation to adaptive and learning-oriented mechanisms. In this paper, the author will discuss the incorporation of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in resource allocation models of 5G and 6G networks. Comprising a synthesis of recent advances in the AI-RAN convergence, dynamic Quality of Service (QoS) management, and centralised versus decentralised orchestration models, the research paper identifies the way AI-based algorithms can be used to improve spectral efficiency, latency, and energy use. The discussion also reveals existing open issues of scalability, transparency, and real-time learning, which give information on how AI-native architectures can redefine 6G network intelligence.

title: Research on Fault Diagnosis Model of Gas Turbine Under Variable Operating Conditions
authors: Chengdong Cui
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Robotics and Automatic Control (IRAC)
abstract: To address the challenge of low fault diagnosis accuracy in gas turbines operating under varying conditions, a deep learning-based fault diagnosis method is proposed. This method combines a multi-dimensional feature extraction model with dynamic transfer learning to achieve in-depth analysis of operational data. Under different load conditions, this method achieves a diagnostic accuracy of 95.8%, with a temperature adaptability range of -20°C to 45°C. After employing an improved attention mechanism, the sensitivity for compressor blade crack detection reaches 0.5mm, and the early warning time exceeds 72 hours. During eight months of application in an F-class gas turbine, it successfully predicted 41 potential faults.

title: Low-Power Silicon Photonic Modulator for On-Chip Optical Interconnects
authors: Zarifa Mamadiyeva, Shakhlokhon Kurbanova, Erkin Iskandarov, Jushkinbek Yuldoshev, Odilbek Matsapayev, Sudha Shanker Prasad
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: The increasing demand for high-speed and energy efficient data transfer in modern computing systems has driven the adoption of optical interconnects as an alternative to conventional electronic links. In this work, we present a low-power silicon photonic modulator specifically designed for on-chip optical interconnect applications. The proposed device employs a compact Mach–Zehnder interferometer with PN-depletion phase shifters, optimized to achieve a low V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">π</inf>L product, reduced insertion loss, and high extinction ratio. Through simulations and preliminary measurements, the design demonstrates operation up to 100Gb/s with an energy consumption of less than 0.35pJ/bit, outperforming traditional electronic and photonic baselines. There are also results which demonstrate excellence in bit error rate (BER) operation in forward error correction (FEC) thresholds and better thermal stability than is desired in large-scale integration. This confirms the applicability of the proposed modulator to making it possible to provide scalable, low-latency, and power-effective optical interconnects to next-generation high-performance computing and data center architectures.

title: A Hybrid Edge-Cloud Smart Door Surveillance System with Real-Time Risk Assessment and Secure Access Control
authors: Chuan-En Hou, Regina Sliusar, Armin Ghauforian, Tokunbo Makanju, Umme Zakia
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: This paper presents a hybrid edge-cloud smart door surveillance system designed to enhance residential security through real-time video analytics, anomaly detection, and dynamic access control. A local webcam captures live video streams processed at the edge by a Flask-Based server, integrating YOLOv8 object detection, HMM-based behavior anomaly detection, and facial recognition for identity verification. To guarantee uninterrupted operation without network connectivity, we also implement a fully offline face-recognition mode on the ESP32-CAM enabling the door to unlock locally under 100 ms. In parallel, a retrainable cloud-based Azure Custom Vision model detected object identities, assessed risk levels dynamically triggering local actions such as door control and real-time email alerts with contextual evidence. When risk levels exceed predefined thresholds, the system autonomously captures critical frames and sends alert or action-required notifications with attached visual evidence, using risk-specific visual theming. To address edge computing limitations in complex cases, recorded videos are analyzed by AWS Rekognition for comprehensive label detection. A responsive web interface provides live monitoring, event logging, OTP-based visitor access, and remote door operation, enhanced by dynamic UI feedback based on threat severity. This work demonstrates an integrated, scalable, and cost-efficient approach to edge-assisted smart security systems, laying a foundation for future improvements in multi-camera coordination ensuring the embedded firmware remains lightweight and easily updatable.

title: Performance Analyses of Discrete-Time ZNN for Solving Pseudoinversion of Time-Variant Matrices with Different Parameters
authors: Khaled M. Alamrani, Zhihan Xu, Liang Feng, Yueyang Ma, Chao Jiang, Yang Shi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Robotics and Automatic Control (IRAC)
abstract: Neural networks are fundamental tools in artificial intelligence and numerical computation. This paper investigates the performance of discrete-time Zhang neural network (DT-ZNN) models in solving the pseudoinversion problem of time-varying matrices. First, the continuous-time Zhang neural network (CT-ZNN) model is derived for computing the dynamic pseudoinverse of full-rank matrices. Then, drawing on recent advances in discretization methods, we adopt the general-four-instant (GFI) discretization formula—incorporating a tunable selection parameter—to convert the CT-ZNN model into its discrete counterpart. The resulting GFI-type DT-ZNN model undergoes rigorous analysis, focusing on the effects of different selection parameters on convergence and computational precision. Numerical experiments verify the effectiveness of the proposed GFI-type DT-ZNN model, illustrating its superiority in addressing time-varying matrix pseudoinversion across diverse parameter settings.

title: Reframing Financial Forecasting with Information Processing Theory: A Conceptual AI Framework
authors: Yara Mohammed, Koushik Sriram, Gahangir Hossain
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: Deep learning methods such as Bidirectional LSTM (BiLSTM) have been widely applied to financial forecasting [1], [2], [3], yet most studies focus on predictive accuracy and technical optimization. Less attention has been given to the conceptual foundations of how AI systems process financial information and support decision-making. This paper introduces a conceptual framework for stock forecasting grounded in Information Processing Theory (IPT). We adapt IPT stages of attention, encoding, storage, and retrieval to describe how a forecasting pipeline can be structured around three layers: a Data Layer for OHLCV time series and engineered indicators, a Machine Learning Layer using BiLSTM-based modeling, and an AI Analyst Layer that communicates structured outputs for decision support. By aligning this architecture with IPT, we argue that AI forecasting systems can be understood as structured information processors that parallel aspects of human reasoning while contributing to, rather than replacing, analyst expertise. The framework provides a theoretical basis for considering issues such as transparency, interpretability, and reliance, and establishes a foundation for future empirical investigations of AI applications in finance.

title: Deep Learning-Based Fractional Doppler-Resilient Channel Estimation for OTFS Systems
authors: Yi Feng, Guiyang Li, Zhengyao Zhang, Luchao Cheng, Yunfei Li, Chaochao Lv
abstract: Orthogonal Time-Frequency Space (OTFS) modulation technology has garnered significant attention in the field of wireless communications in recent years, particularly demonstrating inherent advantages in high-speed mobile scenarios. In OTFS modulation systems, the fractional Doppler effect has emerged as one of the core challenges in channel estimation under high-mobility environments such as vehicle-to-everything (V2X) networks, high-speed rail, and 6G communications. OTFS effectively mitigates the impact of time-varying channels by transforming signals into the delayed Doppler (DD) domain. However, fractional Doppler disrupts the sparsity of the channel, leading to modeling errors and performance degradation in traditional grid-based sampling methods. This, in turn, results in inaccurate channel estimation, high equalization complexity, and insufficient system robustness. To address this, this paper proposes a novel network architecture based on the Unet framework with residual attention fusion (AR-Unet), specifically designed for fractional Doppler channel estimation in OTFS systems. The model is built on the Unet learning framework, enhancing nonlinear feature fitting capabilities and training stability through deep stacked residual modules. It combines a channel attention mechanism to achieve adaptive modeling of key path gain features, effectively capturing the energy structure in the delay-Doppler domain. The encoder consists of multi-scale residual stacks, performing layer-wise feature compression to significantly enhance the model’s representational capacity, while the decoder incorporates an upsampling mechanism to reconstruct high-dimensional channel structures. Experimental results demonstrate that, compared to traditional deep learning methods (e.g., deep neural networks (DNN)/convolutional neural networks (CNN)) and the DRANet network, it exhibits outstanding estimation accuracy and generalization capabilities. This fully validates its application potential in complex high-mobility scenarios.

title: A Multi-Resonant Multi-Output (MRO) DC Converter with Multi-Electrolyzer Hybrid Connections
authors: Lifeng Gou, Qingping Ye, Jinpei Duan, Yong Chang, Junqing Wang, Lu Qu, Bojin Tang, Bin Cui, Liang Dong, Zhanqing Yu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: Large-capacity DC hydrogen production converters stand as a core equipment for large-scale DC hydrogen production systems using renewable energy. To address the fluctuations of wind and solar energy and meet the diverse demands of large-scale hydrogen production, this paper introduces a novel architecture for large-capacity DC hydrogen production converters with multi-electrolyzer hybrid connections. The study analyzes the architecture’s typical topology, operational mechanism, and key parameter design methodology. Based on multiple resonant cavities and a multi-channel independent output structure, this architecture integrates medium-frequency inversion with non-isolated DC/DC cascading to achieve wide-range, low-ripple, and high-efficiency power supply to various types of electrolyzers. At last, the effectiveness and feasibility of the proposed scheme are validated in a hybrid system simulation model incorporating multiple loads.

title: RFD-YOLO: A Lightweight Method for Efficient Rotten Fruit Detection
authors: Haifeng Xu, Jingke Chen, Jinming Mo, Jiangling Guo
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Software Engineering and Service Science (ICSESS)
abstract: The detection of rotten fruits is crucial for the production of fruit products. However, existing object detection algorithms often have high computational demands and require substantial hardware resources. We propose a lightweight detection method, RFD-YOLO, based on an improved YOLOv8, to address these issues, achieving automatic detection of rotten fruits. First, we reconstruct the YOLOv8 backbone by employing Shuffle Block and StemBlock and replace the C2F module in the head with DWConv to reduce the model's parameters. Furthermore, we introduce the LSKBlock and Shape-IoU loss function to enhance the model accuracy while maintaining small parameter size. Finally, the RFD-YOLO model was trained and validated using a handcrafted dataset specifically constructed for detecting rotten fruit. The model's parameter size is 0.9M, representing a 72.7% reduction compared to the lightest model in the YOLOv8 series, YOLOv8n, while achieving mAP@0.5 of 90.9% and mAP@0.5-0.95 of 46.5%.

title: Electroencephalography (EEG)-Based Forgetting Analysis in Fragmented Learning Contexts
authors: Mingyan Zhang, Jingjing Bai, Zhaozhuan Zeng, Yaxin Deng, Lizhao Zhang, Nan Zhang
abstract: Fragmented learning, characterized by high flexibility and knowledge segmentation, enhances time utilization efficiency but is prone to forgetting phenomena, leading to memory impairments and attentional dispersion. This study examines knowledge forgetting in fragmented learning through a designed experiment. Participants' knowledge retention was evaluated based on response accuracy, while EEG signals were analyzed to assess cognitive load, relaxation, and attention states during forgetting episodes. The testing effect in fragmented learning was also explored. Key findings include: (1) Forgetting and the testing effect coexist in fragmented learning — while knowledge decay occurs, retrieval practice facilitates memory recovery; (2) Cognitive load remains stable during forgetting, whereas attention and relaxation exhibit an inverse relationship; (3) Maintaining moderately high cognitive load helps reduce forgetting, while attention fluctuations correlate with knowledge loss.This research provides insights into forgetting mechanisms in fragmented learning, linking behavioral performance with neurophysiological states. The findings have theoretical and practical implications for optimizing learning strategies through testing-based interventions.

title: Research on the Complementary Operation Model of Pumped Storage and Hydropower under Generation-Grid-Load-Storage Coordination
authors: Xiaowei Yu, Jianhua Yang, Chengyuan Li
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: With the growing integration of wind and solar power, power systems face increasing peak-shaving demands. This paper proposes an optimized joint operation model for pumped storage, reversible hydropower, and cascade hydropower under generation-grid-load-storage coordination, aiming to minimize total operating costs while considering multiple constraints. Case studies based on the H cascade system show that adding reversible units or pumping stations significantly improves renewable energy integration (S3 by 3.86% over S1), reduces renewable curtailment, and enhances peak-shaving and economic performance. Reversible hydropower demonstrates strong flexibility and energy transfer efficiency.

title: Evaluating Security Checks Against Malicious Payloads with Forged Signatures
authors: Lalchandra Rampersaud, Behzad Ousat, Seyed Ali Akhavani, Javad Zandi, Selcuk Uluagac, Amin Kharraz
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: Adversaries increasingly leverage diverse techniques to distribute malicious payloads across the web. One common, low-cost tactic is the hijacking of digital signatures and their attachment to malicious binaries, with the intent of deceiving both web browsers and operating systems. While code-signing certificates have traditionally served to verify the authenticity and integrity of software, adversaries now exploit these same certificates to evade detection mechanisms and facilitate the propagation of malicious code. This study seeks to empirically evaluate how modern web browsers respond to untrusted code by analyzing their reactions to signed malicious binaries. Our analysis shows that browsers’ responses to certificate abuses may differ significantly, and the operating system may respond ineffectively potentially leaving end-users vulnerable to straightforward adversarial tactics. We also show that it is possible to significantly reduce the attack surface against certificate abuse with the use of a browser extension.

title: Challenges and Solutions for High-Speed Intra-Datacenter Connections Based on VCSEL-MMF Links
authors: Ann Margareth Rosa Brusin, Dario Pilori, Francesco Aquilino, Antonino Nespola, Fabrizio Forghieri, Andrea Carena
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: Around 30%-40% of intra-datacenter connections still rely on vertical cavity surface emitting lasers (VCSELs) and multi-mode fibers (MMFs), generally legacy OM3 and OM4. However, the next-generation systems will require transmission throughputs above 100G/lane, with targets towards 200 G/lane. An open discussion is undergoing whether VCSEL-MMF technology is still suitable, so in this paper we discuss the challenges and the solutions for high-speed intra-datacenter connections.

title: Queuing Analysis of a Traffic Shaping Scheme
authors: Peter Buchholz
publish: 2025 33rd International Symposium on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Computer and Telecommunication Systems (MASCOTS)
abstract: In [1] a new traffic shaping scheme denoted as Quasi-Deterministic Transmission Policy’ (QDTP) has been proposed and analyzed under deterministic and stochastic assumptions. This model is extended by considering phase type distributed and possible correlated arrivals, delays and services combined with load dependent behavior. Load dependent behavior is important to model overload situations at processing devices in a realistic way. It is shown that the resulting model describes a Quasi Birth Death Process (QBD) without state dependent rates for the delays and a Level Dependent Quasi Birth Death Process (LDQBD) with state dependent rates for the delays. We present an approach based on the recursive computation of QBDs or LDQBDs which can be applied if the number of states remains moderate. Larger models can be solved by a block iteration method. Finally, we show how the population in the system can be minimized by choosing an appropriate delay rate or vector of delay rates.

title: Profiling the Energy Consumption of Secure Neural Network Inference
authors: Tanjina Islam, Ana Oprescu, Zoltán Ádám Mann, Sander Klous
publish: 2025 33rd International Symposium on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Computer and Telecommunication Systems (MASCOTS)
abstract: Secure neural network inference (SNNI) enables the use of deep neural networks in scenarios involving multiple stakeholders, protecting the confidentiality of client data and of the neural network’s parameters. The cryptographic techniques used introduce high computational overhead, leading to significant energy consumption. Reducing the energy consumption of SNNI is thus an important objective. A prerequisite for energy optimization is the ability to profile the energy consumption of SNNI. However, this is challenging due to the complexity of the cryptographic techniques, neural networks, and technical setup involved. This paper is the first to propose an energy profiling approach for SNNI. Our approach measures the energy consumption for securely processing individual layers of the neural network, thus providing fine-grained insights into the energy profile of SNNI. We evaluate our approach using the ResNet50 neural network and the Cheetah SNNI framework. Our results show that we can reliably measure the energy consumption of individual layers. By introducing short periods of inactivity between layers to disentangle them, we achieve high correlation between execution time and energy consumption, suggesting that, under appropriate conditions, execution time may be used as a proxy for energy consumption. Our approach and insights can foster the design of more energy-efficient SNNI protocols.
