title: Modality Interaction Decoupling: Spatiotemporal Memory-Driven Unified Multimodal Tracking Framework
authors: Lifeng Wang, Binbin Wang, Fasheng Wang, Mengyin Wang, Fuming Sun, Haojie Li
abstract: Current designs of multimodal tracking networks primarily focus on spatial feature interaction within the backbone and lack the exploitation of temporal information. Although some approaches incorporate temporal cues by introducing sequential information from adjacent frames or employ updated temporal features during the feature extraction stage, they struggle to capture dynamic object variations and motion information in complex scenarios. To address these limitations, this paper proposes a Spatiotemporal Memory-Driven Unified Multimodal Tracking Framework (SMMTrack). Unlike existing works relying on feature interaction paradigms within the backbone network, this study innovatively introduces a decoupled backbone feature extraction framework. It deploys parallel, independent Vision Transformer (ViT) networks dedicated to extracting information from RGB and X modalities (RGB-T, RGB-D, RGB-E), abandoning the conventional intra-backbone feature interaction. Furthermore, we introduce a memory mechanism during the feature extraction stage to enable long-term object modeling. In addition, a Long-term Memory storage and retrieval module is designed to dynamically update the Memory-list, thereby allowing the model to capture object appearance variations and motion trends comprehensively. SMMTrack is a unified framework across three tasks (RGB-T, RGB-D, and RGB-E tracking). Experimental results demonstrate that SMMTrack outperforms the state-of-the-art (SOTA) models, achieving outstanding performance in diverse multimodal tracking scenarios. Codes and results are released on https://github.com/qfxb/SMMTrack.

title: Enhancing Metaverse Fidelity and Freshness via GAI–aided Semantic Communication in Low-Altitude IoT Networks
authors: Xiaoyi Zhou, Hongzhi Guo, Yijie Xun, Bomin Mao, Dejun Mu
abstract: The rapid iteration of artificial intelligence (AI) and 5G technologies has created essential foundations for Metaverse, easing bottlenecks in content generation, real-time interaction, and large-scale deployment. Integrating unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) with semantic communication (SemCom) further provides a lightweight sensing and uplink solution, but semantic compression and bias may degrade fidelity. Generative AI (GAI), with powerful contextual modeling and generation capabilities, helps mitigate these issues. Based on this, this paper proposes a GAI-aided SemCom architecture and evaluates the feasibility of applying it to low-altitude internet of things (IoT) networks. We build evaluation models for representative image compression and GAI-aided SemCom techniques, replacing traditional task assumptions with realistic cases. Then, taking UAV networks as an example, we design a path planning and two task allocation schemes. Specifically, the UAV path planning strategy together with a greedy task allocation scheme improves the Metaverse update frequency and ensures the data freshness, while a parametrized deep Q-network (PDQN) task allocation scheme jointly optimizes Metaverse fidelity and freshness through mixed action selection, i.e., preprocessing methods (discrete) and compression size (continuous). Extensive analysis and numerical results corroborate that GAI-aided SemCom technology has practical significance in low-altitude IoT networks. Through the collaboration of multiple data processing schemes and the rational resource allocation, the fidelity and freshness of Metaverse can be greatly improved.

title: SurgRAW: Multi-Agent Workflow with Chain of Thought Reasoning for Robotic Surgical Video Analysis
authors: Chang Han Low, Ziyue Wang, Tianyi Zhang, Zhu Zhuo, Zhitao Zeng, Evangelos B. Mazomenos, Yueming Jin
abstract: Robotic-assisted surgery (RAS) is central to modern surgery, driving the need for intelligent systems with accurate scene understanding. Most existing surgical AI methods rely on isolated, task-specific models, leading to fragmented pipelines with limited interpretability and no unified understanding of RAS scene. Vision-Language Models (VLMs) offer strong zero-shot reasoning, but struggle with hallucinations, domain gaps and weak task-interdependency modeling. To address the lack of unified data for RAS scene understanding, we introduce SurgCoTBench, the first reasoning-focused benchmark in RAS, covering 14256 QA pairs with frame-level annotations across five major surgical tasks. Building on SurgCoTBench, we propose SurgRAW, a clinically aligned Chain-of-Thought (CoT) driven agentic workflow for zero-shot multi-task reasoning in surgery. SurgRAW employs a hierarchical reasoning workflow where an orchestrator divides surgical scene understanding into two reasoning streams and directs specialized agents to generate task-level reasoning, while higher-level agents capture workflow interdependencies or ground output clinically. Specifically, we propose a panel discussion mechanism to ensure task-specific agents collaborate synergistically and leverage on task interdependencies. Similarly, we incorporate a retrieval-augmented generation module to enrich agents with surgical knowledge and alleviate domain gaps in general VLMs. We design task-specific CoT prompts grounded in surgical domain to ensure clinically aligned reasoning, reduce hallucinations and enhance interpretability. Extensive experiments show that SurgRAW surpasses mainstream VLMs and agentic systems and outperforms a supervised model by 14.61% accuracy. Dataset and code is available at https://github.com/jinlab-imvr/SurgRAW.git.

title: Floe: Federated Specialization for Real-Time LLM–SLM Inference
authors: Chunlin Tian, Kahou Tam, Yebo Wu, Shuaihang Zhong, Li Li, Nicholas D. Lane, ChengZhong Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Parallel and Distributed Systems
abstract: Deploying large language models (LLMs) in realtime systems is challenging due to their high resource demands and privacy concerns. We propose Floe a hybrid federated learning framework designed for latency-sensitive, resourceconstrained environments. Floeombines a cloud-based blackbox LLM with lightweight small language models (SLMs) on edge devices to enable low-latency, privacy-preserving inference. Personal data and fine-tuning remain on-device, while the cloud LLM contributes general knowledge without exposing proprietary weights. A heterogeneity-aware LoRA adaptation strategy ensures efficient edge deployment across diverse hardware, and a logit-level fusion mechanism enables real-time coordination between edge and cloud models. Experiments demonstrate that Floenhances user privacy and personalization, while significantly improving model performance and reducing inference latency on edge devices under real-time constraints, compared to baseline approaches.

title: Beyond Connectivity: How Large AI Models Unlock Semantic 6G Networks?
authors: Xupeng Niu, Weijie Yuan, Long Tan, Nanchi Su, Yunyang Zhang, Tony Q. S. Quek
abstract: Large AI models (LAMs) are primed to take wireless systems beyond bit-level reliability toward genuine meaning-aware operation, a shift that aligns squarely with the vision of 6G semantic communication. In this article, we develop a three-axis lens - technology integration, security assurance, and computational efficiency - that clarifies why and how LAMs strengthen the semantic stack. Guided by these insights, we outline an end-to-end architecture in which a single LAM powers multi-source joint coding and decoding, infuses physical-layer security with generative intelligence, and supports lightweight, distributed training for edge deployment. A sentiment- analysis case study illustrates the design's ability to keep inference robust under noisy channels, while a forward look at drone networks, embodied robots, and immersive media shows its breadth of impact. We close by highlighting open problems in data curation, model transparency, and resource-constrained deployment, setting a concise research agenda for "understand-everything" 6G networks.

title: Stability Boundary Analysis for Grid-Following (GFL) and Grid-Forming (GFM) Inverters
authors: Xi Luo, Efstratios Batzelis, Abhinav Kumar Singh
abstract: Studying the dynamics and stability of inverter-driven power systems has become a top priority for grid operators in view of the massive renewable energy deployment. The simplest and most widely used model for stability analysis for such networks is the single-inverter single- bus (SISB) equivalent model. Although quite insightful, SISB models with an L-filter for the inverter suffer from implementation difficulties due to algebraic loops. This paper develops a closed-form SISB model for grid-following (GFL) and grid-forming (GFM) inverters and derives symbolic formulation for the linearized system, which resolves algebraic loops and obtains fast results with uncompromised precision. This model is then used in an N-Dimensional Stability Boundary Tracking (ND-SBT) algorithm, which identifies the stability boundary for GFL and GFM inverters. This is the first method to infer the stability region for an arbitrary number of dimensions in a computationally efficient and software-agnostic manner while preserving accuracy. A detailed sensitivity analysis yields useful findings on the stability impact of individual parameters, while the results are validated using the IEEE 14- bus system.

title: High Power Diamond Photoconductive Switch with sub-bandgap responsivity
authors: Langning Wang, Shiyu Cui, Bohan Li, Ripin Wang, Tao Xun
abstract: In this study, a vertical diamond photoconductive semiconductor switch with sub-bandgap responsivity was developed. The device was fabricated on a 0.5 mm thick, nitrogen-doped diamond substrate. A sub-nanosecond laser pulse with a wavelength of 355 nm was used to axially trigger the device through a metal grid electrode. Under the 350-μJ 355-nm sub-ns laser pulse illumination and DC bias voltages of up to 20 kV (electric field: 20 kV/0.5mm=40 kV/mm), the device achieved sub-ns pulses with a peak current of 102 A, corresponding to a power capacity of 2 MW. The device R<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">on</sub>/R<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">off</sub> ratio is greater than 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">11</sup>. This work highlights the potential of diamond in building ultrafast high-power photoelectric device.

title: A Hybrid Quantum-Meta Reinforcement Learning and Graph Attention Transformer Approach for Low-Latency and Secure D2D Routing in 6G Networks.
authors: SambiReddy Gottam, Udit Narayana Kar
abstract: This work involves the development of intelligent and security-oriented Device-to-Device (D2D) routing protocols specifically designed to handle dynamic, heterogeneous, and latency-critical communications in the emerging wireless communication environment, particularly for 6G setups. For instance, conventional routing solutions based on classical deep reinforcement learning and static optimization methodologies commonly fail to scale, adapt in real-time to dynamically changing topologies, and remain robust against security threats; thus, limiting their efficacy in the architectural frame of future 6G. However, this work focuses on introducing Quantum-Meta Learning Fusion with Graph Attention Transformer Networks for low-latency and secure D2D routing in 6G. The proposed framework is formed of three critical methodologies: (i) Quantum Meta Reinforcement Learning (QMRL), (ii) Graph Attention Transformer Network (GATN), and (iii) Evolutionary Graph Neural Network (EGNN). QMRL uses the parameterized quantum circuits to better balance the trade-off between exploration and exploitation. Additionally, a meta-learning module enables rapid adaptation to changing network conditions generated by gradient-based updates during end-to-end training. GATN combines graph attention mechanisms with transformer-based self-attention to capture spatial-temporal dependencies in network graphs; thus, the network will also be resilient to adversarial attacks. EGNN incorporates evolutionary approaches to enhance both node embeddings and routing policies, ensuring that traffic dynamics diversify over time and that link failures are appropriately addressed. Empirical analysis reveals that the proposed system will ultimately reduce latency by approximately 35-40%, improve the packet delivery ratio by 20%, and increase energy efficiency by 30-35% compared to classical models. Additionally, it increases resilience to jamming attacks by approximately 40%. Hence, these results substantiate the effectiveness of the fusion model in offering secure, adaptive, and low-latency routing solutions, making her a worthy candidate for future deployment in 6G D2D communications frameworks.

title: Ultra-Efficient Circuit-Integrated Self-Adaptive Cooling with Liquid Metal for Electronic Circuits
authors: Junchong Fan, Yuzhou Yao, Zhining Zhang, Jin Wang
abstract: With the accelerating advancement of electric vehicles, electric aircraft, unmanned aerial vehicles, and artificial intelligence, the demand for innovative liquid-cooling-based thermal management systems for high-power-density electric and electronic systems is paramount. Conventional cooling systems, typically designed separately from the circuitry, result in inefficiencies, bulky configurations, high acoustic noise, and reliability concerns associated with rotary pumps. This work introduces an integrated design paradigm that unifies electrical and cooling systems by employing circuit components as both functional elements of the electric circuit and magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) pumps for liquid metal, such as the non-toxic gallium alloy. This approach substantially enhances cooling efficiency, delivers load based self-adaptive cooling performance, and eliminates noisy and often unreliable rotary pumps. Moreover, the exceptional thermal conductivity of liquid metal relaxes the design requirements for cold plates and radiators. Prototypes of the proposed approach have demonstrated that remarkable power density can be achieved in a three-phase inverter with a self-adaptive and highly efficient integrated liquid cooling system. These innovations not only improve performance but also streamline the design process, potentially transforming cooling strategies for electric circuits across multiple industries.

title: A Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm for Resource Allocation in Database System
authors: Jakub Kołota
abstract: This paper presents a novel approach for partitioning database sessions into groups using the quantum MaxCut problem solved by the Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA). Each session is represented as a node in a graph, with edges indicating the degree of resource contention between sessions. By defining a comprehensive resource demand function that accounts for CPU time, memory usage, and input/output operations, the problem is formulated as a graph partitioning task aimed at optimally distributing sessions to minimize overlap and enhance resource utilization. The paper outlines the implementation of the QAOA algorithm using Cirq, including the construction of the quantum circuit, the optimization of parameters, and the measurement of results. The results are visualized through graphs and heatmaps that illustrate the division of sessions and the reduction in resource contention. As its main contribution, the paper demonstrates the practical application of quantum algorithms to resource allocation in database systems, indicating a promising approach for improving system performance and mitigating resource conflicts.

title: Resource Allocation for the Mixture of Periodic and Aperiodic Machine Users under Latency Constraints
authors: Yuan Zhang, Peng Du
abstract: This paper studies the method of resource allocation for the coexistence of periodic and aperiodic machine users under the latency constraints, which belongs to the scenario of ultra-reliable low-latency communication (URLLC). A semi persistent resource allocation framework under periodic user latency constraint is proposed, the corresponding mathematical model is derived, including feasibility conditions, upper bound on the latency for periodic users, latency probabilities for aperiodic users based on the stochastic network calculus theory, and the procedure of determining key parameters of the framework is provided. Numerical examples are reported to verify the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Robust Context Modeling for Unsupervised Non-rigid Point Cloud Correspondence
authors: Haozhe Chen, Rui Li, Jiaming Guo, Ya’nan He, Zhengbao Wang, Xian-Feng Han, Kun Sun, Jiaqi Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: We address the “long-range ambiguity” problem for unsupervised non-rigid point cloud correspondence, where corresponding points own inconsistent features while different local regions are spatially or geometrically similar. Previous methods struggle with this problem, since local reference frames (LRF) or coordinate-based methods struggle to exclude locally similar or spatially near mismatches, and widely used independent geometric relations might be inconsistent under non-rigid deformation, introducing extra ambiguity. To this end, we propose a novel robust context modeling module (RCM) to alleviate long-range ambiguity in two aspects: 1) RCM tackles the ambiguity problem by introducing inter-relation attention (IRA), which mines robust cues from the interplay between relative geometric relations. 2) RCM enhances features with accessible long-range information from IRAs, following a local-to-global manner. Our method shows significant improvements in multiple benchmarks, with accurate correspondence over rotation and large deformation perturbation. Specifically, our method achieves a new state-of-the-art performance with correspondence accuracy of 33.9% and mean error of 4.2 on the SURREAL benchmark.

title: RBMS: A Robotic Batch Microinjection System for Zebrafish Larval Hearts_supp1-3664398.mp4
authors: Qingsong Xu
abstract: The zebrafish is a highly promising model organism in biomedical research. A critical procedure for its use is the microinjection of larvae, which is commonly performed manually. Manual injection, however, suffers from inherent limitations, including low efficiency, success rate, and consistency. To address these challenges, this paper presents a Robotic Batch Microinjection System (RBMS) designed for targeting the hearts of zebrafish larvae. The system’s uniqueness lies in a novel computer vision algorithm that efficiently locates the heart region based on key physiological features, significantly accelerating image processing. Furthermore, an Agarose Petri Dish (APD) is employed for batch immobilization of larvae. We established a dedicated hardware system for automated microinjection and developed an intuitive software interface. Experimental results demonstrate that the RBMS achieves high-throughput automated microinjection into the larval heart at a rate of 11 seconds per sample. The developed system offers a robust and efficient solution for large-scale cardiovascular drug screening using zebrafish larvae.

title: C-PRISM: a Comprehensive Privacy-Preserving and Behavioral-Incentive Mechanism for Sustainable Mobile Crowdsensing
authors: Jing Bai, Mande Xie, Houbing Song, Mianxiong Dong, Tian Wang, Anfeng Liu
abstract: Mobile Crowdsensing (MCS) has emerged as a promising paradigm for large-scale, real-time data collection by leveraging the sensing capabilities of widely distributed mobile workers. However, its practical adoption is challenged by privacy risks and unsustainable incentive structures that inadequately compensate for workers' inherent participation costs, leading to diminished motivation, sparse task coverage, and reduced data availability. Existing approaches either provide limited and utility-degrading privacy protection or design incentive mechanisms that incur substantial costs, even under the Nash equilibrium. To bridge this gap, we propose C-PRISM (Compre hensive Privacy-preserving and Behavioral-Incentive Sustainable crowdsensing Mechanism), an integrated framework that seamlessly combines privacy-preserving techniques with behavioral economic incentive design. Specifically, C-PRISM employs ran domized matrix perturbation for fine-grained location protection and a two-phase proxy re-encryption protocol to secure task details and sensing data across evaluation, recruitment, and transmission. Building upon this secure foundation, behavioral economic incentives grounded in prospect theory, the Aronson effect, and a dual reference-point model are introduced to promote sustained worker participation at sub-Nash-equilibrium costs. Rigorous theoretical analysis validates C-PRISM's security and individual rationality. Extensive experiments on real-world datasets demonstrate that C-PRISM increases data collection efficiency by 7.42%-193.75%, improves worker retention by 2.53%-69.78%, and effectively maintains overall system utility.

title: IoT-Enabled Deployment Optimization for Urban Low-Altitude Airspace Surveillance Networks
authors: Shaochuan Zhu, Yuanwen Lai, Jinqu Chen, Xiaolian Li, Yumeng Li
abstract: In the context of widespread applications of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), low-altitude airspace surveillance has emerged as a critical task for public security. However, current low-altitude surveillance systems mainly rely on single-point device deployment, which provide limited coverage and lack the capability to ensure reliable UAV detection and tracking. Therefore, the development of an efficient Internet of Things (IoT)-enabled low-altitude surveillance network has become an urgent necessity. This paper proposes a new deployment optimization approach for low-altitude airspace surveillance network (LASN). A detector signal-UAV accessibility strategy is proposed to explicitly account for urban structural characteristics. Then, a novel metric, called UAV-Exposure, is introduced to quantify surveillance effectiveness within the LASN. Finally, a hub–spoke-based network deployment model is formulated to determine the optimal solution of LASN nodes under realistic constraints. Computational results show that compared with traditional methods, the planned LASN solution has substantially enhanced the monitoring performance of UAVs and improved low-altitude security level.

title: Analysis of Lurie Systems with Magnitude Nonlinearities and Connections to Neural Network Stability Analysis
authors: Carl R. Richardson, Matthew C. Turner, Steve R. Gunn
abstract: This paper considers the interconnection of a continuous time linear time-invariant system and a multivariable magnitude nonlinearity. A number of different quadratic constraints are established for the magnitude nonlinearity and then used to derive stability criteria based on quadratic and Lurie-type Lyapunov functions. The new stability criteria are cast as matrix inequalities and in some cases solved using semi-definite programming. Connections are made between the magnitude nonlinearity and neural network activation functions, such as the rectified linear unit (ReLU) and leaky ReLU, effectively allowing the stability criteria derived here to be used to analyse interconnections of dynamical systems and neural networks. Using the positive homogeneity property, shared by the (leaky) ReLU and magnitude functions, mild conditions are also established to show that the existence of a unique equilibrium point is sufficient for local and global stability to be equivalent. Finally, the new global stability criteria are tested on several numerical examples, including a Hopfield network with 100 states and neurons, and compare favourably with competing criteria from the literature.

title: EduMechanic: A Study on the Impact of a 3D Model-Based Interactive E-Learning Platform for Car Mechanic Equipment Training
authors: Mary Jane C. Samonte, Paul James L. Perez, Ronnel Christian B. Langit, Reymart P. Ambayon, Jairus Lester T. Tolentino, Irah Nathanne D. Tiburcio
abstract: EduMechanic is a web-based e-learning system developed for mechanical students pursuing Automotive Servicing NC I under the Technical Education and Skills Development Authority (TESDA). It is intended to address auto mechanics' constraints in the educational sector, such as insufficient digital learning experience and a lack of online interactive activities. It also focuses on teaching the utilization process of various tools and diagnostic gadgets often used in automobile service and maintenance. In particular, the creation of EduMechanic enables students to interact and learn through 3-dimensional models of mechanic tools through the application of Preventive Maintenance Service (PMS). This study examines the system's design and implementation and evaluates the student outcomes from the system's usability. Results found that students who use the EDUMECHANIC e-learning system have proven to be a highly effective digital learning platform by integrating 3D interactive models in automotive education.

title: Analog Fiber Laser Transmitter for Deep Oil Well Testing Under High Temperature
authors: Hengyang Wang, Shijie Tang, Qian Gao, Huiting Huan, Lixian Liu
abstract: Real-time measurement in drilling deep oil well requests reliable and fast communication in order to obtain bit, pup joint and subterranean conditions. Compared to conventional mud- and electromagnetic (EM)-pulse methods which are susceptible to interference and exhibit significant attenuation due to high-temperature circumstances, fiber optic communication is able to resolve these issues thanks to its high-speed and EM interference immunity in electro-optical coupling. There already exists high-temperature fibers which can serve in underground scenarios, but the transmitter which can be integrated into a tubing pup joint and operates at >150°C faces technical challenge and has limited report from literature. In this work, a pure analog electro-optical conversion (EOC) module (analog driver) supporting measurement and digital data transmission for downhole drilling up to 6 km has been developed. A thermal compensation modality was proposed for diodes rectification, which allows optical data transmission within a dynamic temperature range from 25°C to 175°C. The EOC module enables OOK modulation and is compatible to TTL/RS-485 digital signal with a wide frequency range. Validated by experiments, this EOC module can achieve mW-level optical power output within the designed temperature range. By counting the losses in 1550 nm fiber, the system still reaches 115200 bps Baud rate of serial communication which is more than 4-order higher than the mud-pulse in transmitting measured data in the downhole.

title: Comparative Evaluation of Wireless Communication Technologies for Critical Infrastructure Monitoring
authors: Khayot Alimdjanov, Dilmurod Davronbekov, Djamshid Isroilov, Zafar Khakimov
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: This article deals with the issue of appropriate wireless technology in the choice of critical infrastructure monitoring. The introduction describes the growing use of technologies like wireless sensor networks in creating dependable surveillance of different essential and significant structures. The inability to find a unified framework of comparing popular standards, including NB-IoT is specifically addressed in the problem statement section. There are LTE-M and LoRa, ZigBee, and GPRS with their advantages and possible drawbacks. The answer to this question lies in the fact that a uniformly structured approach, in which the main technical features of the technologies mentioned above are introduced, are developed.The proposed method can enable the creation of various tables, graphs, and charts visually demonstrating performance under identical conditions. This method provides a tool for engineers and other decision makers to compare wireless technologies with the operational requirements for monitoring critical infrastructure.

title: Blended Learning in Intelligent Sports Engineering Education
authors: Yuzhou Fan, Guoying Zhang
abstract: Since the establishment of the International Sports Engineering Association in 1998, the field of sports engineering has undergone substantial evolution and growth. Initially centered on designing and enhancing sports equipment and devices, the discipline has transitioned into a more interdisciplinary domain referred to as Intelligent Sports Engineering. This study seeks to examine the status quo of Intelligent Sports Engineering programs by analyzing data from two universities’ official websites. A novel blended learning (BL) framework for an Intelligent Sports Engineering Program is proposed, emphasizing: (1) an integration of online and in-person coursework, augmented by virtual laboratories and practical, hands-on training in on-site laboratories, and industry partnerships; (2) a dynamic and customizable curriculum tailored to meet the needs of diverse groups, including college students and the general public; and (3) artificial intelligence-driven personalization to optimize learning pathways for individual learner. The envisioned program aims to equip learners with cutting-edge technologies and methodologies to foster a sustainable sports ecosystem, i.e. to enhance elite athlete performance, promote public health, prevent injuries, and minimize environmental impact through advanced protective gear and injury mitigation strategies. Achieving these objectives necessitates a robust interdisciplinary approach, requiring the collaboration of highly skilled faculty, engineers, practitioners, and administrators across academic institutions, research centers, and sports organizations worldwide. This BL model will contribute to educational sustainability by enhancing accessibility, resource efficiency, and learning outcomes while fostering teacher development and promoting sustainability education.

title: Research and Simulation on Multi-Mode Operation Control Strategy of Combined Diesel and Energy Storage Power Supply System
authors: Cunping Wang, Yanxia Chen, Ruoxi Liu, Jing Zeng, Yifan Wu, Shuchang Wan
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: This paper addresses the coordinated control problem of multi-mode operation in a photovoltaic-diesel generator-energy storage microgrid system under the context of renewable energy integration. A joint operation strategy based on the collaborative control of photovoltaic systems, diesel generators, and energy storage systems is proposed. By constructing five operational modes, the strategy achieves dynamic source-load matching and ensures stable system operation. The backup power mode guarantees rapid response during main grid failures, the load balancing mode optimizes energy distribution under low-load conditions, the peak shaving mode collaboratively handles load peaks, the fuel-saving mode reduces fuel consumption through the economic load rate of diesel generators, and the fast power balancing mode suppresses sudden power fluctuations. Simulation results based on MATLAB/Simulink demonstrate that the proposed strategy effectively enhances system stability and economic performance, supports smooth grid-connected/islanded transitions, and meets power demand under various operating conditions. The research findings provide a theoretical foundation and technical reference for microgrid systems with high penetration of renewable energy, contributing significantly to the advancement of clean energy applications and the sustainable development of power systems.

title: Innovation in Technology Management: An Agile-Driven Digital Solution for Academic Health and Dental Record System
authors: Renz M. Buctuan, Unife O. Cagas
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Software Engineering and Service Science (ICSESS)
abstract: This study introduces an agile-driven digital solution for academic health and dental record management, specifically designed to meet the dual needs of students and employees within educational environments. The system was developed around six key modules—Student, Employee, Health, Dental, Medical Supplies, and E-log—to create a comprehensive and modular digital framework for healthcare service delivery. Guided by the Agile Scrum methodology, the platform was iteratively refined through stakeholder feedback and evaluated using ISO/IEC 25010 standards, focusing on usability, reliability, and adaptability. The findings confirm that the system is intuitive and user-friendly, dependable in maintaining accurate and retrievable records, and adaptable to institutional requirements through agile iterations. Usability tests showed that the design promotes ease of navigation and efficiency in record-keeping, while reliability measures demonstrated consistent data accuracy and system stability. Adaptability results further highlighted the platform’s capacity to integrate new features and respond to evolving institutional needs. While piloted at Surigao del Norte State University, the platform is designed to be scalable and applicable to other higher education institutions seeking to modernize health and dental record management. Beyond technical efficiency, the study highlights how secure, cloud-ready, and user-centered healthcare IT designs can strengthen satisfaction, sustainability, and service continuity in academic institutions. The proposed solution therefore provides a scalable model for digital transformation, underscoring the broader potential of agile practices in education-based healthcare technology management.

title: NoteMCU 8266 CH340 WiFi Module in Complex Real-Time Processing of Transmitted Signals in VR Simulator
authors: Nodirbek Abdulkhayev, Anvar Musayev, Mukhriddin Umarov, Urinboy Naziraliyev, Berdiyev Alisher Alikulovich
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: In this paper, the implementation and design of a human shock sensing complex on Virtual Reality (VR) technology will be provided with the help of the WiFi board NodeMCU ESP-12E (8266 CH340). As mentioned in the proposed system, real-time perception of the impact events is possible because of the controlled vibration feedback using DC motors driving through an L293D motor driver. The combination of wireless communication and embedded control with VR simulation environment available in the system has made it an option that is costeffective compared to the traditional haptic feedback solutions. WiFi modules and motor drivers are compared and analyzed to support their choice of component. Experimental validation proves to be reliable at responding and scaling in real-time to educational, training, and simulation applications.

title: Simulation Analysis of Interface Structure of 10kV High Current Circuit Breaker
authors: Lufeng Guo, Shaohua Hong, Lifei Yang, Yipeng Wang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: This paper investigates the interface structure of a 10kV high-current circuit breaker. Using a multi-physics simulation approach, it analyzes the magnetic flux distribution inside the breaker, the distribution of electric field intensity, the plasma temperature field at the contact interfaces, and the temperature field of the contacts. The simulation results indicate that after the optimization design, the contact resistance of the breaker is significantly reduced, and both the plasma temperature and the contact temperature rise are effectively controlled, resulting in a marked improvement in the breaker’s interruption performance and reliability.

title: A Data-Driven Monitoring System for Commodity Futures Liquidity Risk: Architecture and Algorithm
authors: Fengxuan Li, Jinyu Zhang
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Software Engineering and Service Science (ICSESS)
abstract: High-frequency trading in commodity futures generates massive datasets characterized by noise and complex interdependence, posing challenges for real-time liquidity risk monitoring. This paper proposes a data-driven system architecture designed to ingest, process, and visualize liquidity risks across heterogeneous futures contracts. The proposed framework integrates a three-layer pipeline: (1) Data Preprocessing Layer that implements a Hampel filter-based algorithm for anomaly detection in millisecond-level tick data; (2) Risk Quantification Layer that constructs multi-dimensional metrics (Amihud ratio, Roll spread) to vectorize liquidity features; and (3) Network Analysis Layer that utilizes a Dynamic Conditional Correlation (DCC-GARCH) model to construct a time-varying weighted complex network. By calculating centrality metrics on the dynamic graph, the system identifies systemic risk contagion paths. Experimental results on China’s commodity market data demonstrate the system’s effectiveness in capturing rapid risk transmission and visualizing cross-market correlations, providing a scalable solution for financial surveillance.

title: Research on the Evaluation of Autonomous Controllability of Power Grid Dispatching Technical Support Systems
authors: Li Zhao, Bijing Liu, Xiaosong Zhu, Jiancheng Guo, Yong Yang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: The power grid dispatching technical support system holds a significant position in power systems. To enhance its level of autonomous controllability, the primary task is to establish a scientific evaluation framework and quantitative assessment methods. This paper investigates evaluation methods for the autonomous controllability of power grid dispatching technical support systems, proposing an integrated approach that combines the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) and Fuzzy Comprehensive Evaluation (FCE) for quantitative analysis. This evaluation method provides a theoretical basis and decision-making reference for system optimization, contributing to the advancement of power systems toward greater security, efficiency, and autonomy.

title: KernelPID: Fine-Grained GPU Virtualization via Dynamic Kernel Dispatch Control
authors: Yan Lu
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Software Engineering and Service Science (ICSESS)
abstract: Precise computing resource management is essential for efficient GPU virtualization, enabling secure and isolated sharing of physical GPU resources among multiple users. Traditional GPU virtualization approaches typically rely on time slicing and spatial partitioning to allocate resources. However, these methods often suffer from inefficiencies such as heavy GPU context switching and unbalanced warp scheduling. In this work, we propose and implement a novel resource scheduling algorithm called KernelPID, which dynamically adjusts the dispatch of GPU kernel functions for fine-grained control over computing resources. By closely managing kernel function distribution, KernelPID minimizes performance overhead and enhances resource utilization. To further accelerate the convergence of resource control, we introduce an auxiliary algorithm: kTune, an adaptive hyperparameter tuning method. These techniques enhance the responsiveness and precision of the KernelPID scheduler by providing internal parameter optimization based on real-time workload characteristics. Together, this suite of algorithms enables an efficient and scalable GPU virtualization framework that significantly improves performance isolation and resource efficiency in multi-tenant GPU environments.

title: Global Optimization of Micro-Meteorological Station Siting for Ultra-High-Voltage Transmission Lines
authors: Qingtian Ge, Kai Yang, Wenke Pan, Ye Feng, Huayue Huang, Jiangjiao Xu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: Micro-meteorological monitoring along ultra-high-voltage (UHV) transmission corridors is crucial for risk-aware operation, but limited station counts and uneven layouts create a persistent accuracy–cost trade-off. Empirical spacing rules secure coverage yet do not guarantee reconstruction accuracy in complex terrain, whereas optimization-based siting often lacks an interpretable sampling scale and a unified evaluation. We present a physics- and data-driven framework that couples an empirically estimated correlation scale with constrained global optimization, semivariograms from historical records define a maximum interstation spacing used as a hard coverage constraint, then a genetic algorithm minimizes weighted-interpolation error subject to right-of-way, accessibility, and minimum-separation constraints and is benchmarked under a unified protocol against uniform and terrain-weighted layouts. In a real UHV corridor, the framework achieves full coverage with a maximum spacing of about 8 km and reduces wind-speed reconstruction error relative to uniform placement—RMSE from 2.41 to 2.10 m/s, MAE from 2.14 to 1.88 m/s, and MAPE from 26.93% to 23.82% —while improving network compactness. By linking an interpretable correlation scale with global optimization, the approach provides a practical basis for planning, staged densification, and rapid emergency deployment of corridor monitoring networks.

title: Enhanced Small Object Detection in Aerial Imagery: Integrating Pyramid Pooling Attention and Space-to-Depth Convolution in YOLOv8
authors: Chandan Chakma, Bin He, Aba Agi Kader Aba Agi, Amrul Kayes
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Robotics and Automatic Control (IRAC)
abstract: Detecting small objects in aerial and drone imagery remains a challenging problem in computer vision due to limited spatial resolution and information loss during feature extraction. This paper presents an enhanced YOLOv8 architecture that addresses these challenges through three strategic modifications. First, we introduce C2F PPA, a novel feature extraction module that replaces standard bottleneck blocks with Pyramid Pooling Attention mechanisms that combine spatial, channel, and local-global attention for a richer multi-scale feature representation. Second, we employ Space-to-Depth Convolution (SPDConv) in the network’s downsampling operations to preserve spatial information that would otherwise be lost with traditional strided convolutions. Third, we extend the detection capability by incorporating a P2-level detection head operating at 160×160 resolution, specifically targeting objects as small as 4×4 pixels. Extensive experiments on the challenging VisDrone dataset demonstrate that our approach achieves 26.7% mAP@0.5:0.95 with only an 11% increase in parameters compared to baseline YOLOv8n, showing particular improvements in detecting pedestrians, vehicles, and other small objects in complex aerial scenes.

title: A Fast Calculation Method for Equivalent Transformer Windings Based on Thermal Parameter Equivalence
authors: Deming Huang, Lei Su, Tao Liu, Jiangjun Ruan, Heli Ni, Fei Liu, Haohao Qin
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: The accurate calculation of hot spot temperature of oil-immersed transformer windings is one of the key technologies for evaluating the status of power equipment. However, the refined numerical models have the problems of complex modeling and low computational efficiency, which are difficult to meet the requirements of rapid simulation in engineering practice. Therefore, this study proposes a simplified method based on thermal parameter equivalence, aiming to improve the reliability and speed of numerical calculation of transformer temperature fluid field. According to the structure of the transformer winding, the equivalent thermal parameters method is used to derive the equivalent thermal conductivity and equivalent specific heat capacity in the radial and axial directions. Then, a two-dimensional fine model considering the winding details and a two-dimensional simplified model using equivalent thermal parameters are established respectively, and the temperature fluid field simulation is carried out under the same boundary and load conditions. The comparison results show that the overall temperature field distribution characteristics obtained by the simplified model based on thermal parameter equivalence and the fine model are highly consistent, with the simulation error of the hot spot temperature not exceeding 1℃. The total number of grids is reduced by 86.41%, and the calculation time is shortened by 71.43%. The equivalent model greatly reduces the difficulty and number of grid division, and the computational efficiency is improved by an order of magnitude.

title: From Teaching Assistant to Co-Intelligence: Agent Technology Reshapes the Paradigm of Teaching Academic Writing to Graduate Students
authors: Kaiwen Ren, Yaping Wang, Yunwu Wang
abstract: The rapid development of generative artificial intelligence calls for agent technology to deeply optimize graduate academic writing teaching. By studying and analyzing the basic concept of agent, an agent system is constructed through specialized equipment, and the chain reasoning mechanism is used to promote the deep collaboration between teachers, students and technology. Based on 104 valid questionnaires, the dimensions and item network structure and centrality indexes of the academic writing assistant scale were systematically analyzed by using the regularized Gaussian graph model, which revealed the core position of the agent in improving the efficiency and quality of writing, and the multi-node synergistic effect of interaction experience and use intention dimensions. The research results not only enriched the theoretical perspective of Al-enabled writing teaching in higher education, but also provided an operational path and strategy for the construction of intelligent writing support practice for graduate students.

title: Targetless LiDAR-Camera Calibration with Neural Gaussian Splatting
authors: Haebeom Jung, Namtae Kim, Jungwoo Kim, Jaesik Park
abstract: Accurate LiDAR-camera calibration is crucial for multi-sensor systems. However, traditional methods often rely on physical targets, which are impractical for real-world deployment. Moreover, even carefully calibrated extrinsics can degrade over time due to sensor drift or external disturbances, necessitating periodic recalibration. To address these challenges, we present a Targetless LiDAR–Camera Calibration (TLC-Calib) that jointly optimizes sensor poses with a neural Gaussian–based scene representation. Reliable LiDAR points are frozen as anchor Gaussians to preserve global structure, while auxiliary Gaussians prevent local overfitting under noisy initialization. Our fully differentiable pipeline with photometric and geometric regularization achieves robust and generalizable calibration, consistently outperforming existing targetless methods on the KITTI-360, WAYMO, and FAST-LIVO2 datasets. In addition, it yields more consistent Novel View Synthesis results, reflecting improved extrinsic alignment. The project page is available at: <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://www.haebeom.com/tlc-calib-site/</uri>.

title: TinyLSN: A Lightweight Network for Real-Time Marine Pipeline Leakage Detection in IoT Systems
authors: Yuchen Lu, Yuxuan Zhang, Hongbing Liu, Sebastian Bader
abstract: Intelligent acoustic emission-based pipeline leak detection technology plays a critical role in Internet of Things structural health monitoring for offshore platforms. However, traditional deep networks possess large parameter counts and high computational complexity, making them infeasible for deployment on resource-constrained edge nodes, while lightweight methods universally adopt single-scale feature extraction and cannot simultaneously capture short-duration burst and long-range attenuation characteristics of acoustic emission signals, resulting in insufficient discriminative capability for adjacent valves. To address this, this paper proposes Tiny Leak Sense Net (TinyLSN), a novel lightweight leak localization framework specifically designed for Internet of Things edge nodes. TinyLSN achieves optimal balance between computational efficiency and detection performance through three innovative components we designed including the Inverted Residual Block (IRB), Multi-Scale Dilated Perception Module (MSDPM), and Large Kernel Feed-Forward Network (LK-FFN), which respectively enhance cross-channel interactions, capture multi-scale temporal features, and extract global attenuation patterns. On our self-constructed experimental dataset simulating real offshore platform operational pipeline leakage, TinyLSN achieved detection accuracy of 97.11% to 97.45% and an extremely low false positive rate of 0.27% to 0.32%, significantly outperforming lightweight baseline methods. Validation on publicly available benchmark datasets further confirmed its generalization capability. When deployed on the STM32H7B3I-DK microcontroller, TinyLSN requires only 267.16 KiB Flash memory and achieves 3.417 ms inference latency. Furthermore, TinyLSN maintains over 90% accuracy under strong noise and achieves 94.83% accuracy with only 10% training samples, fully validating its reliability in harsh industrial environments and providing an efficient and feasible solution for offshore platform Internet of Things edge intelligence.

title: One-Time Programmable Passive Electromagnetic Skins
authors: Giacomo Oliveri, Francesco Zardi, Giorgio Gottardi, Andrea Massa
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Antennas and Propagation
abstract: The implementation of simple, inexpensive, and mass-production-oriented solutions for smart electromagnetic environments (SEMEs) is dealt with by introducing the concept of one-time programmable electromagnetic skins (OTP-EMSs). The simultaneous achievement of modular fabrication, (one-time) configurable reflection properties, passive-static operation, and zero maintenance is yielded by integrating expendable components at the atomic level of EMSs. Towards this end, an OTP meta-atom structure is properly defined and optimized to build EMSs featuring the desired scenario-dependent EM wave manipulation functionalities. In order to illustrate the features as well as to point out the potentialities of OTP-EMSs, a representative set of analytical, numerical, and experimental results is reported by considering different apertures, illuminations, and EM wave manipulation requirements.

title: Study on Efficiency Map Prediction of Synchronous Motors Using Tandem Variational Autoencoder-Based Surrogate Model
authors: Ji-Hoon Han, Jong-Hoon Park, Sun-Ki Hong
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Industry Applications
abstract: To reduce the computational cost of finite element analysis for rapid optimal motor design, surrogate modeling techniques have been widely studied. While conventional surrogate models mainly predict scalar performance metrics, propulsion motors must be evaluated over a wide operating range, requiring the prediction of high-dimensional outputs such as efficiency maps. Owing to the large dimensional gap between design variables and efficiency maps, conventional neural networks often suffer from limited accuracy and unstable convergence. This paper proposes a Tandem Variational Autoencoder (TD-VAE) that directly predicts high-dimensional efficiency maps from motor design variables. The model employs a tandem architecture in which a variational autoencoder compresses and reconstructs efficiency maps, while an auxiliary autoencoder reconstructs the design variables to enforce latent consistency. This structure enables stable training and allows previously collected simulation data to be used without modification. The TD-VAE is further extended to predict physically interpretable loss components, including copper and iron losses. The model performance is evaluated using mean absolute percentage error (MAPE) and the coefficient of determination (R²), and predictive uncertainty is analyzed through pixel-wise confidence and prediction intervals. When applied to an interior permanent magnet synchronous motor, the proposed TD-VAE achieves a maximum MAPE of 0.18% compared with finite element analysis, demonstrating accurate prediction, stable convergence, and significantly reduced design iteration time.

title: Experimental Investigation of Specified-Time Adaptive Control for MEMS Gyroscopes with Sampling Constraints
authors: Yu Bai, Yanhu Shan, Rang Cui, Xiaoyi Wang, Wenbiao Zhou, Yue Ji, Huiliang Cao
abstract: In this paper, we present a novel specified-time adaptive output-feedback control scheme for microelectromechanical system (MEMS) gyroscopes subjected to sampling constraint. The primary contribution of this study lies in the development of a computationally efficient Unknown System Dynamics Estimator (USDE) based on the invariant manifold principle, which accurately estimates total system uncertainty with minimal computational cost. To overcome the potential corruption of velocity signals due to measurement noise and the inherent resource limitations of MEMS gyroscope platforms, we integrate a variable-threshold event-triggered state observer into the USDE. This innovative architecture replaces actual velocity measurements with their estimated values, ensuring high estimation accuracy while minimizing computational burden. Additionally, to meet the stringent response speed requirements of MEMS gyroscopes in practical applications, we introduce a Specified-Time Funnel Control (STFC) scheme. This control approach guarantees that the displacement error converges to the desired value within a predefined time, simultaneously constraining the error bounds, which results in superior transient and steady-state performance of the system. The novelty of this work lies in the combination of the USDE with the event-triggered observer and STFC, providing a robust solution for MEMS gyroscope control under stringent resource constraints. The effectiveness and superiority of the proposed method are rigorously validated through both theoretical stability analysis using Lyapunov methods and extensive simulation and experimental results, demonstrating its significant improvement over existing approaches.

title: Stable and Durable BTOnws–PVDF Triboelectric Nanogenerator for Self-Powered energy supply and Real-Time Impact Monitoring
authors: Xiong Dien, Nurulazlina Ramli, Tzer Hwai Gilbert Thio, Yang Zhuanqing
abstract: Triboelectric nanogenerator (TENG) has emerged as promising candidates for self-powered systems due to their ability to harvest mechanical energy and serve as active sensors. In this work, we report the fabrication of a barium titanate nanowire (BTOnws)-doped poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) composite TENG, designed to enhance mechanical robustness and electrical output. The optimized TENG exhibits stable and superior output performance including open-circuit voltage (VOC) of 280 V, short-circuit current (ISC) of 12 μA, and power density of 1.45 W/m2. The effects of device structural on output performance are systematically investigated. Environmental stability tests reveal that the TENG maintained stable voltage and current outputs across a wide temperature/humidity range and over 10,000 contact–separation cycles and that the output attenuation of this TENG is superior to that of the previously reported PVDF-based TENG. Furthermore, we verify its power supply capability by lighting up 52 LEDs and fabricated a new TENG-integrated table tennis bat for wireless position detection. The sensing system utilize a two-stage amplification circuit to overcome the high output impedance of TENGs, achieving accurate localization of ball impacts with only nine sensing units. This study not only provides insights into optimizing TENG structural and environmental resilience but also highlights their potential in electronic devices, sports analytics, and intelligent sensing networks.

title: GaussFocus RPN for Remote Sensing Object Detection
authors: Zilong Wang, Zishan Xu, Wei Yang, Wei Chen, Yunyue Li, Hongxian Tian, Jueting Liu, Tingting Xu, Zehua Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Emerging Topics in Computational Intelligence
abstract: Objects in remotesensing imagery are often unevenly distributed and densely clustered, making foreground selection particularly challenging. In two-stage detectors, the Region Proposal Network (RPN) is pivotal, yet proposals from conventional RPNs can be imprecise and redundant, hurting recall and inflating computation.We introduce GaussFocus, a density-guided two-stage detector that builds a unified Gaussian foreground prior from rotated annotations and injects it into proposal generation, feature sampling, and RoI score calibration. Specifically, we derive an image-level Gaussian foreground density map and train a lightweight density branch inside the RPN, where MDeformConv uses regression-guided offsets and density-aware gating to produce features that better align with object geometry and foreground regions. A Gauss Guided Selector further leverages the predicted density map to retain proposals concentrated in foreground-dense areas, reducing background clutter and second-stage computation. In addition, an inference-only Gauss-Guided RoI logit shift calibrates RoI classification scores using the same density prior without retraining, leading to more reliable foreground–background separation and ranking. Across four challenging datasets (including DOTA-v1.0, DOTA-v2.0, and HRSC2016), GaussFocus consistently improves proposal quality and detection accuracy over strong baselines while reducing redundant RoIs and computation.

title: A Fault-Tolerant Resonant DC-Link Inverter with Bidirectional Alternate Commutation
authors: Qiang Wang, Ze Zhao, Ling Chang, Haijun Sun
abstract: Contemporary resonant DC-link inverter (RDCLI) designs predominantly maintain soft-switching operation exclusively during unidirectional power flow from the DC source to the load. However, under reverse power transfer conditions where energy flows from the load back to the DC bus, the auxiliary circuits fail to enable zero-voltage or zero-current switching for the main power devices. This limitation results in conventional hard-switching operation during regenerative modes, consequently compromising the system's overall energy recovery efficiency. This paper proposes a novel RDCLI incorporating two structurally symmetrical auxiliary resonant circuits at the DC interface. These complementary circuits operate alternately according to the direction of power flow, enabling consistent soft-switching performance during bidirectional energy transfer. Furthermore, in the event of an open-circuit fault within either auxiliary set, the inverter maintains soft-switching capability along one power flow direction while experiencing performance degradation only in the opposite direction. This fault-tolerant characteristic prevents complete loss of soft-switching functionality across both power transfer directions during auxiliary device failures. This work presents a systematic analysis of the auxiliary network's operational mechanisms under bidirectional power flow conditions, coupled with the development of a complete parametric design framework. Experimental results verify that the auxiliary circuit maintains all theoretically derived operating modes during both power flow directions, with all semiconductor devices successfully achieving soft-switching transitions throughout the operational range. The measured peak efficiencies of 98.1% in forward operation and 96.7% in reverse operation at rated power establish the distinct advantage of the proposed bidirectional architecture over conventional unidirectional soft-switching alternatives. These findings validate the topology's considerable potential to advance the performance envelope and practical implementation of resonant DC-link solutions in high-frequency bidirectional power conversion systems.

title: AC Loss Suppression of High-Speed Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motor for Vehicles Based on End Transposed Winding Method
authors: Haigui Gong, William Cai, Mingchong Sun, Ying Xie, Yue Tang, Shoulun Guo, Yongxi Yang, Zhanxi Lin, Zhiran Su, Xuesheng Jiang
abstract: Flat wire winding has some advantages, such as a high slot fill factor and low vibration noise, which is a mainstream technology solution for vehicle drive motors. However, when the motors operate at high-speeds, high-frequency AC losses of the flat wire winding are prominent, which directly limit the improvement of motor efficiency and power density. To reduce high-frequency AC losses, this article proposed a scheme based on end transposed winding (ETW). The conductors near the slot openings use ETW, whereas those in the other layers are flat wire windings. Firstly, based on the distribution of AC losses in the flat wire winding (FWW), the ETW scheme is proposed. Then, the stator winding slot shape and conductor size parameters are optimized to determine the structural dimensions. Finally, the AC losses and efficiency of ETW and the original FWW are calculated and compared, as well as the impact on efficiency under the China Light-duty vehicle Test Cycle (CLTC) driving conditions. The effectiveness of the proposed ETW prototype in suppressing AC loss is verified experimentally. The results indicate that, compared with the FWW, the AC loss of the proposed ETW is reduced by 21.2% at the 24000r/min.

title: JANUS: A Difference-Oriented Analyzer for Financial Centralized Risks in Smart Contracts
authors: Wansen Wang, Pu Zhang, Renjie Ji, Wenchao Huang, Zhaoyi Meng, Jie Cui, Hong Zhong, Yan Xiong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Some smart contracts violate decentralization principles by defining privileged accounts that manage other users' assets without permission, introducing centralized risks that have caused financial losses. Existing methods, however, face challenges in accurately detecting diverse centralized risks due to their dependence on predefined behavior patterns. In this paper, we propose JANUS, an automated analyzer for Solidity smart contracts that detects financial centralized risks independently of their specific behaviors. JANUS identifies differences between states reached by privileged and ordinary accounts, and analyzes whether these differences are finance-related. Focusing on the impact of risks rather than behaviors, JANUS achieves improved accuracy compared to existing tools and can uncover centralized risks with unknown patterns. To evaluate JANUS's performance, we compare it with other tools using a dataset of 540 contracts. Our evaluation demonstrates that JANUS outperforms representative tools in terms of detection accuracy for financial centralized risks. Additionally, we evaluate JANUS on a real-world dataset of 33,151 contracts, successfully identifying two types of risks that other tools fail to detect. We also prove that the state traversal method and variable summaries, which are used in JANUS to reduce the number of states to be compared, do not introduce false alarms or omissions in detection.

title: An Artificial Bee Colony algorithm with Machine Learning for Constrained Optimization in HPC
authors: Roberto Sala, Nikita Litovchenko, Davide Gadioli, Gianluca Palermo, Danilo Ardagna
publish: 2025 33rd International Symposium on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Computer and Telecommunication Systems (MASCOTS)
abstract: High-Performance Computing (HPC) is a fundamental tool for tackling complex scientific and engineering problems. Optimizing applications for the heterogeneous and massively parallel nature of modern HPC hardware is essential for achieving timely and resource-efficient results. This paper introduces ABC-MLCO, a novel Artificial Bee Colony (ABC) algorithm enhanced with machine learning for constrained optimization in discrete configuration spaces, specifically targeting HPC scenarios with black-box performance metrics. ABC-MLCO extends the original ABC algorithm with mechanisms that define the feasible region, promote escape from local optima, prevent redundant evaluations, and intensify exploration and exploitation. We first evaluate the algorithm on benchmark functions, observing improvements in regret, feasibility rate, and convergence speed over the original ABC. Then, targeting a virtual screening application for drug discovery, ABC-MLCO outperforms well-known state-of-the-art methods in terms of final regret, achieving average improvements up to $93 \%$.

title: Isharah: A Large-Scale Multi-Scene Dataset for Continuous Sign Language Recognition
authors: Sarah Alyami, Hamzah Luqman, Sadam Al-Azani, Maad Alowaifeer, Yazeed Alharbi, Yaser Alonaizan
abstract: Current benchmarks for sign language recognition (SLR) focus mainly on isolated SLR, while there are limited datasets for continuous SLR (CSLR), which recognizes sequences of signs in a video. Additionally, existing CSLR datasets are collected in controlled settings, which restricts their effectiveness in building robust real-world CSLR systems. To address these limitations, we present Isharah, a large multi-scene dataset for CSLR. It is the first dataset of its type and size, collected in an unconstrained environment using signers' smartphones. This setup resulted in high variations of recording settings, camera distances, angles, and resolutions. This variation helps with developing sign language understanding models capable of handling the variability and complexity of real-world scenarios. The dataset consists of 30,000 video clips performed by 18 deaf and professional signers. Additionally, the dataset is linguistically rich as it provides a gloss-level annotation for all dataset's videos, making it useful for developing CSLR and sign language translation (SLT) systems. This paper also introduces multiple sign language understanding benchmarks, including signer-independent and unseen-sentence CSLR, along with gloss-based and gloss-free SLT.

title: Cost-Effective Adversarial Attacks Against Code LLM with Model Attention
authors: Weifeng Sun, Naiqi Huang, Meng Yan, Li Huang, Zhongxin Liu, Xiao Liu, David Lo
abstract: Code LLMs (CLLMs) are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, where semantically identical code mutations mislead models into incorrect predictions. To address this, adversarial training has been proposed, retraining models with adversarial examples generated by attack methods. Among various attack approaches, black-box methods have attracted increasing attention due to their flexibility and applicability. However, existing black-box attack methods face two key challenges: 1) vast mutation spaces limit attack efficiency and effectiveness, and 2) resource-intensive model queries constrain scalability. These challenges hinder the practicality of black-box attacks, especially under resource constraints, prompting the critical question: Can we enhance the efficiency of existing attack methods without compromising their effectiveness? To answer this, we conduct an empirical study using Explainable AI (XAI) techniques to investigate differences between adversarial and non-adversarial (failure) examples. After analyzing state-of-the-art attack methods against two CLLMs, we introduce the concept of model attention deviation, which quantifies differences in the model’s focus between unmutated (original) and mutated code. Our findings reveal that adversarial examples exhibit significant attention deviations, with the direction of deviation critically affecting attack success. Building on these insights, we propose ADVSEL, an efficient adversarial attack framework comprising two proxy components: the Attention Proxy Model (APM), which quickly estimates attention deviations to filter unpromising mutations, and the Deviation Direction Proxy Model (DDPM), which assesses whether attention shifts lead toward incorrect predictions. By integrating these proxy models with existing attack methods, ADVSEL effectively prioritizes promising mutations, significantly improving attack efficiency. Experimental evaluations across five CLLMs, four downstream tasks, and three attack methods demonstrate that ADVSEL maintains comparable attack success rates (a slight ASR reduction of 0.62%–0.70%) while significantly reducing model queries (by 34.98%–42.91%) and runtime (by 20.84%–21.45%). Under resource constraints, ADVSEL consistently outperforms baselines, highlighting its practical advantage in cost-effective adversarial evaluation.
