title: A Transformer Fault Diagnosis Approach Based on WCGAN-GP and Multimodal Deep Feature Fusion
authors: Ping Zeng, Wei Bao, Desheng Zhou, Zhaoxin Du, Yuqing Shen, Xiangli Deng
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: To address the challenges in multimodal intelligent diagnosis of transformer faults, such as limited sample size, imbalanced data distribution, insufficient feature fusion capability, and consequently low diagnostic accuracy, this paper proposes a fault diagnosis method based on Wasserstein Conditional Generative Adversarial Network with Gradient Penalty (WCGAN-GP) and deep multimodal feature fusion. A WCGAN-GP model is constructed by integrating Wasserstein distance with conditional generative adversarial learning to achieve high-quality augmentation of small-sample data. An improved Residual Network (ResNet) and an enhanced Densely Connected Network (DenseNet) are employed to perform deep feature extraction from multimodal data. A Multi-Layer Cross-Attention (MLCA) mechanism is introduced within the network to fuse deep multimodal features, enabling early fault diagnosis of transformers. Finally, the proposed intelligent diagnosis method is validated using both simulation data and dynamic model test data, demonstrating its effectiveness in improving diagnostic accuracy.

title: Over‑the‑Air Federated Transformer Learning for Dynamic 6G Network Slicing and Real-Time Edge Intelligence
authors: Santosh Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: This paper introduces OTA-FedTransformer, a novel Over-the-Air Federated Transformer Learning framework designed to address the dual challenges of privacy and latency in dynamic 6G network slicing. The proposed system leverages lightweight transformer models at edge devices, enabling context-aware, sequence-based learning for diverse 6G service requirements such as eMBB, URLLC, and mMTC. To overcome the communication bottlenecks of traditional federated learning, OTA-FedTransformer employs analog over-the-air aggregation, significantly reducing uplink communication overhead while preserving model convergence integrity. The framework incorporates model compression techniques, including attention-head pruning and quantized transformer weights, to ensure deployment feasibility across heterogeneous and resource-constrained edge clients. Experimental evaluation on a synthetic 6G slicing dataset demonstrates that OTA-FedTransformer achieves a ~9.2% improvement in accuracy and a 62% reduction in convergence time compared to FedAvg and OTA-FL baselines. Moreover, it maintains stable performance under non-IID data and wireless noise conditions, demonstrating its robustness and scalability. This work represents a significant step toward real-time, privacy-preserving AI for next-generation mobile networks and edge intelligence, with direct applications in autonomous vehicles, smart industry, and tactile Internet systems.

title: Geospatial Cyber-Physical Risk Assessment of Critical Energy Infrastructure in Essex County, New Jersey
authors: Samuel Grant Quansah, Winston Akai Nettey, Hilda Afeku-Amenyo, Pankaj Lal
publish: 2025 New Jersey Future Energy Transmission Conference (NJFET)
abstract: As New Jersey advances towards its 2035 clean energy goal, a critical gap remains in identifying where cyber-physical threats to the grid are most likely to trigger high-impact disruptions. This study addresses the question: where in Essex County do cyber exposure, flood risk, and social vulnerability converge to create high-priority zones for infrastructure hardening? We develop a GIS-based multi-criteria risk model using publicly available data sources including census tract boundaries from NJOGIS and the U.S. Census Bureau, internet-exposed Industrial Control System (ICS) devices identified via Shodan passive scanning, FEMA Digital Flood Insurance Rate Maps, and CDC Social Vulnerability Index data at the census-tract level. Risk scores are generated via weighted linear combination with equal weights applied to each component (33% each) to provide a balanced, transparent assessment. Preliminary analysis reveals exposed ICS devices concentrated in Newark and elevated social vulnerability scores in 62% of Essex County tracts, suggesting non-trivial spatial overlap of vulnerability factors. Final outputs include a composite risk map and statistically significant hotspots identified via Moran’s I spatial autocorrelation and Getis-Ord Gi* analysis. This work demonstrates how open-source geospatial analytics can bridge academic research, utility operations, and state energy policy, enhancing grid resilience where it matters most.

title: A Coq-based Interactive Verification Tool for Analog Circuits
authors: Jingwen Yang, Zihang Zhang, Hao Deng, Kangqi Zhou, Gang Chen
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Software Engineering and Service Science (ICSESS)
abstract: Printed circuit board design relies on EDA (Electronic Design Automation) tools, and ensuring the correctness of analog circuit design is a crucial step in the design process. This article introduces an interactive verification tool for analog circuits based on the Coq theorem prover, and develops a graphical user interface that combines formal verification. The interface enables users to draw analog circuit diagrams and automatically convert them into Coq description code, significantly enhancing the efficiency of the verification process. By using the tool, we draw a series of typical linear analog circuit diagrams and generate their Coq descriptions. Furthermore, we use theorem provers to verify that the physical quantities of the circuit design meet the expected standards. The experimental results indicate that formal verification can be effectively applied to analog circuit design, providing new research directions and practical methods for software engineering.

title: Analytical Calculation Method for Parasitic Capacitance of Annular Excitation Winding in Non-uniformly Distributed Motors
authors: Jiaqiang Zou, Shengbo Mo, Qianqian Liu, Ruxin Chen, Shushu Zhu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: The excitation controller is the core component for regulating the excitation current and controlling the output voltage of a generator. By employing wide-band gap power devices (such as SiC and GaN), the excitation controller achieves the advantages of low losses and high switching frequency. However, parasitic capacitance in the circuit can significantly affect the switching performance of power devices, increase switching losses, and introduce oscillations and electromagnetic interference. Among these, the parasitic capacitance of the excitation winding is a critical part of the excitation control circuit, and reducing its value can effectively enhance the controller’s performance. For multi-layer, multi-turn annular windings, the calculation of the equivalent total parasitic capacitance C<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">p</inf> becomes particularly complex due to strict slot-width constraints. In practical applications, mismatches between conductor diameter and fixed slot width often cause coil displacement, leading to a non-uniform winding distribution, which makes the traditional uniform-winding assumption no longer applicable. To address this, this paper proposes an analytical modeling method for non-uniform annular windings. The winding is conceptually divided into a uniformly distributed Region I and a slot-constrained nonuniform Region II. Analytical expressions of inter-turn capacitance C<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">tt</inf> and inter-layer capacitance C<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ll</inf> between adjacent circular conductors are derived. Based on these, an equivalent capacitance network is established to represent both the uniform and non-uniform regions. The total parasitic capacitance C<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">p</inf> is then calculated using the principle of energy conservation, by equating the electrostatic energy stored in the equivalent network with that stored in the actual winding. Finally, finite element simulations are conducted to validate the proposed analytical model, demonstrating its accuracy and effectiveness.

title: Adversarial Robustness in Cloud-Native Core Banking Systems: Topological Data Analysis (TDA) for AI Model Integrity Under Cyber-Physical Attacks
authors: Rajesh Vayyala
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: Since cloud-native core banking systems are increasingly integrated with AI for core financial transactions, it is imperative to make these models robust to cyber-physical attacks. In this work, Topological Data Analysis (TDA) is employed for measuring and enhancing adversarial robustness, using a real-world dataset comprising transaction records and network logs from a major financial institution. By probing the intrinsic data structures with the help of TDA, the research identifies dormant vulnerabilities that could potentially be exploited by attackers. It involves simulating cyber-physical attacks in an effort to estimate the integrity and robustness of the AI model being attacked, and consequently designing specific defense solutions. The results not only add to the theoretical knowledge base of TDA in secure banking systems, but also offer practical recommendations for securing cloud-native environments against evolving cyber threats.

title: Research on the AI-Empowered Assessment System of English Classroom Learning in Primary and Secondary School
authors: Shoujun Qiao, Yong Nie, Longlong Chen, Fuhe Niu, Zhenfeng He
abstract: The traditional classroom learning assessment based on the fourth-generation assessment theory overemphasizes democratic construction and subjective judgment, with outdated technology, lack of scientific data, and untimely feedback. With the rapid development of AI technology, educational assessment theory has undergone four iterations and has now entered the fifth generation, which is characterized by "intelligence." Human-AI collaborative assessment has become an inevitable trend. This paper analyzes the policy basis and theoretical foundation for constructing the new assessment system, proposes the elements of the AI-empowered English assessment system in primary and secondary schools, and provides a detailed analysis and interpretation from seven aspects: the fundamental assessment goal of cultivating virtue and talent, the multi-dimensional assessment subjects of human-computer collaboration, the multiple assessment contents focusing on core literacy, the indepth multi-dimensional assessment standards, the scientific and intelligent assessment tools, the diverse assessment methods focusing on process and value-added, and the instant and multimodal assessment feedback. It is expected to provide references for future research.

title: Coordinated Mitigation of Transient Overvoltage in Wind Power HVDC Outbound Systems Using Synchronous Condenser and Energy Storage
authors: Qianhui Zhang, Qilao Mengke, Rihan Hai, Shaogong Zhai
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: To address transient overvoltage (TOV) and steady-state instability risks in high-penetration wind power DC-transmission systems, as well as the response mismatch issues from independent control of synchronous condensers (SCs) and energy storage systems (ESSs), this paper proposes a SC–ESS coordinated control strategy leveraging functional complementarity. By analyzing the mechanisms of TOV formation, a " voltage–frequency double closed-loop" control architecture is designed: The inner frequency loop adopts droop control for fast ESS active power compensation to suppress frequency fluctuations, while the outer voltage loop employs PI control to coordinate reactive power allocation—with SCs as the primary provider and ESSs as auxiliary regulators. Power coordination between the two is achieved through a dynamic division-of-labor mechanism based on voltage deviation thresholds, resolving response mismatches and functional overlaps in traditional single-device or independent control strategies. Simulations on a DC transmission system model demonstrate that the proposed strategy effectively suppresses TOV, significantly improves system power characteristics, enhances transient stability, and provides a feasible solution for the secure operation of high-penetration wind power systems.

title: Energy-Efficient LiFi-Enabled Indoor Localization System for Smart Campus Environments
authors: Alok Misra, Sunil Shukla, Ashulekha Gupta, Khusnidinova Nozima Fakhridin Kizi
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: An important facilitator of smart campus services amid navigation assistance, asset tracking, occupancy analytics, and emergency management is indoor localization. The application of localization systems based on the radio frequencies is characterized by the problems of multi-pathing, congestion of the spectrum, and the consumption of even more energy in highdensity indoor areas. In this paper, a proposal is made to design an energy efficient LiFi based localization system with indoor coverage based on a current LED lighting system that offers high accuracy positions to users at very low power overhead cost. There is the development of a received signal strength (RSS)based localization model using the economic channel qualities, and an energy consumption model is created to measure system efficiency. Simulation results demonstrate sub-meter localization accuracy with up to 40% lower energy consumption compared to WiFi-based indoor positioning systems, making the proposed approach suitable for sustainable smart campus deployments.

title: Power Electronics for Renewable Energy Generation and Hydrogen Production
authors: Dongmei Yao, ZhiXiang Hou
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: This paper describes the power converter, which based on power electronics technology, application in renewable energy generation systems, especially to wind turbine and solar photovoltaic panels as primary energy sources, and hydrogen production by water electrolysis, as an energy storage carrier. The hybrid energy sources system could be connected to a central direct current (DC) bus for energy storage system by power converter. And by three-phase bidirectional converter connects to grid, and/or by alternating current (AC) or DC power inverters give power to local load. The grid connection of renewable energy requires an efficient and reliable power conversion process to meet various grid connection performance requirements for high controllability and flexibility from the power grid. With the continuous increase of installed capacity proportion of renewable energy in the future, hydrogen can be as energy carrier to stabilize the fluctuation of renewable energy and optimize the power system operation.

title: Retrieving Amplitudes of Internal Solitary Waves in the Arctic Ocean from Sequential Satellite Observations
authors: Igor E. Kozlov
abstract: Here we propose a methodology to retrieve amplitudes of internal solitary waves (ISWs) in the Arctic Ocean from combination of sequential synthetic aperture radar (SAR) observations and in situ measurements. We use Sentinel-1 A/B SAR and hydrography data acquired in Fram Strait and near Svalbard in summer 2018. Amplitudes of ISWs are obtained using nonlinear phase speed of ISWs derived from sequential SAR observations and linear phase speed of first mode internal waves theoretically predicted from vertical density profiles within a two-layer KdV model. Comparison of SAR-based phase speeds of ISWs with theoretical predictions generally shows the best correspondence when the time lag between satellite and in situ data is shortest. The range of predicted ISW amplitudes is from 2 to 56 m, in agreement with in situ records made in the study region. The proposed methodology gives promising results for detection of large-amplitude ISWs and quantify their energetics in the Arctic Ocean.

title: Augmented Reality for RObots (ARRO): Pointing Visuomotor Policies Towards Visual Robustness
authors: Reihaneh Mirjalili, Tobias Jülg, Florian Walter, Wolfram Burgard
abstract: Visuomotor policies trained on human expert demonstrations have recently shown strong performance across a wide range of robotic manipulation tasks. However, these policies remain highly sensitive to domain shifts stemming from background or robot embodiment changes, which limits their generalization capabilities. In this paper, we present ARRO, a novel visual representation that leverages zero-shot open-vocabulary segmentation and object detection models to efficiently mask out task-irrelevant regions of the scene in real time without requiring additional training, modeling of the setup, or camera calibration. By filtering visual distractors and overlaying virtual guides during both training and inference, ARRO improves robustness to scene variations and reduces the need for additional data collection. We extensively evaluate ARRO with Diffusion Policy on a range of tabletop manipulation tasks in both simulation and real-world environments, and further demonstrate its compatibility and effectiveness with generalist robot policies, such as Octo, OpenVLA and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\pi _{0}$</tex-math></inline-formula>. Across all settings in our evaluation, ARRO yields consistent performance gains, allows for selective masking to choose between different objects, and shows robustness even to challenging segmentation conditions. Videos showcasing our results are available at:https://augmented-reality-for-robots.github.io

title: Neural-Adaptive Finite-Time Consensus Tracking of Singular Multiagent Systems With Actuator Attack
authors: Xiaofan Liu, Yunyi Yan, Yongfang Xie, Xianxiang Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems
abstract: Since the actuator attack is an important threat to the complicated network, the problem of finite-time consensus tracking (FTCT) control for time-varying delay singular multiagent systems with actuator attack is investigated in this article. First, to approximate the states of the follower agents and design the sliding mode surfaces under actuator attack, a state observer is proposed. Then, the novel neural-adaptive distributed FTCT protocol and actuator attack estimation protocol are designed based on the radial basis function neural network estimation method. The sliding mode control with a partitioning strategy is adopted for the FTCT problem analysis of singular multiagent systems. The sufficient conditions and solving strategies of FTCT for singular multiagent systems over the whole finite-time interval are provided. Finally, the validity of FTCT for singular multiagent systems is verified by simulation examples.

title: Dual-domain Modulation Network for Lightweight Image Super-Resolution
authors: Wenjie Li, Heng Guo, Yuefeng Hou, Guangwei Gao, Zhanyu Ma
abstract: Lightweight image super-resolution (SR) aims to reconstruct high-resolution images from low-resolution images under limited computational costs. We find existing frequencybased SR methods cannot balance the reconstruction of overall structures and high-frequency parts. Meanwhile, these methods are inefficient for handling frequency features and unsuitable for lightweight SR. In this paper, we show introducing both wavelet and Fourier information allows our model to consider both highfrequency features and overall SR structure reconstruction while reducing costs. Specifically, we propose a Dual-domain Modulation Network that integrates both wavelet and Fourier information for enhanced frequency modeling. Unlike existing methods that rely on a single frequency representation, our design combines wavelet-domain modulation via a Wavelet-domain Modulation Transformer (WMT) with global Fourier supervision, enabling complementary spectral learning well-suited for lightweight SR. Experimental results show that our method achieves a comparable PSNR of SRFormer [1] and MambaIR [2] while with less than 50% and 60% of their FLOPs and achieving inference speeds 15.4× and 5.4× faster, respectively, demonstrating the effectiveness of our method on SR quality and lightweight.

title: Image Coding for Machines via Feature-Preserving Rate-Distortion Optimization
authors: Samuel Fernández-Menduiña, Eduardo Pavez, Antonio Ortega
abstract: Many images and videos are primarily processed by computer vision algorithms, involving only occasional human inspection. When this content requires compression before processing, e.g., in distributed applications, coding methods must optimize for both visual quality and downstream task performance. We first show that, given the features obtained from the original and the decoded images, an approach to reduce the effect of compression on a task loss is to perform rate-distortion optimization (RDO) using the distance between features as a distortion metric. However, optimizing directly such a rate-distortion trade-off requires an iterative workflow of encoding, decoding, and feature evaluation for each coding parameter, which is computationally impractical. We address this problem by simplifying the RDO formulation to make the distortion term computable using block-based encoders. We first apply Taylor's expansion to the feature extractor, recasting the feature distance as a quadratic metric with the Jacobian matrix of the neural network. Then, we replace the linearized metric with a block-wise approximation, which we call input-dependent squared error (IDSE). To reduce computational complexity, we approximate IDSE using Jacobian sketches. The resulting loss can be evaluated block-wise in the transform domain and combined with the sum of squared errors (SSE) to address both visual quality and computer vision performance. Simulations with AVC across multiple feature extractors and downstream neural networks show up to 10% bit-rate savings for the same computer vision accuracy compared to RDO based on SSE, with no decoder complexity overhead and just a 7% encoder complexity increase.

title: Enhancing Depression Detection with Cognitive Distortion and User-level Information
authors: Yujie Wan, Zaiquan Dong, Baoxing Jiang, Meiwen Li, Shenggen Ju
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Depression is a common mental illness that can greatly impact an individual's ability to function when the condition is severe. With the proliferation of social media platforms, more and more studies have started to analyze users' social media data to detect their depression. However, most of the existing studies ignore information about users' cognitive distortions. In addition, these studies focus only on the semantic information of users' posts and ignore a variety of user-level information related to depression. To address these weaknesses, we propose a depression detection model fusing cognitive distortions and user-level information. On the one hand, the model captures potential multi-granularity cognitive distortion in formation in user text via a cognitive distortion encoder trained by a multi-granularity cognitive distortion learning method. In addition, we propose a post-level distortion aware mechanism to identify key cognitive distortion in formation related to the subjective cognition of users. On the other hand, the model fuses user-level information that is highly correlated with depression symptoms. It also dynamically identifies key post-level fusion information and multiple user-level information for different users through a multi-feature adaptive weighting method, which reduces noise from data irregularities. The results of the experiments show that the model achieves state-of-the-art performance on a public dataset. In addition, we discuss the impact of different cognitive distortion learning strategies and the importance of different user-level information in detecting depression through various experiments.

title: Energy Dynamics of Green IoT Nodes with Time-Varying Energy Harvesting, Leakage, and Consumption Patterns
authors: Godlove Suila Kuaban, Tadeusz Czachórski, Erol Gelenbe, Piotr Pecka, Piotr Czekalski
publish: 2025 33rd International Symposium on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Computer and Telecommunication Systems (MASCOTS)
abstract: The growing proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) devices has intensified the need for sustainable energy solutions, particularly in resource-constrained deployments where non-rechargeable batteries and supercapacitors are the primary energy sources. Green IoT (G-IoT) frameworks address this challenge by combining energy-saving techniques with energy harvesting from ambient sources such as solar power. However, the intermittent nature of renewable energy and the non-ideal behavior of energy storage systems-such as energy leakage and capacity degradation-complicate reliable energy provisioning. This paper presents a novel Markovian framework for modelling the coupled dynamics of time-varying solar energy harvesting, time-dependent energy consumption, and state-dependent energy leakage in G-IoT systems. Unlike traditional steady-state models, our approach uses Discrete-Time Markov Chains (DTMCs) to capture the stochastic variability in both energy harvesting and consumption processes. We also introduce a refined leakage model in which the leakage rate is dynamically dependent on the stored energy level, enabling a more realistic characterization of energy losses due to energy leakage. Through extensive analytical evaluation, we examine how key parameters-such as storage capacity, leakage rate coefficient, and energy harvesting and consumption patterns-affect critical performance metrics, including the mean stored energy and energy-related service outage probability. Furthermore, we propose a parameter tuning strategy to optimize energy reliability and storage efficiency. The proposed model provides valuable insights for the design and optimization of robust, energy-aware IoT systems powered by renewable energy sources.

title: Nesterov Accelerated Gradient-Based Fixed-Time Convergent Actor-Critic Control for Nonlinear Systems
authors: Shuangsi Xue, Junkai Tan, Hui Cao, Badong Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: This paper presents a novel Nesterov accelerated gradient-based fixed-time convergent actor-critic (NAG-FxT-AC) scheme for the optimal control of nonlinear systems. The proposed approach integrates the Nesterov accelerated gradient method with FxT concurrent learning to achieve rapid convergence while ensuring optimal performance. Actor-critic neural networks (NN) are employed to approximate the optimal value function and control policy, where the accelerated gradient mechanism introduces auxiliary variables to enhance learning efficiency. A FxT concurrent learning algorithm is developed to update the NN weights, guaranteeing convergence to bounded regions within fixed time independent of initial conditions. Lyapunov stability analysis proves that both the closed-loop system states and NN estimation errors are ultimately uniformly bounded with FxT NN weights convergence properties. Simulation results on a nonlinear system validate the effectiveness of the proposed control scheme. Compared to the baseline methods like FxT-ADP, the proposed NAG-FxT-AC reduces the state convergence time by up to 12% and the weight convergence time by 84%, demonstrating superior learning efficiency.

title: Stability of time-varying homogeneous systems with mixed delays and disturbances through novel nonlinear Halanay inequality
authors: Yazhou Tian, Yuangong Sun, Mengqian Liang
abstract: This paper investigates the stability of time-varying homogeneous systems subject to mixed time delays and exogenous disturbances. The primary contributions include: (1) The innovative development of nonlinear Halanay-type differential inequalities that fundamentally extend conventional formulations through (i) the removal of stringent coefficient constraints prevailing in current literature, and (ii) the unification of some existing results under a generalized analytical framework; (2) Establishment of rigorous stability criteria through synergistic integration of the proposed inequalities with nonlinear comparison principles, enabling precise characterization of practical exponential stability and practical polynomial stability; (3) Comprehensive numerical verification, which not only demonstrates remarkable consistency with theoretical predictions but also successfully applies these theoretical findings to address the consensus problem in leader-follower multi-agent networks. These contributions collectively establish a critical linkage between stability theory and engineering applications under complex constraints.

title: Recent Advancements and Emerging Trends in Biosensors: A Review on Disease Diagnosis and Personalized Medicine
authors: Vivek Arya, Dharmendra Kumar, Vijay Shanker Chaudhary, Smita Kumari, Anupam Sahu, Sneha Sharma, Ragini Singh
abstract: Recent research advances and developments in biosensor technology and an overview of its innovative applications for the healthcare industry are reviewed in this article. Biosensors can monitor and detect a variety of biological and chemical characteristics with accuracy and less or minimal invasiveness. It can be classified depending upon their working principle and transducing property, like electrochemical, optical, and piezoelectric processes, and are deployed for various medical applications discussed in this article. This paper provides a brief review of the novel applications of biosensors in healthcare, including illness diagnosis, medication development, and personalized medicine. Difficulties in healthcare biosensor technology as well as the future directions for research and development is highlighted. The fundamental elements of biosensors, their types—such as electrochemical, piezoelectric, thermometric, and optical—as well as current developments in the area, operating theories, and their potential applications, have been covered. This article provides a thorough understanding of the most current advancements in biosensor technology for healthcare and how they may further enhance outcomes and treatment for patients.

title: Satellite derived estimates on methane emissions from rice paddies across China
authors: X. Y. Zhang, M. L. Shi, J. Y. Qin, J. F. Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: On the basis of Tro!pospheric Monitoring Instrument (TROPOMI) XCH4 columns, gridded methane (CH4) emissions from rice paddies across China were estimated in this study. The proposed method follows the principle of bottom-up analysis, and the key factor of methane emission rate was estimated from TROPOMI observations. Via the use of 175 data pairs of field-observed methane emission rates across paddy fields in China and the corresponding XCH4 enhancements in paddy fields compared with local background areas, a forward model was established, with a R2 value of 0.86 (p < 0.01). In 2019, the XCH4 enhancement in rice paddies than in local background areas at a 0.5°-resolution ranged from 0.04 to 16.57 ppb across China, and the mean methane emission rate reached 5.10 ± 3.29 mg CH4 m-2 yr-1, with high spatial variation across eastern China. Considering rice cultivate areas, the rice-growing season, and the estimated methane emission rates, the national methane emission from rice paddies was estimated to reach 5.88 Tg CH4 yr-1. The proposed method provides insights into the estimation of methane emissions from nonpoint sources on the basis of satellite observations.

title: SCImputation: Mitigating Feature Confounding From a Structural Causal Perspective for Data Imputation
authors: Yue Yin, Jiaoyun Yang, Ning An
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Biology and Bioinformatics
abstract: Missing data remain a critical challenge in data analysis, often leading to biased estimates and reduced reliability. Many imputation methods, operating under the assumption that similar instances share similar feature values, overlook the pivotal role of the feature associated with the missing value. Consequently, they apply uniform strategies to all missing values within an instance, often resulting in suboptimal neighbor sets and less accurate predictions. In this paper, we adopt a structural causal perspective to examine data imputation, revealing that once the target feature guides neighbor selection, it acts as a confounder and biases subsequent missing-value estimations. Building on this insight, we propose Structural Causal Imputation (SCImputation), a strategy that leverages both instance-level and feature-level information to refine neighbor selection, and applies a back-door adjustment formula that reweights local estimates with the global distribution, thereby mitigating the confounding introduced by the target feature. We integrate SCImputation with KNNimpute and LLSimpute, and evaluate the resulting variants on five datasets (NACC, three NCBI microarrays, and the Turkiye Student Evaluation) with ablation studies. In comparative evaluations against 12 baselines, SCImputation achieves 3.0%–4.6% gains in accuracy and 0.009–0.059 reductions in RMSE over the established approaches, and demonstrates competitive performance against leading deep learning baselines across diverse missingness mechanisms. These results suggest that SCImputation provides a causally grounded strategy for data imputation in both biomedical and general applications.

title: Coherent Nonlinear Ultrasound Imaging: From Microvasculature to Capillaries
authors: Shuangyi Cheng, Long Xu, Dean Ta, Kailiang Xu
abstract: It is not straightforward for ultrasound imaging from microvasculature to capillaries. The main challenge stems from the detection of low-velocity or quasi-static signal components in the capillaries. To address this, we propose a coherent nonlinear ultrasound imaging method, where a nonlinear coherence operator acted on point spread function is leveraged to improve detection sensitivity of microbubbles. Low-velocity microbubbles can thus be extracted without clutter filtering. Through visualizations of low-velocity microvasculature in rat brain/kidney/testis and early-stage glioma, coherent nonlinear ultrasound imaging paves the way towards capillary-level microangiography.

title: Category-Guided Captioning for Multispectral Change Description in Remote Sensing
authors: Busra Tuzlupinar, Ali Can Karaca
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Geographic Information and Remote Sensing Technology (GIRST)
abstract: Remote sensing image change captioning (RSICC) aims to generate natural-language descriptions of changes between bi-temporal satellite images. Existing studies, however, predominantly operate on RGB imagery and only partially exploit the richer cues available in multispectral data. Motivated by this gap, we focus on multispectral RSICC on the Sentinel-2-based MOSAIC-SEN2-CC dataset and investigate how explicit category guidance can be used to obtain more accurate and scene-consistent change descriptions. We propose a Category-Guided Change Captioning (CGCC) framework with a shared ResNet-101 backbone and a Transformer-based caption decoder. Within this framework, a lightweight category-guided encoder uses an auxiliary head to predict the scene category from fused multispectral features and maps this prediction to a learnable category embedding. An epoch-dependent interpolation between ground-truth and prediction-based embeddings is used to condition cross-temporal fusion on the scene type. Experiments on MOSAIC-SEN2-CC show that the proposed method consistently improves BLEU, METEOR, ROUGE-L, CIDEr-D, SPICE and the composite score $S_m^{\ast}$ over strong ResNet-101-based baselines, particularly on changed scenes, while achieving high category classification accuracy across all semantic classes.

title: The Use of Optocouplers in Signal Formation and Transmission in Security Systems
authors: Ulugbek T. Aliev, Yarashbek T. Yusupov, Asadbek U. Aliev
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: The paper discusses the use of optocouplers in forming and studying the ability of broadband radio signals to pass through obstacles made of various materials. An analysis of related works has been carried out. The main problems in signal transmission are considered. An autonomous optocoupler circuit for signalling the stoppage of a lift when it is switched off has been developed. When studying the propagation of broadband radio signals inside buildings through various reinforced concrete walls and elevator cabin walls made of iron plywood, signal levels were measured in a 9-storey residential building and corresponding graphs of dependence were constructed. The study obtained data on the influence of different materials on the propagation of broadband radio signals. Estimates were made of the passage of broadband Wi-Fi and LTE signals through various obstacles and between floors of the building.

title: Research on the Arrangement of Conductor Tension String in Extreme Icing Environments
authors: Muga Ma Hai, Jiong Liu, Zhuo Chen, Ming Luo, Yijun Tang, Xin Li
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: This paper investigates the challenges associated with the traditional horizontal arrangement of multi-bundle, large-cross-section conductor (with a total cross-sectional area exceeding 5000 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> per phase) tension strings in Ultra-High Voltage (UHV) transmission lines under extreme icing conditions. These challenges include excessive inter-group spacing, difficulties in arranging tower attachment points, uneven structural stress distribution, and installation deformation of hardware. A vertically layered arrangement for tension strings is proposed. By determining the mechanical strength, number of groups, arrangement type, number of attachment points, and optimal inter-group spacing of the tension string, the design requirements concerning electrical performance, mechanical offset, and ice-shedding jump for multi-group tension strings are systematically analyzed. The results indicate that adopting a vertically layered arrangement effectively mitigates the issues of excessive intergroup spacing and uneven force distribution inherent in horizontal arrangements. This configuration enhances the safety, stability, and economic efficiency of tension strings in severe ice regions and provides technical support for the subsequent engineering design of UHV transmission lines in extreme icing environments.

title: Optimization of Soil Pixel Extraction from Sentinel-2 Time-Series Based on the TDBSS-RF
authors: Huijing Zhang, Xiaofei Wang, Lin Gao
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Geographic Information and Remote Sensing Technology (GIRST)
abstract: Soil is a fundamental component of terrestrial ecosystems and plays a crucial role in Earth science research. As soil in the fragmented Huang-Huai-Hai Plain is frquently covered by vegetation or crop residues, it is essential to develop a effective technique for accurate extraction of soil spectral information. In this study, we integrated two-dimensional bare-soil separation (TDBSS) based on computer pattern recognition with an ensemble machine learning algorithm (Random Forest) to develop an enhanced TDBSS-RF classifier for bare soil pixel extraction. The TDBSS algorithm was optimized by integrating multiple spectral index combinations (NDI5-DFI, NDI7-DFI, NBR2-NDI5, NBR2-NDI7, NBR2-NDVI, and NDVI-STI), achieving a bare soil extraction rate of 64%. Additionally, the RF classifier was refined through feature selection and classification optimization, the extraction rate was further improved from 72% to 76%. Validation using sample points in Google Earth Engine (GEE) and comparison with a multi-band soil map showed that 67% of the samples achieved an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> greater than 0.8. These results demonstrate that the proposed method not only generates high-spatial-resolution soil maps but also significantly optimizes computational algorithms, providing a robust and technically enhanced solution for precision agriculture and sustainable land management.

title: Hybrid Ensemble and Deep Learning Architectures for Advanced Persistent Threat Detection
authors: Saleeem Ishaq Tijjani, Bogdan Ghita, Nathan Clarke, Matthew Craven
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: This paper examines classical machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) models for advanced persistent threat (APT) detection, with a focus on hybrid ensemble configurations. We propose multi-stage hybrid ensemble ML models. Simulation results demonstrate that hybrid ensemble models outperform single classifiers by leveraging model diversity and complementary decision-making to capture complex attack patterns. DL architectures, particularly convolutional long short-term memory (CNN-LSTM), further surpass traditional ML models by learning hierarchical features and temporal dependencies in the network traffic. To address the scarcity of real-world APT datasets, we constructed an APT-aware dataset from UNSW-NB15 and evaluated it across multiple learning paradigms. The results highlight improved adaptability to evolving APT tactics and bridge the gap between generic intrusion detection and specialized APT detection through life-cycle-aware modeling.

title: Hybrid Integration of Photonic and Electronic Circuits for On-Chip Optical Interconnects
authors: Ambuj Kumar Agarwal, Shalu Tandon, Vandana, Shikha Singh, Nitin Rakesh, Shreyas Rajendra Hole
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: The constantly growing need of high-speed and energy efficiency in data transmission of contemporary computing platforms has been a prominence in investigating hybrid photoelectronic integration of on-chip optical interconnection. It is explored in this paper that silicon photonics combined with CMOS electronics can prove useful in addressing the drawbacks of electrical interconnects, which enhances the possibility of solutions characterized by low latency, high bandwidth, and scalability. We introduce modeling, performance analysis and comparison to the traditional interconnects. The outcomes of the simulation show that the hybrid integration could contribute a great deal in terms of minimizing power usage and maximizing the signal quality, which would be the future of the next-generation data centers and high-performance computing systems.

title: Distributed Photovoltaic Cluster Power Forecasting Based on an Improved Graph Attention Network Model
authors: Yanping Zhu, Pan Chen, Yueguang Zhang, Yi Feng, Jingzhe Shan, Liang Wang, Tianrun Wen, Delin Zhao, Yuntian Liu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: The regional distributed photovoltaic (PV) clusters are geographically dispersed, resulting in diverse power output characteristics among different PV plants within the cluster, which compromises the accuracy of power forecasting. This paper proposes a short-term power forecasting model based on an enhanced graph attention network (GAT-TPA-ED). In the proposed framework, following sub-clustering of the distributed PV cluster, a deep learning model featuring an encoder-decoder architecture integrated with graph attention (GAT) and temporal pattern attention (TPA) mechanisms is applied to capture multi-site, multi-variable, and multi-time-step information, thereby improving forecasting accuracy. The method is validated using actual operational power output data from distributed PV clusters in East China. The results indicate that the proposed regional PV power forecasting approach is capable of effectively capturing the output characteristics of distributed PV plants and enhancing the forecasting accuracy for distributed PV clusters.

title: A Proposal for a Data Governance Framework for Project Observatory
authors: Jailton Cardoso Da Cruz, Hermano Perrelli De Moura, Jeferson Kenedy Morais Vieira, Ivaldir Honorio De Farias
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Software Engineering and Service Science (ICSESS)
abstract: Digital data is a vital asset for businesses. Extracting value from these assets makes Data Governance (DG) essential to ensure the accuracy, consistency, and accessibility of data. In the context of Project Management (PM), the need for accessible, well-governed data is particularly critical to project success; thus, a Project Observatory (PO) can serve as an informational platform to monitor project activities. This research introduces a conceptual DG Framework (DGF) specifically designed for application in PM Observatories with the aim of improving data analysis efficiency, decision-making quality, and transparency. This study addresses the intersection of Data Governance and Project Management, providing a foundation for developing reliable, data-driven Project Observatories.

title: Early Reactions to Measles and Chikungunya on TikTok: Which Outbreak Triggered More Fear, Toxicity, and Identity Attack?
authors: Nirmalya Thakur, Faria Nishat Khan
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: This paper presents the first multilingual cross-outbreak comparison of TikTok discourse, focusing on the early reactions of TikTok users related to two ongoing outbreaks: measles and chikungunya. The first few cases of the ongoing measles outbreak were recorded in 2024, and the first few cases of the ongoing chikungunya outbreak were recorded in 2025. To capture the early reactions, TikTok videos about measles posted between January and May 2024 and about chikungunya posted between January and May 2025 were collected, and their descriptions were analyzed. A multilingual analytical framework was developed, incorporating advanced data preprocessing, outlier detection and removal, language detection, zero-shot natural language inference for fear and anxiety detection, deep learning models for toxicity and identity-attack detection, and correlation analysis. The findings showed that descriptions of TikTok videos about both outbreaks were consistently associated with a high level of fear and anxiety, and there were no significant differences in the trends of fear or anxiety across both outbreaks. The toxicity analysis revealed a difference between the two outbreaks. The average toxicity score per month in descriptions of TikTok videos about measles was consistently higher than that of descriptions of TikTok videos about the chikungunya outbreak. In addition to analyzing the average toxicity per outbreak per month, this was confirmed by performing the Mann–Whitney U test, which resulted in Cliff’s δ ≈ 0.36, favoring measles. Furthermore, the top-decile analysis showed that measles video descriptions were almost twice as likely as Chikungunya video descriptions to occur in the upper 10% of video-description toxicity scores (10.3% vs. 5.5%). Across both outbreaks, instances of identity attack in video descriptions were rare, and when they occurred, they were more common in descriptions of videos related to chikungunya. This finding was also supported by the Mann– Whitney U test (p ≈ 0.01) and the top decile analysis, which showed that descriptions of videos about Chikungunya were more likely to fall in the highest 10% of identity-attack scores than those about Measles. Finally, the results of the correlation analysis showed statistically significant correlations across toxicity and identity attacks for both outbreaks.

title: Research on Small Wildlife Target Detection in Drone Imagery Using EGSOD-YOLOv8
authors: Yating Li, Yang Liu, Lin Gan, Fan Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Robotics and Automatic Control (IRAC)
abstract: The YOLO series of algorithms, leveraging a single-stage, end-to-end detection paradigm, achieves an effective balance between speed and accuracy, and has been widely deployed in applications such as autonomous driving, security surveillance, and remote sensing identification. However, in drone-based wildlife detection scenarios where targets are small-scale and densely distributed, challenges such as insufficient feature extraction capability, low target response, and inadequate representation of small objects remain, leading to elevated rates of missed and false detections. To address these limitations, this paper introduces EGSOD-YOLOv8, a lightweight improved algorithm. The proposed approach integrates re-parameterization techniques to simplify the GFPN structure and strengthens multi-layer feature fusion through cross-layer skip connections and cross-scale feature interaction. In addition, a multi-scale EMA attention mechanism is embedded into the C2f module, enabling adaptive modeling of feature importance and enhancing the representation of contour features for small objects. Furthermore, during the bounding box regression stage, the Shape-Nwd loss is employed to replace CIoU, which utilizes Wasserstein distance to measure the similarity between predicted and ground-truth boxes, thereby improving detection accuracy and stability. Experimental results show that the proposed method attains a mean average precision (mAP) of 98.6% and improves inference speed by approximately 17% over the baseline model. It significantly alleviates missed and false detections and effectively achieves an optimal balance between lightweight design and high accuracy in wildlife small object detection.

title: A Predictive Bandwidth Distribution Model for 5G Network Slices Based on Long-Range Dependent Traffic Patterns
authors: Vikrant Chole, Minal Chole, Swapna Lokhande, Deepa Nikam, Jhankar Moolchandani, Santosh Sahu
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: The presented paper proposes a predictive bandwidth distribution model of 5G network slices that explicitly characterizes the long-range dependence (LRD) as it may be followed among the slice traffic. It starts with the characterization of the patterns of demand by Hurst exponent in an attempt to quantify long-memory demand. Based on these perceptions, the fractionalorder FARIMA and fGn model are used to produce correct multistep predictions of the traffic. These predictions are then fed into a constrained optimization assigner which proactively allocates bandwidth among slices with two goals; reducing SLA violations and enhancing overall utilization efficiency. It determines the evaluation by the synthetic LRD traces and the operator-like multi-slice workloads. It was found that the suggested approach is much better than ARIMA, EWMA and no movement strategies and would provide a better forecasting precision, lower SLA risk and bandwidth allocations more constant in dynamically changing conditions. The results emphasise the significance of LRD-conscious models in the efficient management of resources in the 5G and beyond networks in the future.

title: A Hybrid Framework for Dynamic Patient Consent Management using Blockchain and OAuth 2.0
authors: Raghu Avula, Cliff Zou
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: Over the years, managing patient consent for sharing health data has remained a significant challenge due to a lack of transparency about how the data is shared with other systems and the absence of a verifiable audit trail. This paper introduces a new hybrid design that uses an industry-standard Open Authorization (OAuth) 2.0 authorization framework for detailed access grants, complemented by a decentralized, on-chain consent ledger built on the ERC-6551 blockchain standard, enabling digital assets (using Non Fungible Tokens) to act as independent accounts. The primary concept behind this paper is the utilization of the ERC-6551 Token Bound Account (TBA) as a patient-controlled on-chain portfolio of consent grant tokens, which are represented as semi-fungible tokens. We have solved the problem of converting the static, database-bound permissions into a dynamic, patient-owned digital system supported by timely-expiring JWT tokens. With the utilization of the OAuth 2.0 flow, short-lived JSON Web Tokens (JWTs) act as pointers to the durable, immutable consent records on the Blockchain. With our dual-validation approach, resource servers can verify both the off-chain time-based short-lived tokens and the granted access, along with on-chain consent status, to determine whether the patient has revoked the token. This provides a robust, auditable, and patient-sovereign system for managing healthcare data access. Finally, we present the complete design and architecture, along with data flows and cryptographic operations, which we used to analyze the security and performance characteristics and evaluate the outcomes of this implementation.

title: Path Planning for Inspection Robots Based on an Improved Particle Swarm Optimization Algorithm
authors: Xu Yan, Chao Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Robotics and Automatic Control (IRAC)
abstract: To address path planning challenges for inspection robots, this paper proposes an improved particle swarm optimization (PSO) algorithm that combines cubic spline interpolation function optimization with a dynamic inertia weight adjustment strategy. Building upon the standard PSO approach, cubic spline optimization transforms the path in simulation results from a polygonal line into a smooth curve, thereby achieving a smaller optimal distance value. Simultaneously, when interpolation points along the path collide with obstacles in the map, a substantial penalty is added to the optimal distance value, thereby achieving obstacle avoidance. Regarding the core formula of the PSO algorithm itself, the particle swarm algorithm is enhanced through dynamically adjusting the inertial weight. Four distinct strategies are employed to modify the inertial weight, yielding corresponding simulation results. Finally, simulation experiments were conducted using standard PSO and the four improved PSO algorithms for path planning. Based on the corresponding data, an evaluation system for the algorithms was established to determine the optimal path planning algorithm.

title: Next-Generation Elastic Optical Networks with Quantum-Assisted Spectrum Allocation
authors: Shafiq Sharhrah, Shashi Prakash Dwivedi, Rajeev Kumar, Kaushal Kumar, Rajendra Kachhava, Pradeep Kumar Mishra
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: Elastic Optical Networks (EONs) are widely recognized as a key enabler for high-capacity and flexible communication infrastructures. However, spectrum fragmentation and inefficient resource utilization limit their scalability. In this paper, we propose a quantum-assisted spectrum allocation (QASA) framework for next-generation EONs, leveraging quantum optimization algorithms to enhance spectrum assignment efficiency and reduce blocking probability. Analytical modeling and simulation results demonstrate significant performance gains compared to conventional methods.

title: Performance Evaluation of Asymmetric Six-Phase Induction Motors Using an Improved DTC-SVPWM Technique
authors: Kaniz Suburna, Shirazul Islam, Atif Iqbal, S. M. Muyeen
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: Multiphase induction motors play a crucial role in industrial applications, particularly in the mining sector, due to their superior reliability, fault tolerance, and efficiency. Despite these advantages, maintaining accurate torque and speed control while reducing power losses continues to be a major challenge. This study aims to enhance the operational performance of multiphase induction motors by implementing an advanced Direct Torque Control with Space Vector Pulse Width Modulation (DTC-SVPWM) technique. The proposed approach leverages sensor less DTC and the inherent capabilities of SVPWM to improve efficiency and accuracy while reducing power dissipation. The research specifically investigates the performance of a six-phase asymmetric induction motor operating under a variable-speed environment with a DTC-SVPWM strategy. To simplify control implementation and potentially minimize the required filter size, a fixed switching frequency is adopted, ensuring more stable and predictable operation. The study evaluates key performance metrics, including torque ripples, speed regulation, and overall dynamic response, to determine the effectiveness of the proposed method in enhancing efficiency and precision. The findings of this research contribute to enhancing multiphase motor control strategies for mining applications, where high performance and energy efficiency are critical.

title: A New Manifold Learning Based Algorithm LapRegOSVM for Wine NIRS Classification
authors: Juan Huo
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Software Engineering and Service Science (ICSESS)
abstract: The wine industry is undergoing a digital transformation driven by Industry 4.0 principles, with Near-Infrared (NIR) spectroscopy playing a central role in quality control and classification. This paper introduces LapRegOSVM, a novel semi-supervised One-Class Support Vector Machine (OSVM) leveraging manifold learning and graph Laplacian regularization to enhance classification performance with limited labeled NIR data. Evaluated on an open-source NIR wine dataset, LapRegOSVM demonstrates superior performance compared to existing methods, achieving high classification accuracy with much less labeled samples required by traditional supervised techniques. These results highlight the potential of LapRegOSVM to facilitate efficient and reliable wine analysis within the evolving landscape of Industry 4.0.

title: Real-Time Formation Control for Arbitrary Pattern Generation in Multi-Robot Systems
authors: Xiao Xiao, Qingbo Zhang, Jinsha Xu, Dongxing Jing, Qingxiang Ma, Hao Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Robotics and Automatic Control (IRAC)
abstract: Multi-robot formation control plays a crucial role in cooperative exploration, transportation, and environmental monitoring. However, existing approaches still face challenges in efficiently generating and maintaining arbitrary geometric patterns in real time. Most current methods are limited to predefined formation types and lack the capability to track dynamically changing formations. To address these limitations, this paper proposes a novel formation control maneuver that achieves arbitrary pattern generation and real-time tracking by minimizing the image-domain error between the current and target formations. Through the mapping of robot positions into a complex-plane image representation, the proposed method enables each robot to adjust its position cooperatively to minimize global formation error. To further ensure real-time performance and convergence efficiency, a zeroing neural network (ZNN) model is incorporated into the control framework. Simulation experiments demonstrate that the proposed control maneuver can generate arbitrary complex target formations from random initial position. The robots collectively converge toward the desired pattern "IRAC2025" from random initial postion. The results validate the effectiveness, real-time capability, the proposed formation control approach for complex and dynamic multi-robot systems.

title: From Sensors to Safety: A Systematic Review of IoT Detection Solutions in Construction Management
authors: Aretha Gracella Santoso, Olivia Augusta Soeyatno, Ali Gunawan
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Software Engineering and Service Science (ICSESS)
abstract: The construction industry remains a high-risk workplace due to safety issues and dynamically changing work sites. The Internet of Things (IoT) has emerged as an important tool to improve safety management through real-time monitoring and predictive risk analysis. A Systematic Literature Review (SLR) utilized Scopus as the primary database and the PRISMA framework, this study applies. 28 of the 486 papers met the inclusion criteria, which were found using the keywords "Internet of Things," "Worker Safety," and "Construction" published between 2020 and 2025. The growing usage of IoT-based detection systems, such as wearable technology and sensors, improves worker safety and lowers the risk rate of incidents. The three most frequently mentioned challenges in IoT adoption are high implementation and maintenance costs, device limitations, and data security and privacy. However, there is a significant barrier to long-term adoption that includes workforce training and employee safety culture. Other emerging technologies have been integrated with the Internet of Things (IoT) for better automation, like artificial intelligence, edge computing, cloud computing, Building Information Modeling (BIM), and Augmented Reality (AR/VR). This review contributes to highlighting the necessity of maintaining a balance between organizational readiness and technological advancements to achieve sustainable IoT adoption for construction safety management.

title: Exponents for Shared Randomness-Assisted Channel Simulation
authors: Aadil Oufkir, Michael X. Cao, Hao-Chung Cheng, Mario Berta
abstract: We determine the exact error and strong converse exponents of shared randomness-assisted channel simulation in worst case total-variation distance. Namely, we find that these exponents can be written as simple optimizations over the R´enyi channel mutual information. Strikingly, and in stark contrast to channel coding, there are no critical rates, allowing a tight characterization for arbitrary rates below and above the simulation capacity. We derive our results by asymptotically expanding the meta-converse for channel simulation [Cao et al., IEEE Trans. Inf. Theory (2024)], which corresponds to nonsignaling assisted codes. We prove this to be asymptotically tight by employing the approximation algorithms from [Berta et al., Proc. IEEE ISIT (2024)], which show how to round any non-signaling assisted strategy to a strategy that only uses shared randomness. Notably, this implies that any additional quantum entanglement-assistance does not change the error or the strong converse exponents.

title: Enhancing Field Homogeneity of Dipolar Ultra-low-field MRI Magnets via Bézier Radial Parameterization and Dual-material Optimization
authors: Liang Xuan, Xianfeng Xu, Cai Wan, Zheng Xu
abstract: Dipolar ultra-low-field (ULF) magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) systems, with compact size and open geometry, offer promise for portable MRI. However, the limited spatial distribution of the magnet constrains optimization toward high field homogeneity, thereby restricting imaging quality. This work presents a geometric optimization framework for dipolar magnets using a novel third-order Bézier radial parameterization (TBRP), which extends conventional single-radius designs to a multi-degree-of-freedom configuration, enhancing geometric flexibility. Optimizations of samarium–cobalt (SmCo) and neodymium–iron–boron (NdFeB) magnets are performed via a coupled Genetic Algorithm–Finite Element approach. A dual-material (DM) composite magnet is proposed to combine the advantages of both materials for improved field uniformity. Simulations show that, with the average main magnetic field maintained within the target range, the optimized SmCo- and NdFeB-based magnets achieve inhomogeneities of 1292 ppm and 3164 ppm, corresponding to improvements of approximately 20–30% over conventional disk designs, while the proposed DM magnet further reduces the inhomogeneity to 556 ppm, representing an improvement of nearly 60%. The analyses of magnetic thermal stability and engineering tolerances indicate that, although all magnet systems exhibit certain sensitivities to temperature variations and assembly deviations, the DM configuration demonstrates relatively better stability in maintaining field homogeneity. This study provides a scalable and cost-effective approach for the design of ULF MRI magnet systems.
