title: On Zero Skip-Cost Generalized Fractional-Repetition Codes from Covering Designs
authors: Wenjun Yu, Bo-Jun Yuan, Moshe Schwartz
abstract: We study generalized fractional repetition codes that have zero skip cost, and which are based on covering designs. We show that a zero skip cost is always attainable, perhaps at a price of an expansion factor compared with the optimal size of fractional repetition codes based on Steiner systems. We provide three constructions, as well as show non-constructively, that no expansion is needed for all codes based on sufficiently large covering systems.

title: Centimeter-Scale Roughness Characteristics of Lunar Geological Structures and Permanently Shadowed Regions: Insights from Mini-RF SAR Data
authors: Yao Gao, Bo Wu, Jiapei Hu, Yi Xu, Fei Zhao, Zihan Xu, Pingping Lu, Robert Wang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Topographic roughness is a critical parameter in lunar exploration and scientific research due to its scale-dependent properties. Synthetic aperture radar (SAR) is a powerful tool for characterizing lunar surface physical properties. This study investigates the centimeter-scale roughness characteristics of lunar terrain using S-band Mini-RF SAR data, including seven types of geological structures at the mid-latitude regions and permanently shadowed regions (PSRs) at the lunar poles. First, a novel roughness parameter, single scattering trace (SST), is proposed based on matrix trace statistics to quantify lunar surface and near-surface roughness from radar echoes. The effectiveness of SST is validated using high-resolution Narrow Angle Camera (NAC) Digital Terrain Model (DTM) data. Then, by comparing the radar observations, topographic roughness, topographic slopes, and rock abundance of different geological structures, we find that radar observations can reveal wavelength-scale textural variations of geological structures that are not apparent in larger-scale topographic roughness measurements. Furthermore, the roughness characteristics of PSRs and non-PSRs at the lunar polar regions are analyzed. Results show that PSRs exhibit slightly lower roughness than non-PSRs at the south pole, while the opposite trend is observed at the north pole. The inter-polar roughness differences can be attributed to the distinct roughness characteristics of non-PSRs rather than variations within PSRs. Overall, our results demonstrate that the proposed SST parameter is an effective metric for assessing lunar surface roughness.

title: Multi-Mode-Group-Equalized Fiber Designed via a NN-GA Framework based on Mode Distribution Figure of Merit
authors: Yanghua Xie, Shecheng Gao, Jiajing Tu, Yuanhua Feng, Weiping Liu, Zhaohui Li
abstract: In short-distance high-capacity optical communication scenarios, space-division multiplexing technology based on multimode fiber enables large-capacity transmission at lower costs by efficiently utilizing mode resource, showing significant application potential. However, conventional multimode fibers are plagued by severe mode group (MG) crosstalk and significant differential mode delay (DMD), which severely undermine signal integrity and increase bit-error rates, thus limiting their practical use. This paper proposes a multi-mode-group-equalized fiber (MGEF) characterized by the equalization of crosstalk and DMD. Introducing the mode distribution figure of merit (MD-FOM) as a criterion, the MGEF is designed by integrating neural network and genetic algorithm (NN-GA) and adopting a complex multi-ring core structure for fiber design. MD-FOM guides NN-GA optimization, with larger values indicating better alignment with design requirements, enabling iterative refinement of fiber structure for desired mode separation and equalization performance. The MGEF can support over 100 modes, which are divided into 10 MGs according to effective refractive index (n<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">eff</sub>), and the minimum difference of n<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">eff</sub> (Δn<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">eff</sub>) between MGs is 1.52×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-3</sup>. It exhibits excellent performance with inter-group crosstalk lower than -20 dB/km, maximum DMD under 15 ps/m, and the fabrication tolerance for the radius and refractive index difference of each layer in the multi-ring core is ±3%. This effectively addresses the aforementioned critical issues.

title: Deadline-Aware Task Offloading with Concurrency in Serverless Edge Computing
authors: Minh-Tuong Nguyen, Quang-Trung Luu, Vo Phi Son, Le-Nam Tran, Van-Dinh Nguyen
abstract: Serverless edge computing enables low-latency Internet of Things (IoT) services but faces scalability challenges due to complex concurrency and resource management. While existing approaches address function initialization and edge-cloud offloading, they often overlook the joint optimization of serverless concurrency and physical-layer resources, leading to potential service degradation and increased costs. To tackle this, we propose OPLA, a novel cross-layer framework for joint latency and concurrency optimization, designed to minimize end-to-end latency while optimizing concurrent serverless functions. OPLA models interactions between physical-layer resources (e.g., bandwidth, transmission power, offloading ratios) and application-layer concurrency decisions. The formulated problem is a highly non-convex mixed-integer nonlinear program (MINLP), which we prove to be at least NP-complete in certain cases. To approximate its optimal solution efficiently, we propose an iterative exploration-exploitation procedure (EEP). The exploration phase, which is embarrassingly parallelizable, balances solution quality and efficiency with single parameter tuning. The exploitation phase is just a simple successive convex approximation to OPLA. Moreover, we also develop a presolve-postsolve heuristic with deterministic rounding to ensure feasibility for OPLA. Numerical results demonstrate that EEP consistently achieves solutions within a 6% optimality gap relative to a global solver across a wide range of network scales and workloads, confirming its effectiveness and scalability for real-world serverless edge deployments.

title: Machine-Learning Empowered Propagation Measurement and Modeling for an Amphitheater
authors: Soo Yong Lim, Chee Ren Ong, Jay Sern Chow, Khee Lee, Qi Ping Soo, Juinn-Horng Deng, Jeng-Kuang Hwang, Sheng-Kai Chen, Yan-Di Liu, Yu-Chien Wu, Hsiang-Chuan Hsien
abstract: This paper presents a machine learning (ML) approach to modeling radio signal strength in an open-air amphitheater environment. Towards this end, we have first collected field measurement data from an amphitheater located on the Malaysia Campus of the University of Nottingham at 900 MHz, 2.4 and 5.8 GHz. We have conducted the measurement campaign over the course of six months, with repeatability test done for each frequency for at least one cavea level to make sure the results are repeatable. These measurement data are plotted and analyzed before being fed to a ML model for training purposes. In particular, we have explored three options of the ML methods, namely, the Linear Regression method, the Random Forest method, and the Neural Network method; and finally settled on the Neural Network method for is superiority over the other two methods -it performs better when more input data were inserted to train continuously. In addition, we have run ray-tracing simulation to provide an extra layer of comparison to the ML-generated prediction results. Beyond this, we have expanded the ML model to account for a larger geometry of amphitheater. The output of this work is expected to enhance wireless communication reliability in amphitheaters, with potential benefits for event management, public safety, and entertainment industries.

title: Frequency-Difference Electrical Impedance Tomography for Stroke Monitoring: Effects of Model Accuracy and Reconstruction Methods
authors: Taweechai Ouypornkochagorn, Nick Polydorides, Jiabin Jia, Hugh McCann
abstract: Stroke covers a number of critical abnormalities in cerebral hemodynamics that require prompt diagnosis and continuous monitoring to improve patient outcomes. Electrical impedance tomography (EIT) is an imaging technology that enables dynamic cerebral monitoring through electrical conductivity contrast. Traditionally, monitoring with EIT relies on time-difference measurements (hence, tdEIT), requiring prior measurement data from a healthy state, which is typically unavailable in clinical practice. Frequency-difference EIT (fdEIT) offers an alternative approach that eliminates this requirement. However, fdEIT presents greater challenges in image reconstruction because conductivity variations with frequency change occur for all head tissues, making reconstruction model accuracy more critical than in tdEIT. In this study, the effects of model accuracy, conductivity change restrictions, and noise tolerance are investigated for three fdEIT reconstruction methods. Simulations of intra-cerebral hemorrhage reveal that, unlike tdEIT, accurate model geometry and the inclusion of cerebrospinal fluid are necessary, and restricting conductivity change in the skull region is highly recommended. When accurate head geometry is available, the reference-weighted fdEIT method demonstrates markedly superior performance compared with standard fdEIT, and comparable to an ideal tdEIT case. On the other hand, when accurate head geometry is not available, the standard fdEIT method is recommended, though with limited performance. Regardless of the reconstruction method, ensuring a measurement signal-to-noise ratio of at least 50 dB is essential for reliable imaging.

title: Semantic-Spatial Feature Refinement Network for Road Extraction from Remote Sensing Images
authors: Zhigang Yang, Huiguang Yao, Qiang Li, Weiping Ni, Junzheng Wu, Qi Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Extracting precise road information from remote sensing images remains challenging due to the interference from similar objects and occlusion from surroundings. To alleviate these issues, we propose a novel road extraction network to enhance both the precision and topological connectivity of extracted road networks, dubbed as CRNet. Specifically, a Global-Local Context Decoupling Module (GLCDM) is introduced to explicitly model long-range contextual dependencies while preserving fine-grained local road features, thereby improving the model’s inference capability in occluded regions. Furthermore, a Semantic-Spatial Feature Refinement Module (SSFRM) is integrated into the skip connections, which leverages deep semantic features to guide the suppression of background noise in shallow feature maps across both channel and spatial dimensions, ensuring the decoder receives structurally accurate road representations. Experimental results on the remote sensing road datasets demonstrate that CRNet achieves state-of-the-art performance in terms of both segmentation accuracy and road connectivity. The source code is publicly available at https://github.com/CVer- Yang/CRNet.

title: NIASM: Non-Idiomatic Abstractive Summarization Model to Reduce Hallucination and Factual Inconsistency Problem in Text Generation
authors: Estabraq Abdulreda Kadhim, Mohammad-Reza Feizi-Derakhshi, Hadi S. Aghdasi
abstract: Abstractive summarization models have demonstrated impressive progress in producing fluent, concise, and human-like summaries. Nevertheless, they also face long-term difficulties, including factual inconsistencies, hallucinations, and misunderstandings of idiomatic expressions, which commonly lead to distortions of intended meanings and incorrect information. To improve the semantic reliability and factual consistency of generated summaries, this paper proposes a new hybrid framework, known as the Non-Idiomatic Abstractive Summarization Model (NIASM), which combines idiomatic substitution and masked named entity (MNE) modeling. We then train a BERT-based idiom detection system on a specifically designed Idiom and Literal Sentence Dataset and achieve accurate classification of idiomatic and literal expressions. Moreover, we present three domain-specific datasets, namely Non-idiomatic BBC, XSum, and CNN, in which the idiomatic phrases are substituted with literal ones in order to enhance the processing of figurative language. The framework improves named entity recognition and minimizes factual hallucinations in generation by training MNE models on large language models (LLMs) such as T5, BART, Hie-BART, and PEGASUS. This model was tested on three benchmark datasets - BBC News, XSum, and CNN/DailyMail with various metrics: ROUGE, which measures lexical overlap; BERTScore, which measures semantic similarity, comparing generated text and reference texts on deep contextual embeddings and cosine similarity; QA-Eval, FactCC, which measures factual consistency, and human evaluations. The results of the experiment indicate that the proposed NIASM framework consistently outperforms methods based on the baseline. For example, BART scored a QA-Eval of 0.7205 and a BERTScore of 0.8195 on XSum, and PEGASUS scored a FactCC of 0.898075 and a BERTScore-F1 of 0.8737, which represents factual and semantic coherence. Hie-BART outperforms other LLMs on the Readability metric, generating more readable summaries on the XSum, CNN, and BBC datasets. These results support the success of our NIASM strategy, which incorporates idiom substitution and MNE.

title: An SVPWM Method of Three-Level SNPC Inverter to Achieve ZVS of Inverter Stage Devices and Reduce CM Ripple Based on Zero Vector Transitions
authors: Shuangxi Zhu, Jiajia Guan, Xuchen Sun, Xinyue Guo, Cai Chen, Yong Kang
abstract: The three-phase three-level (3-L) sparse neutral point clamped (SNPC) inverter features a reduced number of power semiconductor devices, compared to the classical 3-L NPC and T-type inverters, representing a promising alternative for industrial motor drives and electric vehicle traction systems. However, the switching losses of the 2-L inverter stage increase significantly under non-unity power factor condition when applying conventional sequences, resulting in reduced efficiency. To address this issue, a novel space vector pulse width modulation (SVPWM) method based on zero vector transitions is proposed in this article. The proposed sequence achieves zero voltage switching (ZVS) of the 2-L inverter stage devices. Thus, the switching losses of the 2-L inverter stage can be theoretically eliminated. Furthermore, the dwell-time calculation of the vectors is reconsidered, and an adjusting parameter is introduced, which influences the differential-mode (DM) and common-mode (CM) voltage-time area ripples. Finally, experimental validation on a 1.5-kVA hardware prototype demonstrates that the proposed method achieves higher efficiency over a wide power factor range, with a 0.3% increase at inductive load (PF = 0.7) and a 0.35% increase at capacitive load (PF = 0.65) compared with the conventional low-switching loss modulation method. Meanwhile, the proposed method generates lower CM voltage-time area ripple over a wide modulation index range, which is further verified by CM current measurements.

title: AI-Assisted Interpretation of Children’s Drawings via Retrieval-Augmented Generation
authors: Haneen M. Aljalal, Heleen H. Alshareef, Najla M. Alduraib, Hala M. Hamdoun, Rawabi Alsedais
abstract: This paper presents a retrieval-augmnted, CLIP-based pipline to support educators and psycologists in interpreting children’s drawings. The proposed system integrates vision-language captioning, case based retrival, and large language model generation, where CLIP produces descriptive captions, FAISS retrieves the top-k=3 semantically similar expert-annotated cases, and GPT-3.5 synthesizes a psychologically informed narrative report. Evaluation on 1,222 drawings with expert reference analyses considers six controlled variants (A1–A6) across two axes: (i) semantic similarity to expert interpretations (cosine similarity, BERTScore, ROUGE-L F1) and (ii) coverage and robustness (content-unit precision/recall/F1, ROUGE-L recall, new-information rate, and negation mismatch). In addition to the CLIP/BLIP ablations (A1–A4), we benchmark two image-only multimodal VLM baselines (GPT-4o and LLaVA; A5–A6) and conduct a small blinded expert rating study on 20 randomly selected drawings to contextualize trade-offs. Results show that retrieval-grounded configurations improve coverage compared to non-retrieval baselines and, in the CLIP-based comparison (A3 vs. A4), reduce polarity (negation) mismatches while maintaining competitive semantic similarity. Although GPT-4o attains the strongest similarity and content-unit scores overall, it incurs substantially higher latency and does not provide retrieval-based evidence trails; LLaVA shows mixed gains with notably lower content recall. The proposed CLIP-based variant achieves a practical balance of faithfulness and efficiency for deployment, and is explicitly positioned as decision support rather than diagnosis, surfacing salient cues and transparent evidence trails for expert oversight. Overall, this work demonstrates that retrieval grounding can make AI-assisted interpretation of children’s drawings more consistent, transparent, and scalable in educational and clinical contexts.

title: Real-World Autonomous Driving: Exploring Energy Dynamics in Gradually Evolving Traffic Flows
authors: Jianchang Huang, Hongliang Liu, Xin Wang, Qinghai Lin, Guohua Song, Pengfei Fan, Lei Yu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: In car-following scenarios, trailing vehicles tend to fluctuate around the motion of the lead vehicle and gradually converge toward their preferred trajectories. With the large-scale integration of autonomous vehicles (AVs) into traffic streams, differences in desired trajectories among vehicles are amplified. This amplification intensifies fluctuation propagation and complicates platoon-level energy consumption mechanisms. This study addresses these dynamics through the development of a mixed-platoon energy consumption estimation model that accounts for gradually evolving traffic flows (MP-ECEMG), incorporating real-world data from light-duty human-driven vehicles (HVs) and AVs. Results indicate that the model leads to a broader range of energy consumption variation than conventional models due to complex vehicle interactions, while the transitions of energy consumption between vehicles are smoother than those predicted for theoretical AVs. For the three powertrains examined, potential energy savings at a 0.5 AV penetration rate (PR) are 11.4%, 18.1%, and 41.8% for internal combustion engine vehicles (ICEVs), recovery electric vehicles (EVs), and non-recovery EVs, respectively. In contrast, actual savings based on AV testing data in Apolloscope are 2.9%, 4.7%, and 11.5%. Regional energy performance is comparable between Apolloscope and Waymo, with both slightly outperforming A2D2. This study provides key insights into the effects of real-world AV technology on energy consumption.

title: Cross-Layer Caching for High-Performance Computing: Experimental Analysis of Alluxio, Ceph Tiering, and Hybrid Designs Using HACC-IO Traces
authors: Blessing J. Siwonde, Prince Hamandawana, Kudzai Nevanji, Tae-Sun Chung
abstract: High-performance computing (HPC) applications exert substantial pressure on distributed storage systems, where backend latency, metadata overheads, and small-object amplification often limit I/O throughput. Caching is therefore critical to achieving scalable performance; however, the relative effectiveness of inbuilt distributed caching (IDC) such as Ceph tiering and external FUSE-based caching (EFC) such as Alluxio remains underexplored under realistic scientific workloads. This study presents a comprehensive evaluation of three caching architectures—Ceph writeback/readonly tiering (IDC), Alluxio Tier-1 selective caching (EFC), and a Hybrid multi-tier design combining EFC with Ceph SSD caching—using 100 GB of real HACC-IO cosmology traces. Results reveal two dominant asymmetries. First, EFC-only achieves the highest Tier-1 read locality, reaching 59.5% T1 hits and requiring nearly 324 backend HDD block reads, compared to only 459 T1 hits and 341 promotions in the Hybrid setup. Second, for write-intensiveworkloads, Hybrid ASYNC_THROUGH + writeback decisively outperforms all other configurations, reducing backend HDD activity by more than an order of magnitude. In read workloads, Hybrid narrows the performance gap with EFC by serving 332 read misses from SSD rather than HDD, lowering HDD fetches from 324 blocks (EFC) to only 9 blocks (Hybrid) with a 35× reduction in backend disk I/O. Overall, the findings demonstrate that while EFC maximizes pure read locality and IDC excels in write absorption, the Hybrid design delivers the most balanced and robust performance across mixed HPC workloads. By combining Alluxio’s selective promotion with Ceph’s SSD writeback tier, Hybrid caching achieves near-EFC read performance and superior write throughput while dramatically reducing HDD load. These insights provide a quantitative foundation for designing effective multi-tier caching strategies in modern distributed HPC storage systems.

title: MSFFNet: Multi-Stage Feature Fusion With Metadata Injection for Vehicle Re-Identification
authors: Haotian Shi, Yuhui Deng, Jiande Huang, Qifen Yang, Peng Zhou, Ke Wang, Weiping Ding
abstract: Vehicle re-identification is a crucial task in intelligent transportation systems and urban management, aiming to retrieve images of the same vehicle from different camera viewpoints. Prevailing solutions typically rely on computationally expensive modules or costly annotations, hindering their practical deployment. To overcome these limitations, we propose the novel Multi-Stage Feature Fusion Network (MSFFNet), a lightweight and robust feature alignment framework. First, we design the Multi-Stage Fusion Head (MSFH) that generates robust feature representations by fusing multi-stage features based on the inherent hierarchical feature pyramid of CNNs. The resulting fusion features capture both the abstract semantics of high-level features and the fine-grained local details of low-level features. To alleviate the ineffective fusion caused by the varying distance distributions between features at different stages, we introduce the Graph Convolution-based Fusion Block (GCFB) to study the relationships between these features. Second, to mitigate the influence of irrelevant information during fusion, we introduce the Metadata Auxiliary Module (MAM) that injects easily available metadata, such as camera IDs and viewpoints, into fused features. This allows the model to focus on discriminative vehicle information. Our model produces compact feature representations, occupies less storage, and achieves faster retrieval speeds, with a computing time of 1.74 milliseconds per image. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method achieves state-of-the-art performance on three widely used vehicle ReID benchmarks, establishing an optimal balance between speed and accuracy.

title: High-efficiency, Low-cost, Wide-band AFTSAs for W-band and D-band High-resolution Imaging
authors: Hongmin Ruan, Yuyang Zheng, Hui Feng, Shuai Wu
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: This letter presents a W-band antipodal Fermi tapered slot antenna (AFTSA) with 37.8% relative bandwidth and introduces a novel antipodal fin-line waveguide-to-microstrip transition for feeding. Featuring a lightweight design, each AFTSA weighs only 0.23 g. The transition achieves a return loss better than 15.7 dB and an insertion loss below 0.63 dB. Measurements of five AFTSAs fed by this transition show efficiencies exceeding 80% at most frequency points, with gains ranging from 15 to 20 dB across the W-band. At the target frequency of 100 GHz, the gain is approximately 18.7 dB, the efficiency reaches 88%, and the half-power beamwidths are 1–3° wider than the simulated values of 17.0°/22.8° (E/H). The measurements show favorable agreement with the simulations. Additionally, an array of eight AFTSAs is integrated on a single RO3003 substrate, and a D-band AFTSA design is also presented.

title: Optical Flow Processing for Efficient Video Data Transmission in Telecommunications
authors: Anastasia Puziy
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: The paper presents a method for optimizing inter-frame prediction based on optical flow analysis and the selective activation of affine motion models. The proposed approach is designed to enhance the efficiency of video data transmission in telecommunication networks by reducing bitrate and latency while maintaining visual quality. The author addresses the practical challenge of reducing bitrate load and latency variability during uplink live video transmission in 5G/6G networks. A method referred to as curl-gated Flow is proposed, in which local affine motion models (both SIM(2) and the general six-parameter affine model) are selectively activated only in those frame tiles where the magnitude of the optical flow curl indicates a non-zero rotational or deformational component of motion.

title: An Enhanced Multi-Source Domain Adaptation Framework for Grounding Fault Diagnosis in Urban Rail Transit Systems under Varying Operating Conditions
authors: Bo Chen, Qiaoyue Li, Guifu Du, Yanrong Ren
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: With the extension of rail service life and the impact of surrounding environmental conditions, the running rail in the DC traction power supply system of urban rail transit is prone to insulation degradation, which can lead to ground faults. These types of faults can result in elevated rail potentials and excessive stray currents, which may induce electrochemical corrosion and compromise passenger safety. Consequently, effective diagnosis of grounding faults in urban rail systems is of critical importance. In this paper, an Enhanced Multi-Source Domain Adaptation Framework (EMDAF) is proposed to diagnose grounding faults under varying operating conditions. The proposed EMDAF comprises three key modules: a ResNet-based feature extractor, a domain discrepancy minimization module and a classifier alignment strategy to improve diagnostic performance. It is ultimately employed to achieve accurate ground fault identification across various zones and operating conditions. Experimental comparisons indicate that EMDAF outperforms existing methods in both transfer learning performance and ground fault diagnosis accuracy, confirming its robustness and overall superiority.

title: Design of Optimal Spatial Layout System for Ecological Environment Based on GIS Technology
authors: Yuxia Li
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Geographic Information and Remote Sensing Technology (GIRST)
abstract: In the process of urbanization, the contradiction between population growth and ecological carrying capacity has intensified. Traditional spatial layout systems are limited by data sources, making it difficult to achieve coordinated optimization of ecological benefits and population distribution. This paper designs an optimal spatial layout system for the ecological environment based on GIS. On the hardware side, spatial positioning is realized through optical communication technology, and a microcontroller is used to complete signal conversion and transmission; on the software side, a spatial analysis layer is built based on GIS, and the GTWR model is combined to solve the global optimal solution. Experimental sample data from typical regions were selected, and the performance was verified by comparing with traditional systems. The results show that the total value of the ecological benefits of the system meets expectations, the standard deviation of population density distribution is 28%-35% lower than that of traditional systems, and the calculation accuracy and layout rationality are significantly improved. This provides technical support for the spatial optimization of the ecological environment.

title: Characterization of Photonic Crystal Fibers for Terahertz Signal Transmission in 6G Networks
authors: Gulmira Ibrohimova, Sevara Sadullaeva, Temur Eshchanov, Izzatbek Nafasov, Musobek Rakhimboev, Manik Rakhra
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: The sixth-generation (6G) of the wireless communication will stretch into the terahertz (THz) range with unparalleled data rates, sub-milliseconds latency, and enormous scale in the connectivity between devices. The design of the effective waveguides however remains a key issue as at THz propagation losses are high. Photonic crystal fibers (PCFs) and its special capacity to be able to engineer dispersion, birefringence, and confinement has been one of the promising ones in allowing terahertz-based 6G transmission. The given paper is a detailed characterization of a PCFs to THz communication taking into consideration factors such as the effective mode index, dispersion, confinement loss, and polarization factors. Simulations using Finite element method (FEM) have been conducted on hollowcore and solid-core PCFs over the frequency range of 0.1-1 THz. Findings indicate that the hollow-core PCFs with optimal designs attain confinement losses of less than 0.05 dB/m and almost zero dispersion over a large THz spectrum. These results indicate that alternative uses of PCFs as a viable transmission medium of 6G backhaul, short-range interconnects, and radio-over-fiber systems are possible. Other challenges that the study raises in the allocation of Ka-band spectrum, integration into the IoT ecosystems and coupling with reconfigurable intelligent surfaces are the exitsence and management interference.

title: Cultivation of Industry-Oriented Digital Transformation Service Providers Based on Structural Equation Modeling
authors: Jingyi Peng, Yuhong Wang, Wei Tao, Zhong Wang
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Software Engineering and Service Science (ICSESS)
abstract: Digital transformation is an effective path to facilitate the sustainable development of industrial enterprises. Fostering industry-oriented digital transformation service providers with both domain-specific expertise and digital capabilities is essential for advancing the depth and effectiveness of digital transformation in the manufacturing sector. This study is grounded in the Technology–Organization–Environment (TOE) framework and adopts a configurational perspective through the application of qualitative comparative analysis (QCA) to explore the multiple interacting factors and complex causal mechanisms underlying high-quality development among such service providers. Based on an empirical analysis of 80 cases in Zhejiang Province, the findings identify knowledge accumulation as a necessary condition for their development. Three distinct configurational pathways are revealed: a knowledge-and strategy-driven pathway, supported by aligned policies and emphasizing coordinated efforts; a knowledge-and environment-driven pathway, influenced by external conditions; and a technology-and organization-driven pathway, guided by policy structures. These pathways exhibit potential substitutive relationships. The study recommends strengthening the development ecosystem for service providers, enhancing demand-side traction from small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), and promoting collaborative synergies to establish actionable strategies for the cultivation of industry-oriented digital transformation service providers.

title: Edge-FIT: Federated Instruction Tuning of Quantized LLMs for Privacy-Preserving Smart Home Environments
authors: Vinay Venkatesh, Vamsidhar R Kamanuru, Lav Kumar, Nikita Kothari
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: This paper proposes Edge-FIT (Federated Instruction Tuning on the Edge), a scalable framework for Federated Instruction Tuning (FIT) of Large Language Models (LLMs). Traditional Federated Learning (TFL) methods, like FedAvg, fail when confronted with the massive parameter size of LLMs [3], [6]. Our Edge-FIT framework combines federated learning with 4-bit Quantized Low-Rank Adaptation (QLORA), mitigating the core issues of communication and computational overhead. We demonstrate this by filtering the general-purpose Databricks Dolly 15k dataset for the IoT domain. Experimental results show the Edge-FIT-tuned Llama 2 (7B) achieves an F1-Score of 0.89. We also demonstrate a viable trade-off using the 3.8B Phi-3-mini model, validating Edge-FIT as a scalable framework for decentralized LLM deployment on home compute gateways.

title: HVS-Patroller: A Frank–Wolfe Guided Multi-Robot Patrolling Learning Framework
authors: Ningwei Chu, Hongliang Guo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Robotics and Automatic Control (IRAC)
abstract: This paper studies the long-term multi-robot patrolling (MuRP) on discrete graphs, and the goal is to achieve uniform node coverage and maintain high unpredictability, and operate stably under weak communication and partial observability. Existing planning methods are computationally expensive, heuristic methods lack global guarantees, and learning methods are susceptible to the design of rewards and exploration. Therefore,we propose HVS-Patroller (HFW-VDN-SUBPO-LSTM) for distribution shaping: The outer layer directly optimizes the long-term access distribution using the Frank–Wolfe method and provides a global direction; the inner layer approximates the linear sub - problem on the decentralized MDP using VDN-LSTM; on the behavior side, SUBPO is used to achieve exploration with low variance and first-visit priority. The experiments show that HVS-Patroller significantly improves the distribution uniformity and coverage advancement speed under various topologies and scales, and unify the global sense of direction in planning and the scalable adaptability in learning within the same framework, effectively compensating for the deficiencies of the existing three types of methods in terms of scale, stability, and dynamic robustness.

title: A MOOC Dropout Prediction Algorithm Incorporating Behavioral Sequences and Weights
authors: Xuandi Zhang, Yu Sun
abstract: One of the major challenges in the field of online education is the high dropout rate. In order to improve the effect of dropout prediction, Considering that learners' behaviors have different levels of importance in influencing dropout. Behavior shows significant periodical characteristics, on this basis this paper proposes a deep learning dropout prediction algorithm. A behavioral sequence is created from the learner's behavioral data, and the behavioral sequence and additional information are firstly fed into a convolutional neural network to automatically extract the general features of the behaviors and additional information. Second, the self-attention mechanism is combined to assign different attention levels to the behaviors that have different impacts on dropout in different periods of the learner's behavioral sequence. Finally, the behavioral sequences incorporating key features of behaviors in different periods are further fed into a recurrent neural network(RNN) to capture sequence features and classify the output. On the XuetangX dataset, the proposed algorithm performs better compared to other methods.

title: ESP32-Based Water Monitoring System Using Wi-Fi, LoRa, and Cellular Telecommunication Networks
authors: Abdusamat Ubaydillayev, Yekaterina Lyan, Nazokat Saidkhanova Joldasovna, Zafarjon Abdurashidov Abdumajidovich, Rustam Muradov
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: Efficient water monitoring is a critical requirement for smart cities, agriculture, and industrial automation. Traditional wired monitoring systems lack scalability and realtime responsiveness, particularly in geographically distributed environments. This paper presents an ESP32-based intelligent water monitoring system that integrates Wi-Fi, LoRa, and cellular communication networks to enable reliable, long-range, and real-time data transmission. The proposed architecture supports multi-parameter sensing, including water level, flow rate, and quality indicators, while dynamically selecting the most suitable communication technology based on deployment constraints. Mathematical modeling of sensor measurements, energy consumption analysis, and communication latency evaluation are presented. Experimental results demonstrate that the hybrid communication approach significantly improves coverage, reliability, and energy efficiency compared to single-network solutions, making it suitable for next-generation smart water management systems.

title: How Gen AI Enhance Critical Thinking in Argumentative Writing: An Empirical Study
authors: Zhuoqi Guo
abstract: This study explores the impact of generative artificial intelligence (Gen AI) on high school students’ critical thinking with argumentative writing, using a sample of 100 students in Shaanxi Province to compare their performance before and after Gen AI-assisted writing across three dimensions: language expression, critical thinking, and stylistic characteristics. The research found that Gen AI effectively helps students improve language proficiency and compose articles that better comply with stylistic norms. However, its impact on enhancing critical thinking is less consistent, influenced by students’ baseline thinking abilities and technical proficiency in using AI tools. Looking ahead, there is a need to further develop methods for students to interact with Gen AI effectively while guarding against replacing personal writing with AI-generated content.

title: Secure Quantum Key Distribution over Hybrid Photonic–Telecom Platforms
authors: Bharat Bhushan, Md Irfanul Hasan, Zahraa Alkhafajy, Preeti Maan, Ravi Kant Prasad, Jasgurpreet Singh Chohan
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: Quantum Key Distribution (QKD) promises information-theoretic secure key exchange by exploiting the properties of quantum states. However, real-world deployments must bridge laboratory photonic devices and carrier-grade telecom infrastructure that carries high-power classical traffic over wavelength division multiplexed (WDM) fiber and sometimes free-space backhaul. This paper presents a practical architecture for hybrid photonic–telecom QKD that integrates integrated photonic transmitters/receivers, standard G.652 fiber with WDM coexistence, and metro aggregation toward core networks. We model loss, noise, and crosstalk introduced by in-band and out-of-band classical channels, characterize secret-key rate under decoy-state BB84 and measurement device-independent (MDI) variants, and include clock/synchronization constraints typical of carrier networks. A reference implementation with low-jitter timing, narrowband filtering, and probabilistic decoy intensities is analyzed. Simulation results indicate that, with 100GHz WDM spacing and filtering > 55dB, secure operation is feasible beyond 100km fiber or mixed 60km fiber + 1km free-space hops at QBER < 3%, with secret-key rates in the 1×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> −1×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">5</sup> bps range depending on detector efficiency and gate width. The proposed stack highlights a deployable path for secure keying across brownfield telecom networks without dedicated dark fiber.

title: Application Research on Automated Aerial Survey of UAVs Based on Pure Bearing Passive Positioning and Multi-Beam Detection
authors: Junjie Li, Cuilian Liu, Yixiang Cui
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Software Engineering and Service Science (ICSESS)
abstract: To enhance the accuracy and efficiency of UAV-based aerial surveying in complex terrain environments, this paper proposes an automated UAV survey scheme that integrates passive bearing-only positioning with multi-beam detection. The proposed scheme addresses limitations inherent in traditional single-beam methods, such as positioning inaccuracy, suboptimal survey planning, and incomplete data acquisition. To mitigate positioning inaccuracies, a passive bearing-only positioning model is constructed, and its core algorithm is derived. For issues related to survey planning and data collection, a multi-beam detection algorithm is established, which determines the optimal survey direction by analyzing multi-beam data. For curved terrain, an innovative K-means clustering segmentation algorithm based on point cloud normal vectors is proposed, enabling precise slope division and efficient survey path planning. Finally, a simulation test platform is developed to validate the models. In a detection mission spanning a total area of 69.216833 million square meters, the missed area constituted merely 2.5% of the total, demonstrating the scheme's exceptional performance in handling complex terrain aerial surveys.

title: Research on Settlement Mechanism for Special Scenarios in Electricity Spot Markets Cleared by Locational Marginal Price
authors: Ying Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: As a crucial component of the electricity market, the settlement mechanism of the electricity spot market directly affects the benefit distribution among market entities and the efficiency of market operation. Currently, the widely adopted settlement method based on Locational Marginal Price (LMP) may, under specific conditions, result in a discrepancy between the settlement price and the pricing intentions of market entities, undermining the effectiveness of price signals and the interests of market entities. This paper first systematically analyzes the causes of settlement limitations. Subsequently, combined with economic theories, it explores the welfare losses and market distortions arising when the settlement price on the user side is higher than the quoted price and when that on the generation side is lower than the quoted price. Furthermore, this paper constructs typical calculation examples to verify the adverse impacts of special settlement scenarios on market entities and overall social welfare, and proposes improvement suggestions, including cost compensation for the generation side, factors influencing clearing price limits, and unified zonal settlement for the user side.

title: An Early Warning Method Combining Autoencoder and Local Attention Mechanism for K-12 Education
authors: Mingyan Zhang, Zhaozhuan Zeng, Yumeng Liu, Jingjing Bai, Jui-Long Hung, Chao Duan
abstract: As online learning has gained wide attention in K - 12 education, it is more important to identify students with academic risks as early and accurately as possible through early warning models to help teachers carry out personalized interventions and achieve joint efforts between schools and families to improve students' learning performance. Students' online learning behaviors are continuous and time-dependent. The early warning effect can be improved through the analysis of learning behavior patterns. This paper designs an early warning model AE-Local-AT that combines autoencoders and local attention mechanisms. The model eliminates noise in the data and extracts behavioral pattern features through autoencoders, and then captures the behavioral dependencies between adjacent time steps through the sliding window strategy of the local attention mechanism to focus on key features. The test results on K -12 dataset 1 show that AE-Local-AT achieves higher recall, F1-Score, and AUC than the baseline model and other attention mechanisms, and identifies 3/4 of at-risk students 2 units earlier than other models. While having higher prediction indicators, it can reserve more time for teachers and parents to intervene in teaching. This paper further verifies the above results on K -12 dataset 2.

title: Smart Grid NOMA Resource Allocation Optimization Using Quantum Approximate Techniques
authors: Shijun Luo, Daquan Qiu, Lu Tang, Hua Wang, Qiwei Xiang, Liqiang Zhao
abstract: For the first time, we transplant the Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA) from quantum computing labs to the radio links that connect smart meters inside power grids, reframing Non-Orthogonal Multiple Access (NOMA) resource allocation as a combinatorial task within a multi-carrier downlink. The search for optimal pairs is then delegated to QAOA, whose superposition and entanglement resources explore the solution space far more compactly than any classical heuristic. An Improved-QAOA (I-QAOA) algorithm is also proposed, which dynamically adjusts user grouping based on channel state information, significantly enhancing spectral efficiency. Simulation results demonstrate that I-QAOA achieves higher spectral efficiency compared to traditional channel-based and random pairing methods, even at low transmission power, and maintains superior performance at high power levels, offering a promising approach for optimizing smart grid communication networks.

title: Comparative Analysis of Predictive Accuracy: Revenue Estimation Based on Electricity Consumption Forecasts versus Historical Billing Data
authors: Weipeng Qi, Heng Yue, Siyang Xu, Xin Jin, Leilei Zhao
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: Based on comprehensive examination and assessment of past regional power consumption records, we have identified underlying patterns and distinctive features within the data. Drawing from these findings, we developed a novel approach for projecting monthly electricity usage. The methodology works by first estimating aggregate quarterly power consumption for the period containing the target month, then determining the specific monthly figure by applying the historical monthly-to-quarterly ratio to this quarterly projection. Additionally, our approach accounts for Spring Festival impacts through appropriate modifications when necessary. We applied this technique to project monthly power consumption in one Jiangsu city spanning April 2020 through December 2022. The outcomes demonstrated an average deviation of merely 2.35%, representing substantial improvement over conventional approaches. These results confirm the superior precision and dependability of our methodology. This fresh approach offers a practical and effective alternative for monthly electricity consumption projection, contributing valuable insights for both academic investigation and professional application in relevant sectors.

title: The Impact of the Innovation of AI Education System Based on the TAM and SOR Theory on Students' Flow Experience
authors: Zichen Wang, Yanglu Wan, Yuqi Wei
abstract: This research, grounded on the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM) and stimuli-organism-response (SOR) theory, examines the impact of the innovativeness of artificial intelligence education systems on students' flow experiences, emphasizing the mediating effect of perceived utility in this context. The findings demonstrate that the innovativeness of artificial intelligence teaching systems substantially increases students' perceived utility, hence fostering their flow experiences. This study use quantitative analysis to develop a mediation model that verifies the role of perceived usefulness in the link between system innovativeness and flow experiences. The findings indicate that perceived usefulness directly affects flow experience and serves as a significant mediator between system innovation and flow experience. This discovery broadens the applicability of TAM theory and offers fresh perspectives for educational practice, indicating that educators should focus on the innovative attributes of AI-driven educational systems and ways to augment students' perceived usefulness in their design, thereby effectively fostering the development of flow experiences during learning and enhancing educational outcomes. This work possesses considerable theoretical importance and practical utility for the enhancement and reform of artificial intelligence education systems.

title: Stray Current Distribution in Shaanxi Power Grid over a Large Area
authors: Wei Shen, Bo Tan, Lin Geng, Bichuan Xu, Xin Liu, Zhuohong Pan
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: Low-frequency stray currents in new energy systems will invade large AC systems, resulting in adverse effects of ground corrosion and DC bias of transformers. In this paper, the entrance equivalence of substation grounding grid is carried out from the perspective of theoretical modeling, which simplifies the stray current distribution model of large power grid, and puts forward the corresponding calculation method. Aiming at the problem of stray currents in 110kV and above voltage level power grids of Shaanxi Power Grid, this paper analyzes the propagation law, invasion path and impact on power grid equipment by establishing a model of stray current distribution, and combining with the actual distribution of 411 new energy sites in Shaanxi. The study shows that the incident stray current of new energy sites in Shaanxi power grid is small (<10A), and the average value of the stray current induced in the neutral point of the main transformer is 0.1454A, which has a small impact on the DC bias of the transformer and the corrosion of the grounding network; through the simplification of the model and the decoupling theory, the threshold value of the safe distance between new energy sites and transformer substations is verified (the stray current is <6A when it is >0.2km). The study provides theoretical and practical basis for the prevention and control of stray current in Shaanxi power grid.

title: Educational Theory-Enhanced DKVMN: Improving Interpretability and Predictive Performance in Knowledge Tracing
authors: Shasha Xiong
abstract: To enhance the interpretability and predictive performance of knowledge tracing models, this paper proposes an educational theory-enhanced DKVMN. Building upon the standard DKVMN framework, the proposed model incorporates many core educational theories. Specifically, the model integrates slip and guess parameters estimated by the DINA model, combined with personalized parameters learned via neural networks, to improve the "read process" of learners’ knowledge states. In the "write process", the ZPD theory is utilized to jointly consider learners’ current and potential knowledge state when computing knowledge growth vectors. Furthermore, inspired by the Ebbinghaus forgetting curve, the LSTM models are introduced to capture individual forgetting rates across different knowledge, enabling more accurate updates of learners’ knowledge states. Experiments on both synthetic and CL datasets demonstrate that the proposed model significantly outperforms the baseline DKVMN in terms of prediction accuracy and interpretability. The results validate the effectiveness of integrating educational theories into deep knowledge tracing, offering fine-grained insights into learners’ cognitive processes and knowledge evolution.

title: Designing High-Throughput Event-Driven Architectures for E-Commerce Fulfillment at Global Scale
authors: Karan Kumar Ratra, Dhruv Kumar Seth, Deepika Verma, Hemant Burman
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: Traditional monolithic systems struggle to scale effectively in the current global e-commerce landscape, characterized by high transaction volumes and unpredictable traffic spikes, and require real-time responsiveness. This paper conducts a systematic review of High-Throughput Event-Driven Architectures (EDAs) as the base design approach for developing flexible and responsive fulfillment systems with low latency. The research investigates core principles, including asynchronous communication, service decoupling, and event-carried state transfer, alongside advanced design patterns such as Event Sourcing, Saga orchestration, and Command Query Responsibility Segregation (CQRS). Real-world case studies from Walmart, eBay, and Shopify demonstrate how EDA can enable sub-second order processing, dynamic inventory synchronization, and rapid elasticity. The review in this paper also evaluates cloud-native event brokers, serverless frameworks, and event meshes for their ability to support global and distributed deployments at scale. Additionally, the paper includes a section specific to implementation challenges faced while implementing EDAs in real-world scenarios and the resolution of those challenges through architectural best practices, which include idempotent consumers, versioned event contracts, and Dead Letter Queues for distributed debugging, schema evolution, and event ordering. The review establishes EDA as a strategic business enabler that delivers speed, fault tolerance, and competitive agility for e-commerce fulfillment operations. Towards the end, the paper identifies three future research areas, including adaptive event routing and observability in federated systems, as well as the integration of AI-driven decision-making within event streams.

title: Educational Innovation Driven by Physiological Signal Monitoring: Research Contexts and Future Trends
authors: Mingyan Zhang, Yumeng Liu, Jin Yang, Zhaozhuan Zeng, Jingjing Bai, Chao Duan
abstract: Physiological signal monitoring in education aims to collect real-time data on learners' states during the learning process. Due to its significant potential for educational innovation, physiological signal monitoring in education is regarded as a promising research direction. It enables the analysis of learning outcomes across the entire educational journey, from single-modal data to multimodal data fusion. However, challenges persist in areas such as cognitive and affective classification of collected physiological data, data feature selection, and multimodal data fusion. Consequently, extensive research efforts have been dedicated to exploring physiological signal-driven educational innovations. This paper provides an independent and unified framework for physiological signal-driven education. In particular, we focus on prominent studies that conduct in-depth analyses of each category of single-modal physiological signals. Additionally, we examine innovative approaches integrating multimodal physiological signals and the fusion of physiological signals with behavioral data. Building on a comprehensive review of physiological signal monitoring research in education, we further propose emerging trends and future directions for such studies in educational settings.

title: Multi-Robot Map Fusion Using an N-Mutation Particle Swarm Optimization Algorithm
authors: Lingjie Gan, Yongchuan Tang, Zexi Hua
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Robotics and Automatic Control (IRAC)
abstract: Aiming at the map fusion problem in multi-robot collaborative Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) systems, this paper proposes a map fusion method based on an N-Mutation Particle Swarm Optimization (N-Mutation PSO) algorithm. By analyzing the dissimilarity of grid maps and the alignment features in overlapping regions, a fusion fitness function is designed. Leveraging the global search capability of the PSO algorithm, the optimal coordinate transformation matrix is solved. To address the shortcoming of traditional PSO algorithms stagnating at local minima, a particle age structure and a mutation mechanism are introduced: when a particle’s personal best position remains unchanged for a sustained period, a random position-velocity mutation is triggered to escape local optima, and the balance between exploration and exploitation capabilities is maintained by dynamically adjusting the number of mutation operations. Optimization experiments using CEC2017 datasets (IEEE Congress on Evolutionary Computation 2017) functions demonstrate that the proposed algorithm achieves improvements in both convergence accuracy and convergence speed compared to the standard PSO algorithm. Results from map fusion experiments validate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm for the multi-robot map fusion problem.

title: Research on the Optimal Distribution Demand Response Strategy Based on Limited Resources
authors: Tao Liao, Kan Zhang, Pengcheng Wan, Yan Zhao, Xiaoxiao Zhang, Zixuan Yu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: Facing multiple constraints such as warehousing capacity, verification resources and transportation vehicles in the process of metrological asset distribution, the traditional dispatching strategy relying on manual experience is difficult to achieve efficient and accurate demand response under the condition of limited resources. This paper proposes an intelligent distribution demand response optimization strategy based on a dual-model self-checking mechanism. This strategy integrates four links: "demand forecasting - resource matching - path planning -dynamic feedback", and uses the self-checking mechanism of the intelligent prediction model (LSTM+XGBoost) and the rule prediction model to improve the prediction accuracy. On this basis, a multi-objective resource optimization model and an improved genetic algorithm path planning model are constructed. Verified by the measured data, the method proposed in this paper has achieved significant improvements in prediction accuracy, distribution cost and resource utilization rate compared with the traditional scheme.

title: Harmonic-Constrained Optimal Modulation for Converters Connected to a Distorted Grid
authors: Shirin Rahmanpour, Petros Karamanakos, Tobias Geyer, Arttu Ruusila, George Papafotiou
abstract: Compliance with harmonic grid standards becomes particularly challenging under non-ideal operating conditions, e.g., when other converters—bedsides the one of interest—inject harmonic distortions, referred to as disturbances, at the point of common coupling (PCC). This paper proposes optimized pulse patterns (OPPs) for grid-connected converters with an <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$LCL$</tex-math></inline-formula> filter that ensure PCC current and voltage harmonics meet the relevant harmonic grid standards, even in the presence of such disturbances. This is achieved by formulating the OPP problem as a robust optimization problem that explicitly accounts for external harmonic distortions and incorporates explicit current and voltage harmonic constraints. The proposed framework can be applied under different levels of disturbance information: (i) full knowledge of harmonic amplitudes and phases, (ii) uncertain but bounded characteristics, and (iii) complete lack of knowledge during the OPP computation. Numerical results and experimental tests demonstrate that the proposed OPPs achieve significantly better compliance with harmonic grid standards compared with advanced modulation strategies such as selective harmonic elimination (SHE) and conventional OPPs.

title: DOJS: A Distributed Online Joint Scheme to Optimize Cost in Mobile Edge Networks
authors: Ziyi Teng, Juan Fang, Neal N. Xiong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management
abstract: Edge computing deploys computing and storage resources at the network edge, thereby providing services closer to terminal users. However, in edge networks, the mobility of terminals, the diversity of requests, and the dynamic nature of wireless channels pose significant challenges for efficiently allocating limited wireless and caching resources among multiple terminal devices. To address the issues of unbalanced network load and high caching costs caused by resource allocation in edge networks, we propose a Distributed Online Joint Optimization Scheme (DOJS). Specifically, we design a joint optimization scheme, referred to as DOJS, which combines centralized user association at the cloud with distributed cache placement at the base stations. This scheme analyzes the impact of terminal device association policies on caching costs and develops a caching cost model that integrates the activity level and content request probability of terminal devices. Based on this model, the relationship between user association selection and caching costs is analyzed, and a Game Theory-based User Association (GTUA) selection algorithm is proposed. In order to adapt to the dynamic characteristics of terminal-user requests in mobile edge networks, we develop a dynamic cache update method LS-TD3, which combines Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and Twin Delayed Deep Deterministic policy gradient (TD3). Specifically, we integrate the LSTM layer into the policy model framework of reinforcement learning to better predict the content popularity from dynamic time data, thus improving the accuracy of cache decision making. To further reduce computational complexity and enhance overall system performance, we employ a distributed optimization strategy to improve the dynamic caching decision process. Extensive experimental results demonstrate the superiority of the proposed algorithm in achieving inter-node load balancing and minimizing caching costs.

title: CAPLAI: AI-assisted Lifecycle Provisioning for GPU data centers
authors: Chengyi Nie, Anna Xing, Imran Latif, Zhenhua Liu
publish: 2025 33rd International Symposium on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Computer and Telecommunication Systems (MASCOTS)
abstract: The accelerating deployment of artificial intelligence (AI) workloads, driven by recent advancements in AI technology, has significantly increased the demand for computing resources and supporting infrastructure. However, the physical and electrical capacity of data centers cannot scale at the same pace, which introduces a new challenge: accommodating rising compute demand under stringent power and space constraints. New high performance GPUs offer better power efficiency compared to previous generations, and liquid cooling systems are significantly more efficient than traditional air cooling. These advancements create an opportunity to upgrade data centers that accommodate more AI workloads with limitations in physical infrastructure and power availability.We propose CAPLAI, Capacity-Aware PLanning for AI infrastructure, an AI-assisted stochastic optimization framework for lifecycle planning in GPU data centers. Our method adopts large language models (llMs) to generate diverse and plausible future scenarios that capture demand growth, hardware efficiency decay, electricity prices, and resale market trends. These scenarios feed into a stochastic optimization model that determines GPU purchase, retirement, and cooling infrastructure upgrades. We evaluate our framework using real-world traces and constraints derived from a large-scale AI data center at Brookhaven National Lab. Compared to conventional threshold-based heuristics, our approach increases the effective GPU computing capacity within the same power limit by up to 36 % and reduces lifecycle operating cost by up to 32 %. Results demonstrate that capacityaware, AI-guided planning significantly enhances efficiency and robustness with the escalating demand and infrastructural limits.
