title: Information, Technological, Computer and ChatGPT Usage among Senior High School Students
authors: Ben Oliver D. Tutor, Alathea S. Jimenez, Myra A. Flordeliza, Arnel T. Ausillo, Cristina T. Malimban
abstract: This study explores the digital literacy levels of Senior High School (SHS) students in the Philippines and their use of ChatGPT to support learning. It focuses on three components of digital literacy: information, technological, and computer literacy. The study aims to examine the relationship between digital literacy and ChatGPT use in educational contexts. Using a quantitative descriptive-comparative design, data were collected from 367 SHS students across grade level, academic tracks, and socio-economic class. Findings showed no significant differences in digital literacy based on these variables. Moreover, a very weak, statistically non-significant positive relationship was found between digital literacy components and ChatGPT use. These findings suggest that while digital literacy contributes to students’ ability to engage with digital tools, external factors such as teacher guidance, classroom integration, and task relevance are more influential in driving ChatGPT use. The study highlights the need to strengthen both digital literacy and instructional support to optimize AI tool integration in education.

title: Designing Accessible Cybersecurity Curriculum for K-12 Educators: A Content Analysis of the PERFECT Project’s Framework
authors: Tayiba Raheem, Gahangir Hossain, Mikyung Shin
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: The shortage of qualified cybersecurity professionals has prompted initiatives to strengthen K-12 cybersecurity education, yet many high schools STEM teachers lack the training to effectively teach cybersecurity concepts. This paper analyzes the curriculum design of the PERFECT (Providing Environment and Resources for STEM 9th–12th Graders in Effective Cybersecurity Training) project, a Department of Defense-funded professional development program that trains high school STEM teachers in cybersecurity through a 16-module online framework. Using content analysis method, this study examines the project’s scaffolded learning approach, cross-curricular integration strategies, and innovative inclusion of emerging technologies. The analysis identifies design principles including progressive complexity management, ethics-first orientation, and emerging technology integration that distinguish this approach from traditional university coursework. While this study is limited to curriculum design documentation and does not evaluate implementation effectiveness or learning outcomes, it provides a foundational framework for understanding how cybersecurity professional development can be specifically tailored for K-12 educators. The findings contribute theoretical and practical insights for curriculum developers designing similar teacher training initiatives and establish a basis for future empirical studies examining implementation effectiveness and impact on student learning outcomes.

title: CryptoSRAM: Enabling High-Throughput Cryptography on MCUs via In-SRAM Computing
authors: Jingyao Zhang, Elaheh Sadredini
abstract: Secure communication is a critical requirement for Internet of Things (IoT) devices, which are often based on Micro-controller Units (MCUs). Current cryptographic solutions, which rely on software libraries or dedicated hardware accelerators, are fundamentally limited by the performance and energy costs of data movement between memory and processing units. This paper introduces CryptoSRAM, an in-SRAM computing architecture that performs cryptographic operations directly within the MCU’s standard SRAM array. By repurposing the memory array into a massively parallel processing fabric, CryptoSRAM eliminates the data movement bottleneck. This approach is well-suited to MCUs, which utilize physical addressing and Direct Memory Access (DMA) to manage SRAM, allowing for seamless integration with minimal hardware overhead. Our analysis shows that for common cryptographic kernels, CryptoSRAM achieves throughput improvements of up to 74 × and 67 × for AES and SHA3, respectively, compared to a software implementation. Furthermore, our solution delivers up to 6 × higher throughput than existing hardware accelerators for AES. CryptoSRAM demonstrates a viable and efficient architecture for secure communication in next-generation loT systems.

title: A Switching Localization and Coverage Path Planning Method Based on BDS and Visual-Inertial Odometry for Farmland Information Collection
authors: Fangyi Zhu, Yang Liu, Fan Li, Qingli Zeng
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Robotics and Automatic Control (IRAC)
abstract: To address the problem of weakened satellite positioning signals encountered by intelligent vehicles during information acquisition in high-stem crop fields—particularly in areas beneath dense crop canopies—this study proposes a seamless localization scheme based on BDS–T265–IMU integrated positioning. When the signal is strong, BDS/IMU integrated positioning is adopted, while T265 visual-inertial odometry is used under weak signal conditions. The switching mechanism takes the Position Dilution of Precision (PDOP) and illumination intensity as the main decision factors, combined with a counting threshold judgment method to realize localization mode switching. This approach ultimately ensures seamless localization of the inspection vehicle in structured farmland environments where signal strength alternates between strong and weak regions. Building upon this, the combination of global coverage path planning and local A*-based obstacle avoidance enables highly efficient and exhaustive field traversal within regular farmland blocks, while also providing the capability to handle dynamic obstacles.

title: Neural Network-Based Detection of Open and Closed-Circuit Faults in Single-Phase Voltage Source Inverters
authors: George Owusu, Joshua Afosa-Baffoe
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: The single-phase Voltage Source Inverter (VSI) is one of the most commonly used converters for transforming a DC source into an AC source to supply power to a connected load. However, during operation, the system may experience an open-circuit (OC) or short-circuit (SC) fault, resulting in an interruption of power supply to the load. To reduce the frequency of such interruptions, this study proposes an Artificial Neural Network (ANN)-based technique to support the restoration of continuous operation in the event of a fault. The proposed controller manages two conventionally designed VSI circuits connected in parallel, enabling the system to switch power supply to the alternate circuit in the event of an OC or SC fault in the primary circuit. The design incorporates two additional switches between the inverter output lines to prevent backflow of current within the system. A simulation analysis was performed using MATLAB/Simulink to evaluate the performance of the proposed system. Simulation results demonstrate the system's capability to restore continuous power supply from the DC source to the load during an OC or SC fault in either circuit. The proposed approach can be extended to other categories of VSI to improve the efficiency and reliability of power delivery from source to load.

title: Raspberry Pi–Driven Digital Twin of Optical Sensor Networks for Predictive Maintenance in Smart Campuses
authors: Durdona Nabiyeva, Nigora Hayitova, Baljinder Kaur, Asalkhon Jamaldinova
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: In this paper, I have introduced the Raspberry Pi-based digital twin architecture of optical sensor networks in smart-campus settings to support predictive maintenance. It uses low-cost optical sensors (LED/photodiode arrays) in conjunction with Raspberry Pi edge nodes and transmits preprocessed telemetry to a digital twin to predict the state of the components and provide maintenance warnings. We detail the system design, state estimation mathematical models, an implementation in commodity hardware and lightweight protocols, and experimental outcomes through proper representation of the initial warning indications of a degradation and an anomaly.

title: Photovoltaic Error Analysis and Intelligent Operation Optimization of Power Stations in Complex Environments
authors: Jingde Yin, Dongxu Wang, Xiangqun Zhou, Ying Ma, Zhiheng Lei, Lichen Yan
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: Photovoltaic (PV) output prediction error is inevitable and cannot be ignored, and the accurate description of forecasting error is conducive to the optimal operation of power plants and intelligent decision-making. To address this, the correlation between PV forecasting errors and their influencing factors under complex environmental conditions is analyzed, and a forecasting error modeling approach on the basis of numerical characteristic clustering is proposed. Classify the overall forecasting errors using a density matrix–based adaptive K-means clustering algorithm, then partition them according to the amplitude and variation characteristics of the predicted output. For each partition, the PV forecasting error is modeled by a confidence interval–based fuzzy set construction method (CIAS). By integrating the confidence interval fuzzy set considering error characteristics with the information gap theory (IGDT), named data-driven IGDT (DIGDT), a hybrid decision model for power plants is constructed to achieve intelligent operation optimization under varying meteorological conditions and different prediction levels. Based on the historical prediction of PV and meteorological data from Elia and NASA, the results demonstrate that the proposed error model effectively captures the distributional skewness of PV outputs in complex environments, and the intelligent operation model achieves superior economic performance.

title: A Photonic Communication Model for Enhancing Safety Messages in VANET Environments
authors: Bakhtiyor Makhkamov
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: The credible sharing and communication of safety information is the key element in minimizing collisions and enhancing situational awareness in Vehicular Ad-Hoc Networks (VANETs). Traditional RF-based solutions of IEEE 802.11p and C-V2X may face congestion, interference, and changing latency in high traffic conditions that may compromise the delivery of event notifications in a timely manner in critical situations. In this paper, a photonic communication model to achieve the augmentation of VANET safety messages through an intensitymodulation/direct-detection (IM/DD) optical medium and embedded into conventional vehicular communication stacks is presented. The suggested architecture includes a scaled photonic transmitter-receiver device, a mobility conscious framework of optical paths and a hybrid RF-photonic framework of receiving messages. A hybrid simulation system of optical modeling with MATLAB, mobility generation with SUMO and network evaluation with NS-3 are created to test the performance in conditions of real urban traffic. The findings indicate that photonic connection greatly minimizes the end-to-end latency and increases the packet delivery ratio compared to RF baselines, especially in dense environments. Seamless hybrid operation is also supported in the model and guarantees reliable transmission of messages even when the line-of-sight is constrained dynamically. These results suggest that the photonic communication can become an efficient supplementary technology in augmenting safety critical communication to intelligent transportation systems in the future.

title: Unintentional Islanding Detection Method based on Voltage and Reactive Power Adjustment in Grid-Forming Inverter Systems
authors: Yejin Choi, Inchan Hong, Jaehoon Jung, Seungmin Jung, Yeuntae Yoo
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: As the proportion of inverter-based resources (IBRs) in the power systems increases, the problem of the grid inertia is becoming increasingly significant. To address this challenge, there is ongoing research into grid-forming (GFM). The prevalent inverter control method, known as the grid-following (GFL), is susceptible to faults and does not have the ability to maintain voltage and frequency. However, grid-forming inverters (GFMIs) overcome these shortcomings. Nevertheless, due to its ability to autonomously generate voltage and frequency, there is difficult to detect unintentional islanding, and there is a potential risk of encountering a Non-Detection Zone (NDZ) may occur. This paper analyzes the response characteristics of GFMIs when the reference values of voltage and reactive power injected into the GFMI are changed using PSCAD/EMTDC. Furthermore, it proposes a innovative unintentional islanding detection method (IDM) applicable to GFMIs, which is based on the rate of change voltage and reactive power before and after the reference adjustment.

title: Research on Glacier Extraction Methods for the Western Section of the Nyenchen Tanglha Mountains Based on Remote Sensing and Cloud Computing
authors: Wanjing Chen, Bo Pang, Xiaoyan Han, Wenbing Cui, Bo Fang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Geographic Information and Remote Sensing Technology (GIRST)
abstract: Against the backdrop of global warming, glaciers on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau are undergoing rapid changes. Accurate monitoring of their dynamics is crucial for understanding regional water cycles, assessing ecological risks, and studying climate change impacts. This study employs an automated glacier extraction method integrating remote sensing cloud computing with an improved deep learning model to extract glaciers in the western section of the Nyenchen Tanglha Mountains over the past two decades. This method achieves high-precision, automated glacier extraction in the study area. Results indicate that the method achieved a 94.6% extraction rate, effectively delineating complex glacier boundaries and fragmented areas. It successfully distinguished glaciers from easily confused features such as mountain shadows, snow cover, and surface moraines, demonstrating strong generalization capabilities in complex environments. This approach ultimately yielded detailed glacier distribution maps for the region spanning 2003–2023. The approach based on the AI Earth platform and the optimized DeepLab V3+ model enables efficient and precise extraction of glacier information across long time series and large spatial scales. It effectively overcomes the limitations of traditional methods, providing reliable technical support and practical examples for monitoring glacier changes and studying their mechanisms on the Tibetan Plateau and globally.

title: Finite Element Analysis of Guided Wave Dispersion in Aluminum Sheaths with Coating Effects
authors: Jingyi Xiao, Xinhua Guo
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: The structural integrity of the aluminum sheath of high-voltage cables is crucial for the safety of the power system, so the detection of its defects is particularly important. However, the selection of ultrasonic guided wave modes and frequencies directly affects the detection results. Based on finite element simulation and introducing Floquet-Bloch boundary conditions, the dispersion curve of the aluminum sheath guided wave is calculated, and compared with the SAFE method. The maximum error is only 0.16%, verifying the reliability of the method. On this basis, the influence of asphalt layer and polyvinyl chloride outer sheath material parameters on the phase velocity and cutoff frequency is analyzed. The results show that the covering layer has a significant effect on the dispersion characteristics, especially in the high-frequency region. The research results suggest that the low-frequency axial mode should be prioritized to reduce the interference caused by the instability of the outer covering layer. This paper provides a theoretical basis for the selection of excitation parameters in guided wave detection of high-voltage cables and is of great significance for improving the defect identification accuracy in engineering applications.

title: Multi-Granular Encoder-Decoder Architecture for Explainable Fact-Checking via Multi-Task Learning
authors: Mohit Nathani, Rajiv Misra, Supratik Mukhopadhyay
abstract: While significant advances have been made in fact-checking systems, many AI models still struggle to understand the multi-granular relationships between claims and evidence. The inability of such models to assess the internal consistency of evidence or gaps or contradictions in evidence often leads to them arriving at wrong or misleading conclusions that are provided to the user without any warning. To counter such challenges, this paper proposes a novel framework that is able to acquire representations of multi-granular relationships between claims and evidence. This representation allows more nuanced, context-aware logical reasoning. Our framework can also summarize evidence, providing transparent, interpretable chains for verifying claims. Architecturally, our framework uses a multi-encoder and a decoder. It is able to extract appropriate features from the evidence making sure that each feature is considered individually and in relation to the broader context. Additionally, we leverage Multi-Task Learning (MTL) for improved efficiency and performance by simultaneously training the model on both claim classification and evidence summarization tasks. This approach helps achieve better accuracy and trustworthiness of fact-checking systems, especially in complex scenarios with ambiguous or conflicting evidence.

title: Performance Optimization of WiFi–LiFi Heterogeneous Networks for Autonomous Vehicle Platooning
authors: Bakhtiyor Makhkamov, Ibrohimbek Yusupov, Djamshid Sultanov, Mandeep Singh, Jaspreet Kaur, Gagandeep Kaur
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: CAV platooning requires low-latency and reliable communication in order to coordinate vehicle motion, quick control responses, and consistent inter-vehicle distance. WiFi offers strong non-style of sight coverage but suffers in congestion and fluctuating lag in a busy traffic whereas LiFi offers full bandwidth, interference free links under both line-of-sight and dense traffic situations but is vulnerable to mobility and obstruction. The present paper includes a performance optimization framework of heterogeneous WiFiLiFi networks, specifically in autonomous platoons. A resource distribution and handover approach of mobility-awareness makes use of dynamic process of selecting the most appropriate communication interface according to forecasted link quality, vehicle geometry and latency needs. The model separates the mission-critical control traffic and highbandwidth sensor traffic. Comparison of the simulation results of WiFi-only, LiFi-only and hybrid deployments reveal that the proposed heterogeneous deployment method is significantly minimizing the control latency and enhancing the throughput. These results indicate that integrated WiFiLiFi systems are effective at satisfying very high communication requirements of autonomous vehicle platooning of the next generation.

title: A Hybrid Deep Learning Network with Attention Mechanism for Robust Human Activity Recognition Using Motion Sensors
authors: Sakorn Mekruksavanich, Anuchit Jitpattanakul
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Software Engineering and Service Science (ICSESS)
abstract: Human activity recognition (HAR) plays a crucial role in applications such as healthcare monitoring, fitness assessment, and innovative environments. This study proposes a hybrid deep learning model, CNN-CBAM-LSTM, that integrates a CNN for spatial feature extraction, CBAM for attention-based feature enhancement, and LSTM networks for modeling temporal dependencies. Evaluated on the MotionSense dataset, which contains smartphone-based motion sensor data, the proposed architecture achieves superior performance with 99.989% accuracy, 0.0008 loss, and 99.986% F1-score, surpassing conventional deep learning models such as CNN, LSTM, BiLSTM, GRU, and BiGRU. The low variance across 5-fold cross-validation confirms its robustness and generalization ability. By integrating spatial, attention-driven, and temporal modeling mechanisms, this framework provides a reliable and efficient solution for real-world HAR applications in healthcare, fitness, and intelligent context-aware systems.

title: Does Learning Emotion Tune Expression? Investigating Linguistic Adaptation in ChatGPT-4 for Math Tutoring
authors: Wanqiang Wang, Wei Zheng
abstract: Emotion-aware interaction is critical for sustaining motivation and engagement in intelligent tutoring systems (ITS). However, with the integration of large language models (LLMs) like ChatGPT-4, it remains unclear whether these models can recognize learner emotions and generate adaptive responses that promote meaningful interaction. To address this gap, we collected 895 rounds of math-related dialogue between learners and ChatGPT-4, annotated with seven emotions. Further, we evaluated ChatGPT-4’s emotion recognition accuracy and analyzed the linguistic diversity of its responses across emotional contexts. Experimental results show that it achieved 78.7% accuracy in classifying learning emotions. Meanwhile responses to positive emotions displayed higher lexical, syntactic, and semantic diversity, while negative-emotion responses were simpler and more homogeneous. Importantly, variability in syntactic and semantic structures correlated positively with engagement metrics like interaction frequency and message complexity. These findings suggest that emotion-sensitive language adaptation by ChatGPT-4 can foster learner engagement and inform the design of emotionally intelligent educational agents.

title: VQ-Gait: Codebook-based reconstruction for Occluded Gait Recognition
authors: Kun Liu, Ning Ma, Jicheng Huang, Jiajun Wu, Wenxiong Kang, Weijie Sun, M. Saad Shakeel
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Robotics and Automatic Control (IRAC)
abstract: Gait recognition (GR) is a technique that identifies individuals based on their walking patterns. However, most existing research predominantly focus on non-occluded gait data, whereas real-world scenarios often involve occlusions caused by various factors, such as carried objects or pedestrian interactions. Due to the lack of occluded gait datasets, research on occluded gait recognition (OGR) remains limited. To address this issue, we propose an Occluded Gait Synthesis (OGS) framework that generates occluded gait sequences by introducing multiple types of synthetic occlusions into clean, publicly available gait datasets, thereby simulating real-world conditions. Building on OGS, we further introduce a novel codebook-based framework for gait reconstruction and recognition. VQ-Gait learns a discrete code-book of gait patterns and employs an attention-based decoder to recover missing information, enabling realistic and temporally consistent reconstruction of occluded sequences. The completed gait sequences are then fed into a downstream recognition model, yielding robust identification. Experimental results demonstrate that our method effectively restores occluded silhouettes and significantly enhances recognition performance across various occlusion scenarios.

authors: Tianyi Yu, Ling-An Cheong, Zhonghao Chen, Teng Yi, Yongpan Liu, Huazhong Yang, Xueqing Li
abstract: This paper presents a fully digital compute-in-ROM/SRAM macro for edge AI acceleration, fabricated in a 28nm CMOS technology. The proposed architecture integrates 18Mb of compressed ROM with 8Kb of trainable SRAM, achieving a record-high memory density of 26.9 Mb/mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. This work introduces a novel sparsity-aware ROM mapping mechanism, reducing area by 91% and 88% for sparse and dense weights compared to SRAM implementation. The proposed ROM macro employs a value-aware balanced adder tree that enhances computing throughput by 28% via critical path optimization. Furthermore, this chip utilizes a scalable ROM/SRAM hybrid architecture that maintains <0.5% accuracy loss in transfer learning scenarios, while supporting model expansion through time-division multiplexing (TDM). Measurement results demonstrate a 7.940.3x improvement in density FoM over prior CiM designs, achieving 1159.4 TOPS/W x Mb/mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> in SWaP (Space-Wattageand-Performance-Density) metric. For complete inference tasks, the proposed design exhibits 43.8x higher energy efficiency than volatile SRAM/eDRAM CiM works.

title: Task-Oriented MoE-LoRA: Expert Specialization and Routing for Remote Sensing Image Segmentation
authors: Kai Ma, Lichen Zhang
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Software Engineering and Service Science (ICSESS)
abstract: Semantic segmentation in remote sensing imagery represents a fundamental task for Earth observation, supporting diverse applications in environmental monitoring and urban planning. However, the high diversity of land cover categories and complex spatial structures in high-resolution images continue to pose considerable challenges. While parameter-efficient tuning techniques such as LoRA allow large foundation models to be adapted effectively, they still face limitations in representing the strong spectral and spatial variations found in remote sensing data. This paper introduces a task-oriented MoELoRA framework that combines a mixture-of-experts structure with LoRA, encouraging individual experts to specialize implicitly in different land cover types. We design a routing network that uses global context to assign features dynamically to the most suitable experts. Without predefined expert domains, our approach accurately models varied geographical characteristics. Evaluations on the LoveDA remote sensing dataset show the proposed method achieves higher segmentation accuracy than standard LoRA and other parameter-efficient tuning baselines, providing an efficient and practical option for deploying large vision models in remote sensing.

title: Relay Protection Strategies for Renewable-Dominated Power Grids: A Review of Adaptive and AI-Based Approaches
authors: Haochi Tang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: The rapid growth of renewable energy, especially solar and wind, has reshaped modern power systems. Unlike conventional synchronous generators, inverter-based resources (IBRs) supply only limited fault current, respond rapidly to disturbances, and often produce non-standard waveforms. These characteristics challenge traditional protection schemes, which were built on the assumptions of strong and predictable fault signatures. As a result, utilities are reporting more frequent false trips, delayed clearance, and undetected faults in renewable-dominated grids. This paper examines the shortcomings of conventional methods and emerging solutions for modern grids. It first outlines classical overcurrent, voltage, and distance protection, whose simplicity, low cost, and reliability remain valuable, but whose fixed settings and impedance assumptions no longer suit high-IBR networks. Next, it explores adaptive protection strategies that update relay settings in real time using dynamic thresholds, online calibration, and wide-area measurements. These methods enhance relay performance but rely on reliable data and communication. The review also considers hybrid approaches that combine advanced pattern recognition with adaptive logic, offering adaptability but facing challenges related to data, interpretability, and computation. The paper concludes by identifying key evaluation factors—accuracy, speed, robustness, and trustworthiness—and highlighting hybrid frameworks as a promising path forward. Together, adaptive and AI-based approaches represent the most viable direction for future protection in renewable-rich power systems.

title: Beyond Attention: The Critical Role of FFN Tuning in GQA-Based Large Language Models
authors: Xuan Mao, Zhen Zhao
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Software Engineering and Service Science (ICSESS)
abstract: Low-Rank Adaptation is currently the standard for efficient parameter fine-tuning, which mainly prioritizes adjustments to the attention mechanism. However, modern large language models, such as Qwen2, utilize Grouped Query Attention and SwiGLU activation functions to shift the density of model parameters toward feedforward networks. This paper systematically evaluates adaptation methods focusing on attention, feedforward networks, and all linear layers within the Qwen2-7B architecture, revealing a fundamental shift in the focus of fine-tuning efficiency. Our experimental results show that adaptation targeting feedforward networks is crucial for inference tasks. Compared to the baseline model using only the attention mechanism, the full linear adaptive strategy achieves a relative improvement of 9.1% in accuracy on abstract algebra tasks. While a cost-benefit analysis shows that this approach increases the number of trainable parameters by a factor of eight, the absolute memory overhead is still small at about 80 MB. Based on this, we advocate adapting all linear layers as the optimal configuration to balance logical reasoning ability and hardware efficiency in modern large language models.

title: AC and DC Power Flow Calculation Method in Distribution Networks Based on Power Electronic Transformers
authors: Zhen Zheng, Yinan Huang, Wenwen Chen, Xiao Yang, Haijun Xing
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: To characterise the multi-port power coupling characteristics of power electronic transformers, this research proposes a method for calculating power flow in AC and DC distribution networks incorporating PETs. Firstly, by constructing a multi-port power flow decoupling model for PETs based on controlled source pairs, the power coupling characteristics of the power conversion elements under voltage control and power control modes are characterised. Secondly, an alternating iteration algorithm is employed to achieve efficient collaborative solution for AC and DC systems. Finally, power flow calculations for an enhanced 26-node AC and DC hybrid distribution network in a specific region demonstrate that the proposed method satisfies the requirements for power flow calculations in distribution networks incorporating PETs. The proposed PET power flow decoupling model accommodates multi-voltage level AC and DC buses. It accurately calculates both PET port power flows and internal power flow distributions under both voltage control and power control modes, whilst exhibiting a low number of iterations and rapid convergence.

title: Analysis of OTDR Trace Curves of Fiber-Optic Communication Lines in the Harsh Climatic Conditions
authors: Rikhsi Isaev, Saparniyaz Tursimuratov, Avazbek Jurabekov, Kholisakhon Davletova
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: This paper explores the operation status of backbone transport network fiber-optic communication lines under the extreme weather conditions of continental climate of Karakalpakstan region of Republic of Uzbekistan. An OTDR equipment was used to measure the measurements and SOR and CSV trace format obtained was processed in MATLAB software. The attenuation of waves and the behavior of backscattering of the fiber optical communication lines were analyzed using wavelet transform techniques. The findings prove that the main mechanical effects of extreme temperature changes can produce a discernible effect on the signal characteristics. These results underline the necessity of constant monitoring and high-quality signal processing techniques of preventing the long-term functioning and condition of fiber-optic installations in regions, which have adverse environment.

title: Optimization of Distribution Network Reliability Improvement Measures: A Quantitative Decomposition Approach for Enhanced Decision-Making in Power Systems
authors: Chenying Yi, Yangjun Zhou, Wei Zhang, Like Gao, Hongwen Wu, Yuanchao Zhou, Ke Zhou, Weixiang Huang, Juntao Pan, Shan Li
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: Traditional distribution network reliability planning models often face inefficiencies and challenges due to complex power flow constraints and high-dimensional decision variables. This paper presents an optimization approach for reliability improvement measures based on quantitative decomposition, introducing reliability parameters as intermediary variables to quantify their impact on key reliability indices such as SAIDI. A bi-objective optimization model is developed, aiming to minimize both reliability index values and investment costs. The model is solved using a multi-objective particle swarm optimization (PSO) algorithm, incorporating Pareto dominance principles. The method is validated on a real urban distribution network in China, demonstrating the ability to identify cost-efficient strategies that significantly reduce reliability indices across multiple zones. This study offers practical guidance for utilities to optimize distribution network investments, balancing cost with reliability enhancements in an efficient manner.

title:
Self-switchable W-doped VO
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    Smart Radiative Film for Synergistic Indoor Air Conditioning Energy Conservation
authors: Xiangfeng Xiao
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: Switchable radiative cooling systems utilizing VO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> materials dynamically modulate thermal emittance in response to ambient temperature fluctuations. However, achieving effective indoor thermostatic control solely through VO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>-based radiative cooling remains challenging, particularly under low-temperature conditions. The study proposes a reverse-switching radiative cooling strategy that exploits the room-temperature phase transition of W-VO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> to synergistically enhance indoor thermal regulation with air conditioning systems. Diverging from conventional W-VO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>-based coolers, the proposed system implements a novel thermal management strategy by activating radiative cooling at low ambient temperatures while inhibiting it under high-temperature conditions. This temperature-inversely responsive behavior synchronizes radiative cooling cycles with HVAC (Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning) operational modes, thereby enabling precise temperature stabilization. Computational simulations validate the superior performance of the W-VO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>-based system, which achieves a 36% reduction in HVAC energy consumption relative to conventional static counterparts under consistent indoor thermal conditions. The work presents an innovative paradigm integrating intelligent radiative thermal management with conventional HVAC to advance building energy efficiency.

title: Measuring Far-UVC Radiation using Off-the-Shelf Sensors and Spectrometer: a Comparative Study
authors: Thalita Ferreira Cavalcanti, Nataly Albuquerque Dos Santos, Ane Polline Lacerda Protasio, Cleonilson Protasio de Souza
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: It is well known that UVC radiation is effective in inactivating bacteria and viruses, but it has adverse health effects in humans. Understanding the mechanism of UVC transmission through transparent and translucent surfaces is very relevant today due to the increasing use of this technology in disinfection applications. Specifically, UVC refers to the ultraviolet radiation within the wavelength range of 100 to 280 nm, also known as germicidal UV, and previous studies show that glass and other translucent films can affect the effectiveness and safety of UVC applications, since they can act as barriers to UVC, depending on the specific wavelength. In this way, this study describes the use of commercially available low-cost UV sensors and an industry-grade spectrometer to measure the impact of different glass thicknesses on the intensity and spectrum of UVC radiation, with the aim of contributing to improving UVC applications. The main result shows that UVC at about 220 nm is almost completely blocked by glass, whereas 254 nm is not.

title: Python-Based Architectural Framework of End-to-End BB84 Noise Simulation
authors: Larry McMahan, Aditya Das, Sophia Ren, Samiha Das, Elaine Huang, Sai Sanjay Devi, Ashvik Ghosh
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: Quantum Key Distribution (QKD) provides a novel alternative to Classical Key Distribution in protecting secure communications, but poses challenges in terms of research and widespread adoption. While the resource-intensive nature of QKD setups limit experimental studies to specialized laboratories, we present an end-to-end simulation that models photon generation, transmission, and detection, thereby lowering the barrier to testing hypotheses regarding experimental setups under realistic conditions. In this study, a fiber optic-based simulation is utilized along with a quantum circuit and a detailed noise model within the BB84 protocol to recreate an experimental setup. Our BB84 simulation retained ≈50% of transmitted bits after sifting, matching the experimental expectations. Our model incorporates customizable noise, such as multi-photon emissions and channel disturbances, directly into the key exchange process, allowing for an approach that utilizes simulated fiber optics and theoretical noise models to replicate physical conditions. Our findings support the development of QKD as a scalable solution for securing the quantum internet and future communication networks.

title: Numerical Analysis of D-Shaped Optical Fiber Sensor for an Early Breast Cancer Detection
authors: Santos Kumar Umar, Nishant Kumar, Akhilesh Tiwari
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: This work presents the numerical analysis and development of D-shaped optical fiber biosensor based on surface plasmon resonance (SPR) for the early detection of breast cancer cells. The cladding of the single-mode fiber is polished on both sides with residual thickness of 50 nm to create flat sensing surfaces. Each polished surface is coated with a 35 nm thin film of Gold (Au) to induce plasmonic effects. The proposed sensor is analysed using the finite element method (FEM) with perfectly matched layer (PML) boundary conditions, and mode analysis is carried out to optimize the sensing performance parameters. The maximum wavelength sensitivity achieved by the proposed sensor is 2000 nm/RIU to 5000 nm/RIU for a range of refractive index 1.33 to 1.41 of the sample, meanwhile the sensor distinguishes between healthy and cancer-affected liquid samples by detecting resonance wavelength shifts (ReWSs) corresponding to differences in refractive indices. A high sensitivity of 3571.43 nm/RIU is achieved for two types of breast cancer cells. These results highlight the potential of the proposed dual D-shaped SPR sensor as a highly sensitive platform for early-stage breast cancer detection.

title: Robust Speech Event Detection Using Transformer Encoder and Mel Spectrogram for Speech-Guided Robot Navigation in Composite Sound Mixtures
authors: Tank Prasad Awasthi, Saujan Prakash Niroula, M. Sabarimalai Manikandan
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: Sound-guided and vision-guided robot navigation techniques have significant potential for home and industrial automation. Among them, speech-aware robot navigation is widely adopted for entertainment and control applications, yet it faces major challenges in complex noise environments. In this paper, we present a robust speech event detection method based on a transformer architecture and log-Mel spectrogram. To meet low-latency and energy-efficiency requirements, we investigate the optimal Mel-filter order that offers the best balance between accuracy and computational efficiency. The proposed log-Mel-spectrogram transformer-net (LMSTN) models are evaluated across 16 noisy environments at signal-to-noise ratios (SNRs) of 20, 15, 10, 5, and 0dB. The performance of the best model is further compared with two pretrained networks, MobileNetV2 and VGG16. Experimental results show that segment duration (100 ms, 250 ms, 500 ms) and Mel-filter (MF) order (40, 64, 80, 128) significantly influence sensitivity, specificity, and computational cost. The LMSTN model with an MF order of 64 achieved strong performance, obtaining average sensitivities of 92.13% and 86.02% at SNRs of 5 dB and 0 dB, respectively, across sixteen indoor noise conditions, outperforming all other MF-order-based configurations.

title: Distributed Energy Dispatch for Energy Community Using Decision-oriented Net-load Prediction
authors: Yibo Ding, Jian Zhao, Jiaqi Ruan, Zhao Xu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: This paper focuses on distributed energy dispatch under uncertainties for an energy community. To effectively handle these uncertainties, a decision-oriented predict-then-optimize framework is employed, achieving statistically lower operation costs compared to traditional accuracy-oriented predict-then-optimize approaches. Furthermore, peer-to-peer energy sharing among agents is specially considered to promote renewable energy consumption. Dual consensus alternating direction method of multipliers is employed to solve the distributed energy dispatch problem. Simulation results over extensive scenarios have demonstrated the effectiveness of the proposed methodology.

title: A Fusion Framework for Anomaly Detection in IoMT Environment Using GraphSAGE and Performer Transformer
authors: Diego Arteaga, Andrew Boghosian, Angelica Marie Ignacio, Serineh Megerdichian, Jose Villalobos Carrillo, Rashida Hasan
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: The Internet of Medical Things (IoMT) interconnects medical devices and sensors to enable continuous monitoring and improved patient care. While this connectivity offers significant benefits, it also introduces critical security risks, as resource-constrained devices are highly vulnerable to cyberattacks. Anomaly detection in such environments remains difficult because many existing approaches fail to jointly capture the structural relationships among devices and the dynamic temporal patterns of network behavior. To address this gap, we propose a hybrid anomaly detection framework that integrates GraphSAGE based Graph Neural Networks for structural feature extraction with a Performer Transformer for efficient temporal modeling. Experimental evaluations on four benchmark datasets, CICIoMT2024, WUSTL-EHMS-2020, ECU-IoHT, and IoT Healthcare Security, demonstrate that the proposed framework achieves consistently high detection accuracy, robust generalization, and adaptability across diverse IoMT and healthcare network scenarios.

title: Machine Learning-Based Long-Term Forest Fractional Cover Estimation and Spatio-Temporal Attribution Analysis in Northeast China (2000–2021)
authors: Fanrong Huang, Jingwen Hu, Lin Gao, Xiaofei Wang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Geographic Information and Remote Sensing Technology (GIRST)
abstract: Forest cover serves as a critical indicator of ecosystem stability and carbon balance. This study investigated the spatio-temporal dynamics and driving mechanisms of forest fractional cover (FFC) in Northeast China from 2000 to 2021. A machine learning framework integrating Landsat time-series imagery with spectral and phenological features—notably the spectral angle at the NIR band (ANIR) and harmonic characteristics (amplitude and phase) of time-series NDVI—was implemented using a Random Forest classifier to enhance FFC estimation accuracy. The results indicate that during the period from 2001 to 2021, the OA of the generated forest maps varied between 80.0% and 95.4%, while the F-score ranged from 75.0% to 95.3%. Attribution analysis using the CatBoost-SHAP model revealed that precipitation was the dominant driver, contributing 42% to forest loss and 31% to forest gain, while temperature, human activities, and soil properties exerted secondary effects. These findings demonstrate the effectiveness of combining spectral–phenological features with machine learning for accurate FFC estimation.

title: Attitude control experiment design for OPS-SAT Missions
authors: K. Olfe, J.M. Ezquerro, J. Rodríguez, A. Arshadi, A. Laverón-Simavilla, V. Lapuerta
publish: IEEE Aerospace and Electronic Systems Magazine
abstract: This work presents an innovative attitude control experiment design and a novel application developed for in-orbit testing, leveraging the ESA Nanosat Mission Operations Framework in Java. This application was deployed on OPS-SAT-1, an ESA satellite in orbit until May 2024 which served as a powerful, reconfigurable flying laboratory for experiments. However, the experiment could not be executed on OPS-SAT-1 due to a malfunction in the I2C bus. The main advantage of the presented application is its adaptability for use on any satellite with a similar pointing strategy implementing the Nanosat Mission Operations Framework, which is the Service Oriented architecture that ESA will use in future nanosatellite missions. The experiment design could thus be reused in another satellite. The application incorporates two control algorithms for comparison: an experimental fuzzy controller and an experimental PID controller. However, it can be used to test any type of controller and the general objective of this work is to contribute to the advancement of in-orbit testing and validation of new spacecraft attitude control algorithms.

title: Routing-Oblivious and Data-Efficient Network Tomography with Flow-based Generative Model
authors: Yan Qiao, Minyue Li, Xinyu Yuan, Kui Wu, Cuiying Feng, Meng Li, Kun Xie
abstract: Given the high cost associated with directly measuring the Traffic Matrix (TM), researchers have devoted efforts to devising methods for estimating the complete TM from low-cost link loads by solving a set of heavily ill-posed linear equations. Today’s increasingly intricate networks present an even greater challenge: as adaptive and dynamically changing routing strategies are gradually replacing traditional fixed routing schemes, the routing matrix within these equations can no longer be deemed reliable. In our previous work, we pioneered a flow-based generative model, FlowTM, which estimated the TM by establishing an invertible correlation between the TM and link loads without relying on the routing matrix. We demonstrated that the missing information in the ill-posed equations can be decoupled from the TM and learned jointly with the invertible mapping. Considering that acquiring a complete training set for FlowTM is often impractical in many real-world networks, we further propose an enhanced model, FlowTM+, in this extended work. It incorporates an Inspector module to mine deeper latent structures from the partially observed TM data and link load measurements. This new technique effectively compensates for unobservable information in the training data. Extensive experiments demonstrate that FlowTM improves the performance of the best baseline by 38%–58% when the actual routing matrix is absent. Remarkably, with only 2% of the training data, FlowTM+ achieves an estimation accuracy comparable to that of state-of-the-art baselines trained with full routing knowledge and complete training data.

title: The generalized trifference problem
authors: Anurag Bishnoi, Bartlomiej Kielak, Benedek Kovács, Zoltán Lóránt Nagy, Gábor Somlai, Máté Vizer, Zeyu Zheng
abstract: We study the problem of finding the largest number T(n,m) of ternary vectors of length n such that for any three distinct vectors there are at least m coordinates where they pairwise differ. This problem is a special case of the perfect k-hashing problem in theoretical computer science, corresponding to the k = 3 case. For m = 1, we get the classical trifference problem which is wide open. We prove upper and lower bounds on T(n,m) for various ranges of the parameter m and determine the phase transition threshold on m = m(n) where T(n,m) jumps from constant to exponential in n. By relating the linear version of this problem to a problem on blocking sets in finite geometry, we give explicit constructions and probabilistic lower bounds. We also compute the exact values of this function and its linear variation for small parameters. Moreover, we relate the trifference problem to the sunflower conjecture.

title: PRISMA: Physically-Aware Reasoning and Intelligent Semantic Mining Architecture for IoT Process Discovery Using Deep Learning and Large Language Models
authors: Iman El Kodssi, Hanae Sbai, Nassima Ait Mansour
abstract: Internet of Things (IoT) environments generate large volumes of heterogeneous sensor data that remain difficult to exploit for process mining due to the absence of structured event logs with explicit case identifiers, activity labels, and semantic annotations. Bridging the gap between continuous sensor streams and process-level representations remains a major challenge for IoT-aware business process analysis. This paper introduces PRISMA (Physically-aware Reasoning and Intelligent Semantic Mining Architecture), an end-to-end framework for automatically discovering physically realistic business processes from raw IoT sensor data. PRISMA integrates three complementary components: (i) a neural transformation pipeline that converts heterogeneous sensor streams into structured event logs through adaptive parsing, temporal segmentation, activity recognition, and case identification; (ii) a semantic enrichment engine that augments events with IoT-aware business semantics using domain ontologies and neural language models; and (iii) a physics-aware discovery stage that enforces temporal, causal, and resource constraints during process model construction. PRISMA is evaluated on three real-world IoT datasets comprising 7.2 million events collected from 270 sensors across different application domains. Experimental results demonstrate that PRISMA achieves X% completeness, Y% semantic accuracy, and Z violations, outperforming state-of-the-art baselines. These results show that PRISMA provides a promising unified approach for end-to-end IoT-aware process mining, with future work needed to address deployment challenges such as streaming scalability and concept drift.

title: G-CDNet: A Generalized Architecture for both Semantic and Binary Change Detection Tasks
authors: Xiuwei Zhang, Lei Yu, Yamin Han, Yizhe Yang, Xiaomeng Hu, Wencong Wu, Chenxu Wei, Hanlin Yin, Liang Chen, Haohao Zhou, Yanning Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Change detection (CD) is a crucial task in remote sensing image analysis, including several fundamental tasks such as binary change detection (BCD), semantic change detection (SCD), etc. Recently, deep learning-based models (e.g., Convolutional neural networks (CNN) and Transformers) have made impressive progress in the field of remote sensing CD. However, those CD models are carefully designed for a specific fundamental task (BCD or SCD) and cannot achieve impressive progress in both BCD and SCD tasks simultaneously. In this paper, we designed a generalized architecture for both BCD and SCD tasks by investigating the common characteristics of these two tasks. In the feature extraction stage, a Multi-scale Attention Enhanced Encoder (MSAE) is introduced to extract global context and capture fine-grained features, which is beneficial for both BCD and SCD. In the training stage, a Change Detection Contrastive Learning Module (CDCL) is proposed to optimize feature distribution, improving the discriminative ability in distinguishing change regions and categories. To mitigate class imbalance issues in both BCD and SCD, we introduce Dynamic Rare-Aware Sampling for Change Detection (DRAS-CD), which dynamically prioritizes rare categories and enhances model robustness. Additionally, we collect the Yellow River Basin Semantic Change Detection dataset (YRSCD), which includes 13 change categories across diverse scenes with broad spatial and temporal coverage. Extensive experimental results on four public datasets (WHU-CD, LEVIR-CD, SECOND, Landsat-SCD) and YRSCD have shown superior performance in comparison to other state-of-the-art approaches, especially those based on the visual fundamental model, offering a generalized solution for both BCD and SCD tasks.

title: From Sight to Touch: Haptic Sensory Integration Can Facilitate Multi-Limb Coordination
authors: Kihun Hong, Ada Kanapskyte, Harshavardhana T. Gowda, Leila Harper, Manya Murali, Wilsaan M. Joiner, Lee M. Miller, Stephen K. Robinson, Richard S. Whittle, Sanjay S. Joshi, Jonathon S. Schofield
abstract: Humans possess an innate ability to seamlessly coordinate movement across multiple limbs, whether driving a motor vehicle, playing a musical instrument, or performing other daily tasks. Here, supplemental sensory information, such as haptic feedback, can enhance this coordination in applications ranging from controlling teleoperated robots to prosthetic limbs and collaborative robotics. Yet, a critical gap remains in our understanding of how visual and haptic information are integrated within sensorimotor feedback systems, as well as the extent to which these sensory channels may serve as substitutes for one another. To address this gap, we conducted an experiment investigating how sensory feedback can be incorporated in a multi-limb coordination task. To determine the degree to which visual or haptic feedback dominates in multi-limb coordination, 25 participants performed a virtual cursor-to-target task using both upper limbs (via a joystick controller) and one lower limb (via a foot pedal controller). Throughout the task, we systematically manipulated visual and haptic feedback, using a vibrotactile haptic feedback algorithm that delivered task-relevant information to all three limbs. We assessed participants' task performance measures relating to trial success rates, completion times, ability to move their limbs in coordination, and overall movement efficiency. Additionally, participants completed a cognitive workload questionnaire to evaluate their perceived task difficulty level and cognitive demands. Our findings indicate that haptic feedback can effectively substitute for one degree of visual information (cursor movement along one axis). We found no significant difference between conditions where all visual cues were presented in the task and the condition where one aspect of visual feedback was replaced by haptic feedback. These results suggest that haptic feedback can, to an extent, serve as a viable alternative to visual feedback in multi-limb coordination tasks.

title: WiSACL: A subdomain adaptive Wi-Fi-based gesture recognition via contrastive learning
authors: Chuan Liu, Yangjing Zhou, Xiaochen Yuan, Yue Liu, Yuanwei Liu
abstract: Wi-Fi-based gesture recognition faces significant performance degradation in cross-domain scenarios due to the distribution shifts between various environments, user locations, and facing orientations. To address this challenge, we propose WiSACL, a novel Wi-Fi-based gesture recognition framework that integrates innovative CSI signal processing with advanced subdomain adaptation techniques. We propose a novel Wi-Fi CSI phase difference representation that suppresses the environmental noise and highlights the motion features via phase ratio computation, wavelet denoising, and temporal differencing, which are then encoded into discriminative image representations for enhanced gesture recognition. Building upon this robust signal representation, we develop an Adaptive Distributioncalibrated Pseudo-Label (ADPL) module that progressively refines target labels through subdomain distribution alignment and confidence-aware selection. To fully exploit these pseudo-labels while mitigating the adverse effects of domain shift and label noise, we further introduce a contrastive learning (CL) model that explicitly enhances intra-class compactness and inter-class separation in the feature space. Extensive experiments on the Widar3.0 dataset demonstrate that WiSACL achieves an average accuracy of 98.62% across cross-location, cross-orientation, and cross-environment scenarios, significantly outperforming state-of-the-art methods and validating the effectiveness of our approach for robust cross-domain wireless gesture recognition.

title: Smart Elevator with Reconfigurable Sensor Monitoring
authors: I-Wen Chang, Yi-Bing Lin, Hsiang-Jung Meng, Lan-Da Van
abstract: Elevator systems require robust operation monitoring to ensure safety, performance, and effective fault detection, particularly in environments where sensor configurations may evolve over time. Traditional approaches often rely heavily on expert knowledge and rule-based systems, limiting scalability and responsiveness. With the advent of IoT technologies, real-time data collection and intelligent fault analysis have become both feasible and effective. To address these limitations, we present ElevatorTalk-M, an IoT-based elevator operation monitoring system that introduces a novel finite state machine (FSM)-based framework capable of dynamically generating operational models for arbitrary sensor configurations. Building on the earlier ElevatorTalk platform, ElevatorTalk-M enables sensors to be added or removed transparently while maintaining accurate and consistent operational modeling, a capability that is not available in existing smart elevator solutions and is particularly beneficial for legacy elevators. Experimental results show that all door obstruction events are successfully detected with an average detection time of 0.1 seconds. We further provide a formal correctness proof of the proposed fault detection algorithm. By integrating an auxiliary vibration sensor, the system can significantly enhance detection reliability, reducing the detection error from 0.18% to 0.0054%. These results demonstrate that ElevatorTalk-M offers a scalable, interpretable, and resilient solution that reduces reliance on domain experts while improving real-time elevator operation monitoring.

title: The Microwave Remote Sensing Laboratory (MIRSL): 45 Years of Microwave Radar and Radiometer Development With a Look at Today
authors: Paul Siqueira, Stephen Frasier
abstract: The Microwave Sensing Laboratory (MIRSL) at the University of Massachusetts in Amherst has a 45-year history of development, deployment and application of microwave instrumentation for studying the environment. In this article, the research, teaching and engagement missions of the lab are described and put into the context of current trends that are prevalent in the field. These trends manifest themselves through the wider incorporation of digital systems into microwave instrumentation as well the impact of multimodal (e.g. hyperspectral and microwave) remote sensing. The article concludes by describing ongoing projects for the remote sensing of the atmosphere, of snow, and other emerging opportunities that are occurring within MIRSL.

title: Proof of Unlearning for Semantic Knowledge Bases in Large Language Models-Enabled Semantic Communication
authors: Yijing Lin, Ze Chai, Jiacheng Wang, Zhipeng Gao, Nan Ma, Ping Zhang, Dusit Niyato
abstract: Semantic communication is a paradigm shift in wireless systems that transmits semantic information, such as intent, context, and meaning, instead of raw data to reduce redundant data. At its core, semantic knowledge bases (SKBs) store and organize the contextual knowledge required for accurate encoding, decoding, and reasoning over semantic information. Recently, large language models (LLMs), pretrained on massive and diverse text corpora, have been integrated into SKBs to generate high-quality semantic embeddings, enable zero-shot retrieval of relevant knowledge, and support complex inference tasks across a wide range of domains. However, since the training corpus of LLM may include outdated, malicious, or privacy-sensitive content, LLM-enabled SKBs should be updated efficiently and verifiably to remove specific data without retraining from scratch. In this article, we first conduct a survey on related works and then propose a model-agnostic proof of unlearning framework for LLM-driven SKBs in semantic communications. Specifically, we track the evolution of the unlearning process by measuring drifts in the LoRA adapter subspace. We then execute successive reverse steps and generate the proof trace that a verifier can compare to provide a quantitative and verifiable unlearning guarantee. Finally, experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed framework.

title: Safe Fairness Guarantees Without Demographics in Classification: Spectral Uncertainty Set Perspective
authors: Ainhize Barrainkua, Santiago Mazuelas, Novi Quadrianto, Jose A. Lozano
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: As automated classification systems become increasingly prevalent, concerns have emerged over their potential to reinforce and amplify existing societal biases. In the light of this issue, many methods have been proposed to enhance the fairness guarantees of classifiers. Most of the existing interventions assume access to group information for all instances, a requirement rarely met in practice. Fairness without access to demographic information has often been approached through robust optimization techniques, which target worst-case outcomes over a set of plausible distributions known as the uncertainty set. However, their effectiveness is strongly influenced by the chosen uncertainty set. In fact, existing approaches often overemphasize outliers or overly pessimistic scenarios, compromising both overall performance and fairness. To overcome these limitations, we introduce <monospace xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">SPECTRE</monospace>, a minimax-fair method that adjusts the spectrum of a simple Fourier feature mapping and constrains the extent to which the worst-case distribution can deviate from the empirical distribution. We perform extensive experiments on the American Community Survey datasets involving 20 states. The safeness of <monospace xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">SPECTRE</monospace> comes as it provides the highest average values on fairness guarantees together with the smallest interquartile range in comparison to state-of-the-art approaches, even compared to those with access to demographic group information. In addition, we provide a theoretical analysis that derives computable bounds on the worst-case error for both individual groups and the overall population, as well as characterizes the worst-case distributions responsible for these extremal performances.

title: Harnessing Transferable Adversarial Examples via Multi-layer Attention-guided Spatial Transformations
authors: Pengfei Dong, Yatie Xiao, Chi-Man Pun, Fei Peng, Kongyang Chen, Qingxian Guan, Siyuan Chen, Xiangyu Ye, Zhenbang Liu
abstract: Transfer-based adversarial attacks are key for evaluating the robustness of deep neural networks (DNNs) in black-box settings, yet their effectiveness is often constrained by limited cross-model transferability. Existing feature-level approaches typically rely on single-layer attention guidance or static perturbation patterns, which restrict adaptability across diverse architectures. In this work, we introduce a unified adversarial framework, named Multi-layer Attention-guided Spatial Transformations (MAT), to exploit class-discriminative cues from multiple feature layers to craft highly transferable adversarial examples. MAT integrates Multi-layer Attention Fusion (MAF) to capture complementary low-level and high-level semantics from multiple intermediate layers, Attention-guided Augmentation (AGA) to selectively perturb non-critical regions while preserving semantic integrity, and Spatial Random Transformation (SRT) to introduce stochastic spatial augmentations to diversify patterns during optimization. Unlike prior methods that use static or layer-specific attention, MAT dynamically adapts feature guidance to the architecture and task, which enhances generalization. We evaluate MAT against eleven state-of-the-art (SOTA) transfer-based attacks across nine CNN-based and Transformer-based architectures on ImageNet. Comprehensive experiments demonstrate that MAT consistently outperforms eleven state-of-the-art transfer-based attacks in both white-box and black-box settings, including against adversarially trained and input preprocessing-based defensive models, while maintaining higher semantic similarity to the original inputs. It highlights the superior adversarial robustness and excellent adaptability of MAT in adversarial machine learning. Our code is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/dislab-gzhu/MAT</uri>.

title: Multi-UAV Coverage Path Planning Based on Balanced Graph Partitioning
authors: Mengfan Cao, Zaiyue Yang, Haoyu Miao
abstract: Coverage path planning is a critical problem in multi-UAV systems for daily inspection and patrol missions, requiring coordinated movements of UAVs along predetermined trajectories to cover the entire map. Existing methods are often inadequate in considering both workload balance and motion efficiency during task assignment, resulting in imbalanced coverage areas or unnecessary turning maneuvers. To address these limitations, this paper presents a hierarchical structure that integrates spatial decomposition, balanced task assignment through graph partitioning, and turn-aware trajectory planning. The approach follows three key steps: first, spatial decomposition partitions the map into subregions; second, the partitioned map is transformed into a weighted graph, where task assignment distribution is optimized by iteratively migrating and swapping nodes among subgraphs while preserving connectivity, ensuring a balanced workload distribution across UAVs. Finally, trajectory planning incorporates turn optimization to reduce completion time. The results show that our method ensures even task assignment among UAVs, fewer turns, faster task completion, and lower computation time compared to other popular algorithms.

title: A Lightweight Adaptive Camera-Radar Fusion for Object Detection Under Fog-Haze Environment
authors: Jinpeng Li, Tianhua Xu, Guang Wang, Weiyang Cai, Muyang Miao, Ziqing Wang
abstract: With the rapid advancement of autonomous driving technology, ensuring vehicle safety and robust perception in real time, particularly for obstacle detection under adverse conditions such as fog or haze, has become increasingly imperative. In this paper, we propose a Lightweight Adaptive Camera–Radar Fusion (LACRF) framework for context-aware obstacle detection, which enhances the detection of small and long-range objects in fog–haze environments while remaining effective under clean weather conditions. LACRF employs GhostNetV2 as a lightweight backbone and incorporates a Gated Attention Fusion (GAF) mechanism to adaptively regulate modality dependencies through pre-gate and post-gate strategies. This design effectively suppresses noise from low-quality sensor inputs and enhances overall robustness. Furthermore, we introduce a Dynamic Routing Defogging (DRD) module that adapts to changing environmental conditions by selectively activating or bypassing the defogging process based on predicted haze scores, thereby reducing unnecessary computation and inference latency in clear-weather scenarios. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves a mean Average Precision (mAP) of 92.8% on the DENSE dataset and 96.3% on the self-constructed Foggy Dataset with real-time inference speed. This enhancement in performance, when compared with conventional methodologies, offers a robust and efficient solution for context-aware obstacle detection in adverse weather conditions.

title: CAP-SSM: Context-Aware Prototypes and Selective State-Space Modeling for Efficient Wearable Human Activity Recognition
authors: Gyuyeon Lim, Myung-Kyu Yi
abstract: Human Activity Recognition (HAR) plays a crucial role in Internet of Things (IoT) applications such as healthcare, smart homes, and rehabilitation. Despite remarkable progress, most sensor-based HAR models struggle with subject variability, sensor orientation shifts, and limited computational resources on wearable devices. To overcome these limitations, we propose a novel HAR framework that combines a Convolutional Block Attention Module (CBAM) for adaptive refinement of channel-wise and temporal representations, a light Mamba-based state-space module for efficient modeling of long-range temporal dependencies, and a context-aware prototype classifier. The classifier dynamically adjusts class prototypes according to the input context, yielding adaptive classifications with prototype-based interpretability. Experimental results on five benchmark datasets—UCI-HAR, WISDM, PAMAP2, USC-HAD, and MHEALTH—demonstrate competitive performance comparable to state-of-the-art methods, particularly excelling in efficiency. Our method achieves 99.3% accuracy with 0.48M parameters and approximately 4.6 ms inference latency, demonstrating a superior accuracy–efficiency trade-off compared to recent CNN-, Transformer-, and Mamba-based approaches. We further validate real-time on-device feasibility via Raspberry Pi deployment, confirming practicality on resource-constrained edge platforms. These findings indicate that the proposed model is computationally efficient, robust to inter-subject variability, and well-suited for real-world IoT applications requiring reliable and explainable activity recognition.

title: Joint Denoising and Feature Selection for Leakage Identification in Mine Air-Supply Pipelines
authors: Wenjuan Lu, Haodong Li, Hongliang Zhao, Yu Chen, Jinxi Wang
abstract: This study investigates the identification of leakage in mineral air-supply pipelines using vibration signals. To address the issue of severe environmental noise and high signal dimensionality, a unified framework integrating joint denoising, feature selection, and leakage-type identification is proposed. First, the dung beetle optimization (DBO) algorithm adaptively tunes the parameters of variational mode decomposition (VMD) to achieve effective signal decomposition. The resulting modes are grouped by energy and kurtosis into transient leakage modes and major/minor sustained-leakage modes. An improved wavelet packet decomposition (WPD) is then applied to denoise the minor modes, which are reconstructed with the remaining modes to obtain a clean signal. Next, a wrapper feature selection method based on an improved binary DBO (IBDBO) is introduced. The Bernoulli map and extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost) are used to initialize an elite population, and a grey wolf optimization mechanism is incorporated to avoid premature convergence. Finally, the selected features are fed into a random forest to identify the types of leakage. Experiments show that the proposed method achieves an average accuracy of 95.68% with only 4.35 selected features on average, effectively improving leakage identification while reducing the number of features.

title: Joint Multi-Frame Super-Resolution Reconstruction Approach for Video Imaging Based on Information Metasurfaces
authors: Xuejun Huang, Yuanlin Li, Liwu Wen, Jinshan Ding
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: Information metasurfaces offer a low-cost solution for microwave forward-looking imaging. However, imaging dynamic and non-sparse scenes using information metasurfaces remains challenging. To address this issue, we present a joint multi-frame super-resolution reconstruction approach for video imaging using information metasurfaces. By leveraging the ultra-fast code-switching capability of information metasurfaces, we formulate the video imaging problem as a joint multi-frame super-resolution reconstruction task. Furthermore, by exploiting the temporal correlation of the background and the sparsity of dynamic variation across multiple frames, we introduce a low-rank and sparse decomposition with inter-frame smoothness model for the super-resolution reconstruction. An effective algorithm based on the proximal gradient method is developed to solve the proposed model, enabling high-resolution imaging of dynamic and non-sparse scenes. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves superior reconstruction performance compared to the existing computational imaging methods.
