title: Optimal Controller Design for Bidirectional DC-DC Converter in Battery Electric Vehicle System using the Adaptive Tabu Search Algorithm
authors: Pawin Seesamlee, Jakkrit Pakdeeto, Apichai Suyapan, Kongpan Areerak
abstract: This paper presents an optimal controller design based on an artificial intelligence (AI) technique for battery electric vehicles. In almost electric vehicles, a bidirectional DC–DC converter is employed to regulate the high-voltage DC bus at a constant level. In this study, a bidirectional buck–boost converter is used to maintain the high-voltage DC bus voltage at 800 V. Two controller design approaches are investigated: the conventional method and an AI-based optimization using the adaptive Tabu search (ATS) algorithm. In the proposed ATS framework, a control signal penalty condition is integrated into the objective function to ensure that the designed controller parameters can be implemented in practice without control signal saturation. After the optimal controller parameters are obtained, the system performance is evaluated through simulations using SimPowerSystems® and Hardware-in-Loop testing. The results can confirm that the ATS-based controller achieves better overall performance compared with the conventionally designed controller. Furthermore, additional simulation scenarios not used during the ATS optimization process verify that the proposed controller maintains the high-voltage DC bus compliance with ISO 21498-1 and ISO 21498-2 standards.

title: Development of a Hitch Force Observer–Based Adaptive Path–Tracking Controller for Sway Suppression in Vehicle-trailer Systems
authors: Yujin Choe, Donghyun Kim, Jeeyoon Suh, Seungki Kim, Sangho Lee, Yonghwan Jeong
abstract: This paper presents a novel path-tracking controller for vehicle–trailer systems that adapts to variations in trailer specifications and loading conditions without relying on trailer-side sensors. The proposed controller determines the desired steering angle using a yaw-rate-gain adaptive scheme that estimates the steering-to-yaw dynamics of the towing vehicle in real time. To account for trailer-induced effects, a disturbance observer estimates the lateral hitch force using only the vehicle’s yaw rate and speed, while incorporating real-time trailer mass estimation and rear-tire cornering-stiffness scheduling. The estimated hitch force is then used to generate a compensatory steering input that suppresses sway-induced yaw motion, which is selectively activated based on a yaw-rate safety boundary derived from phase-plane analysis and implemented through a finite-state-machine logic. Co-simulation experiments using CarMaker and MATLAB/Simulink demonstrate that the proposed controller achieves accurate and stable path tracking across diverse trailer conditions, including different payloads and driving speeds. The adaptive structure enables robust performance without prior trailer information, while the selective sway suppression strategy effectively mitigates oscillatory yaw responses without degrading path-tracking accuracy.

title: Interactive Spatial-Frequency Fusion Mamba for Multi-Modal Image Fusion
authors: Yixin Zhu, Long Lv, Pingping Zhang, Xuehu Liu, Tongdan Tang, Feng Tian, Weibing Sun, Huchuan Lu
abstract: Multi-Modal Image Fusion (MMIF) aims to combine images from different modalities to produce fused images, retaining texture details and preserving significant information. Recently, some MMIF methods incorporate frequency domain information to enhance spatial features. However, these methods typically rely on simple serial or parallel spatial-frequency fusion without interaction. In this paper, we propose a novel Interactive Spatial-Frequency Fusion Mamba (ISFM) framework for MMIF. Specifically, we begin with a Modality-Specific Extractor (MSE) to extract features from different modalities. It models long-range dependencies across the image with linear computational complexity. To effectively leverage frequency information, we then propose a Multi-scale Frequency Fusion (MFF). It adaptively integrates low-frequency and high-frequency components across multiple scales, enabling robust representations of frequency features. More importantly, we further propose an Interactive Spatial-Frequency Fusion (ISF). It incorporates frequency features to guide spatial features across modalities, enhancing complementary representations. Extensive experiments are conducted on six MMIF datasets. The experimental results demonstrate that our ISFM can achieve better performances than other state-of-the-art methods. The source code is available at https://github.com/Namn23/ISFM.

title: Integrated Perception, Communication, and Computation for Autonomous Vehicle and Road Infrastructure Network
authors: Lu Yang, Jiujun Cheng, Mengchu Zhou, Cong Liu, Zhangkai Ni, Mande Xie, Shangce Gao
abstract: Vehicle-to-Infrastructure (V2I) collaboration constitutes an emerging paradigm for advancing autonomous driving. However, the integrated collaboration of perception, communication, and computation within V2I system remains a critical challenge. To address it, we propose a Software-Defined Network (SDN)-based collaborative approach for Autonomous Vehicle and Road Infrastructure Network (AVRIN). The architecture designates road infrastructures as road nodes and autonomous vehicles as dynamic vehicle nodes, establishing AVRIN through SDN. The control plane dynamically maintains global network topology and distributed flow tables by continuously evaluating node accessibility, while the forwarding plane is responsible for packet transmission via the OpenFlow protocol. In the perception module, road nodes divide the perception range into spatial units, whereas vehicle nodes dynamically align these units with their drivable areas across temporal sequences. Through coordinated communication and computation modules, road nodes strategically allocate dedicated bandwidth and computational resources. Building on this approach, we develop a particle swarm-based multi-objective optimization algorithm to achieve balanced co-optimization across perception, communication, and computation. Experimental validation demonstrates its superior collaborative Bird's Eye View (BEV) detection performance on the V2X-Sim 2.0 dataset, outperforming existing approaches by 10.37% in mean Average Precision. Furthermore, evaluations on the newly collected Jiading dataset, from a real-world urban roadway, confirm the approach's robustness with 1.823-second computation time under dynamic network conditions.

title: Digital Twins and Predictive Analytics for Next-Generation Power Transmission Systems
authors: Khairy Sayed, Mohammed M. Elsayed, David Kirakosian, Ahmed G. Abokhalil
publish: 2025 New Jersey Future Energy Transmission Conference (NJFET)
abstract: The ongoing transition toward a clean, reliable, and resilient energy future demands intelligent tools capable of managing the increasing complexity of modern power transmission networks. This paper presents a comprehensive framework for utilizing Digital Twin (DT) technology and Predictive Analytics (PA) to develop the monitoring, control, and optimization of next-generation power transmission systems. The proposed framework incorporates high-fidelity physical modeling, sensor data, and artificial intelligence (AI) algorithms to facilitate continuous system diagnostics, performance optimization, and fault prediction. By coupling machine learning (ML)-based predictive models with dynamic grid simulators, the DT enables proactive asset management, adaptive protection coordination, and intelligent congestion mitigation under high renewable penetration scenarios. Case studies on a modified IEEE test system validate that the proposed DT-PA platform can decrease unplanned outages by up to 35%, improve voltage stability margins, and advance energy dispatch efficiency while supporting state-level clean energy objectives. The study highlights the pivotal role of DT ecosystems in accelerating grid modernization, allowing data-driven decision-making, and ensuring flexible, resilient, and sustainable transmission infrastructure for the clean energy era.

title: An Improved Approach to UAV Path Planning
authors: Jing Zhou, Jianguo Qian, Yi Sui, Jinzhao Mi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Robotics and Automatic Control (IRAC)
abstract: To address the challenges of low search efficiency, suboptimal path quality, and limited adaptability in UAV path planning within complex environments, this study proposes an enhanced A-star path planning algorithm that integrates multi-resolution techniques with an improved heuristic function. First, a multi-resolution search hierarchy determination mechanism is designed within the FALCON framework. This mechanism enables adaptive adjustment of search precision according to environmental complexity and mission requirements through the definition of different resolution levels. A multi-resolution retry fault-tolerance mechanism is implemented to automatically transition from lower to higher resolution levels when initial searches fail, thereby improving algorithm robustness in complex scenarios. Second, an improved heuristic function termed STAR-Searcher is developed. This function incorporates information gain and viewpoint quality into the heuristic computation to enhance the algorithm's path search capability in complex environments. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm achieves superior performance compared to the conventional A-star algorithm across environments of varying complexity levels. This research provides an effective solution for UAV path planning in complex environments, offering both theoretical contributions and practical application value.

title: AI-Driven Fault Detection in Coherent Optical Systems Using Deep Convolutional Networks
authors: Jahongir Norqulov, Azizbek Matmuratov, Erkin Iskandarov, Ikhlosbek Jumabayev, Barno Matchanova, Amarinder Kaur
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: The next generation networks require more bandwidth than ever before, which can only be attained through coherent optical communication systems. Nevertheless, these systems are also very prone to various impairments which include laser phase noise, polarization mode dispersion and nonlinear impairments, and proper fault detection is therefore an important activity in ensuring reliable transmission. Conventional methods of monitoring are based on optical performance monitoring(OPM) parameters or on a modelbased approach that may fail in non-linear or dynamical operating features. The proposed paper introduces using deep convolutional neural networks (CNNs) as an artificial intelligence (AI)-based system fault detector of coherent optical systems. The presented approach makes use of eye diagrams, constellation diagrams, and time-series as the inputs to CNNs which allows automatic extraction of features and classification of the fault states. In simulation experiments with different signal-to-noise ratios (SNR), modulation formats and fiber impairments, the proposed CNNbased fault detection is shown to have over 96 percent classification accuracy, which is better than support vector machines (SVMs) and shallow neural networks. The findings indicate that deep learning can be used to facilitate intelligent fault-tolerant coherent systems, which establishes the path to autonomous optical networks (AONs).

title: Research on intelligent diagnosis technology for secondary circuits based on expert knowledge base
authors: Jianhua Zhang, Junni Su, Kai Liu, Ou Li, Quanke Ba
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: This article proposes an intelligent diagnosis method for secondary circuits based on expert knowledge base to solve the problems of difficult troubleshooting and low fault localization accuracy in secondary circuits of intelligent substations. Firstly, build the architecture of the secondary circuit intelligent diagnosis system and establish standardized signal feature templates based on different types of equipment such as protection devices, measurement and control devices, and intelligent terminals. Secondly, by parsing the SCD configuration file, the standard template is converted into an actual signal mapping table, and the logical rules of the knowledge base are instantiated to form a dedicated signal relationship network within the substation. Finally, the real-time collected secondary circuit signals are preprocessed and feature extracted, and then subjected to multidimensional matching analysis with the instantiated knowledge base to achieve accurate positioning of secondary circuit faults. Taking a 220kV intelligent substation as an example, the feasibility of the proposed method was verified, providing strong support for the reliability and stability of the power system.

title: Drift-Driven 2DEG Surface Plasmons Analysis based on Electromagnetic and Hydrodynamic Views
authors: Hanghui Deng, Ping Zhang, Yubin Gong, Shengpeng Yang, Shaomeng Wang, Yixin Peng
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: Two-dimensional electron gases (2DEGs) supported in the heterostructures sustain surface plasmon polaritons (SPPs) in the terahertz (THz) band with remarkable tunability. Modeling such waves by a local Drude sheet conductivity suffices at low drift and long wavelengths, but it cannot explain drift-induced nonreciprocity nor the frequency softening observed in Dyakonov–Shur (DS) cavities under bias. This paper revisits the problem from a unified electromagnetic–hydrodynamic perspective. We first recall the local Drude picture and its gated/ungated dispersions. We then couple a hydrodynamic 2DEG to the device electrostatics, obtaining a closed dispersion that includes drift, relaxation, pressure, and viscosity. Time-domain simulations with DS boundary conditions confirm growth above a drift threshold and clarify why the fundamental cavity frequency decreases with drift even though the forward eigen-branch hardens. These insights provide guidance for engineering 2DEG-based active plasmonic devices.

title: From NOP to ADD and Beyond: A Novel Fault-Model Comprising Variable-Length Instruction Sets
authors: Xhani Marvin Sas, Thomas Martin Johannes Lehrach, Jean-Pierre Seifert
publish: 2025 Workshop on Fault Detection and Tolerance in Cryptography (FDTC)
abstract: Fault Injection Attacks (FIAs) pose significant security threats to embedded devices, compromising the security of critical systems. Although the implications of Fault Injection (FI) are well understood for embedded platforms exhibiting Reduced Instruction Set Computer (RISC) architectures, Complex Instruction Set Computer (CISC) platforms have received much less attention in security research. Modern x86 processors employ variable-length instructions spanning 1 to 15 bytes, creating unique vulnerability patterns that remain largely unexplored in existing FI research.We present the first systematic study of Electro-Magnetic Fault Injection (EMFI) attacks against variable-length Instruction Set Architectures (ISAs), highlighting misalignment effects. Our research introduces a novel fault model that demonstrates how strategically induced bit flips in instruction opcodes cause decoder misalignment, ultimately leading to the execution of completely different code sequences. We provide proof-of-concept evidence on Intel N100 hardware, showing how EMFI can transform a NOP instruction sequence into an equivalent-length ADD sequence, demonstrating novel misalignment vulnerabilities specific to variable-length ISAs.

title: A Study of the Impact of Collaborative Space on Learning Effect during C-steam Instruction
authors: Guan Huang, Ying Fang, XiaoQin Hu, XinYan Yang, Song Qin, Miao Chen
abstract: This study explores the impact of cooperative space on the learning effect in C-steam teaching. Through research and analysis of actual classroom cases, we found that cooperative space can effectively improve the' learning effect in C-steam teaching. Cooperative space not only helps students communicate and collaborate, but also stimulates their enthusiasm and interest in learning, and enhances their independent learning ability and teamwork spirit. In this study, we use interactive geographic analysis to analyze the changes in cooperative space in the case classroom as well as the changes in the space in which teachers and students are located, and evaluate the impact of cooperative space on learning effects by analyzing and studying the changes of cooperative space in the process of students' teaching in C-steam. After the analysis, we found that the cooperative space played a crucial role in the C-steam teaching process, which not only improved students' hands-on skills and problem-solving abilities but also enhanced their learning motivation and self-confidence. Additionally, the cooperative space fosters communication and collaboration among students, thereby helping to develop their teamwork and communication skills. This study shows that the cooperative space can effectively improve students' learning in the teaching process of C-steam. Therefore, teachers should pay attention to the construction of cooperative space in the teaching process and provide more communication and collaboration opportunities for students to promote students' learning progress and overall development.

title: Adaptive-Weighted EKF and LiDAR–IMU Tight-Coupling Enabled GPS-Denied UAV Navigation
authors: Fan Li, Luyurui Wang, Wei Qing, Yating Li, Yang Liu, Yibo Niu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Robotics and Automatic Control (IRAC)
abstract: To address the problems of localization drift and unstable flight performance of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) in GPS-denied environments, this paper proposes an autonomous navigation framework based on Adaptive-Weighted Extended Kalman Filtering (AW-EKF) and tightly coupled LiDAR–IMU fusion. The system employs an open-source Pixhawk flight controller and a Livox Mid-360 LiDAR, and establishes a real-time perception–fusion–control loop through sensor clock synchronization, point-cloud distortion compensation, sliding-window feature optimization, and adaptive gain feedforward control. The proposed AW-EKF introduces a time-varying covariance adjustment mechanism that dynamically adapts to changes in feature availability and IMU noise, significantly enhancing robustness in complex indoor environments with low illumination, strong reflections, and sparse textures. Meanwhile, the adaptive feedforward controller adjusts control gains based on error energy, enabling improved attitude stability and smoother transitions under nonlinear disturbances. Experiments conducted in a 10 × 8 × 3 m indoor environment demonstrate centimeter-level navigation performance, achieving an average hovering error of 0.0341 m, a path deviation of 0.0346 m, and a closed-loop mapping error below 0.05 m. The results indicate that the AW-EKF and LiDAR–IMU tight-coupling framework ensures highly reliable localization, stable flight control, and strong environmental adaptability. This study provides a practical solution for autonomous UAV operations in intelligent warehousing, indoor inspection, and other GPS-denied scenarios.

title: Low-Temperature High-Energy Photoluminescence in CdTe Films for Solar Cells
authors: Dilkhumor Mamadieva, Nosirjon Yuldashev
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: This study presents an in-depth investigation of the low-temperature photoluminescence (LTPL) spectra of finegrained polycrystalline cadmium telluride (CdTe) films, a material of great interest in thin-film solar energy technologies. The observed dominant high-energy emission band, located above the fundamental absorption edge, is linked to the unique microcrystalline structure and excitation conditions. The films were synthesized via thermal vacuum evaporation and analysed using optical and photovoltaic methods. The results demonstrate significant improvements in photovoltage and photocurrent after doping and thermal annealing, making the material suitable for high-efficiency photovoltaic applications. These findings are directly relevant to the development of sustainable, low-cost, and scalable solar energy solutions, aligning with the thematic areas of renewable energy, environmental sustainability, and energy resource management.

title: Isolation-Forest-Based Online Detection of Unbalanced Loads in Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motor
authors: Jiawei Chen, Xiang Luo
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: Permanent-magnet synchronous motors (PMSMs) are widely used in industrial and daily applications. During operation, asymmetric faults degrade motor performance. Addressing the insufficient treatment of load-imbalance effects in existing data-driven methods and the limitations of using three- phase currents as inputs, this paper proposes an online detection method for unbalanced loads based on an Isolation Forest. The method takes the q-axis current, q-axis current reference, and rotor speed as inputs, and builds a cascaded feature-extraction pipeline. Frequency-domain features are obtained from the q-axis current and its tracking error, an Isolation Forest model is trained offline, and the model is validated with both normal and abnormal samples. Finally, online tests on a laboratory platform under normal operation and multiple levels of load imbalance demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: Integrated energy business investment risk model based on risk matrix method
authors: Jianfei Lu, Xiaoyu Fan
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: To address the multidimensional, cross-cycle risks associated with integrated energy business investments, this study constructs a dynamic risk assessment model based on the risk matrix approach. Taking electrochemical energy storage projects as the empirical subject, the study first employs the Best-Worst Method (BWM) to identify critical risk factors, establishing a risk assessment indicator system encompassing four dimensions: commercial, policy, technical, and operational. Subsequently, precise quantitative formulas are innovatively designed for each risk indicator to calculate its impact level. Combined with the probability of risk occurrence, a comprehensive risk rating is ultimately determined through the risk matrix. Empirical analysis indicates the project's comprehensive risk value stands at ¥ 54.717 million, categorised as ‘low risk’. Key risks identified include capacity leasing revenue, revenue recovery from curtailed wind and solar power, and capacity tariff risks. This research provides a scientific and intuitive risk assessment tool for integrated energy business investments, offering practical significance for enhancing investment decision-making quality.

title: Digital Transformation, Energy Saving, and Modernization of Communication Networks in the Gas Transportation Industry
authors: Nargisa Babanazarova, Elena Borisova
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: This paper focuses on the energy efficiency of gas transportation facility in terms of electricity consumption at a facility that has been integrated with communication network. The analysis indicates the comparison of the actual fuel and energy resource (FER) consumption and the established standards, gathers the fuel and energy balance, and develops a specific program to enhance energy performance. The given complex of technical and organizational actions is based on the inefficiency in the usage of electricity and the communication infrastructure. On every measure, the anticipated physical and economic savings are calculated in addition to the implementation costs, which can be considered a practical foundation to make decisions.Relevant terms Digital transformation; smart energy systems; energy efficiency optimization; communication network modernization; fuel and energy resources; gas transmission networks; gas pipeline systems; power factor improvement; load factor analysis; natural gas compression; centrifugal compressor units; electric motordriven compressors; energy performance indicators; energy-saving technologies; gas cooler systems.

title: Preventing Wildfires in Energy Transmission by Automatic Power Line Defects Detection Using Machine Learning and AI
authors: Chengyu Yang, Rishik Reddy Yesgari, Vineet Vora, Philip Pong, Jie Li, Chengjun Liu
publish: 2025 New Jersey Future Energy Transmission Conference (NJFET)
abstract: Wildfires caused by faults in electrical power lines remain a significant threat to lives, infrastructure, economy and ecosystems. When transmission lines fail or contact vegetation, electrical arcing can easily ignite fires that spread rapidly under dry and windy conditions. This paper reviews state-of-the-art technologies for wildfire prevention in energy transmission systems and presents an initial framework that leverages computer vision for automatic detection of power line defects and potential ignition sources. As a proof of concept, a rule-based falling-wire detection pipeline is implemented using computer vision methods such as Canny edge detection and the Hough Transform. The results demonstrate the feasibility of identifying hazardous conditions through visual analysis. Building on this foundation, future work will incorporate advanced machine learning and deep learning models to achieve more robust, scalable, and adaptive inspection systems for proactive wildfire prevention.

title: Da Vinci: A Forensic Tool Recommendation System
authors: Harshith Sunkara, Gnaneswar Naidu Reddy, Grace Sarah Sunitha Yenubari, Umme Zakia
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: In the dynamic realm of digital forensics, the Da Vinci Tool is a pivotal android application, streamlining investigative processes with its intelligent interface. From personal incidents to professional inquiries, it simplifies usage and selections of forensic tool adapting customized needs. Da Vinci leads users through preliminary investigation, in-depth analysis, final proceedings, and submissions - integrating visual evidence for comprehensive security ratings. Additional features like real-time news updates and accessible case histories enhance usability, while integration with forensic APIs ensures access to robust resources. The Da Vinci Tool improves forensic investigation effectiveness with informative, interactive ease platform ready to tackle emerging digital challenges.

title: Research on primary frequency regulation of high proportion new energy power system
authors: Yuxin Luo, Feiyue He
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: In the context of the global dual carbon strategy, the integration of substantial renewable energy into power systems presents significant challenges, particularly system inertia degradation and diminished frequency regulation capacity. These issues impose new demands on the stability of power grid frequency stability. This study presents a systematic review of the impacts of high-penetration renewables on power system primary frequency regulation, organized around the analytical framework of 'regulation mechanism analysis—technical assessment—future perspectives'. Initially, the frequency variability induced by large-scale renewable integration is investigated, followed by an examination of frequency control strategies and their contemporary implementations across generation, transmission, load, and storage domains. Subsequently, the paper discusses in detail the specific effects of new energy integration on frequency stability, highlighting both the applications and limitations of existing frequency modulation technologies. Finally, future research directions are proposed, focusing on multi-resource coordinated control methods and comprehensive optimization strategies within the digital era. Through this analysis, the study aims to improve frequency stability and overall operational reliability of power systems, particularly under high renewable penetration scenarios.

title: Dynamic Mode-Multiplexed Optical Links for Data-Center Interconnections
authors: Amit Kumar Upadhyay, Shilpi Chauhan, Shubham Sharma, Ali Alkwzahy, Chandni Tiwari, Sandeep Singh
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: This paper proposes a dynamic mode-multiplexed (DMM) optical interconnect for data-center networks that adaptively schedules spatial modes according to instantaneous channel quality, mode-dependent loss (MDL), and crosstalk. We formulate a MIMO-based system model for few-mode fiber (FMF) links, derive a weighted sum-rate optimization with power constraints, and present a low-overhead scheduler compatible with blockbased DSP. Numerical studies indicate that dynamic scheduling across M ∊ {2,4,6,8} spatial modes improves aggregate throughput while maintaining target BER under practical OSNR and MDL. We report link parameters, give closed-form insights for water-filling power allocation, and show trends for BER vs. OSNR, throughput vs. mode count, and crosstalk scaling. Results suggest that DMM can unlock 20%–35% higher throughput over static allocation at comparable transceiver complexity, making it attractive for next-generation data-center fabrics.

title: Consumer Taste Classification Using Transformer and BiLSTM Models on EEG-fNIRS Signals for Neuromarketing Promotion
authors: Oyshi Pronomy Sarker, Michael Babinec, Kiran George
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: Accurate measurement and classification of consumer taste preferences are vital for creating appealing nutritional products. This research presents a multimodal Brain-Computing Interface (BCI) Electroencephalography (EEG) and functional Near-Infrared Spectroscopy (fNIRS) to classify five basic tastes: Bitter, Salty, Sour, Sweet, and Umami. Data were simultaneously collected from 15 healthy participants using the wet g.Nautilus fNIRS-8 Research Headset during controlled taste sessions.The dataset was formed from 100 trials, each lasting 10 seconds, segmented into overlapping windows, resulting in 544 segments of 1000 time steps by 16 channels. Labels were one- hot encoded for classification. The preprocessed data were used to train and evaluate two deep learning models— a Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) network and a Transformer encoder—designed to capture temporal and contextual features in the brain signals. Experimental results showed the Transformer model achieving 88% validation accuracy, while the BiLSTM reached 72%, demonstrating the power of deep sequence learning for BCI-based taste classification. These findings offer promising directions for neuromarketing and sensory neuroscience application.

title: Correction Method for Renewable Energy Out of Limit Data Based on Time Series Prediction
authors: Weidong Gao, Weisi Deng, Jiale Liu, Jiaqiu Hu, Hao Chen, Haohuai Wang, Wenzhong Zou
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Software Engineering and Service Science (ICSESS)
abstract: With the growing integration of renewable energy into power systems, ensuring the accuracy and reliability of energy data has become increasingly crucial. However, deviations and limit violations in time-series data, such as those in solar power generation, can adversely affect grid stability and reduce forecasting accuracy. To address this issue, this paper proposes a novel hybrid method for correcting limit-violating data in renewable energy time-series prediction. The approach combines Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and the Informer model to enhance prediction accuracy and identify anomalous data points. Specifically, both models are employed to capture long-term dependencies, with the attention mechanism in Informer improving the efficiency and precision of long-sequence prediction. By lever-aging the complementary strengths of LSTM and Informer, the proposed framework achieves superior predictive performance. A data correction mechanism is then applied to adjust values that applied to ajust values exceeding predefined thresholds, ensuring compliance with operational constraints. Experimental results demonstrate that the LSTM-Informer hybrid model outperforms individual models in prediction accuracy and effectively corrects limit-violating data points. This approach provides a reliable solution for enhancing the quality of renewable energy data, supporting better grid management and decision-making.

title: Decomposition-Driven Transformer for Accurate and Trend-Aware Wind Power Prediction
authors: Cheng Shen, Huanzhi Lou, Bo Ding, Jing Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: Wind power (WP) is increasingly integrated into power systems, making accurate short-term forecasting critical for economic and secure grid operation. While Transformer-Based models have reduced point-wise numerical error, they often fail to preserve trend consistency—a property more relevant for dispatch decisions than small numerical deviations. In this paper, we propose decomposition-transformer (DTrans), a trend-aware transformer variant that (1) embeds a learnable hierarchical decomposition layer in each encoder / decoder block to separate trend and seasonal components; (2) adopts a value–delta dual-output paradigm to predict both absolute power and step-wise increments; and (3) uses an adaptive multi-objective loss to jointly optimize numerical accuracy and directional reliability. Empirical studies on benchmark wind-power datasets show that DTrans significantly outperforms mainstream baselines in MAE, RMSE and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> and achieves a 38.27% relative improvement in trend-consistency metrics, thereby offering a theoretically grounded and practically deployable solution to this enduring problem in renewable-energy forecasting.

title: Analogy-Augmented Uncertainty-aware Monocular Visual Odometry_supp1-3664426.pdf
authors: Jituo Li
abstract: Visual odometry (VO) is a critical component of autonomous robot systems, enabling precise pose estimation from visual inputs. Learning-based VO methods are increasingly recognized for their robustness in challenging scenarios, including dynamic environments, motion blur, and low-light conditions. However, their performance is constrained by both the diversity of the data and its utilization rate. To overcome these limitations, we propose an end-to-end monocular VO system incorporating a novel learning-based end-to-end VO framework and multiple analogy augmentation strategies. We introduce the Context Attention Uncertainty-aware VO Network (CUVO), which prioritizes semantically rich regions and mitigating interference from high-uncertainty areas to enhance attentional focus and pose estimation accuracy. Furthermore, our analogy augmentation methods—temporal reversal, random rotation, and geometric mirroring—enhance image pairs and compute corresponding true pose transformations, significantly increasing training data quantity and diversity. Simultaneously, an analogous loss is applied to ensure consistency between the original and augmented data. Extensive experiments demonstrate that CUVO significantly enhances VO performance, outperforming previous end-to-end VO methods on TartanAir and KITTI datasets. By leveraging analogy augmentation strategy to expand training data under limited data conditions (27k), zero-shot capability of CUVO degrades by up to 29.5% on TartanAir and 23.3% on KITTI. Our work introduces the first image-to-pose data augmentation method tailored for VO and establishes CUVO as a robust system for advancing learning-based visual odometry.

title: Ultra-Compact Humidity Sensor Based on Twin-Core Fiber Tip Integrated Dual Microcavities
authors: Xin Lv, Zhihai Liu, Xiaoting Wu, Zhuo Ren, Xuhao Ji, Wei Jin, Yu Zhang
abstract: While conventional optical fiber humidity sensors offer high sensitivity and stability, their size limits their application in narrow spaces. To overcome the limitation, this paper presents an ultra-compact fiber humidity sensor fabricated via 3D printing. It integrates a monolithic dual Fabry–Perot (F–P) microcavity structure at the tip of a twin-core fiber (TCF). The sensor utilizes a low humidity-sensitive photopolymer to form the structural frame and the reference cavity(A) and utilizes a humidity-sensitive hydrogel to act as the sensing layer in the sensing cavity(B). Humidity changes cause significant deformation of the hydrogel, resulting in a much greater change in the cavity length of cavity B compared to cavity A. By precisely controlling the cavity lengths to 43 μm (Cavity A) and 39.5 μm (Cavity B), the sensor can harness the Vernier effect to achieve a significant sensitivity enhancement. Experimental results demonstrate a high sensitivity of -4.056 nm/%RH over a relative humidity (RH) range of 32.8% to 85.1%. Furthermore, the sensor also exhibits a temperature sensitivity of -0.35 nm/°C, with response times of 508 ms and 583 ms during humidification and dehumidification processes, respectively. This work provides a practical solution for high-sensitivity gaseous humidity detection in narrow and confined spaces.

title: An Active Tangential Electric Field Probe for Switching Noise Diagnosis in Power Modules
authors: Zhiqiang Yi, Linyan Li, Shuaibing Guo, Zhanjun Huang, Litao Ruan, Hui Li, Zhizhe Wang, E Shao, Yunlei Shi, Maning Zhang, Weiheng Shao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Components, Packaging and Manufacturing Technology
abstract: Wide-band-gap semiconductors have brought about a revolution in the speed of power electronic switching, but electromagnetic interference has become a new burden. In this paper, we present a tangential electric field probe dedicated to the diagnosis of power electron electromagnetic noise. The proposed probe adopts four-layer printed circuit board technology and can measure the Ex or Ey of the tangential electric field. The detection structure adopts enhanced dipole and differential amplifier with a 20 dB gain to improve the detection sensitivity. Through the measurement results, the proposed probe can operate from 100 kHz to 4.6 GHz, which is just right for power circuits. Its unwanted field suppression is above 10 dB, and maximum frequency response reach -25.8 dB at 0.65 GHz. The measurement results of a typical GaN power module demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed probe.

title: Conservative Linear Envelopes for Nonlinear, High-Dimensional, Hamilton-Jacobi Reachability_supp1-3661791.pdf
authors: William Sharpless
abstract: Hamilton-Jacobi reachability (HJR) provides a value function that encodes the set of states from which a system with bounded control inputs can reach or avoid a target despite any bounded disturbance, and the corresponding robust, optimal control policy. Though powerful, traditional methods for HJR rely on dynamic programming (DP) and suffer from exponential computation growth with respect to state dimension. The recently favored Hopf formula mitigates this “curse of dimensionality” by providing an efficient and pointwise approach for solving the reachability problem. However, the Hopf formula can only be applied to linear time-varying systems. To overcome this limitation, we show that the error between a nonlinear system and a linear model can be transformed into an adversarial bounded artificial disturbance. One may then solve the dimension-robust generalized Hopf formula for a linear game with this “antagonistic error” to perform guaranteed conservative reachability analysis and control synthesis of nonlinear systems; this can be done for problem formulations in which no other HJR method is both computationally feasible and guaranteed. In addition, we offer several technical methods for reducing conservativeness in the analysis. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our results through one illustrative example (the controlled Van der Pol system) that can be compared to standard DP, and one higher-dimensional 15D example (a 5-agent pursuit-evasion game with Dubins cars).

title: Identification of Periodic Sensor-Reading Modification Attacks in Cyber-Physical Systems
authors: Wenli Duo, Shouguang Wang, Meng Chu Zhou
abstract: Cyber-physical systems are extensively utilized in industry and critical infrastructures due to their ability to facilitate mutual cooperation and interaction between physical and virtual worlds. Nevertheless, their security has been increasingly threatened by cyber-attacks. Motivated by the need to address the resulting security concerns, this work studies a class of periodic sensor attacks that periodically modify sensor-readings to disrupt the performance of remote estimators in a system. After analyzing system behavior under such attacks based on discrete event systems, we focus on identifying malicious modifications on each event. In particular, we formalize the concept of modification identifiability under attacks, which indicates whether any modification can be uniquely identified in finite observations. Its verification problem is addressed by developing a novel state estimator.

title: Power Optimization in RIS-assisted SWIPT-IoT System with Discrete Phase Shift
authors: Neha Sharma, Sumit Gautam, Symeon Chatzinotas, Björn Ottersten
abstract: The integration of reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RIS) and simultaneous wireless information and power transfer (SWIPT) present a promising solution for sustainable and efficient wireless communications in large-scale IoT networks, especially within energy-constrained smart agriculture applications. However, most existing works assume ideal energy harvesting (EH) models and continuous RIS phase shifts that limit their practical relevance. This paper addresses these limitations by proposing a total transmit power minimization framework for a multi-user RIS-assisted MISO power-splitting (PS) SWIPT system. First, a practical logistic non-linear energy harvesting (NL-EH) model is adopted to better reflect the realistic behavior of RF energy conversion circuits. Second, a discrete phase shift (DPS) model with finite quantization levels is employed to account for practical RIS hardware constraints. Third, an alternating optimization algorithm is developed for the resulting non-convex optimization problem through joint optimization of the base station’s beamforming vectors, RIS reflection matrix, and PS ratio. Techniques such as Zero-Forcing (ZF), Semidefinite Relaxation (SDR), and Gaussian randomization (GR) are leveraged to address the associated sub-problems, while an alternate one-dimensional search strategy is used for RIS phase shift optimization. Finally, numerical simulations are conducted to validate the proposed framework in terms of performance and convergence. The results demonstrate robustness under imperfect channel state information (ICSI) and varying system parameters for next-generation IoT-enabled smart farming use-case.

title: Research on Base Station Energy-Saving Optimization Method Integrating Spatial Features and Temporal Modeling
authors: Linwei Jiang, Lika Li, Qian Wang, Huanhao Zeng, Baihong Xie, Zhenlin Qin
abstract: As mobile communication networks continue to scale, energy-saving optimization for base stations is increasingly constrained by the need for fine-grained, timely decision-making under complex and dynamic operating conditions. In practical deployments, the effectiveness and stability of existing energy-saving strategies are primarily limited by two factors: (i) the lack of high-precision and frequently updated base station scene labels that accurately reflect heterogeneous service environments, and (ii) the prohibitive computational cost of modeling complete annual traffic patterns for large-scale networks, which forces most solutions to rely on short-term or sampled data, thereby weakening their ability to capture long-term traffic regularities. The combination of these issues restricts achievable energy-saving depth and undermines operational stability. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a scenario-aware energy-saving optimization framework that integrates semantic scene perception with long-term spatio-temporal traffic modeling. First, fine-grained and dynamically updated scene labels are generated through the fusion of natural language processing on configuration texts and cloud-based geographic map image recognition, enabling accurate characterization of base station service environments without manual annotation. Second, a GeoAutoformer-Transformer model is developed by embedding geographic-aware graph attention into a decompositionbased Transformer architecture, allowing the model to efficiently learn long-term temporal patterns and spatial dependencies among neighboring base stations while remaining computationally tractable for large-scale deployments. In addition, a masking mechanism is introduced to explicitly distinguish between normal zero-traffic intervals caused by energy-saving shutdowns and abnormal zero values resulting from data loss or transmission failures, thereby improving the robustness and reliability of traffic prediction and subsequent energy-saving decisions. Through jointly extending effective energy-saving durations and recommending more suitable energy-saving strategies for eligible base stations, the proposed framework achieves a 17–19% improvement in overall energy-saving efficiency. At the same time, more accurate scene perception and comprehensive traffic modeling contribute to more stable network excellence rates and reduced negative feedback, indicating improved operational reliability. Extensive experiments conducted on a large-scale real-world dataset comprising approximately 50,000 base stations from a nationwide commercial network demonstrate the effectiveness and general applicability of the proposed framework across diverse geographic regions and service scenarios.

title: A Four-Phase Spatio-Temporal and Quantum-Enhanced Framework for Traffic Speed Forecasting with Calibrated Uncertainty
authors: Shishir Singh Chauhan, Vijay Kumar Jha, Gauri Shankar Gupta
abstract: Short-term forecasting of traffic speeds is a foundational requirement for adaptive signal control, congestion mitigation, and emerging real-time digital twin infrastructures. Despite substantial progress, many deep learning approaches continue to experience difficulties in capturing long-range temporal behavior, handling non-stationary traffic conditions, and producing reliable measures of predictive uncertainty. To address these challenges, this work develops a four-stage hybrid spatio-temporal framework consisting of: (i) a graph-attention spatial encoder, (ii) a temporal Transformer module, (iii) a variational quantum fusion layer, and (iv) a conformal calibration component for uncertainty adjustment. In all our experiments we used the METR-LA benchmark which we did in order to maintain the like conditions for method and empiric study. In the put forth pipeline the Transformer which we introduced in Phase 2 does the best job in terms of point forecast accuracy, we see Mean Absolute Error (MAE) values of 3.46, 3.68, and 3.76 for the 5, 10 and 15 minute prediction horizons which is a 50% or greater improvement over the Spatial-Temporal Graph Attention Network (ST-GAT) base. In Phase 3 we looked at the quantumaugmented version which did see a small improvement at the short term horizon but as the time horizon increased we saw a slight drop in performance which we note is a common issue in present variational quantum circuits. Conformal calibration for uncertainty estimation produces prediction intervals with empirical coverage of 92.8%, significantly outperforming ensemble-based and Monte Carlo Dropout (MC-Dropout) methods. On an RTX-class Graphical Processing Unit (GPU), end-to-end inference takes about 150-250 ms, which is compatible with real-time operational requirements in intelligent transportation systems. A configuration with four attention heads, a one-hour historical input window, and a thirty-minute model update interval provides a workable trade-off between accuracy and computational cost, according to sensitivity analyses based on MAE and Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) combined with latency monitoring. Overall, the findings show that the suggested framework facilitates accurate traffic speed forecasting with calibrated uncertainty, allowing for more timely and informed decision-making in urban mobility applications.
