title: BAG: Body-Aligned 3D Wearable Asset Generation
authors: Zhongjin Luo, Yang Li, Mingrui Zhang, Senbo Wang, Han Yan, Xibin Song, Taizhang Shang, Wei Mao, Hongdong Li, Xiaoguang Han, Pan Ji
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: While recent advancements have demonstrated remarkable progress in general 3D shape generation, the challenge of automatically generating wearable 3D assets remains largely unexplored. To address this gap, we present BAG — a Body aligned Asset Generation method that produces 3D wearable assets which can be automatically fitted onto given 3D human bodies. This is achieved by controlling the 3D generation process using human body shape and pose information. Specifically, we first construct a general single-image-to-consistent-multi-view diffusion model, and train it on the large-scale Objaverse dataset to ensure diversity and generalizability. We then train a body conditioned multi-view ControlNet to guide the generator toward producing body-aligned multi-view images. The control signal leverages multi-view 2D projections of the target human body, where pixel values represent the XYZ coordinates of the body surface in a canonical space. The resulting body-conditioned multi-view diffusion outputs body-aligned images, which are subsequently fed into a native 3D diffusion model to reconstruct the 3D shape of the asset. Finally, we recover the similarity trans formation using multi-view silhouette supervision and mitigate asset-body penetration using physics-based simulation, ensuring accurate asset fitting onto the target body. Experimental results demonstrate that our method significantly outperforms existing approaches in terms of prompt adherence, shape diversity, and shape quality.

title: Modeling and Experimental Characterization of Microwave Propagation Properties in Laser-Induced Solid-State Plasma in Silicon Waveguides at 140-220 GHz
authors: Mehrdad Rezaei Golghand, Alireza Madannejad, Umer Shah, Nikolaos Xenidis, Joachim Oberhammer
abstract: This paper presents the modeling and experimental characterization of the microwave properties of laser-induced solid-state plasma in silicon dielectric waveguides at 140-220 GHz. Lasers with wavelengths of 1550, 1064, 980, 852, 785, 685, 520, and 405 nm are used at different laser intensities to investigate their effects on electromagnetic wave propagation. An improved analytical model is developed to accurately predict the behavior of laser-induced solid-state plasma, taking into account wavelength and intensity-dependent excess carrier generation, and the resulting depth-dependent conductivity and permittivity. The analytical results are implemented in a multi-layer simulation model in CST Studio Suite to simulate full-wave electromagnetic propagation. The 980 nm laser achieves the largest attenuation, reaching up to 67 dB at 20 W/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> at 200 GHz. The simulation results show excellent agreement with experimental measurements, confirming the validity the analytical and simulation models.

title: Two-Dimensional Vertical Photonic Crystal Waveguide Array for Multi-Analyte Mid-Infrared Sensing
authors: May Hlaing, Sourabh Jain, Kang-Chieh Fan, Jason Midkiff, Ray T Chen
abstract: Two-dimensional photonic crystal waveguides (PCWs) enhance light–matter interactions through slow-light effects and resonant field confinement. We report the design, simulation, and experimental realization of silicon VPCW arrays exhibiting dual mid-infrared (mid-IR) resonances: a symmetric Lorentzian-type and an asymmetric Fano-type resonance. Each VPCW is formed by introducing a hollow air-core defect into a hexagonal lattice of deeply etched air holes in silicon. By tuning the defect radius and lattice constant, these resonances were aligned with the absorption lines of acetaldehyde (C<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>H<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</sub>O) (λ ≈ 5.88 μm) and water vapor (H<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>O) (λ ≈ 6.05 μm), enabling multiplexed gas detection. Simulations predicted large group indices (n<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">g</sub> ≈ 1064 for C<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>H<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</sub>O and n<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">g</sub> ≈ 204 for H<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>O), consistent with slow-light features. Experimentally, Lorentzian and Fano resonances were observed, with linewidth broadening attributed to fabrication imperfections, at photonic band-edge wavelengths where slow-light modes are expected. This work demonstrates the first realization of dual Lorentzian–Fano resonances in VPCWs under normal-incidence light excitation, establishing a CMOS-compatible platform for compact mid-IR absorption spectroscopy and multiplexed gas sensing.

title: High-Precision Resolver-to-Digital Conversion via Composite PLL with Noise Reduction
authors: Peng Liu, Zhong Wu, Yuewei Hu
abstract: high precision servo systems, phase-locked loops (PLLs) with feedforward compensation can simultaneously ensure dynamic performance and steady-state accuracy in extracting the information of angular position and speed from sinusoidal signals. However, these composite PLLs can not effectively suppress the effect of measurement noise on the estimated speed and the estimation accuracy may be seriously deteriorated. In this paper, a noise reduction composite PLL is proposed for resolver-to-digital converters (RDCs) to prevent the measurement noise from polluting the estimated speed with higher comprehensive accuracy. The proposed method consists of two tracking loops. The main loop adopts a noise reduction PLL (NRPLL) to track the angular position in resolver signals and output angular speed with enhanced noise immunity and high steady-state accuracy. The secondary loop adopts an angle-tracking observer (ATO) to generate feedforward speed since it can effectively suppress measurement noise in estimating speed. Thus, the proposed method combines the advantages of NRPLL and ATO in noise reduction and also can improve dynamic performance and steady-state accuracy by using feedforward. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Modeling and Calibration of Posture-Dependent Denavit-Hartenberg Errors and Angular Positioning Deviations of a Six-Axis Robotic Manipulator
authors: Tianhao Cui, Soichi Ibaraki
abstract: Prediction accuracy of a kinematic model is critical for offline compensation of volumetric errors of a six-axis robotic manipulator. Numerous scholars have employed kinematic models incorporating Denavit-Hartenberg (D-H) errors for offline compensation, and some have studied their enhancements by integrating stiffness parameters of rotary axes. However, previous works primarily focused on predicting deviations resulting from posture changes within the rotary plane. This article proposes a novel modeling scheme capable of capturing deviations both within and outside the rotary plane. A key idea is that, instead of explicitly measuring the 6 DOF stiffness parameters, the end effector trajectory is measured to quantify the position and orientation of the rotary axis average line, varied due to the posture of downstream axes, which are parameterized as posture-dependent D-H errors and posture-dependent angular positioning deviations. Measurement for the calibration of posture-dependent errors can be completed within one hour. A case study shows that the proposed posture-dependent kinematic model can significantly improve the prediction accuracy by over 36%, highlighting the importance of including posture-dependent errors.

title: A High-Voltage-Gain Three-Port DC–DC Converter With Reduced Semiconductor Stress and Low Input Current Ripple
authors: Xianjun Chen, Mingzhu Zhou, Peiyao Rao, Ronghuan Xie, Yang Yi, Yizhan Zhuang, Yiming Zhang
abstract: In the DC microgrid system, the efficient integration of renewable energy source (RES), energy storage units, and loads is critical to the stable operation of the system. This article proposes a high-voltage-gain three-port DC–DC converter with reduced semiconductor stress and low input current ripple. This converter employs coupled-inductor and switched-capacitor boost mechanism, incorporating a bidirectional power storage port. The converter offers the advantages of high-voltage-gain and low-input current ripple, while significantly reducing the voltage stress on the switches and diodes. The output voltage can be flexibly adjusted by varying the duty ratio of the switch and the turns ratio of the coupled-inductor. Finally, a 50-kHz 200-W experimental prototype with a 38-V RES voltage, a 76-V battery voltage, and a 380-V load voltage is built to validate the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed converter.

title: A time series based comprehensive energy optimization and scheduling method for carbon neutral energy storage
authors: Weiwei Zhang, Yongliang Yin, Chenbo Xu, Qinyu Chen, Kun Wang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: A single time scale cannot effectively correspond to hourly and daily scheduling problems, making it difficult to adapt to the differences in time scales of different energy sources. Therefore, a comprehensive energy optimization scheduling method for carbon neutral energy storage based on time series is proposed. The integrated energy system includes energy input, conversion, and energy storage equipment. Under the assumption of steady state and without considering line losses, an energy hub state model is constructed. Using time series linear analysis to process data, calculate the slope of the characteristic curve to obtain the frequency change, and then analyze the frequency modulation characteristics. Construct an optimization scheduling model with the optimization objectives of meeting user electricity and heat load demands, achieving carbon emission reduction targets, and minimizing total system operating costs. The experimental results show that the proposed method has a large actual output of wind power during low load periods (such as 01:00-05:00), with a total cost of 2157209 yuan, achieving zero wind and solar power curtailment, and the fluctuation rate of interconnection line interaction power is less than 5%. And through energy storage, peak shaving, valley filling, and full absorption of wind and solar energy, fossil energy consumption can be reduced, system carbon emissions can be lowered, and technical support can be provided for the transformation of comprehensive energy systems towards carbon neutrality.

title: Design and Performance Analysis of Silicon Photonic Ring Resonators for High-Speed Modulation
authors: Ambuj Kumar Agarwal, Subhra Kulshrestha, Garima Saini, Nitin Rakesh, Neema Gupta, Bhupesh Kumar Dewangan
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: A search has found a new promising device in form of silicon photonic ring resonators (RRs) that are used to modulate optical circuits at high speed. They are small, CMOS compatible and can accommodate advanced modulation schemes making them to be ideal in the next generation optical communication systems. In this paper, the design methodology, mathematical modeling, and performance analysis of silicon photonic ring resonators to high-speed modulation have been provided. Analytical equations of resonance conditions and modulation response are obtained and results of simulation are checked by using performance measuring parameters including quality factor, extinction ratio and bandwidth. The paper brings to the fore; the trade-offs between the resonator geometry and the modulation efficiency, which provides an idea on how to achieve optimal photonic integrated circuits.

title: NLP-based Cyber Threat Data Analysis with MITRE ATT&CK Techniques
authors: Haochen Zhang, Haoyang Hong, Binghan Shen, Marlon Esteban Brenes Rojas, Ezzeldin Tahoun, Umme Zakia
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: Recognizing and classifying attacks, threats and actors plays vital role in cyber threat intelligence (CTI). Analyzing potential threats correctly require adequate knowledge, experience and resources. Most enterprises do not have a clear classification plan after the cyberattacks to detect or prevent future threats. In this paper, we examined effective categorizing of the attacks through MITRE ATT&CK's classification to provide targeted protective measures. This article describes classifying cyberattacks via manual labeling and automated labeling process using a machine learning approach, i.e., the BiLSTM classifier, RF and LGBM model by describing them through the MITRE ATT&CK framework. Both the BiLSTM and the RF model obtained accuracies around 56%-62% while the LGBM classifier obtained higher accuracy of 99% in categorizing cyber threats and warnings using natural language processing. The ML approach can help faster automated labeling and creating good repository of MITRE ATT&CK for organizations and professionals in CTI process.

title: API Guardian: An Educational and Experimental Tool for Learning and Teaching the Verification and Validation of RESTful API Endpoints
authors: Joy Yee Shing Cheng, Francis Teo Ee Cheok, Peter ChunYu Yau
abstract: API Guardian is a Visual Studio Code extension designed to streamline the process of verifying and validating RESTful API endpoints within a software project. The tool aims to minimize manual debugging and testing time, while also reducing dependence on outdated API documentation. While tools like Postman and ThunderClient are commonly used by software developers, participants in the study noted certain drawbacks, such as Postman’s complexity and ThunderClient’s shift from a free to a paid service. In this research, participants tested RESTful APIs using both API Guardian and Postman, then completed a post-survey to share their feedback. The results revealed that API Guardian was able to retrieve and test an API in an average of 3.26 seconds, while Postman took 10 seconds to perform the same task. Overall, participants expressed a preference for API Guardian over Postman, citing problems with accessibility and convenience.

title: An Evaluation Study on the Information Technology Application Competence of High School Physics Teachers in Smart Classrooms: Construction of an Event-Reason Graph Based on Lag Sequential Analysis
authors: Zhibin Tong, Yuxin Luo, Xiaoyu Zhang
abstract: In the context of the digital transformation in education, teachers' information technology application competence is pivotal for classroom innovation. Behavioral sequence analysis provides a new way to overcome the limits of static assessments. It captures how technology is used dynamically in smart classrooms and how it supports students' core competencies. This method is particularly well-suited for the in-depth inquiry required in the high school physics curriculum. This study utilizes LSA to analyze five video recordings of high school physics lessons from the Zhejiang Provincial Teaching and Research Network. By constructing an event-reason graph of technological application behaviors, the research aims to unveil the dynamic logic of teacher-student interactions and evaluate teachers' information technology application competence. The findings indicate that while teachers demonstrate strong capabilities in the knowledge transmission phase, deficiencies exist in the cultivation of core competencies. Specifically, the analysis reveals: a disconnect between the introduction of technology and the stimulation of students' problem-awareness; an imbalance between collaborative support and the depth of inquiry; a gap between knowledge integration and interactive thinking; and a rupture between contextual application and innovative practice. In response to the issues mentioned above, this study further proposes the specific teaching strategies of problem-based inquiry, inquiry scaffolding, thinking visualization, and project-based practice. This research reveals the intrinsic connections between the sequences of technology-supported behaviors, specific teaching stages, and the development of student competencies. It provides empirical support for guiding high school physics teachers toward more profound instructional design, thereby transforming technology from a mere tool into a foundational support for student competency development.

title: BCI-Mediated Unusual Storytelling for Enhancing Deep Attention in Higher Education
authors: Amiao Wu, Xingwen Hu
abstract: Cultivating sustained attention in university students poses a persistent challenge for brain-computer interface (BCI)-enhanced education. In the realm of higher education, the importance of fostering focused attention is paramount for learning in depth. While the cultivation of a mode of concentration through a narrative perspective has gained attention in recent years, very little has been said on unusual storytelling texts in fostering deep attention. This study introduces a novel approach that integrates paradoxical Zen koan storytelling with real-time BCI neurofeedback to enhance attentional engagement and promote learning in depth. Using a pedagogical framework modulated by electroencephalography (EEG) feedback, we evaluate its efficacy through experiments engaging students with unusual koan storytelling. The research reveals that reading koans based on BCI mediation can generate greater cognitive tension that promotes meditative focus compared to conventional narrative scripts. Preliminary findings suggest improved attentional state metrics relative to the baseline measurements.

title: Five Dimensions and Four Integrations: A Study on the Competency Model and Innovative Training Paradigm for Top AI Talent
authors: Xin Wang, Haowen Chen
abstract: With the rapid advancement of artificial intelligence technology, the demand for outstanding and innovative talents in this field is becoming increasingly urgent across various industries. This paper focuses on the characteristics of outstanding and innovative talents in AI, constructing a capability model that includes five dimensions: learning ability, thinking ability, practical ability, communication ability, and influence. It proposes a ‘four-integration’ model for cultivating outstanding and innovative talents in AI, aiming to foster more high-quality, innovative talents in the AI field by reforming the training model, thereby driving technological progress and industrial transformation through talent development.

title: RadScheduler: Proactive Resource Scaling for Kubernetes-based RADIUS Authentication Services
authors: Jui-Hsuan Chang, Jerry Chou
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Software Engineering and Service Science (ICSESS)
abstract: RADIUS authentication services face significant challenges in handling variable loads during predictable peak periods. Traditional Kubernetes HPA relies on reactive metrics, causing performance degradation between load increase and pod readiness. This paper presents RadScheduler, a predictive autoscaling system that leverages historical authentication patterns to proactively scale resources. Using one year of production RADIUS logs from National Tsing Hua University, we identify strong temporal patterns and develop a lightweight prediction model based on historical averaging. Our approach achieves 0.975 R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> Score with 0.6ms inference time. Experimental evaluation demonstrates that predictive scaling reduces 95th percentile latency by up to 69.7% during peak hours compared to reactive CPU-based HPA. Rad-Scheduler provides a practical blueprint for domain-specific predictive autoscaling, demonstrating that simple approaches aligned with the problem domain can outperform complex machine learning models.

title: Edge-Assisted LoRa–Optical Hybrid Communication Model for Ultra-Low-Power Smart Metering Systems
authors: Sarvar Makhmudjanov, Arzieva Jamila Tileubaevna, Devender Kumar, Doniyor Yakhshibaev, Gagandeep Kaur
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: The deployment of smart meters needs long-life end nodes with ultraslow power and a strong uplink connection to the collection points. This paper presents an edge-assisted hybrid communication model, which integrates LoRa (sub-GHz low-power long-range radio) on the downlink and a shortrange visible/infrared optical uplink on the uplink, triggered opportunistically to offload traffic and decrease the energy per presented bit. The architecture puts lightweight intelligence in edge gateways of micro-scale to coordinate channel access, plan an energy-efficient optical burst schedule, and even aggregate and compress data before sending it to the cloud. We propose the system model, power and latency performance, a medium access scheme which leverages the periods of the smart meter traffic and performance analysis through simulation with the comparison of the hybrid model to LoRa-only reference points. Results show that the hybrid model can reduce average energy consumption per meter transmission by up to 38% and decrease network congestion under high device density while preserving delivery reliability above 99% in typical urban scenarios. We will complete with design recommendation and deployment considerations of utility-scales rollouts.

title: Atomic Oxygen Erosion Failure Mechanism and Performance Control Method of Polyimide Insulation in Space Motor Windings
authors: Guanglin Yu, Zhang Li, Junpeng Ji, Wang Guan, Shengrui Zhou
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: Space motor windings commonly utilize polyimide (PI) as an insulating material. In the extreme conditions of space, continuous exposure to reactive species can degrade the insulating properties of polyimide, potentially leading to insulation failures in space motors. Currently, research into the failure mechanisms and mitigation strategies of polyimide under atomic oxygen (AO) erosion in extreme space environments remains insufficiently explored. To investigate the degradation mechanisms of polyimide solid insulation materials under the bombardment of atomic oxygen in the presence of an electric field, molecular dynamics simulations were employed to model the erosion process of polyimide subjected to AO.This study, utilizing molecular dynamics, examines the degradation characteristics of polyimide at the nanoscale under atomic oxygen erosion. Simulations were conducted using Large-scale Atomic/Molecular Massively Parallel Simulator (LAMMPS) in conjunction with the ReaxFF reactive force field, where AO with an energy of 5 eV was directed at the polyimide. Based on the oxidation reaction mechanisms, the reaction processes and changes in material mass were analyzed. The erosion results indicate that the polyimide undergoes rapid cleavage during the AO erosion process, leading to a significant decrease in molecular mass and a deterioration of its insulating properties. Furthermore, the study reveals that the extent of damage to polyimide increases with higher electric field strengths, resulting in greater mass loss and a more severe reduction in breakdown field strength.

title: Hybrid FSO–Satellite Architecture for Remote Monitoring Networks: Analysis and Evaluation
authors: Dilmurod Davronbekov, Alisher Khayrullaev, Jamshid Isroilov, Akrom Sharopov
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: Remote sensing of objects in remote locations with poor geographical topography entails the need to employ credible, high capacity, information exchange as well as employing communication infrastructure using energy efficient network equipment. This paper suggests a hybrid network design that will utilize both free as well as space optical (FSO) communications and satellite networks to eliminate these constraints. The hybrid architecture takes advantage of fast FSO network and satellite fragments in order to form a large communication area in different unfavorable weather conditions so that the transmission and reception of communication signals can remain stable at a distance throughout the entire chain during remote monitoring. Performance indicators were used to test the reliability of the proposal and these include channel bandwidth, communication-signal delay time, packet delivery rate, bit error rate, and signal-to-noise ratio. The SNR or BER model was used to evaluate the state of communication channel (fading, FSPL and AWGN) of each packet transmitted and the likelihood of a successful delivery of a packet based on the simulation study results conducted using Matlab.

title: Research on Distribution System Resilience Enhancement Utilizing Mobile Resources to Improve Substation Supply Capacity
authors: Huashen Liu, Guodong Zhu, Huan Wang, Yongyi Li, Yanwen Li, Lei Shi
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: Against the backdrop of a high proportion of new energy sources being connected and the widespread application of flexible loads, the volatility in low-voltage distribution substation areas has significantly increased, posing new challenges to the stability of the power grid. To address this issue, this study proposes an enhancement strategy for the supply capability of transformer substations based on mobile resources, aiming to enhance the resilience of the distribution system. Firstly, a road network mobility model considering road connectivity and traffic congestion conditions was constructed. Subsequently, detailed constraints were applied to the energy characteristics of diversified mobile modular equipment, such as mobile energy storage systems and electric vehicles. Furthermore, by synergistically optimizing the mobile device movement model within the road network and the power grid flow model, a novel distribution system resilience enhancement model has been developed. This model aims to effectively utilize mobile resources to enhance the supply capacity of substations. The verification results demonstrate that through the collaborative optimization of multiple mobile modular devices, the resilience of the distribution system is significantly enhanced, effectively alleviating the overload pressure on substations caused by distribution line faults and substantially reducing post-disaster recovery time.

title: From Detection to Action: A Concept-Based Framework to Reduce Dwell Time in IT Infrastructure
authors: Richa Trivedi
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: Modern information systems face persistent threats wherein adversaries often remain undetected for extended periods, with average breach costs exceeding USD 4.88 million and containment times surpassing 200 days across industries [1], [2]. Existing Security Information and Event Management (SIEM), Endpoint Detection and Response (EDR), and Security Orchestration, Automation and Response (SOAR) solutions improve visibility yet exhibit weak linkage between detection and mitigation, prolonging dwell time. This paper presents the Detection-to-Action (D2A) Framework, a concept-based architecture that integrates hybrid detection—signatures for known threats and anomaly analysis for unknown behaviors—with tiered, default-safe mitigation playbooks and a continuous feedback loop. Evaluation in a simulated enterprise environment of 200 users and 20 servers demonstrated 92% detection accuracy, a 35% reduction in false positives, and containment time improvement from over 200 minutes to approximately 10 minutes. By bridging detection and response within existing infrastructures, D2A enables measurable reductions in dwell time and establishes a scalable, auditable path toward proactive cybersecurity operations [3], [4].

title: Generative Artificial Intelligence Enabled STEM Learning: Community Garden Practices and Insights
authors: Dehang Zheng, Rong Zhang, Ziyi Cheng, Xiaojun Xia
abstract: This study investigates the integration of generative artificial intelligence (GenAI) in STEM education within community garden ecosystems. Using case studies and questionnaire surveys, it analyzes how GenAI facilitates interdisciplinary and STEM learning mechanisms. Two key practice cases illustrate its efficacy in constructing interdisciplinary contexts and advancing STEM engagement. Findings indicate that GenAI enhances students’ STEM interest, knowledge application, and innovative capabilities, although challenges such as technical instability remain. Future developments will prioritize intelligent and personalized pathways to drive educational transformation.

title: Intelligent Monitoring and Power Management of Optical Telecommunication Networks Using Artificial Intelligence
authors: Amurova Natalia Yurievna
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: The paper will explore the creative uses of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Big Data analytics in managing and monitoring power supply in optical communication networks. DWDM and OTN nodes, as well as optical amplifiers, need to be powered in a stable and energy-efficient manner, which is not always guaranteed in conditions of growing traffic demands by traditional means. AI-applications offer real-time control, anticipatory failure detection, dynamic load allocation, and seamless incorporation with renewable energy resources. The literature review of the international best practice and its applicability to the Telecommunication infrastructure in Uzbekistan is presented. The suggested solutions contribute to the reliability, energy-efficiency, and sustainability of the optical networks in line with the global trends of digital transformation and green technologies.

title: An Empirical Study on the Teaching Effectiveness of Intelligent Adaptive Systems for Enhancing Students' Core Competences in Mathematics
authors: Guolong Quan, Tingting Zhang, Huimin Zhu, Ya Luo, Ying Wu
abstract: The use of adaptive technology to support and promote teaching and learning has always been a concern in modern educational research and practice. The update of curriculum standards oriented by core competences in disciplines and the development of digital intelligent technology provide reasons and opportunities for the design update and technological upgrade of adaptive systems in educational applications, and also make their application effects more scientific, dynamic, and humanized. To further explore the teaching effectiveness of the new intelligent adaptive system, this study applied it to primary school mathematics teaching. It analyzed the changes in students' mathematics scores and core competences in mathematics through experimental comparison. 170 fifth-grade students participated in the one-year research project. The study adopted a quasi-experimental method with two groups to observe the impact of the intelligent adaptive system on students' mathematics scores. And it used an interrupted time-series method to test its effectiveness on students' core competences in mathematics. The results show that: (1) the application of the intelligent adaptive system can improve the mathematics scores of middle - level students, t(115) = - 2.284, p<0.05; (2) after using the intelligent adaptive system, the change in students' core competences in mathematics is significant, in which the system usage time in the first semester can explain the variance by 21.5% (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.215, F(1,232) = 63.375, p<0.001), and the system usage time in the second semester can explain the variance by 89.7% (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.897, F(1,233) = 2021.555, p<0.001). The study provides empirical support for the promotion of the intelligent adaptive system in mathematics teaching and an operational framework for its practical application, which is of great practical significance and value for promoting the digital and intelligent transformation of education.

title: Fault Location Method for Distribution Networks with Distributed Power Sources Based on Improved Binary Particle Swarm Optimization Algorithm
authors: Hui Jiang, Chengrui Hua, Jialong Li, Wenqiang Hao, Yinhao Kou
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: As a substantial amount of green and environmentally friendly energy sources, such as wind power generation and photovoltaic power generation, are connected to the distribution network in the form of distributed generation (DG), the power flow direction and topological structure of the distribution network will change accordingly due to the integration of DG. This situation renders traditional fault location methods less effective. Therefore, regarding the issue of fault section location in distribution networks containing DG, this paper puts forward a fault location method based on an improved binary particle swarm optimization (BPSO) algorithm. A mathematical model of the fault section in the distribution network is constructed. Moreover, simulations are carried out in the IEEE 33 - node system for scenarios including single faults, multiple faults, and cases where location information is distorted in distribution lines. These simulations verify the rapidity and accuracy of the proposed algorithm.

title: Electromagnetic Ultrasonic Measurement of Bolt Axial Stress Using Barker-Coded Pulse Compression: Modeling and Simulation
authors: Zhixun Lei, Yuedong Xie, Fulu Liu, Yu Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: Bolts are critical to power systems and pipeline infrastructure, and their axial stress is indicative of joint integrity. To address the low signal-to-noise ratio of echoes in electromagnetic ultrasonic stress measurement of bolts, a finite element analysis model incorporating Barker-coded pulse compression is developed. The analysis examines ultrasonic propagation under varying axial stress states. A 7-bit Barker-coded sinusoid is used as the electromagnetic ultrasonic excitation current, and the echoes are processed by pulse compression. Compared with windowed-sine excitation, the method increases the signal-to-noise ratio by 10 dB and enables rapid, non-contact stress measurement in bolts.

title: Mitigating Cryptocurrency Misuse: A Survey with a Cross-Domain Adaptive Framework
authors: Vaibhavi Tiwari, Venkata Sai Ram Dasari, Krishanu Agrawal
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: Blockchain enables decentralized, transparent, and tamper-resistant value transfer, yet the same properties also create avenues for misuse, including money laundering, ransomware payments, darknet trade, DeFi exploits, NFT wash trading, and sanctions evasion via stablecoins. This paper offers a comprehensive analysis that links blockchain’s foundational attributes—pseudonymity, immutability, and global accessibility—to observable misuse patterns, organizes the principal threat modes with empirical evidence, and evaluates mitigation across regulatory controls, technological advances, decentralized countermeasures, and industry practices. Building on comparative insights from federated learning, decentralized identity, and distributed storage, the paper then introduces the Cross-Domain Adaptive Mitigation Framework (CDAMF), a layered, privacy-preserving approach that combines reputation-backed accountability, anomaly-driven adaptive guardrails, and parametric backstops with community adjudication, with a feedback loop that updates reputations, thresholds, and models over time. An integrated architecture and event-time algorithm are presented to operationalize CDAMF while preserving decentralization. Together, the survey and framework provide a practical pathway to balance innovation, privacy, and security, strengthening trust, interoperability, and resilience in cryptocurrency ecosystems.

title: A Systematic Review of the Effectiveness of Adaptive Learning Systems in K-12 Education
authors: Yujie Song
abstract: This systematic review synthesizes evidence on the characteristics and effectiveness of adaptive learning systems in K-12 education. A total of 30 peer-reviewed empirical studies published between 2018 and 2024 were analyzed following PRISMA guidelines. Findings indicate that most research focuses on secondary education, particularly mathematics. Methodologically, quantitative or quasi-experimental methods are prioritized to measure students' academic achievement, engagement, and skills development. However, while adaptive learning technologies show positive effects, significant gaps include lacking sufficient research in early childhood education and interpretive subjects such as the arts or humanities. Additionally, few studies critically examine the design principles, algorithmic transparency, or ethical considerations of adaptive systems. From the theoretical perspective, constructivism, sociocultural theory, and self-determination theory are applied to reveal why older students in STEM domains may benefit more from adaptive learning systems. This review also highlights the need for more diverse and context-sensitive studies, particularly in under-resourced educational settings and creative disciplines. Therefore, future research should analyze how adaptive learning systems support equitable and student-centered learning experiences in varied K-12 contexts.

title: HyperSolver: A Practical Unified Framework for Large-Scale Combinatorial Optimization
authors: Parsa Abadi, Roberto Solis-Oba
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: We present HyperSolver, a unified hypergraph neural network framework for solving NP-hard combinatorial optimization problems using a single neural network architecture. Traditional approaches require different algorithms for each problem, while HyperSolver uses the same architecture across multiple minimization and maximization problems, including set cover, hitting set, subset sum, hypergraph max cut, and hypergraph multiway cut. We represent each problem instance as a hypergraph, where hyperedges can connect multiple nodes simultaneously to capture multi-element relationships directly. HyperSolver learns through unsupervised training using problem-specific loss functions without requiring pre-computed solutions or labeled training data. We evaluated HyperSolver on synthetic benchmark datasets with controlled structural parameters and compared its performance to commercial solvers, traditional heuristics, and existing hypergraph neural network methods. HyperSolver consistently computes high-quality solutions with significant speedups over exact methods, traditional heuristics, and competing neural approaches. The framework demonstrates effective knowledge transfer across problem types, where models trained on one problem accelerate training on different problems while maintaining solution quality. These results establish HyperSolver as a practical unified alternative to problem-specific solvers for large-scale combinatorial optimization.

title: Industry-Oriented Instructional Design for High-Frequency Electronic Circuits: —A Project-Based Approach Using FM Transceiver Prototyping
authors: Guoyan Duan, Qianhua Fu, Shuang Chen
abstract: This study develops an innovative PCVE (Preview-Collaboration-Virtual-Physical-Extension) teaching model based on the Occupation-Course-Competition-Certification (OCCC) framework for high-frequency electronic circuits course. Using F30-5 FM transceiver development as a project-based platform, we implemented a credit-based evaluation system that achieved: (1) significant increases in student engagement (50%→85%, p<0.01), (2) 100% attainment of three-dimensional learning objectives (from <70%), and (3) 10% of students exceeding extension task requirements. The approach demonstrated effective learning transfer to other courses , confirming its spiral progression benefits for engineering education.

title: Exploring the Application of Generative AI Agents to Higher Education: A Case Study of "Preschool Educational Psychology"
authors: Wanqiu Meng, Jingshu Wang
abstract: This paper presents a case study on the design, implementation, and evaluation of generative artificial intelligence (AI) agents for personalized teaching in higher education, focusing on the Preschool Educational Psychology course. By integrating generative AI technologies with pedagogical frameworks, we developed an AI agent system comprising two dimensions: a Learning Theory Agent (LTA) and a Research Advancement Agent (RAA). This system addresses challenges in student-centered learning and instructor-led pedagogy through structured knowledge integration, automated workflows, and data-driven analysis, enabling personalized learning pathways, real-time feedback, and adaptive teaching strategies. Semi-structured interviews with students and course instructors highlighted AI’s educational benefits: structured knowledge support, innovative analytics, and efficient information integration. Limitations included theoretical gaps, rigid interaction patterns, and cognitive rigidity risks. Future work should emphasize collaborative synergy between AI-driven efficiency and human educators’ strengths in emotional intelligence and individualized mentoring, aiming to establish a sustainable model for AI-enhanced higher education.

title: Photonics-Enabled LiFi Framework for Ultra-Low-Latency V2X and VANET Applications
authors: Ibrohimbek Yusupov, Komola Makhkamova, Dilafruz Yusupova, Ravin Kumar
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: In this paper, we discuss a photonics-based LiFi system that can be used to provide ultra-low-latency wireless services to new Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X) and Vehicular Ad Hoc Network (VANET) services. The traditional RF-based V2X systems are usually limited because of spectrum congestion, interference and variability in latency that makes them less applicable to safety-critical vehicular services. With the proposed architecture, modulation bandwidth, a relationship between reliability and responsiveness at the link, and dynamic mobility are improved under the dynamic mobility requirements, and influenced by high-speed photonic modulators and visible-light communication channel. The system model is thoroughly designed which involves the behavior of the optical channel and the mobility restrictions of the vehicle in addition to an optimized system of handover which fits rapidly moving conditions. Findings of the simulations show that end-to-end latency is under one milliseconds, and both throughput is enhanced, and the performance is stable irrespective of how crowded the traffic is. The results support the idea that photonics-aided LiFi can be used as the complementary technology to current RF systems and provide the next-generation intelligent transportation, cooperative driving, and situational awareness.

title: SliceMon: Slice-aware SLA Monitoring in the Data Plane Using Ensemble Learning and In-band Network Telemetry
authors: Valerio Luconi, Raffaele Bruno
publish: 2025 33rd International Symposium on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Computer and Telecommunication Systems (MASCOTS)
abstract: Network slicing enables the coexistence of multiple virtual networks over shared infrastructure, each designed to meet distinct service-level requirements. Ensuring SLA compliance in such environments demands efficient and fine-grained monitoring, particularly within the transport network (TN). Existing In-band Network Telemetry (INT) solutions, however, face challenges related to scalability and overhead. We propose SliceMon, a slice-aware SLA monitoring framework for P4enabled TNs. SliceMon deploys lightweight machine learning models in the data plane to locally infer potential SLA violations, while the controller aggregates these inferences using ensemble methods and activates detailed telemetry collection only when necessary. We evaluate SliceMon under delay-based SLAs using datasets gathered via emulation with Mininet and BMv2. Results demonstrate that SliceMon maintains high detection accuracy while significantly reducing monitoring overhead and improving responsiveness compared to traditional periodic telemetry approaches.

title: A Two-Timescale Learning-Based Stochastic Game for Energy-Efficient UAV Trajectory Planning and Replacement in Hierarchical Aerial Computing
authors: Jialiuyuan Li, You Shi, Chen Dai, Yongjian Fan, Changyan Yi, Xiankun Ge, Jiantao Shi
abstract: The integration of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and high-altitude platform (HAP) in hierarchical aerial computing presents a promising paradigm for delivering supplementary computational services to mobile IoT devices. Despite the great potential, this system faces the challenge of timescale. Specifically, the dynamic nature of IoT devices and their corresponding task generations may initialize the frequent adjustment of UAVs-HAP task delegation for fullfiling their needs in small-timescale, but UAVs' trajectory planning and replacement can only operate in large-timescale because of the severe overhead in high-speed maneuvers, motivating the multi-timescale asynchronous decision making which may further complicate the system. To this end, we propose a two-timescale optimization framework, aiming to maximize the system energy efficiency of the hierarchical aerial computing. We formulate the problem as two coupled multi-agent stochastic games, capturing UAV-HAP interactions and system uncertainties, and prove the existence of a Nash Equilibrium (NE). A reinforcement learning-based algorithm, UAV trajectory planning, replacement, task delegation and resource allocation (UTRTD), is developed to achieve the NE. Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed UTRTD over counterparts.

title: Hybrid Intelligent Optimization of Path-Constrained Switched Systems With Free Switching Sequences
authors: Jun Fu, Zexiang Gao, Huan Li, Dali Chen, Xiaochen Zhu, Dongxiao Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: In this article, a hybrid intelligent optimization method is proposed for the dynamic optimization of path-constrained switched systems with free switching sequences. This method combines improved particle swarm optimization and differential evolution (IPSO-DE) method with a gradient-based dynamic optimization method, which can simultaneously obtain the global optimal solution, i.e., optimal control input, optimal switching instants, and optimal switching sequences. First, control vector parameterization (CVP), switching time parameterization (STP), and switching sequence smoothing techniques are employed to transform the original problem into a continuous finite-dimensional dynamic one. Second, the path constraints are discretized into a finite number of point constraints, and the IPSO-DE algorithm is proposed to search for the global optimal solution of the continuous dynamic problem with discretized constraints. Then, the obtained optimal solution serves as the initial point to calculate the gradients of the objective function with respect to control input, switching instants, and switching sequences. Third, the gradient-based deterministic method is applied to obtain the global optimal solution that satisfies the first-order optimality condition. Fourth, the finite termination of the hybrid intelligent optimization method is proven. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed method is verified through three numerical examples.

title: Text-guided Iterative Polymerization with Prototyping for Task-incremental Few-shot Infrared Moving Target Detection
authors: Sicheng Zhu, Luping Ji, Shengjia Chen, Weiwei Duan, Mao Ye, Haohao Ren
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: At present, most existing Infrared Moving Small Target Detection (IMSTD) methods are usually based on both static and task-dependent training. They often require that the available training set is acquired all at once, and each detection model is dedicated to a single task. In some specific scenarios where only few-shot samples are available and training data arrives sequentially, these methods lose their effectiveness. To address this issue, incremental few-shot learning schemes are considered as one of the most promising solutions. However, existing incremental few-shot approaches are mainly for general object detection, with the unsatisfactory performance on specialized IMSTD. In view of this, this paper proposes a Text-guided Iterative Polymerization with Prototyping (TIPP) framework for incremental few-shot IMSTD. In detail, it leverages text features to generate modulation factors to iteratively guide the polymerization of spatio-temporal features. Furthermore, by using statistical features, it can learn one unique prototype to identify one task. The experiments on three datasets (IRDST, DAUB, and ITSDT) demonstrate the effectiveness and superiority of our TIPP. It consistently outperforms existing state-of-the-art (SOTA) methods in both incremental few-shot learning and IMSTD. Source codes are available at https://github.com/UESTC-nnLab/TIPP.

title: Feature classification methods on measuring user engagement in social media campaigns_supp1-3664701.docx
authors: Fotios Misopoulos
abstract: One-third of food produced for human consumption is wasted, with households in high-income countries responsible for nearly half of this total. This study examines user engagement with three major UK food waste reduction campaigns on X (formerly Twitter), analyzing more than 50,000 tweets collected over seven years. Using sentiment analysis, topic modelling, and feature importance classification (Random Forest, Support Vector Machines, Naïve Bayes, Gradient Boosting), the study identifies the content attributes that are most strongly associated with higher engagement. Practical advice (e.g., food storage tips), community mobilization, and food sharing consistently generate the highest levels of interaction, while strategic use of hashtags, mentions, and influencer endorsements amplifies reach. The paper makes three theoretical contributions. First, it advances agenda-setting theory by demonstrating how long-term digital campaigns curate content to elevate food waste as a salient public issue, with distinct strategies (aligning messages with organizational vision, offering actionable tips, and promoting food sharing) driving engagement. Second, it extends framing theory by showing how platform-native tools associate with interaction, with tweets using either hashtags or mentions (but not both) achieving greater resonance, suggesting that simplified framing may be more effective in crowded digital spaces. Third, it offers a methodological contribution by integrating feature importance analysis with sentiment and topic modelling, moving beyond descriptive metrics to predictive insights into which tweet attributes are most strongly associated with higher engagement. For practitioners, the study provides a cost-effective framework for dynamically adapting campaign content, equipping engineering managers and policy makers to design more impactful, scalable, and sustainable digital interventions that promote public engagement and behavioural change.

title: UAV-Mounted RIS-Assisted Legitimate Surveillance Over Maritime Low-Altitude Communication Networks
authors: Wei Wang, Xu Hao, Lei Wu, Feng Zeng, Nan Zhao, Kanapathippillai Cumanan, Emil Bjornson
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: This paper considers a challenging maritime low altitude surveillance issue, in which, a legitimate monitor UAV intends to overhear a suspicious UAV-vessel link with the help of a jammer UAV. Both the suspicious receiver has the jamming detection ability and the jammer UAV is energy-constrained. To address these challenges, we propose a novel UAV-mounted reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) assisted approach, where the RIS is deployed on the jammer UAV to create an additional surveillance channel towards the legitimate UAV. Furthermore, the jammer UAV can also intelligently adjust its power allocation and flight trajectory to covertly disturb the suspicious transmission with the detection thresholds and the energy budgets. In such a setup, we consider a sum eavesdropping rate maximization problem of the legitimate UAV during all time slots. This formulated problem is solved by jointly optimizing the three dimensional (3D) trajectory of the legitimate UAV, the reflecting phase shifts of the RIS, as well as the 3D trajectory and jamming power of the jammer UAV under the mobility, covertness, and power limitation constraints. We decompose the non-convex design problem into three subproblems and propose an iterative algorithm to find its approximated optimal solution by using the block coordinate descent method. In eachiteration, we utilize the successive convex approximation and phase alignment techniques to handle these subproblems. Numerical simulation results are provided to validate the effectiveness and tremendous potential of UAV-mounted RIS in the maritime low-altitude surveillance.

title: State-Optimization Based Semantic SCMA Broadcast with Deep Reinforcement Learning in UAV-Assisted IoV Networks
authors: Nguyen Huu Trung, Doan Thanh Binh, Chao Wang, Zuxing Li
abstract: This paper proposes a semantic Sparse Code Multiple Access (SCMA) broadcast framework for Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV)-assisted Internet of Vehicles (IoV) networks, integrating structural state optimization with Lyapunov-guided Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL). The UAV acts as a semantic-aware aerial Base Station (aBS) that extracts and encodes high-level semantic features before mapping them onto the SCMA factor graph. A state-optimization module designs the semantic projection and energy-mapping matrices to preserve semantic fidelity under power and sparsity constraints. On top of this structure, a Lyapunov-constrained DRL controller adapts the UAV’s transmit-power policy based on instantaneous semantic reliability, channel dynamics, and network conditions. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed Lyapunov-guided learning approach significantly improves energy efficiency and long-term stability while maintaining semantic reliability above the required threshold, with negligible throughput degradation compared to unconstrained SCMA-based learning schemes.

title: DUPGT-CDR: Deep User Preference Gating Transfer for Cross-domain Recommendation
authors: Yusuke Shimizu, Keiko Ono, Takuya Futagami
abstract: Cross-domain recommendation (CDR) seeks to enhance recommendation accuracy in a target domain by utilizing user–item interactions from a source domain, especially in cold-start scenarios. In conventional CDR approaches, user-specific bridge functions generated using only the user’s high-rated interaction history in the source domain are used to map user embeddings from the source domain to the target domain. As a result, these methods cannot effectively leverage both positive and negative feedback. To address this limitation, we propose DUPGT-CDR, a new framework that encodes high (ratings 4–5) and low (ratings 1–3) feedback separately, and then adaptively fuses these signals using a gating network. This gating mechanism enables fine-grained control over transferring high and low feedback. Experiments on three real-world domain pairs with varying overlap ratios demonstrate that DUPGT-CDR consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods (EMCDR, PTUPCDR, DPTUPCDR, MIMNET), achieving up to 17.9% lower MAE and 20.9% lower RMSE, thereby confirming its robustness across different data partition settings. The code is publicly available at https://github.com/isdlyusukeshimizu/DUPGT-CDR.

title: Anti-Jamming Hybrid Beamforming in mmWave Systems via Riemannian Augmented Lagrangian Optimization
authors: Tianhang Wang, Xingyu Zhao, Min Li, Minjian Zhao
abstract: This paper investigates anti-jamming beamforming for massive antenna arrays under hybrid analog–digital beamforming architectures. While hybrid architecture reduces hardware cost by limiting the number of RF chains, it also introduces challenges in jointly optimizing analog and digital beamformers under constant-modulus constraints in the analog domain. To overcome these challenges, we propose an alternating optimization framework that combines a Riemannian augmented Lagrangian method for analog beamforming and a minimum variance distortionless response approach for digital beamforming. Unlike conventional approachs that approximate hybrid beamformers by minimizing the Euclidean distance to a fully digital solution, our approach directly solves the original problem, thereby achieving deep interference nulls and accurate beam pointing. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed scheme achieves performance close to fully digital beamforming while significantly outperforming existing hybrid baselines.

title: MPC-Based Power Management for Energy Efficiency and Li-ion Battery Degradation Mitigation in Off-Grid Hybrid Photovoltaic Inverters
authors: Ezequiel Gonschorowski, Rafael Cardoso, Edivan Laercio Carvalho, Carlos Marcelo de Oliveira Stein, Emerson Giovani Carati, Gustavo Weber Denardin, Jean Patric da Costa
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Power Electronics
abstract: Efficient power management in Hybrid Energy Storage Systems (HESS) for off-grid PV inverters remains a challenge, particularly in terms of energy efficiency and battery degradation mitigation. In this context, this paper proposes a Model Predictive Control (MPC) based power management designed to mitigate Li-ion battery degradation while improving the overall system efficiency. To validate this proposal, extensive experimental results are presented. The proposed formulation aims to minimize battery stress by smoothing the current profile and reducing cycling effects. The performance of the MPC power management is verified through a comparative experimental analysis of four distinct strategies: rule-based, frequency-filtering, a benchmark MPC, and the proposed MPC. Evaluation is based on four key metrics: RMS current, total power losses, Equivalent Full Cycles (EFC), and State of Health variation (ΔSOH). Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms the compared strategies across all evaluated criteria, significantly reducing battery stress in terms of cycling and current distribution. Furthermore, long-term simulations corroborate these findings, showing a substantial reduction in battery degradation compared to other established methods. These results confirm that the proposed method, provides a robust solution for mitigating battery degradation in hybrid inverter applications.

title: LSTM-Based Automated Analysis of Laser-Groove Profiles in Wafer Dicing Using White-Light Interferometry Data
authors: I-Ching Lu, Hsin-Hung Chou, Shih-Ching Yeh, Eric Hsiao-Kuang Wu
abstract: Laser grooving is a critical preparatory step in wafer dicing for advanced semiconductor packaging, ensuring reduced mechanical stress and improved dicing precision. However, groove quality assessment remains challenging due to profile irregularities and noise in depth measurement data. This paper presents an automated groove inspection system that leverages long short-term memory (LSTM) networks to analyze depth profiling data acquired via white light interferometry. The proposed method predicts the original wafer surface level and extracts key groove metrics, including groove depth, width, and debris zone characteristics. Unlike traditional rule-based or image-based methods, the LSTM-based model processes 1D cross-sectional height profiles directly, achieving a prediction accuracy of 99.87% under practical industrial tolerances. The system integrates seamlessly into semiconductor manufacturing pipelines, supporting real-time process monitoring, adaptive parameter tuning, and predictive maintenance. Experimental results validate the superiority of the proposed approach over conventional techniques, offering enhanced robustness, accuracy, and scalability for high-throughput wafer-level metrology.

title: Real-Time, High-Resolution and Wide-Dynamic-Range Demodulation Algorithm for Fiber Fabry–Pérot Sensors
authors: Tao Jin, Xiao Wu, Jianhua Yang, Zhihang Zhang, Lijun Miao, Heming Wei, Dapeng Han, Dengwei Zhang
abstract: Fabry–Pérot interferometer (FPI) sensors have been widely employed in precision measurement applications. The trade-off among resolution, dynamic range, and real-time capability in conventional spectral demodulation algorithms, however, constrains their achievable performance in practice. In this paper, a real-time, high-resolution and wide-dynamic-range demodulation algorithm for FPI sensors is proposed within a discrete Fourier transform (DFT)-based spectral demodulation framework. A modified frequency estimation method is introduced to extend the effective dynamic range, and a refined phase reconstruction strategy is employed to suppress the phase jumps under different signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) conditions. The proposed algorithm realizes a cavity-length resolution of 0.086 nm at a spectral SNR of 29.4 dB, and maintains stable and continuous demodulation over a cavity-length variation exceeding 195 μm. In the experimental system, the demodulation rate is limited to 33 kHz by the sampling rate of the spectrometer, whereas demodulation speed analysis indicates that the proposed algorithm is capable of supporting rates exceeding 100 kHz. In addition, the pressure sensing experiment further confirms its applicability in practical sensing scenarios. The proposed algorithm is expected to provide an effective demodulation solution for high-resolution and real-time FPI sensing applications.

title: Automatic Generation of Lane-Level Road Topology Using Vision-Based Geometry
authors: Shuochen Li, Yafei Liu, Zhengdong Wang, Lishi Zhang, Xiangyin Meng, Xiaoguo Zhang
abstract: Vehicle positioning technology is essential for intelligent vehicles, supporting applications such as path planning, route guidance and autonomous parking. High-precision road topology network information is also crucial for vehicle positioning and navigation. However, approaches that generate road topology from remote sensing images are limited by viewing angle and resolution, often missing road segments and generating only road-level topology. Ground mapping vehicle systems such as simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM) based methods struggle to directly obtain road centerlines and are rarely used directly for topology generation, while deep learning-based methods can dynamically produce lane-level topology but often lack global consistency and interpretability, suffering from redundant misconnections and high perception cost. In this paper, we present a geometry-driven framework for automatic lane-level topology generation from a monocular front-view camera, with global map alignment supported by external localization. Unlike purely deep learning-based approaches, our approach leverages existing high-precision ground vehicle mapping algorithms to extract road geometry constraints and incorporates semantic cues to ensure interpretable and globally connected topology generation, combining interpretability with strong geometric supervision. Specifically, we introduce a lane semantic information based lane enhancement strategy to fill topological gaps, a DBSCAN based three-stage pipeline to denoise and regularize lane center nodes, and a virtual-node representation to simplify complex intersections. Our approach has been experimentally validated in real-world urban areas and compared to existing mainstream deep learning-based topology generation methods. The results indicate that our method achieves higher topological accuracy and completeness within the same front-view camera field of view, demonstrating its effectiveness for lane-level topology construction.

title: An Advanced Hierarchical Control Strategy for Modeling and Stability Evaluation of a Novel Series-Connected Energy Routing System
authors: Xianyang Cui, Shiquan Han, Yusheng Fang, Mohamed A. Mohamed, Tao Jin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: This paper proposes an advanced structural modeling and stability evaluation of a novel series-connected energy routing system for residential applications. To address the limitations of conventional converters regarding voltage gain and component stress, the system utilizes a Mirrored SEPIC front-stage integrated with a Dual Active Bridge (DAB) post-stage. This hybrid topology features a high theoretical voltage gain and low hardware complexity. A hierarchical control strategy coordinates photovoltaic (PV) generation, energy storage, direct current (DC) loads, and grid interaction across four distinct energy flow modes. Furthermore, a rigorous small-signal impedance model is derived, and a stability criterion based on the Forbidden Region concept is introduced to guide parameter tuning for the cascaded system. Experimental validation on a 10kW prototype confirms the performance of the system. It achieves a stable 500V DC bus output from an 80V input, corresponding to a voltage conversion ratio of 6.25, while maintaining a low normalized complexity of 1.25 switches per port. During dynamic transitions including 50% load step changes and grid power reversals, the DC bus voltage fluctuation is limited to 3% with a settling time of less than 80ms. The proposed solution provides a scalable, cost-effective, and highly stable platform for residential renewable energy integration.

title: Real-Time Coverage Path Planning for Bone-Aware Robotic Ultrasound Scanning
authors: Yu Zhang, Minqi He, Dong Han, Shengwei Guo, Shaohua Zhang, Lin Yan, Hongdi Liu, Dahu Zhu
abstract: Robotic ultrasound systems offer significant potential for automated organ coverage scanning, yet acoustic shadows from bone structures can cause incomplete scans and missed diagnoses. This work presents a real-time coverage path planning method for bone-aware robotic ultrasound scanning. A voxel based perception map is built by segmenting organ regions with a U-Net network and back-projecting acoustic shadows to estimate bone locations. Ultrasound image data are then fused with real time probe poses and mapped into 3D space. The proposed method runs online over a continuously updated perception map, selecting the next path segment in real time by maximizing motion efficiency and information gain. Phantom experiments demonstrate that the proposed method effectively avoids bone obstruction, while human experiments confirm its clinical feasibility. On average across the kidney and spleen experiments, the proposed system achieved 87.69% of ultrasound physician performance while requiring only 1.22 times the scanning time, demonstrating strong potential for clinical application.

title: WEMA-VINS: Visual-Inertial SLAM With ELSED-MIS Line Filtering_supp3-3664654.mp4
authors: Guoliang Liu
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) are widely used in various fields due to their flexibility and maneuverability. However, for UAV systems that rely solely on point features, weak-texture environments cause a decline in pose estimation accuracy, creating a severe localization challenge. The fusion of line and point features introduces more geometric constraints, enhancing system robustness and localization accuracy. This letter presents a lightweight monocular visual-inertial SLAM framework, WEMA-VINS (Weak-grid ELSED MIS-filtered and Angular-constrained VINS), designed for robust point-line fusion. It integrates weak-texture region elimination, ELSED line detection, Maximum Independent Set (MIS)-based pruning of redundant segments, and an angular-constrained line optimization module. Our proposed framework collectively improves point feature quality, preserves structural line information, and enhances robustness against endpoint drift and partial occlusion, leading to reliable point-line fusion and efficient state estimation. Extensive experiments on the KAIST VIO and EuRoC datasets demonstrate that WEMA-VINS significantly improves both localization accuracy and robustness, consistently achieving leading performance over recent point-line SLAM baselines while maintaining real-time efficiency.

title: Online Targetless Camera-Lidar Extrinsic Calibration Using Object-oriented Semantic Feature
authors: Xinchun Ji, Zheng He, Shuhang Gu, Dongyan Wei, Deyun Zhou
abstract: Accurate extrinsic parameters are critical for fusing heterogeneous data from cameras and Lidars. To solve the problems of incomplete feature extraction, poor scene adaptability and unstable parameter convergence in conventional automatic calibration methods, this paper proposed an online extrinsic calibration method using object-oriented semantic features, which consisted of a coarse-calibration based on trajectory-consistency and a fine-calibration based on feature-consistency. With the initial parameters from the coarse-calibration, fine-calibration pictorialized the sparse point cloud to obtain its depth, intensity and class attributes simultaneously. Then, the SAM network was used to process both the visual image and the point cloud pseudo-image to extract consistent object-oriented features. To enhance the stability and adaptability of extrinsic calibration to various scenes, an observability-based IoU was proposed to perform the camera-Lidar feature matching. In addition, we designed an adaptability function to evaluate the quality of scene features, thereby ensuring the effectiveness of extrinsic calibration. Results of testing on KITTI dataset and real-world dataset demonstrate that the proposed method can effectively obtain accurate extrinsic parameters in multiple scenes. By comparing with the ground truth, errors of the rotation and translation are less than (0.15deg, 0.05 m), and the variances are less than (2.0×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-3</sup> deg<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, 3.0×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-4</sup> m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>), which indicates good potential for engineering applications.

title: Channel Modeling Toward 6G in 3GPP Release 19
authors: Wenfei Yang, Narcis Cardona, Jian Li, Ziming Yu, Jinhuan Xia, Zhening Zhang, Jiafeng Shao, Peiying Zhu
abstract: In Release 19, the Third Generation Partnership Project (3GPP) not only focused on the commercial deployment needs of 5G-Advanced but also prepared channel models for 6G. Targeting feasible channel models that satisfy the requirements of upcoming 6G studies and evaluation, two study items (SIs) on channel modeling for the 7-24 GHz spectrum and integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) were conducted in Release 19. The existing channel model was validated for the emerging 7-24 GHz spectrum and extended to accommodate characteristics introduced by larger antenna arrays. Meanwhile, a new ISAC channel model was proposed to bridge the gap in ISAC performance evaluation. This article presents a comprehensive overview of Release 19 channel modeling and discusses potential implementations for 6G performance evaluation.

title: Dual Memristor-coupled Unidirectional Ring Neural Network: Abundant Hidden Firings and Application in Hardware Image Encryption
authors: Bowen Li, Sen Zhang, Jie Wang, Chengjie Chen, Xin Ding
abstract: Due to the fixed weights and simple topology of traditional unidirectional ring neural networks, it is challenging to generate complex firing dynamics. This paper introduces two threshold memristor models to mimic neuronal autapses, constructing a novel dual memristor-coupled unidirectional ring neural network (DMCURNN). Benefiting from the dual memristor-based autapse emulation, the DMCURNN enriches diverse hidden firing dynamics that are absent in conventional unidirectional ring neural networks, and the richness and complexity of these hidden firing dynamics are highly sensitive to the memristive coupling strengths. Numerical simulations indicate that the DMCURNN is able to generate various hidden firing activities, pattern transitions, homogeneous firing multistability of infinite coexisting homogeneous firing patterns and heterogeneous firing multistability of seven heterogeneous firing patterns. Furthermore, through adjusting the coupling parameters along with the external current intensity, the regulatory mechanisms of hidden firing patterns and their amplitude and frequency regulation are revealed. Subsequently, the hidden firing dynamics of this network are verified on an FPGA hardware platform. Finally, Using the hidden firing multistability characteristic of the DMCURNN, a novel bitstream-based hardware image encryption scheme with a dynamic key update mechanism is designed. Performance evaluations demonstrate that the proposed scheme exhibits exceptional robustness and high efficiency for IoT security applications.

title: PAG-FL: Personalization via Adaptive Gradient Filtering in Federated Learning
authors: Yuri Seo, Hyeon-ki Jo, Eui-Nam Huh
abstract: Personalized Federated Learning (PFL) has emerged as a key paradigm for delivering personalized AI services across diverse clients. While prior research has primarily focused on handling data heterogeneity, recent studies have additionally targeted noise and communication efficiency. However, most approaches exchange knowledge only at the logit or prototype level, which limits representation sharing and struggles to mitigate both data heterogeneity and noise. Moreover, communication overhead accumulated over hundreds of training rounds still imposes substantial bandwidth costs, and fixed personalization ratios hinder effective optimization to non-IID data. To address these challenges, we propose Personalization via Adaptive Gradient Filtering in Federated Learning (PAG-FL), a communication-efficient and robust PFL framework. PAG-FL reduces communication costs by collecting only class-wise average embeddings and local prediction heads from clients. It further alleviates embedding bias through L2 normalization and a projection layer, while optimizing personalization ratios using thresholds derived from the interquartile range (IQR) of gradients. Extensive experiments on Fashion-MNIST, CIFAR-10, and CIFAR-100 demonstrate that PAG-FL consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods. Specifically, under label noise and non-IID conditions, PAG-FL achieves accuracy improvements of up to 19% and F1 Score gains of up to 17% compared to the best baselines. In fixed and subset user scenarios, it maintains this robustness, yielding substantial accuracy gains of approximately 19%. Furthermore, PAG-FL significantly accelerates convergence, reducing communication rounds by up to 96% and communication overhead by up to 1,700×.
