title: Future-Proofing Video Quality Assessment: Objective Metrics for Holographic and XR Broadcasting (2026 Outlook)
authors: Khilola F. Khaydaraliyeva
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: The introduction of holographic and extended reality (XR) broadcasting has radically changed the working requirements for video quality assessment (VQA). Traditional metrics like Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR), Structural Similarity Index (SSIM), and Video Multi-Method Assessment Fusion (VMAF) were designed for two-dimensional video and lack good correspondence to the human perceptual judgment in the immersive media world. In the current work, we perform a systematic assessment of conventional, perceptual and AI-driven metrics using 4K, 8K and holographic xr test sequences with various compression ratios and network noise conditions. Subjective Mean Opinion Scores (MOS) were collected from 30 participants and these were then compared with objective metric outputs to evaluate the validity of each measurement method.Experimental results show a correlation with a percentage of more than 90% with mean opinion scores (MOS), with AI-driven hybrid models * perceptual depth cues, which are much more accurate than conventional approaches at the cost of a high computational cost. In order to counteract the issue of latency, the paper examines the use of edge computing architectures and can therefore demonstrate improved scalability for real-time extended reality (XR) broadcasting. These findings imply that hybrid AI-perceptual approaches represent a future-proof methodology for assessing the objective quality of video content, providing robust and reliable solutions able to cope with the needs of immersive broadcasting ecosystems predicted to occur in 2026 onwards.

title: Research and application of key technologies of illegal construction monitoring in urban villages based on real 3D modeling and GIS technology
authors: Shunji Du, Fuxiang Huang, Guanghua Zhou, Kaimeng Li, Minyi Kuang, Qian He
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Geographic Information and Remote Sensing Technology (GIRST)
abstract: Aiming at the problems of strong concealment of illegal construction in urban villages, lagging response and insufficient recognition accuracy of traditional supervision methods, an intelligent monitoring method combining real 3D modeling and GIS technology was proposed. Research based on unmanned aerial vehicle (uav) is constructed tilt photography generated centimeter level 3 d model with GIS data for phase analysis of the technical framework, through the analysis of characteristics of high precision digital surface model difference, spatial distribution and lightweight U - Net deep learning model, implementation of construction, outside enlarge tiny neo-treasure hill ACTS such as automatic recognition and dynamic track. Experiments carried out in typical urban village area of 12.6 square kilometers, the results show that the system space grade decimeter precision, plain square kilometers, the processing time for 15 minutes or less, data update cycle, 7 days or less neo-treasure hill recognition response time shortened to 3 days, the whole formula one - score of 0.859, the rate of false positives to 12.4%, about 40% efficiency than the traditional methods. Research shows that the technology system significantly improved the neo-treasure hill recognition discriminant accuracy and resolution of space and time and provides for the city of fine management to promote the intelligent solution.

title: LLM-Agmented Curriculum Knowledge Graph Construction: Improving NER Accuracy via Hybrid UIE Synergy
authors: Ruyue Pan, Jing Du, Wanbin Wang, Fei Li, Yong Yang, Jie Sun
abstract: The construction of curriculum knowledge graphs faces challenges in model training due to the diversity of entity extraction objectives and domain-specific requirements across academic disciplines. To address the high training costs associated with cross-domain adaptation in multi-disciplinary entity extraction, this study proposes a hybrid framework that integrates a universal information extraction framework(UIE) with a context-aware large language model (LLM). Leveraging the ERNIE-UIE model's transfer learning capabilities, our framework achieves few-shot learning optimization through efficient fine-tuning with minimal manually annotated curriculum texts, thereby significantly reducing model training overhead. Notably, the LLM functions as a semantic enhancement module to validate and augment UIE's extraction outputs. Experimental results demonstrate a 5.61% improvement in precision for knowledge point entity extraction through this collaborative approach.

title: Advanced Cloud Computing and Machine Learning Framework for NDVI Time-Series Analysis and Environmental Change Detection
authors: Ziheng Huang, Takis Kasparis, Wei William Wu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Geographic Information and Remote Sensing Technology (GIRST)
abstract: This paper proposes an end-to-end framework integrating advanced cloud computing and machine learning for NDVI time series analysis and environmental change detection. The framework achieves efficient multi-source data access, quality control, and fusion analysis through modular design, and improves the accuracy and noise robustness of change identification by combining self-attention and recursive hybrid models. Multi-source data fusion and uncertainty quantification mechanisms are introduced to enhance the model's cross-sensor adaptability and result interpretability. Deployment on a cloud platform verifies the system's high throughput and elastic scalability in large-scale data scenarios, providing a scalable and operable technical path for ecological monitoring and agricultural management.

title: Inertia Evaluation Method for Power Systems with Integration of Wind Farms Under Colored Measurement Noise
authors: Yongkang Luo, Mingjiang Liu, Yu Zhang, Ziwen Liu, Xingwei Che, Xiangyu Meng
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: With the integration of high proportion of new energy, the power system gradually exhibits low inertia characteristics. Accurately evaluating the system inertia is of great significance for the safe and stable operation of the power system. However, the colored measurement noise greatly influences on the collection data resulting bias of inertia evaluation. This paper proposes a power system inertia evaluation method based on Improved Adaptive Kalman Filter (IAKF) algorithm. Firstly, the filtering state equation and measurement equation are derived by applying the forward Euler method on the swing equation. Then to decrease the influence of colored noise and data saturation, this article estimates the statistical characteristics of the colored measurement noise, imports the forgetting factor to form the improved filtering gain and proposes the IAKF algorithm. Finally, the effectiveness and superiority of the algorithm proposed in this paper are verified through simulation examples.

title: Day-Ahead Net Load Forecasting Based on Similar-Period Selection and CNN-BiLSTM-Attention
authors: Wei Wang, Shunfu Lin, Bo Zhou, Liang Qian
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: Accurate day-ahead net load forecasting is critical to the reliable and economical operation of modern power systems. Traditional deep learning models typically train on the entire available historical dataset without explicitly considering temporal similarities across different days. To address this limitation, this paper proposes a novel forecasting framework that integrates similar-period selection into a CNN-BiLSTM-Attention model to improve predictive performance. First, the autocorrelation function (ACF) is utilized to determine the optimal length of similar historical periods. Then, Shape Dynamic Time Warping (ShapeDTW) is employed to identify the most similar historical sequences. These selected periods are processed by convolutional layers to extract local features, followed by a BiLSTM-Attention model that captures bidirectional dependencies and highlights key temporal patterns. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach outperforms models without similarity-based preprocessing and those using similarity based clustering based on weather conditions, achieving higher forecasting accuracy.

title: Research on Primary School Teachers' Intention to Adopt Generative Artificial Intelligence in Teaching Based on the Technology Acceptance Model
authors: Jing Zhang, Xiaojie Yu, Lu Liu, Xiu You, Lu Xu
abstract: The rapid dissemination and application of Generative Artificial Intelligence (GenAI) in China have positioned primary school teachers—a critical stakeholder group in the education sector—as distinct adopters with unique behavioral characteristics; to investigate their adoption patterns, determinants, and underlying mechanisms, this study surveyed 243 primary school teachers via a structured questionnaire and employed structural equation modeling (SEM) based on the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM), revealing that (1) Perceived Usefulness (PU) serves as the core driver of teachers' GenAI Usage Intention(UI), exerting a direct, significant, and positive impact on acceptance behavior; (2) Perceived Ease of Use (PEOU) not only directly enhances adoption intention but also mediates its effect through PU, forming a dual-influence pathway; and (3) External Variables(EV) significantly influence PEOU without directly predicting PU, thereby acting as indirect facilitators; these findings validate the applicability of TAM in GenAI-driven educational contexts by confirming the hierarchical relationship between PEOU and PU, emphasizing the necessity for policymakers and technology developers to prioritize both perceived utility and usability in GenAI training frameworks, and offering actionable strategies for education authorities to strengthen institutional support mechanisms and foster cross- institutional collaboration to disseminate evidence-based best practices for integrating GenAI into primary education.

title: The Correlation Between Ground Spectral Sampling Scale and the Representativeness of Observational Data
authors: Tianyi Wang, Fengyan Wang, Lijun Jiang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Geographic Information and Remote Sensing Technology (GIRST)
abstract: The reliability of remote sensing data products necessitates authenticity validation, a process that typically relies on ground-based or near-ground spectral sampling data. In this study, simulation experiments were conducted using ground-based spectral sampling data to simulate sampling outcomes across various scales. The absolute relative deviation between the ground-based sampling results and the actual reflectance of the simulated field was employed as an indicator of representativeness error. A mathematical model was then constructed to establish the relationship between the sampling scale and data representativeness. The experimental results demonstrate that the coefficient of determination (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) for the fitted model is 0.9306. Furthermore, calculations based on the model indicate that for an absolute relative deviation of less than 5%, the ground-based spectral sampling scale must be at least six times the side length of the layout unit. This study provides a theoretical basis and a practical reference for rationally determining the ground-based spectral sampling scale during authenticity validation.

title: Geo-Temporal Tracking For Employee Engagement: Development And Evaluation Of A Web Application For Community Extension Services
authors: Vincent Rivera, Ande M. Luna, Rose Ann C. Malaborbor, Neilson A. Silva, Lorenzo B. Isla, Myra A. Flordeliza
abstract: Universities and colleges have limited capability to track community extension activities. Traditional methods of manual tracking limit the level of accountability to provide an accurate reflection of participation. This research fills a vital gap in the real-time tracking of community participation by constructing a Web-based application system that tracks participants' locations, login/logout times, and service hours for community extension programs. By employing the Design Science Research methodology, the study passed six stages: Problem Identification and Motivation, Definition of Solution Objectives, Design and Development, Demonstration, Evaluation, and Communication. The system used HTML5 Geolocation API, OpenStreetMap’s Nominatim Service for reverse geocoding, and Google Sheets as the backend database to offer automatic attendance taking with location verification based on GPS. The system is organized around four main modules: a frontend application, a data collection module that makes use of the user's geolocation, an integration layer for handling information input using the Google Forms API, and a cloud-based data persistence service. The app is DPA-compliant and gives you both real-time monitoring and comprehensive reporting. The evaluation process included 71 participants who answered the System Usability Scale questionnaire and whose feedback was assessed by Spearman's Rank Correlation as well as by sentiment analysis. The results show a high degree of user satisfaction, with 85.10% as a positive response and a significant relationship between usability factors, with a correlation coefficient greater than 0.55. Ease of navigation was the most important factor (correlation: 0.72), followed by the site's loading speed (0.70). Location tracking was considered the most useful functionality (84.20%), with which no one wanted more help. The study provides a technological intervention to bridge the gap in monitoring community extension services through better accountability, proper resource allocation, and effectiveness of the program for institutions of higher learning. The prototype has shown the feasibility of how attendance records can be recorded automatically in a non-invasive manner that respects data integrity and user privacy.

title: Fault Detection in the Control- and Data-Path of Neural Networks
authors: Matthias Probst, Manuel Brosch, Augustin Ewald, Michael Gruber, Georg Sigl
publish: 2025 Workshop on Fault Detection and Tolerance in Cryptography (FDTC)
abstract: Machine learning and neural networks experience growing usage in resource-constrained devices. However, moving neural networks to small devices also brings new requirements regarding the reliability and security of the networks and their hardware. In many areas, such as autonomous driving, the device must detect possible errors during execution to ensure safe functionality. Moreover, an adversary can gain physical access to the device, opening the door for hardware attacks like fault injections that target misclassification or parameter retrieval. This work proposes a fault detection mechanism for software implementations of neural networks running on a microcontroller to increase the reliability and security of the neural network. Our technique uses AN-codes, a type of error-detecting code, to detect errors in calculations within the neural network without any implications on the accuracy of protected networks. In addition, signature checking ensures the integrity of the control flow. Simulations and real-world testing show that our mechanism successfully detects faults in all possible locations in the neural network’s program code. Despite the robustness of our fault detection mechanism, it has an overhead in code size of only about 10%, independent of the implemented network. The memory usage increases by at most 232 bytes independently of the neural network size, ensuring that the mechanism is not overly burdensome for the memory.

title: Research on Integrated Application of Substation Equipment Panoramic Perception, Diagnostic Prediction, and Intelligent Operation & Maintenance System
authors: Quan Tian, Jia Zeng, Jingkui Jiang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: This research focuses on key technologies for condition-based maintenance (CBM) of primary and secondary equipment in substations, aiming to construct a technical system that integrates panoramic perception, intelligent diagnosis and prediction, and smart operation & maintenance (O&M) .By combining BIM and GIS for component-level 3D modeling, it achieves model lightweighting and full lifecycle management. A multidimensional sensing network and feature extraction mechanism are developed to address issues in data synchronization and quality control. In terms of diagnostic and predictive analytics, a dynamic ampacity prediction model and a multi-dimensional health assessment method are proposed. A fault correlation analysis system is also constructed based on equipment topology. The intelligent O&M system adopts a layered and decoupled architecture, integrating multi-objective optimization algorithms and augmented reality (AR) technologies to form a closed-loop from condition perception to decision execution, offering a systematic solution for condition-based substation maintenance.

title: Building Inclusive Learning Environments through Vocational Education Digitalization: Policy Evolution and Implementation (2012-2025)
authors: Meirong Chen, Shimin You, Rong Huang, Xu Ding, Junfeng Diao
abstract: This study explores the impact of China's digital policies on vocational education and inclusive learning environments between 2012 and 2025. Using policy text analysis and mixed methods, the study analyzes relevant policy documents and selects representative cases for verification. The study reveals three stages of policy evolution focusing on seven themes, which effectively promote educational equity and cater to diverse learning needs. The findings provide policymakers and educators with valuable insights to enhance inclusive education policies, thereby promoting the high-quality development of vocational education and social equity.

title: Experimental Evaluation of Optical Signal-to-Noise Ratio Measurement in Coherent Communication Systems
authors: Kholisakhon Davletova
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: In this article, the author has detailed the challenges and the current developments in the measurement of the Optical Signal-to-Noise Ratio (OSNR) in the high-speed coherent optical communication systems based on polarization multiplexing (Pol-Mux). Measurement of Optical Signal-to-Noise Ratio (OSNR) is now an urgent problem in contemporary coherent optical communication systems with high speed (e.g. polarization multiplexing (Pol-Mux)). The recent trends of tight channel separation, strong spectral filtering and complex modulation schemes at frequencies up to 400 Gbps mean that conventional OSNR measurement methods based on out of band spectral analysis are no more. The study will overcome these shortcomings by experimentally testing the operation of Viavi Pol-Mux OSA-710 a modern optical spectrum analyzer that employs Spectral Correlation Method (SCorM). The suggested solution allows to measure the in-band OSNR correctly, without disruption of the service delivery, independent of the dispersion impairments and modulation format. It has been experimentally shown that the SCorM-based OSNR estimation is precise within a range of ±0.5 dB with regard to conventional OSA methods, and stable under the conditions of different polarizations and filtering. Their results support the Pol-Mux OSA-710 as an effective and stable solution to the real-time OSNR monitoring of the coherent DWDM systems, enhancing the quality of the network performance measurement and lowering the cost of the operational process of the installation and maintenance phases.

title: DS-YOLO: Dual-Domain Background Suppression and Superpixel-Guided Attention for Ship Detection in Natural Cloud-Fog Scenes
authors: Xiaojuan Wang, Songlin Chen, Baoqing Yang, Heng Gu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Geographic Information and Remote Sensing Technology (GIRST)
abstract: Ship detection in optical remote sensing images plays a critical role in maritime surveillance and safety. However, in real-world scenarios, optical remote sensing satellites are susceptible to adverse weather conditions such as clouds and fog, leading to issues in the acquired images such as severely reduced contrast, blurred target edges, and occlusion of features on small ships. This, in turn, causes a sharp decline in the performance of generic detectors (like YOLOv8), resulting in significantly higher missed detections and false alarm rates. To address this severe challenge, this paper proposes a novel DS-YOLO network, a Dual-Domain Background Suppression and Superpixel-Guided Attention network designed for ship detection in natural cloudy and foggy scenes. First, we designed the Dual-domain Background Suppression (DBS) module to mitigate cloud and fog interference via parallel collaborative processing in both the spatial and frequency domains. Specifically, the spatial branch utilizes Large Kernel Attention (LKA) and Pixel Attention to enhance the structural features of ship targets. Concurrently, the frequency branch employs the Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) to selectively suppress low-frequency background noise inherent in foggy scenes while preserving the high-frequency details of the targets. Second, inspired by superpixel segmentation, we integrated the Superpixel-Guided Attention (SGA) module into the network's Backbone to enhance the P4 feature layer. By simulating superpixel region aggregation, this module dynamically fuses original pixel features with reconstructed regional contexts, leveraging effective information from unoccluded areas to accurately repair ship features obscured by clouds and fog. To validate the effectiveness of our method, we collected and annotated a ship detection dataset from Google Earth under real-world cloudy and foggy scenarios, named CFS. Extensive experiments on the CFS dataset demonstrate that our proposed DS-YOLO significantly outperforms the baseline YOLOv8 and other state-of-the-art detection models in key metrics including mAP, Recall, and mAP50-95, demonstrating its strong potential for robust ship detection under adverse weather conditions.

title: Electromagnetic Coupling Simulation Technology of Transformers Based on Maxwell's Theory
authors: Cunjie Ma, Wuguang Tan, Dekai Chen, Fei Yan, Jiaan Chen
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: This study presents a comprehensive numerical and experimental investigation of electromagnetic and thermal performance in a 35 MVA oil-immersed three-phase transformer. A three-dimensional finite element model incorporating electromagnetic-fluid-solid coupling was developed using ANSYS to analyze core losses, winding Joule losses, and temperature distribution under both no-load and load conditions. The core losses—comprising hysteresis, eddy current, and anomalous losses—were quantified through modified Steinmetz formulations, while copper losses (I<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>R dissipation and stray losses) were evaluated considering resistive heating and leakage flux effects. To enhance computational efficiency, the model employed simplifications, such as reducing radiator fin count while maintaining equivalent heat transfer via adjusted convection coefficients. Field-circuit coupling simulations based on Dyn11 connection schemes were conducted, and results were validated against experimental measurements, showing <5% deviation in loss predictions. The study provides key insights into flux distribution, loss mechanisms, and thermal management in power transformers, offering a validated approach for optimizing transformer design and operational reliability.

title: A Study of the Application of Blended Learning Models in the Teaching of Emerging Liberal Arts Practical Courses
authors: Ying Liang, Xiaoran Huang, Yu Liu, Zimeng He
abstract: Practical teaching in liberal arts disciplines constitutes a fundamental pillar of the innovative talent cultivation framework under China’s Emerging Liberal Arts initiative. This study examines the optimization of problem-based learning methodologies in the context of Maker Education practical courses through a restructured seven-step framework. Using a mixed-methods research design, the study finds notable improvements in three areas: transparent assessment enhances student engagement; iterative prototyping with peer feedback strengthens problem-solving skills; and interdisciplinary literacy is effectively fostered. The findings provide both theoretical and practical insights for liberal arts education reform and present an operational model that bridges the gap between theoretical instruction and hands-on application in Maker Education and broader liberal arts curricula.

title: SafeChat: AI-Driven Real-Time Scam Risk Scoring for Messaging Applications
authors: Julia Tyszkiewicz, Shahid Noor
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: In the current digital landscape, smishing scams, particularly sophisticated pig-butchering schemes, have led to global financial losses estimated at $75 billion, as reported by researchers at the University of Texas at Austin. These scams exploit prolonged, trust-building conversations to deceive victims into sharing sensitive information or funds. While machine learning, especially deep learning, has advanced phishing detection through pattern recognition and contextual analysis, existing models primarily focus on individual messages and struggle to classify entire conversations due to challenges like token limits and the delayed emergence of malicious intent. To address this, we propose SafeChat, an innovative system that dynamically assesses the risk of financial scams in SMS conversations by assigning cumulative risk scores to each message, displayed in real-time within the chat interface. SafeChat leverages a curated dataset of real and smishing conversations, identifying scam phases and weighting them by frequency and impact. Users can contribute anonymized conversation data to enhance model accuracy, with robust PII filtering using tools like Presidio and blockchain-based integrity verification via smart contracts to ensure privacy and trust. By integrating SMS APIs (e.g., Twilio), automation platforms (e.g., Zapier), and blockchain (e.g., Hyperledger), SafeChat empowers users with transparent, actionable insights to mitigate evolving scam threats. Experimental results show that SafeChat effectively identifies and scores scam-related content in chat conversations, making it a practical solution for real-time spam risk assessment in messaging applications.

title: A Multi-Scale Spatio-Temporal Model for Eletric Load Forecasting
authors: Muyang Tian, Ruirui Ji, Xin Xin, Chenxi Bai, Tong Jia, Anjie Song
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: Existing electric load forecasting models often focus on a single scale, making it difficult to simultaneously capture long-term trends and short-term disturbances. This paper proposes a multi-scale spatio-temporal deep learning model that models the long-term dependencies within nodes and the short-term correlations between nodes. In the temporal dimension, a Periodic Decomposition Module is introduced to decompose historical sequences into periodic and disturbance components, which are then modeled and fused through a dual-branch Temporal Fusion Transformer to obtain long-term predictions. In the spatial dimension, multi-scale features are extracted based on geographical maps, similarity maps, and weather maps, dynamically fused through an Inter-Graph External Attention Mechanism, and time dependencies are captured through LSTM to obtain short-term predictions. Finally, the block adaptively integrates long-term and short-term results, simultaneously outputting single-day and single-week predictions. On the NYISO dataset, the MAPE for single-day and single-week predictions is 2.05% and 2.33%, respectively, which significantly outperforms existing methods, validating the model's high accuracy and multiscale adaptability.

title: An Electricity Price Forecasting Method Based on Multimodal Temporal Decomposition Framework Under the Mid-to-long-term Market Environment
authors: Xiejun Du, Junjie Li, Kun Wang, Yan Shen
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: Electricity price forecasting in the electricity market is a core component of power system dispatching, trading decision-making, and risk management, and its accuracy directly affects the economic benefits of market participants and system stability. This paper examines the forecasting of monthly time-of-use (TOU) electricity prices in the mid-to-long-term electricity market (MLTEM) for industrial and commercial (I&C) customers. Given the complex characteristics of electricity price fluctuations, which are influenced by a variety of factors such as load demand, fuel prices, renewable energy output, and policy adjustments, an innovative multimodal time-series decomposition framework (MM-TDF) is proposed. This framework enhances the signal-to-noise ratio of features through hybrid signal processing, dynamically integrates multi-source heterogeneous data such as electricity prices and fuel prices by utilizing a conditional LSTMT-ransformer interaction mechanism, and adopts a dynamic weight joint training strategy to optimize multi-task balance. Experiments show that in typical markets such as PJM and Nord Pool, MM-TDF achieves an accuracy rate improvement during peak hours improvement over LSTM, and exhibits strong robustness to data missingness. This research provides an interpretable and adaptive methodological breakthrough for high-precision electricity price forecasting in the electricity market.

title: Review of Modeling and Archival Techniques for Historic Buildings Utilizing Laser Point Clouds and Oblique Aerial Photography
authors: Zimeng Wang, Yong Fang, Yuanhui Li, Tao Zhong
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Geographic Information and Remote Sensing Technology (GIRST)
abstract: Based on the integration of 3D laser scanning and oblique photography, the non-contact digital archiving application technology is a crucial approach for the preservation of historic building. Nevertheless, the current research on application technologies has predominantly concentrated on individual stage, with limited efforts devoted to a systematic synthesis and comprehensive review. Grounded in the complete workflow of historic building digital archiving, and drawing upon both case studies and existing scholarship, this research seeks a structured framework that advances the understanding of historic building digital archiving.The evolutionary paradigms of established engineering techniques have been summarized across successive stages ranging from aerial terrestrial field data acquisition, homologous data processing and registration, heterogeneous point cloud registration, to model reconstruction and texture mapping. The major technical challenges in each stage are identified, and current landscape of deep learning applications permeating the full workflow is critically examined. In conclusion, this study outlines the prospective developments across the respective stages, with the intention of offering a systematic reference for future related research.

title: Quantum Photonic Approaches for Secure Data Transmission in Smart Agricultural IoT Networks
authors: Aliev Ravshan Maratovich, Vivek Veeraiah, Mamatha G, Ankur Gupta, Dharmesh Dhabliya, Shahanawaj Ahamad
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) in agriculture (AgriIoT) networks are changing the way farming is being conducted by the means of precision sensors, UAVs, and automated control. However, these systems are subjected to security risks in terms of eavesdropping, spoofing, and tampering of data by the distributed wireless architecture. Classical cryptographic tools, which are useful over a short period of time, can be compromised by quantum adversaries. To address these risks, we investigate quantum photonic approaches for secure data transmission in smart agricultural IoT networks. Based on the advances in blockchain-controlled trust schemes, self-powered IoT, and sustainable hydroponics surveillance schemes, we introduce a hybrid design that combines quantum key distribution (QKD) with the photonic channels and consensus-based access control. Photonic technologies used to date in agronomy in sensor and control technologies are already being applied to secure communication. Findings indicate that there are better-secure key generation with channel noise, low chances of leakage, and protection against future quantum attacks. The publication is an outline to the next generation Agri-IoT systems in which quantum photonics will guarantee confidentiality, authenticity, and sustainability.

title: Integrated Energy System Optimization Incorporating User Demand Response
authors: Shihua He, Jiaqi Wu, Weicheng Chen, Jiajun Ou, Lijuan Wang, Mengya Yin
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: The low-carbon transformation of the global energy structure and the advancement of the carbon neutrality goal have made the optimization of the Integrated Energy System (IES) the core path to integrate multiple energy flows such as electricity, heat, gas, and hydrogen, improve energy utilization efficiency, and promote sustainable development. As the pivotal technology for coordinating multi-stakeholder interests and coping with renewable-energy uncertainties, IES still confront a constellation of challenges in responding to user demand: a fractured supply– demand architecture, decoupling from social policies, metric-based evaluation biases, and deficient quantification of uncertainties. This paper dissects these impediments in depth and proposes corresponding optimization pathways, aiming to propel IES toward an efficient, flexible, and multi-dimensionally coordinated paradigm, thereby furnishing a systematic reference for IES optimization under high-penetration renewable-energy scenarios.

title: Objective Methods for Quality Assessment of Digital Television Images for Broadcasting and Applied Television
authors: Khilola F. Khaydaraliyeva
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: This paper is an experiment study on how effective digital image resizing is using the different interpolation techniques. The emergence of digital broadcasting and used television triggered a significant increment in the need to broadcast high definition (HD) and ultra high definition (UHD) television programs, which has caused a considerable increase in the amount of video data. The trend brings about the issue of the possible deterioration of visual quality when bulk amounts of data are transferred in real time through the available communication channels.One of the main tasks of video processing is that images need to be scaled-both up (upscaling) and down (downscaling) in the transcoding process in order to ensure compatibility across different resolutions. Additionally, the transmission of video streams with a lower resolution followed by the expansion back to the original dimensions allows significant traffic savings. Therefore, the ability to resize an image adaptively, without changing its visual fidelity, is of significant practical and scientific importance.The research examined and experimentally tested commonly used interpolation techniques for image resizing, namely Bicubic, B-Spline, Mitchell and Lanczos. The experimental protocol involved reducing the sizes of test images successively by one half followed by restoration to the original size using the same interpolator. The quality and fidelity of the reconstructed images were assessed quantitatively through visual inspection of the images and quantitatively through mean square error (MSE). The article presents results which show the relative effectiveness of each of the interpolators investigated in the reduction and restoration operations.

title: Multi-Sensor Observations of Nonlinear Internal Waves in the Kara Gates Strait
authors: Ilya Kopyshov, Igor Kozlov
abstract: In this paper, we study the generation and evolution of nonlinear internal waves. Early studies show the presence of both an intense internal tide in this region and the propagation of a large amplitude of short-period internal waves. Our analysis demonstrates the presence of several mechanisms for generating short-period structures. In situ investigations conducted in 2021 and 2023 confirm the presence of at least 3 different mechanisms here. These mechanisms include lee wave generation, internal tide disintegration, and tide-front-topography interactions. The lee wave generation mechanism prevails at relatively shallow depths (up to ~100 m). The disintegration of the inner tide occurs at great depths, with elevation differences from 100 to 200 m. While the interaction of the tide and the front is important near the interface of surface currents. We assume that the strait is a prototype of other dynamically intensive regions of the Arctic.

title: Bridging the AI-Human Gap in Programming Education: A Case Study on Structured Prompting and Content-Constrained Generation
authors: Tee Hean Tan, Too Khong Tan
abstract: Generative AI has emerged as a transformative tool in education, yet its effectiveness in programming instruction remains limited by unreliable outputs and prompt dependency. MyOOTutor addresses these challenges through a specialized AI tutoring system that combines (1) content-constrained generation (using validated course materials) and (2) structured query guidance (transforming novice prompts into expert-level queries). Implemented in a Year 1 Object-Oriented Programming course, the system demonstrated significant impact: 93% of students reported improved assignment grades, 97% gained programming confidence, and 95% achieved problem-solving independence. While excelling in foundational OOP concepts (81% understanding), limitations persisted in advanced topic support. These results establish a framework for AI tutoring systems that balances generative AI’s flexibility with pedagogical reliability, offering a replicable model for technical education.

title: APX-DREAM-CIM: An Approximate Digital SRAM-Based CIM Accelerator for Edge AI
authors: Asmae El Arrassi, Chenruiyuan Yu, Mottaqiallah Taouil, Rajiv Joshi, Said Hamdioui
abstract: With the increasing demand for energy-efficient solutions in smart edge applications, there is a pressing need for computing architectures that can effectively manage di-verse and computation-intensive workloads. To address this, we propose APX-DREAM-CIM, an approximate digital SRAM-based Computation-In-Memory (CIM) accelerator specifically designed to maximize energy and area efficiency with minimal impact on accuracy by investigating cross-layer optimizations. The architecture uses, on the one hand, quantized models and, on the other hand, integrates a range of approximate adder designs, each offering distinct trade-offs between hard-ware efficiency and computational precision. To further enhance resilience to approximation-induced errors, we introduce a novel Approximate-Aware Training (AAT) methodology, which models the approximate behavior of the hardware during training, enabling the network to adapt accordingly. We evaluate APX-DREAM-CIM using the MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets with LeNet-5 and ResNet-20 topologies. Experimental results show that APX-DREAM-CIM achieves up to 17% energy and 16% area reduction compared to the exact baseline architecture. Moreover, AAT enables the system to retain, and in some cases, even exceed, the accuracy of standard quantized models.

title: Research on Key Technologies of Full-Stack Localized Power-Specific IoT Operating System
authors: Jichuan Zhang, Dawei Lin, Peng Wang, Shuai Zhang, Yuanyi Xia, Yonggui Wang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: To address the issues of "supply disruption risk", "insufficient real-time performance", and "weak cloud-edge collaboration capabilities" in the operating systems of power collection and control devices in the new power system, and in response to the national strategy of achieving independent and controllable next-generation operating systems, this paper conducts research on key technologies of a fully domesticated, power-specific, and Internet of Things (IoT) operating system. Based on the open-source HarmonyOS, a dual-track technical solution of "standard version for edge, terminal, and cloud + lightweight version" is designed: the standard version focuses on multi-core and multi-chip adaptation and cloud-edge-terminal computing power collaboration, breaking through the "real-time + non-real-time" multi-core construction and distributed computing power intelligent scheduling technology; the lightweight version is targeted at resource-constrained devices, overcoming the challenges of microkernel construction and high-reliability, strong real-time kernel technology. This achievement can replace foreign operating systems such as Linux, and it is expected to be deployed on 30,000 terminals within three years, reducing operation and maintenance costs by over 30%, providing an independent and controllable digital foundation for the "source-grid-load-storage" collaboration in the new power system.

title: Heterogeneous Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Robot Task Allocation
authors: Yixiang Hu, Daxue Liu, Jinhong Li, Tao Wu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Robotics and Automatic Control (IRAC)
abstract: Multi-Robot task allocation (MRTA) in complex terrain environments requires a comprehensive integration of task deadlines, robot capabilities, and spatial constraints imposed by the environment. Existing reinforcement learning approaches have effectively addressed MRTA by considering task deadlines and robot capability limitations. This paper further incorporates environmental obstacles as explicit spatial constraints reconstructed from the environment and proposes a reinforcement learning strategy based on a heterogeneous graph Markov decision process. The proposed approach utilizes a neural architecture referred to as the Heterogeneous Graph Neural Network Attention-Based Model (HGNNAM), which adopts an encoder-decoder structure: (1) Heterogeneous Graph Neural Network Encoder, which integrates robot states, task attributes, and accurate path distances computed from environmental maps through a hierarchical message-passing mechanism; (2) Multi-Head Attention Decoder, which enables real-time decision-making guided by dynamically updated task masks, facilitating context-aware action selection. Experimental results demonstrate that the method consistently achieves robust task allocation performance in intricate maze-like environments and exhibits strong adaptability to previously unseen environments and diverse task types. Future work will further explore collaborative decision-making mechanisms for heterogeneous robot teams and varied task specifications.

title: Knowledge Distillation for Efficient Human Activity Recognition on Resource-Constrained Smartwatches
authors: Yongliang Fan, Wikanda Phaphan, Anuchit Jitpattanakul, Sakorn Mekruksavanich
abstract: Human activity recognition (HAR) using smartwatch sensor data is a crucial enabling technology for healthcare monitoring, fitness assessment, and assistive applications. Deploying advanced deep learning architectures on wearable devices with limited computational capacity, however, poses significant challenges. This work presents an efficient HAR solution based on knowledge distillation, enabling compact models to retain high classification accuracy while satisfying smartwatch hardware constraints. The proposed framework adopts a teacher–student paradigm in which high-capacity neural networks—specifically CNN, LSTM, and CNN-LSTM models—trained on multimodal sensor data transfer their learned representations to a lightweight CNN student model optimized for resource-limited environments. Multi-sensor fusion from accelerometer, gyroscope, and magnetometer measurements, commonly available on commercial smartwatches, is incorporated to enhance recognition capability. Evaluation is performed on two benchmark datasets: the CHA dataset, containing 13 daily activities from 10 participants, and the WISDM-HARB dataset, comprising 18 activities from 51 participants. Results indicate classification accuracies of 97.78–98.34% on CHA and 91.03–93.04% on WISDM-HARB, along with storage reductions of up to 85.6% and parameter count decreases of up to 56.9% compared with the original teacher models. These findings demonstrate the practicality of knowledge distillation for delivering accurate, real-time HAR on resource-constrained wearable platforms.

title: Analytical Modeling of Interior Permanent Magnet Machines with Auxiliary Notch Rotor
authors: Fariba Farrokh, Mostafa Shabanpour, Nima Khanbabaeimoghri, Hossein Torkaman, Ebrahim Amiri
abstract: This paper introduces a two-dimensional (2-D) analytical model to predict the performance characteristics of interior permanent magnet (IPM) machines with arbitrary rotor geometry (e.g., auxiliary notch rotor and sinusoidal PM shape). The absence of cylindrical symmetry in such complex rotor structures with auxiliary notch rotor core and rectangular-shaped interior permanent magnets (PMs) poses challenges for solving 2-D boundary conditions and developing the analytical model. To address this issue interior PMs are first mapped to the rotor surface and replaced by sin-shaped PMs. In other words, the original IPM machine with auxiliary notch rotor is transformed into a surface mounted PM machine. Next, sin-shaped PMs are segmented into a number of small pieces to form cylindrical symmetry along the angular length of each piece. Finally, 2-D Maxwell equations are discretely solved in each segment and summated to calculate the resultant flux distribution. Meanwhile, the effects of stator slot’s are modeled with magnetizing current. The accuracy of analytical results are verified by Finite Element (FE), and experimental tests on the motor prototype.

title: Meta and Multi-Task Learning for Action Recognition: A Survey
authors: Gavriela Senteri, Sotiris Manitsaris, Alina Glushkova
abstract: Human movement recognition currently plays an important role in fields where human-machine interaction is included, such as virtual reality and rehabilitation. In these cases, the accurate recognition of human actions has become essential, and is currently making significant steps due to the wide use of Machine Learning algorithms. However, the standard methods in that category currently face several challenges that concern their ability to generalize and adapt to new, unseen data, as well as the need for large amounts of data for training. This survey examines how the methods of Multi-Task Learning and Meta Learning have been deployed as strategies to tackle the above challenges. It studies how the two approaches are applied to human action recognition, focusing on the utilized methodologies, data modalities, and architectural approaches, highlighting the way that the first method promotes task-related knowledge sharing, while the second enables adaptation to scarce data. Through the mapping of studies from 2014 to 2025, this survey identifies trends, methodological gaps, and future insights for the development of more adaptive and context-aware recognition systems.

title: CSP Based Formal Specification of a Resource Allocation for Large-Scale Fog Computing
authors: Youcef Hammal, Khaled Zeraouilia, Lynda Mokdad
publish: 2025 33rd International Symposium on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Computer and Telecommunication Systems (MASCOTS)
abstract: This paper presents a formal specification of two techniques for resource allocation of processing nodes in a largescale Fog network, aiming to optimally handle service requests generated by a set of IoT devices. Fog computing extends Cloud computing services to the network edge by leveraging the computational resources of intermediate Fog nodes. Compared to Cloud resources, Fog resources are typically dynamic, heterogeneous, and constrained by latency and bandwidth. Improving the performance of Fog systems requires effective Fog resource management. To this end, we propose using the CSP process algebra to rigorously specify and validate the techniques we previously introduced, which are based on the stable and efficient Gale-Shapley matching algorithm for large-scale Fog computing networks.

title: MCSim: A Discrete-Event Simulation Framework for Studying Multi-Cloud Networks
authors: Joseph Colton, Ramakrishnan Durairajan
publish: 2025 33rd International Symposium on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Computer and Telecommunication Systems (MASCOTS)
abstract: As enterprises adopt multi-cloud strategies understanding network behavior across heterogeneous cloud infrastructures becomes critical for performance and cost optimization. However, existing network simulators lack support for cloudnative hierarchies (providers, regions, zones) and cannot incorporate empirical inter-cloud measurements or egress cost modeling. We present MCSim, a discrete-event simulator designed specifically for empirical trace-driven multi-cloud network analysis. MCSim models hierarchical cloud topologies with time-varying metrics derived from real measurements, supports cost-aware routing policies, and also supports hybrid emulation by applying simulated network conditions to real hosts using Linux traffic control (tc), bridging simulation with real-world validation. We validate MCSim using 50+ million measurements across $\mathbf{1 0 5}$ VMs in AWS, GCP, and Azure regions. Statistical analysis shows MCSim achieves ${\lt }1 \%$ error in average latency reproduction, with $\mathbf{8 7 \%}$ of inter-cloud pairs showing $\lt \mathbf{5 m s}$ RMSE. Case studies demonstrate MCSim’s ability to analyze cost-performance tradeoffs (27% latency reduction with 57% cost increase), simulate failure scenarios (i.e., impact from regional outages), and enable hybrid testing with ${\lt }2 \%$ deviation from real deployments. MCSim scales to 1000+ nodes with spatial parallelization, enabling reproducible multi-cloud experimentation at unprecedented scale and fidelity.

title: Impact of Parasitic Elements in Low-Energy Marx Generators
authors: Ranjeet Kumar, Sabyasachi Mitra, K. Senthil, Ankur S. Patel, Ankan Basak, Vishnu K. Sharma, Sandeep Kumar Singh, Romesh Chandra, Amitava Roy, R. Israel Bakhtsingh
abstract: This investigation attempts to analyze and optimize the number of stages of low-energy Marx generators. Fast-discharging low-energy Marx generators are composed of stage capacitors of lower capacitance values, which are often comparable with various stray capacitances formed within the Marx system. In this article, analytical expressions for equivalent erected capacitance and open-circuit terminal voltage of the Marx generator are estimated considering the significant presence of stray capacitances. Mathematical observations consistently demonstrate an asymptotic decay in voltage multiplication efficacy with increasing stage count, ultimately reaching a regime of diminishing returns where incremental stages contribute insignificantly to the output potential. The erection dynamics are modeled as a discrete-time process, with comprehensive circuit analysis incorporating distributed stray capacitance elements. Acorrelation function relating three basic parameters: 1) stage count; 2) stage capacitance; and 3) parasitic capacitive coupling between elevated-potential nodes and the grounded containment structure is established. Two innovative design factors, namely stray capacitance loading factor (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol {\beta }$</tex-math> </inline-formula>) and effective voltage multiplication factor (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol {\Gamma }$</tex-math> </inline-formula>), are introduced to accurately estimate and optimize the number of stages. It is also established that the relating equation of these factors under certain conditions omits two fundamental polynomials. One of them is a depressed cubic, whose only real solution is the inverse plastic ratio, and the other is a quadratic whose root is the golden ratio. The inverse plastic ratio solution is opted as the most optimal solution, which is a balance between voltage amplification and energy efficiency, while the golden ratio solution could be the point of relatively higher voltage amplification at the cost of reduced energy efficiency. Amathematical analysis regarding the surge impedance of Marx discovers a condition that indicates the coexistence of Marx and PFN behavior at the same time. On the basis of these analyses and simulations, a 500-kV, 5-kA, 60-ns FWHM Marx generator is developed. Experiments are carried out using a resistive load and validate the analytical findings within 5%–7% accuracy. Details of analysis, optimization, and experiments are narrated in this article.

title: Effectiveness of a High-Velocity-Type Laminar Air Curtain Device for Moisture Isolation under EFEM Airflow Deflection during FOUP Door Opening
authors: Chi-Jen Wen, Tee Lin, Omid Ali Zargar, Chi-Huan Hsieh, Shih-Cheng Hu, Yang-Cheng Shih, Graham Leggett
abstract: As semiconductor manufacturing advances toward the 3 nm node and beyond, wafer sensitivity to particulate and moisture contamination becomes increasingly critical. During front opening unified pod (FOUP) door opening, airflow disturbances and deflection from the equipment front-end module (EFEM) can lead to the intrusion of external moisture and airborne molecular contaminants (AMC), potentially degrading wafer surface integrity and process yield. To address this, a high-velocity-type laminar air curtain device (HV-LAC) was developed using a low-pressure-drop PTFE filter combined with an airflow deflector and perforated plate. This design overcomes deformation and particle-shedding issues seen in conventional ultra-high molecular weight polyethylene (UPE) panels under high flow rates, while improving flow uniformity and barrier stability. The HV-LAC achieved a maximum outlet velocity of 0.54 m/s, maintained velocity non-uniformity around 10% across all flow conditions, and met ISO Class 1 cleanliness. Performance evaluation was conducted under combinations of EFEM background velocities (0.3, 0.4, 0.5 m/s), airflow deflection angles (0°, 15°, 30°), and curtain velocities (0.35, 0.41, 0.54 m/s), with FOUP purge flow at 130 LPM. Experimental results confirmed that the HV-LAC effectively suppressed moisture intrusion, with FOUP internal relative humidity (RH) maintained below 5% in all conditions. The best isolation was observed when curtain velocity matched EFEM airflow, demonstrating that velocity matching is critical to maintaining barrier integrity. This study offers a quantitative design reference for enhancing FOUP micro-environmental control in advanced semiconductor processes.

title: RBF-KAN: Radial Basis Function-Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks
authors: Zengfu Chao, Xinran Liu, Zheyu Wu, Xiaoping Li
abstract: This paper proposes a novel neural network architecture RBF-KAN, integrating the theoretical robustness of Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks (KANs) with the localized features of Radial Basis Function (RBF) networks. To address the low computational efficiency and poor interpretability of original KANs caused by B-spline basis functions, RBF-KAN adopts RBF as the core function for activation parameterization, while retaining KAN’s theoretical guarantees. Experiments on function approximation, basic classification datasets (Moon, Concentric circles, etc.), and the real-world large-scale Adult dataset demonstrate that RBF-KAN achieves competitive accuracy with significantly enhanced efficiency compared to KAN and FourierKAN. Specifically, it reduces parameters by 33%–65% and accelerates inference/training by 65%–99% while maintaining comparable accuracy (e.g., 0.8357 vs. KAN’s 0.8157 on Adult dataset). It exhibits excellent stability and generalization, especially in high-dimensional and large-scale scenarios. This work highlights RBF-KAN’s strengths, limitations, and future directions, underscoring its potential in tackling complex function approximation and classification challenges.

title: A Novel L 1 -and- L 2 -Norm-Integrated Parameter Identification Model for Robot Calibration
authors: Zhibin Li, Pengwei Hu, Xun Deng, Lun Hu, Shuai Li, Xin Luo
abstract: Robots promote the social development by enhancing production efficiency, reducing labor costs, and improving service quality. Meanwhile, their application fields such as healthcare, transportation, and education can drive technological advancement and innovation, thus fostering economic growth and improving our quality of life. However, due to mechanical wear from prolonged operation, the robot absolute positioning error can reach several millimeters, thus it is impossible for them to perform precise tasks. To address this intractable problem, this study innovatively proposes a robot calibration method (FPSA) combining the search algorithm based on proportion integration differentiation (PID) controller and fuzzy strategy for adjusting hyperparameter, its novelties include: 1) designing a novel L 1-and-L2-norm-integrated parameter identification model, then search algorithm [PID search algorithm (PSA)] based on PID controller is adopted to solve this model, which achieves the accurate identification of robot kinematic errors; and 2) developing an efficient fuzzy strategy for adjusting hyperparameter to achieve hyperparameter adaptation in the robot parameter identification model, thereby effectively enhancing the calibration computation efficiency and accuracy. Moreover, we conduct extensive calibration experiments on an HSR JR680 robot. These experimental results demonstrate that compared with other advanced calibration algorithms, the maximum error of the proposed FPSA calibration method is 9.57% higher than that of the most accurate identification model solved by PSA algorithm, which has single L2 norm regularization and objective function. Therefore, this research provides excellent calibration service for a robot, thus contributing to the prosperous development of application fields such as industrial manufacturing and smart agriculture.

title: A Labriform-Inspired Multi-Stable Soft Robotic Swimmer_supp1-3662591.mp4
authors: Yitong Zhou
abstract: Pectoral-fin-based (labriform) swimming combines high-speed propulsion with agile maneuverability through rigid-flexible fin partitioning. Inspired by this principle, we present a multi-stable soft robotic swimmer composed of two wedge-shaped bistable actuators integrated with fin-like rigid-flexible morphologies. The bistable actuators generate large, rapid deformations for thrust production, while the compliant fin membranes enable drag-reducing feathering during recovery. An analytical model is developed to predict the shape of bistable actuators and is validated experimentally with a minimum prediction accuracy of 97.74%. Computational fluid dynamics (CFD) analysis reveals that bistable switching induces vortex dipole ejection, contributing to thrust generation. The proposed robot attains a maximum speed of 17.53 <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\text{cm.s}^{-1}$</tex-math></inline-formula> (1.10 <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\text{BL.s}^{-1}$</tex-math></inline-formula>), a turning radius of 0.58 per body length, and a turning speed of 31.51<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$^\circ$</tex-math></inline-formula>/s, highlighting our design in shaping both swimming speed and maneuverability. By integrating bistable actuation with bio-inspired fin morphologies, this work offers a principled design strategy for achieving fast and maneuverable swimming in robotic systems.

title: Efficient Training of Large-Scale AI Models Through Federated Mixture-of-Experts: A System-Level Approach
authors: Xiaobing Chen, Boyang Zhang, Xiangwei Zhou, Mingxuan Sun, Shuai Zhang, Songyang Zhang, Geoffrey Ye Li
abstract: The integration of Federated Learning (FL) and Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) presents a compelling pathway for training more powerful, large-scale artificial intelligence models (LAMs) on decentralized data while preserving privacy. However, efficient federated training of these complex MoE-structured LAMs is hindered by significant system-level challenges, particularly in managing the interplay between heterogeneous client resources and the sophisticated coordination required for numerous specialized experts. This article highlights a critical, yet underexplored concept: the absence of robust quantitative strategies for dynamic client-expert alignment that holistically considers varying client capacities and the imperative for system-wide load balancing. Specifically, we propose a conceptual system design for intelligent client-expert alignment that incorporates dynamic fitness scoring, global expert load monitoring, and client capacity profiling. By tackling these systemic issues, we can unlock more scalable, efficient, and robust training mechanisms with fewer communication rounds for convergence, paving the way for the widespread deployment of large-scale federated MoE-structured LAMs in edge computing with ultra-high communication efficiency.

title: Modeling and Analysis of Ultrasonic Power Transfer Systems With Asymmetric Transducers
authors: Lining Zhang, Lihua Tang, Mingrui Wang, Mengmeng Li, Peiying Hu, Kean Aw, Aiguo Patrick Hu
abstract: This article presents a novel 2-D equivalent circuit model for analyzing the effects of asymmetric transducer dimensions and radial misalignment on ultrasonic power transfer (UPT) system performance. Based on electromechanical analogies and transfer matrix methods, the model establishes a comprehensive analytical framework incorporating mechanical–electrical coupling effects, energy losses, and geometric parameters. Experimental validation with varying size ratios and radial misalignment conditions between transmitting and receiving transducers demonstrates the model's accuracy. Parametric analysis reveals quantitative relationships between transducer size ratios and system performance, while elucidating the coupling effects between radial misalignment and transducer dimensional differences. The findings show that system efficiency is less impacted under small-range radial misalignment, particularly when the misalignment remains below the difference in transducer radii. Furthermore, the investigation shows a distinct tradeoff relationship: increased dimensional asymmetry enhances misalignment tolerance while reducing overall transmission efficiency. These insights provide theoretical guidance for the design optimization of asymmetric UPT systems.

title: U-StegNet: a Unified Deep Network for Image Steganography
authors: Chuan Qin, Ruijie Du, Lin Huang, Na Wang, Zhenxing Qian, Xinpeng Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Steganography can be mainly classified into two categories: modification-based and generation-based approaches. Modification-based steganography embeds secret messages by altering specific statistical properties of the cover image, offering relatively high capacity and robustness. However, such modifications also make the stego images more susceptible to be detected by steganalysis tools. In contrast, generation-based steganography, which directly generates them via generative models, provides higher security but suffers from limited hiding capacity and poor robustness. To address these limitations, we propose a unified deep network for image steganography (U-StegNet) that integrates the high capacity and robustness of modification-based steganography with the high security of generation-based steganography. Specifically, we design a dual stage hiding strategy. In the first stage, we utilize a generative model to produce an intermediate image that hides part of the secret message while preserving statistical properties consistent with natural images, thereby enhancing resistance to steganalysis. In the second stage, we design a U-Net-based encoder to hide the remaining secret message into the intermediate image, while simultaneously enhancing fine-grained visual details. Moreover, we introduce a message division module that adaptively allocates the message length for each stage based on the image content and capacity constraints, thereby improving both imperceptibility and robustness. Extensive experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our U-StegNet. It achieves a PSNR of 44.41 dB and an SSIM of 0.9968 on stego images, which demonstrates the high imperceptibility of our method. Furthermore, it maintains strong robustness across nine types of common attacks, with message extraction accuracy nearly above 98%.

title: PromptTrack: Streaming Spatial-Temporal Prompt Learning for RGB-T Tracking
authors: Hangfei Li, Guangbin Liu, Xiao Guo, Yufei Zha, Peng Zhang
abstract: This paper presents a novel video-level RGB-T tracking paradigm based on prompt learning, termed PromptTrack, which establishes dense spatial-temporal associations through cross-modal interactions. The method introduces streaming temporal prompts to capture continuous target dynamics (e.g., appearance changes and motion trajectories), while leveraging multimodal spatial prompts to utilize complementary RGB and thermal-infrared (TIR) features dynamically. By propagating temporal prompts through consecutive frames and integrating bidirectional spatial interactions between modalities, PromptTrack achieves superior tracking performance in complex scenarios such as occlusion, low illumination, and distractors. The proposed framework employs a unified multimodal encoder with spatial-temporal modeling via multimodal spatial prompt blocks, enabling efficient fusion of RGB-TIR features without requiring domain-specific structure modifications. Extensive experiments on three RGB-T benchmarks (LasHeR, RGBT210, RGBT234) demonstrate that PromptTrack achieves new state-of-the-art performance, with 76.2% in precision rate on LasHeR and outperforming existing methods by ++1.9% in precision rate and +0.5% in success rate on RGBT234. Notably, its modality-agnostic design facilitates seamless generalization to RGB-D and RGB-E tracking domains achieving new benchmarks on DepthTrack, VOT-RGBD2022, and VisEvent datasets.

title: Audio Watermarking Method with Optimised Embedding Strength Based on DCT-SWT-SVD
authors: Donghan Li, Zhe Chen, Fuliang Yin
abstract: Traditional audio watermarking methods with fixed embedding strengths can not strike a balance between imperceptibility and robustness. In this paper, a robust audio watermarking method with optimised embedding strength based on DCT-SWT-SVD is proposed. Specifically, the watermark bits to be embedded are encrypted using a chaotic map with high randomness. Then, the host audio signal is processed by discrete cosine transform (DCT) to determine the frequency bands for embedding, followed by stationary wavelet transform (SWT) and singular value decomposition (SVD) to extract robust features in these bands. Next, the encrypted watermark bits are embedded in carrier audio based on obtained robust features. After that, the effect of embedding strength on imperceptibility and robustness is theoretically analysed. Moreover, selectable intervals of embedding strength considering robustness and imperceptibility requirements are presented, where robustness is evaluated by attack simulation test using signal processing technique. Finally, the embedding strength is optimised using the sparrow search algorithm (SSA), with its adaptability discussed. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms the existing methods in terms of watermarking performance, exhibiting excellent resilience to common attack methods including desynchronization attacks, without affecting the quality of the watermarked audio.

title: Training-Free Dual Hyperbolic Adapters for Better Cross-Modal Reasoning
authors: Yi Zhang, Chun-Wun Cheng, Junyi He, Ke Yu, Yushun Tang, Carola-Bibiane Schönlieb, Zhihai He, Angelica I. Aviles-Rivero
abstract: Recent research in Vision-Language Models (VLMs) has significantly advanced our capabilities in cross-modal reasoning. However, existing methods suffer from performance degradation with domain changes or require substantial computational resources for fine-tuning in new domains. To address this issue, we develop a new adaptation method for large vision-language models, called Training-free Dual Hyperbolic Adapters (T-DHA). We characterize vision-language relationship between semantic concepts, which typically has a hierarchical tree structure, in the hyperbolic space instead of the traditional Euclidean space. Hyperbolic spaces exhibit exponential volume growth with radius, unlike the polynomial growth in Euclidean space. We find that this unique property is particularly effective for embedding hierarchical data structures using the Poincaré ball model, achieving significantly improved representation and discrimination power. Coupled with negative learning, it provides more accurate and robust classifications with fewer feature dimensions. Our extensive experimental results on various datasets demonstrate that the T-DHA method significantly outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods in few-shot image recognition and domain generalization tasks.

title: Output Synchronization via Intermittent Dynamic Event-Triggered Sampled-Data Security Control for Delayed Reaction–Diffusion Neural Networks
authors: Zi-Peng Wang, Hong-Yu Chen, Junfei Qiao, Haixu Ding, Huai-Ning Wu, Tingwen Huang
abstract: This article addresses the issue of output synchronization via intermittent dynamic event-triggered sampled-data (IDETSD) security control of reaction–diffusion neural networks (RDNNs) under spatially local averaged measurements (SLAMs) subject to both delays and random deception attacks, where a Bernoulli distribution is utilized to describe whether channels suffer from the cyberattacks. An IDETSD security control method under SLAMs and random deception attacks is presented to achieve the output synchronization of delayed RDNNs. Compared with time-triggered intermittent sampled-data (SD) control strategies, a dynamic event-triggered (ET) mechanism to more effectively mitigate the impact induced by random deception attacks that intentionally tamper with the state transmission signals from sensors to controllers is introduced in this article. Moreover, new output synchronization criteria are established by applying an ET-dependent switched Lyapunov functional (LF) and inequality techniques. Then, the desired IDETSD controller is obtained by solving linear matrix inequalities (LMIs). To validate the efficacy of the proposed approach, simulation outcomes from two numerical studies are presented.

title: Power Supply Induced Jitter: Introduction and Recent Advances
authors: Chulsoon Hwang, Jai Narayan Tripathi, Dan Oh
publish: IEEE Transactions on Signal and Power Integrity
abstract: Jitter is a critical concern in modern electronic systems, particularly as semiconductor devices increasingly operate with low supply rails to minimize power consumption. This paper provides a comprehensive review of Power Supply Induced Jitter (PSIJ), which refers to timing variations directly caused by fluctuations in the power supply voltage. It examines the fundamental mechanisms of PSIJ and presents generalized models for predicting jitter. System-level jitter tracking characteristics are analyzed for serial links, memory interfaces, and synchronous logic to explain the resulting jitter spectrum. The paper also summarizes various pre-silicon PSIJ modeling techniques, including time-domain, frequency-domain, slope-based, and delay-based methods. Finally, recent advancements in PSIJ research are discussed.

title: PV Hosting Capacity Assessment of Storage-Integrated Distribution Systems With Constrained PV Curtailment and Load Shedding Under Fault Conditions
authors: Yi Wang, Yuxuan Huang, Shida Zhang, Aiwen Jiang, Yaoqiang Wang, Venkata Dinavahi, Jun Liang
abstract: In recent years, distributed photovoltaic (PV) systems have experienced accelerated deployment in distribution networks, driven by inherent advantages. However, high-penetration PV integration introduces critical operational challenges, including voltage violations and reverse power flows, which become progressively more pronounced as penetration levels increase and may ultimately harm user interests. To comprehensively assess the network's PV hosting capacity (PVHC) while safeguarding the interests of both PV owners and load consumers, this article proposes a novel stochastic biscenario (prefault and postfault) assessment framework, which explicitly quantifies and constrains postfault PV curtailment and load shedding, mediated by battery energy storage systems. We derive an analytical linearized expression for the nonlinear PV curtailment under all N-1 contingencies, transforming the original PVHC assessment model into a tractable mixed-integer linear programming model. Furthermore, our analysis reveals that, an inherent tradeoff exists between reducing fault-induced PV curtailment and enhancing load reliability in storage-integrated grids due to state of charge constraints, which holds significant guiding importance for the practical industrial application of PV integration. Finally, the effectiveness, and scalability of the proposed method are verified through different test systems.

title: Hybrid Event-Triggered Fuzzy Secure Consensus for PDE-Based Multi-Agent Systems Subject to Time Delays and Multiple Attacks
authors: Chuan Zhang, Xiao-Yu Sun, Huai-Ning Wu, Zi-Peng Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: This study constructs an innovative event-triggered (ET) fuzzy consensus framework for nonlinear delayed parabolic PDE-based multi-agent systems (MASs) to resist multiple attacks. Firstly, a novel dual-scale modeling approach is introduced that synergizes Galerkin-based order reduction with Takagi-Sugeno fuzzy technique to construct a relatively precise ODE-based MASs capturing the dominant dynamics. Secondly, a resilient dynamic ET strategy is formulated to orchestrate communication scheduling, which not only curtails the demand on network bandwidth but also delivers superior dynamic performance over established ET schemes. Building upon this mechanism, a distributed consensus protocol is devised with inherent robustness to counteract cyber attacks. Subsequently, by employing a constructed Lyapunov functional, sufficient criteria guaranteeing resilient cooperative control are deduced, and the corresponding controller parameters are computed by solving linear matrix inequalities. The practical effectiveness and theoretical contributions of the proposed approach are ultimately corroborated through simulations conducted on thermal management systems for cooling fins of a hypersonic vehicle.

title: Preferential Bayesian Optimization with Crash Feedback
authors: Johanna Menn, David Stenger, Sebastian Trimpe
abstract: Bayesian optimization is a popular black-box optimization method for parameter learning in control and robotics. It typically requires an objective function that reflects the user's optimization goal. However, in practical applications, this objective function is often inaccessible due to complex or unmeasurable performance metrics. Preferential Bayesian optimization (PBO) overcomes this limitation by leveraging human feedback through pairwise comparisons, eliminating the need for explicit performance quantification. When applying PBO to hardware systems, such as in quadcopter control, crashes can cause time-consuming experimental resets, wear and tear, or otherwise undesired outcomes. Standard PBO methods cannot incorporate feedback from such crashed experiments, resulting in the exploration of parameters that frequently lead to experimental crashes. We thus introduce CrashPBO, a user-friendly mechanism that enables users to both express preferences and report crashes during the optimization process. Benchmarking on synthetic functions shows that this mechanism reduces crashes by 63 % and increases data efficiency. Through experiments on three robotics platforms, we demonstrate the wide applicability and transferability of CrashPBO, highlighting that it provides a flexible, user-friendly framework for parameter learning with human feedback on preferences and crashes.
