title: Soft Auxetic Fingertip (SAF) for Shape-Adaptive and Stable Grasping
authors: Peiyu Ma, Zhengquan Shen, Yukun Ge, Thrishantha Nanayakkara
abstract: This letter presents a soft auxetic fingertip (SAF) that decouples shape adaptability from payload ability by separating rigid support from compliant conformity. A stiff outer frame carries loads while auxetic array provides passive conformity and enlarges the contact area, distal tips improve grasping of flat and thin objects. The fingertip is fabricated by 3D printing conductive thermoplastic polyurethane (TPU). Based on its piezoresistive effect, the soft auxetic layer is used as a mechanical filter to enable contact and slip detection and to drive a grip-force compensation strategy. Under identical input torques, SAF achieves a 10.66%–151.72% payload improvement over the FinRay baseline across eight objects. Combined with slip detection based on resistance signal and grip-force compensation, it achieves a 89.29% success rate in pick-and-place tests on 28 tools and food items.

title: Growth and microwave properties of FeSe thin films and comparison with Fe(Se,Te)
authors: Alessandro Magalotti, Andrea Alimenti, Giuseppe Celentano, Matteo Cialone, Valeria Braccini, Antonella Mancini, Enrico Silva, Andrea Masi, Nicola Pompeo, Giovanni Sotgiu, Kostiantyn Torokhtii, Pablo Vidal Garc´ıa, Angelo Vannozzi
abstract: In this work, we have grown ∼100nm thick pristine FeSe films by pulsed laser deposition. The films were structurally characterized with X-ray diffraction and their surface morphology checked through atomic force microscopy. Microwave measurements, performed with a dielectric loaded resonator tuned at the frequency of 8GHz, allowed the characterization of the samples surface resistance, in view of potential applications in microwave haloscopes for dark matter search. Here, we report the comparison of the microwave properties of FeSe with Fe(Se,Te) thin films, as the temperature is swept from 4K to 20K. By applying a constant static magnetic field of 12T, it was also possible to discern the magnetic field resilience of the two samples. FeSe showed a larger critical temperature drift as the field is applied and a small broadening, while the opposite appears in Fe(Se,Te). A preliminary analysis of vortex pinning shows margins for optimizing pinning in FeSe.

title: A New Dual-Component Magnetic Field Probe for EMI Test
authors: Lei Wang, Enming Luo, Sha Tang, Qiang Wang, Yijun Shi
abstract: This paper presents a new magnetic probe that achieves two different magnetic-field components in near-field scanning measurements. The proposed probe employs a composite architecture comprising three key elements: a pair of conventional monopoles, a T-shaped shorted loop, and two interconnected vias. Different from existing solutions using differential or single U-shaped loops for electromagnetic-field (Hy and Ez) detection, this innovative architecture through integration of monopoles and T-shaped shorted loop successfully enables synchronous detection of vertically orthogonal magnetic field components (Hy and Hz). Moreover, the probe was fabricated using four-layer PCB technology and validated through a near-field measurement system incorporating standard calibration kits. Simulated and measured results reveal the detection sensitivity of the proposed magnetic probe along the y-direction is greater than -45 dB at 3-15 GHz, but it is more than -50 dB at 4.5-15 GHz along the z-direction. Therefore, the proposed probe can achieve simultaneous precise measurement of dual orthogonal magnetic field components (Hy and Hz), and has a wider operational bandwidth (4.5-15 GHz).

title: Research on Artificial Intelligence Empowering Vocational Education Teaching Reform under the Background of Rural Revitalization
authors: Duo Zhang, Min Zhang, Yan Zeng, Yang Guo, Bo Li
abstract: Under the dual background of rural revitalization and the development of generative AI, the upgrading of rural industries is in urgent need of interdisciplinary talents who "understand technology and can practice". However, traditional vocational education has problems such as scattered resources and disconnection between courses and industries. This paper focuses on the core mechanism of artificial intelligence empowering rural vocational education teaching reform. By analyzing relevant data from 2015 to 2023, it reveals the contradiction between "supply-demand mismatch" and "resource constraints", and constructs a three-fold mechanism: the technical support mechanism optimizes resource supply, the model innovation mechanism realizes dynamic connection between industry and education, and the guarantee feedback mechanism improves quality and adaptability.This research provides new ideas for solving the "impossible trinity" of rural vocational education, enriches the scenario-based research of "AI + education", and provides a replicable practical path for vocational colleges. In the future, it is necessary to address challenges such as technological inclusiveness and promote AI to become an accelerator for talent training in rural revitalization.

title: Overhead Prediction for PIM-Enabled Applications with Performance-Aware Behaviour Models
authors: Birte Friesel, Olaf Spinczyk
abstract: Today’s processing-in-memory (PIM) devices, such as UPMEM PIM, behave like computational offloading engines: applications must explicitly allocate memory ranks, upload PIM kernels, transfer data and control commands, launch kernels, and read back output data. Past research has focused on identifying offloading candidates and predicting the performance of corresponding PIM kernels. However, this is only half the truth: PIM management and data transfer overheads can easily jeopardize kernel-level performance gains, and thus must be taken into account by scheduling algorithms. These overheads, incurred as part of software development kit (SDK) operations, are application- and workload-dependent: workload partitioning (i.e., the amount and size of data transfers) often depends on workload size and resource allocation. Hence, PIM performance models must account for PIM SDK operations in addition to kernel execution, requiring time-intensive, application-specific benchmarks that must be repeated for each SDK release or workload change. We present a more efficient performance modelling approach based on behaviour models. We train a behaviour model that predicts an application’s PIM SDK operations for arbitrary workloads and resource allocations, and combine it with application-independent performance models for these operations. Thus, each application must be profiled only once, and profiling does not rely on availability of PIM modules or cycle-accurate simulation. We evaluate a proof-of-concept implementation of our approach on twelve UPMEM PIM applications, and show that it can predict application-specific PIM overheads from simulation traces with an error of less than 25 % in nine cases, and no more than 10 % in six cases.

title: Design and Implementation of a Low-Power Standby Module Utilizing Acoustic Signal Detection
authors: Zixuan Hu, Yunfeng Han, Jiale Hu, Junze Li, Niaz Ahmed, Junjie Shi
abstract: Underwater acoustic positioning responders are generally constrained by signal source power and battery capacity: shortening deployment period while increasing operational costs due to frequent requirement of battery replacement. This paper thus presents the design and implementation of a low-power circuit module allowing long operation times for both signal detection and equipment control. The module not only reduce duty cycle but also conserve battery power by allowing users to manage the responder’s operational state. The main contribution of this paper are: a) the design and detection of low-complexity wake-up signal, b) the design choice and decision of low power hardware circuitry, and c) low power embedded software deployment. Field tests are also conducted to support our claims. The results show that the duty circuit module achieves a detection probability of more than 90% with an average operating power consumption of 7.2 mW. The conventional duty circuit module’s power consumption is typically less than 100 mW; the performance index detailed in this article is considered state-of-the-art.

title: Grids Frequency Response Models and Their Applications: A Review
authors: Xiaolong Guo, Qiang Wang, Jianlin Hu, Jingming Wang, Bingquan Lan, Peng Zhao, Yangyang Guo, Aizhi Luo
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: With the widespread integration of new energy sources and the rapid development of their control technologies, the frequency response characteristics of power systems have become more complex, which posing severe challenges to the accurate prediction of frequency responses. This review introduces the construction methods of frequency response models for units, single-area and multi-area systems, conducts a detailed analysis of the application of frequency response models. Through the review, the research challenges and hotspots related to frequency response models in the future have been clarified, which will serve as a guide for new frequency response models’ designs.

title: GenB Distance Learning: Interactive Web-Based Science Laboratory for Public Secondary Schools
authors: Mary Jane C. Samonte, Marc Edward V. De Jesus, John Lorenz D. Peña, Ellize Angel G. Samson, Jefferson Andrew P. Castalone, Emmillie Joy B. Mejia
abstract: GenB Distance Learning is a web-based laboratory system designed to enhance the teaching and learning of General Biology 2 at Balingasa High School. Developed to align with the DepEd STEM curriculum, it offers interactive features such as an Evolution Timeline, Phylogenetic Tree Explorer, Virtual Dissection, and a Punnett Square Generator. Integrating these tools into a web-based platform aims to improve student engagement, accessibility, and understanding of complex biological concepts. The development of GenB Distance Learning involved extensive user research, incorporating feedback from students, teachers, and IT administrators to ensure an intuitive and effective learning experience. A comparative study between web-based and traditional laboratory methods revealed that students who used the system demonstrated improved comprehension and performance. While users praised its usability, reliability, and overall effectiveness, feedback suggested areas for enhancement, particularly in terms of innovation and long-term engagement. Findings indicate that GenB Distance Learning provides a scalable and accessible alternative to traditional lab-based learning, making science education more interactive and efficient for public school students. Future research could explore its long-term impact on learning retention and its potential integration into broader educational frameworks.

title: On the Effectiveness of End-Users’ Data Backup Practices Against Data Corruption
authors: Lalchandra Rampersaud, Behzad Ousat, Caitlin Brown, Selcuk Uluagac, Amin Kharraz
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: With the rising threat of data loss, data backup has become an important part of defense mechanisms. Data corruption attacks such as ransomware have become more consequential when victims cannot retrieve their data and are more likely to pay the ransom fee. In this study, we evaluate end-users’ readiness in protecting their data and potential issues with their data protection plans. We investigate how users protect their data and what their data recovery plans look like. We identified some contradictory and surprising findings. For instance, we observed that many users were confused about who was responsible for data protection. Only 57 (11.6%) of the participants reported that data protection is a user’s responsibility. We asked participants to give a dollar value on how much their data might be worth. While 4 (0.8%) reported values of more than one million and 114 (23.1%) reported less than $100, 233 (47.3%) participants believed that their data was worth at least $1,000. However, 103 (20.9%) of those participants did not use any viable backup solution to protect their data.

title: Low Cost Methods for Estimating an Unknown Number of Sources for DOA
authors: Ahmed A Hussain, Nizar Tayem, Abdel Hamid Soliman
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: Estimating the number of impinging sources is an essential prerequisite for high-resolution direction-of-arrival (DOA) estimation. Existing methods, such as the Akaike Information Criterion (AIC), Minimum Description Length (MDL), and eigenvalue gap techniques, have been widely used but often suffer from high computational complexity or poor robustness under low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) and small-sample scenarios. In this work, we propose and analyze two novel methods for source enumeration: (i) a normalized eigenvalue gap-based method (PM1), and (ii) a covariance trace-based method (PM2) that computes the number of sources as the ratio of the trace of the covariance matrix to the number of antenna elements. We conduct a comprehensive performance and complexity analysis of these methods in comparison with AIC and MDL. MATLAB simulations demonstrate that PM1 provides robust estimation under low SNR conditions with reduced computational overhead, while PM2 offers ultra-low complexity with competitive accuracy in moderate-to-high SNR regimes. These findings highlight the practical potential of the proposed algorithms for real-time DOA estimation in embedded systems.

title: Detection and Analysis of Spurious Electromagnetic Fields in Indoor Telecommunication Networks
authors: Elena Borisova
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: The article contains the research on the presence of unintended electromagnetic emissions in the home setting. The spectral composition of the observed fields is paid special attention, on the basis of in-situ measures. The results underscore the impact of different domestic appliances on ambient electromagnetic background that helps in understanding the low-level radiation exposure in the daily life more in detail.

title: Profiling Teachers’ Digital Literacy: A Latent Profile Analysis and Its Relationship with Professional Titles
authors: Zhang Xue, Zhang Yi, Xi Linjin
abstract: The digital literacy of teachers is a core competency in the digital age, enabling educators to effectively engage in teaching, adapt to educational transformation, and foster pedagogical innovation. It plays a strategic role in advancing the quality of basic education. This study collected data from 3,587 primary and secondary school teachers in central China through a structured questionnaire. Latent Profile Analysis was employed to identify distinct digital literacy profiles and to examine their associations with professional titles. The results identified four latent types: low-level, lower-middle, upper-middle, and high-level, with professional title and teaching experience significantly influencing profile membership. These findings reveal structural variations in teachers’ digital literacy and provide both theoretical grounding and practical guidance for optimizing professional title evaluation systems, developing differentiated training pathways, and enhancing teachers’ digital competence in the context of educational modernization.

title: Medium-Long Term Balance Analysis Considering Extreme Scenarios at Multi-time Scales
authors: Weijie Wu, Sui Peng, Zhengmin Zuo, Yixin Li, Shucan Zhou, Shijie Lin
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: Global climate change has exacerbated the frequency of extreme scenarios, leading to a higher risk of new power system balance. In order to solve this problem, this paper firstly proposes the extreme scenario timing operation constraints, considers the time-coupled constraints such as unit ramp-up and does not destroy the data characteristics of new energy output in extreme scenarios, and then nests them in the medium-long-term balance analysis model based on the approximate sustained load curve modeling, and then finally launches the case study based on the IEEERTS-1979 to demonstrate that the model can formulate a reasonable unit overhaul and standby It is demonstrated that the model can formulate reasonable unit maintenance and reservation allocation plans, effectively deal with the impact of extreme scenarios, and reduce the risk of system balance.

title: Mathematical Modelling and Programming of the Torsion Test Process of Rods and Beams in the Further Improvement of the Automotive Industry Networks and Economy
authors: Rakhimberdiev Kuvonchbek, Otaboeva Dildora, B. Toshpulov, Rakhmonov Mehriddin
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: In this article, the issues of improving the mechanical characteristics of cars in the development of the economy of the automotive industry are studied. In the course of the research, if the car wheels are fixed at one end of a colourful steering wheel, and a pair of forces lying on its cross section is applied to the oth-er end, a mathematical model of rotation processes, a model in the form of a dif-ferential circuit, and its numerical solutions were calculated. Also, the numerical solutions were algorithmized based on the mathematical model developed in the calculation. A software tool created in the C++ programming language and nu-merical solutions based on this software tool was presented. Also, by modelling this complex mechanical process, a high-accuracy simulation tool was developed, and scientific conclusions were presented that it is possible to achieve high eco-nomic efficiency in conducting research and using this tool in the production of cars.

title: KG-SA-GNN: Knowledge-Guided Self-Attention Graph Networks for Imbalanced Fault Detection in Smart Grids
authors: Yi Guo, Yi Kuang, Bin Duan, Sheng Li
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: Detecting low-frequency faults in smart grids is challenging due to the class imbalance in fault data and dynamic changes in grid topology. To address these issues, this paper proposes a knowledge-guided self-attention graph neural network (KG-SA-GNN). First, a domain-specific knowledge graph is constructed by integrating equipment topological constraints, historical fault co-occurrence patterns, and maintenance rules, which enhances the modeling of physical relationships in the power grid. Second, a dynamic self-attention mechanism is introduced that incorporates relationship weights and fault frequency priors to adaptively focus on critical propagation paths and improve classification performance. Experimental results on the IEEE 39-node system show that the proposed method achieves a recall rate of 78.6% for cascading faults, outperforming SMOTE-GNN by 14.9%. The false alarm rate is reduced by 9.5%, and the macro-average F1-score reaches 87.1%. The results demonstrate that KG-SA-GNN provides an effective solution for imbalanced fault diagnosis in smart grids.

title: Research on Node Evaluation Model of Disciplinary Knowledge Graph Based on Contrastive Learning Theory
authors: Jiang Yuan, Lu Li
abstract: Disciplinary knowledge graphs have increasingly exhibited substantial value in the integration and optimal allocation of educational resources. Node evaluation constitutes a fundamental task within knowledge graph research. To address the critical challenges associated with node representation and the assessment of node importance in disciplinary knowledge graphs, this paper proposes a node representation model grounded in contrastive learning. By leveraging contrastive learning to generate high-quality node representations, combined with the implementation of a two-level hierarchical sampling strategy and an enhanced graph attention network. The experimental results demonstrate a significant improvement in both the quality of node representations and the accuracy of importance assessments within disciplinary knowledge graphs.

title: Effect of Sensor Positions on Wearable Sensor-Based Fall Detection Using Deep Residual Network
authors: Sakorn Mekruksavanich, Anuchit Jitpattanakul
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Software Engineering and Service Science (ICSESS)
abstract: Wearable sensor-based fall detection systems are increasingly vital in elderly care and health monitoring applications. However, determining the optimal sensor placement remains a key challenge affecting detection accuracy and practical deployment. This study examines the influence of sensor position on fall detection performance using the proposed FD-ResNeXt, a deep residual network enhanced with multi-kernel modules and cardinality to improve feature representation from time-series signals. Experiments were conducted on the UpFall dataset, which includes fall and activities of daily living data collected from 17 participants wearing sensors at five body locations: ankle, right pocket, belt, neck, and wrist. The proposed model was trained and validated using five-fold cross-validation with both accelerometer and gyroscope data under single- and multi-sensor configurations. The results show that sensor placement has a significant impact on performance. The neck-mounted sensor achieved the highest accuracy (99.15%), followed by the ankle (98.55%) and belt (98.22%) positions. The wrist showed moderate improvement (97.03%), while the right pocket performed poorly (33.98%). Combining accelerometer and gyroscope data enhanced overall accuracy, confirming the advantage of multi-sensor fusion. The findings underscore critical trade-offs between placement, accuracy, and usability, offering valuable insights for designing robust, user-friendly fall detection systems.

title: Research on a Differential Threshold–Driven Coordinated Switching Mechanism for Dual-System Clearing in Electricity Markets
authors: Jingyi Li, Ciwei Gao, Yunting Yao, Kai Xie, Genjun Chen
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: With the increasing penetration of renewable energy, the reliability of the single clearing mechanism in power systems has become insufficient. However, the switching criteria between the dual systems lack a theoretical foundation. This study is based on the 5-node power system topology, employing the interior point method and sequential quadratic programming method as the clearing algorithms for the main and backup systems respectively. An optimal power flow model was constructed, and a dual-system switching evaluation framework was designed to calculate the critical differential threshold for switching between the two systems. The case study provides the theoretical foundation and technical support for the parallel operation of dual clearing systems in electricity markets, and are of great significance for ensuring the safe and stable operation of market mechanisms in new power systems.

title: Evidence Use in Argumentative Essays: Comparing Student Writings and Deepseek-Generated Texts
authors: Guoye Wu, Yi Zhang
abstract: This study compares the use of evidence in argumentative essays between Chinese students and texts generated by Deepseek, a widely used generative AI. Grounded in Packer & Timpane’s (1997) taxonomy of evidence, the authors analyze 30 student essays (TEM-4 mid-level proficiency) and 30 AI-generated essays under identical prompts. Results reveal that both groups rely heavily on expert testimony, statistics, known facts, and logical reasoning. AI-generated essays exhibited quantitative superiority in expert testimony (p=0.002), statistics (p<0.001), and examples (p=0.017), but qualitative deficiencies in contextual specificity. For instance, AI essays prioritized generalized examples (e.g., "Some companies ignore regulations") and authoritative sources (e.g., WHO citations), while student essays integrated context-specific cases (e.g., "Foxconn discharged 12,000 tons of wastewater in 2022") and nuanced logical reasoning. Notably, known facts and shared beliefs were significantly overrepresented in AI outputs (p<0.001), reflecting a tendency toward consensus-based arguments. Pedagogically, we propose a hybrid approach: students should strategically integrate AI-generated authoritative evidence (e.g., expert citations, statistics) with human-curated contextualized examples and critical analysis to balance persuasiveness, originality, and engagement.

title: Smart Road Infrastructure Using LiFi-Based Roadside Units for Next-Generation Vehicular Networks
authors: Doniyor Rustamov, Bakhtiyor Makhkamov, Ibrohimbek Yusupov, Mandeep Singh, Jaspreet Kaur, Gagandeep Kaur
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: This paper will present a smart road infrastructure architecture, including Light Fidelity (LiFi) enabled roadside units (RSUs) to enhance next-generation vehicular networks with ultra-low latency and high-throughput and localized communication services. We introduce system design, channel and link model, considerations of resources allocation, and performance comparison of LiFi RSUs and conventional DSRC/5G sidelinks when the highway is subject to normal traffic conditions. In a small scale simulation, in throughput and during packet delivery, the dependence of vehicle speed and density of the RSU is showed. An analytical model, diagram, parameter table, and plotted results have been incorporated in the paper. The main results point to the fact that LiFi RSUs are capable of delivering multi-hundred Mbps connections in line-of-sight and can be used as offload hotspots that are local to the cellular networks.

title: A Novel Adaptive Learning Framework Integrating Item Response Theory, Bayesian Knowledge Tracing and Deep Learning with Confidence Calibrated Feedback
authors: Avyakt Agrawal
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: Students often misjudge their own understanding, with overconfidence slowing practice and weakening retention. This work introduces a deployable adaptive assessment framework that combines psychometric modeling with confidence calibration. Items are authored with Revised Bloom’s Taxonomy to make cognitive demand explicit, and learner ability is estimated with Item Response Theory while mastery progression is tracked with Bayesian Knowledge Tracing. A 1–5 confidence rating is captured after each response, enabling calibration feedback and targeted nudges when confidence and accuracy diverge. Evaluation follows a hybrid protocol. Psychometric analyses are conducted on the Eedi dataset from the NeurIPS 2020 Education Challenge, showing moderate accuracy (64%), high reliability (KR20 = 0.98), and weak discrimination, highlighting the need for improved item authoring. Calibration analyses use the OSF Confidence Database, where learners display mild underconfidence and notable calibration error (ECE 0.52), confirming the value of integrating confidence capture.≈A construct validity check also links taxonomy-based difficulty tags with empirical IRT difficulty estimates. The results demonstrate that combining psychometric rigor with calibration-aware feedback is both feasible and informative. By aligning taxonomy tagging, item calibration, mastery tracking, and confidence capture, the proposed framework offers a transparent and practical path toward adaptive systems that improve learning accuracy while reducing metacognitive bias.

title: Amplitude recovery processing of ground penetrating radar data in seasonal freezing area
authors: Tianyu Liao, Xianwu Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Geographic Information and Remote Sensing Technology (GIRST)
abstract: Due to the attenuation of electromagnetic wave in the propagation of underground medium with the depth of the medium, it is usually necessary to recover the amplitude of GPR data in order to achieve the maximum detection depth and accurately obtain the information of buried objects in actual exploration. The seasonal frozen ground area is widely distributed in Xinjiang. Due to the influence of the climate of the seasonal frozen ground area on the shallow engineering geology, the electromagnetic environment of the seasonal frozen ground area shows seasonal changes, which leads to the great influence of the season in the propagation process of the electromagnetic wave in the shallow geology, which brings great trouble to the amplitude recovery of the ground penetrating radar data. In this paper, based on the relative permittivity data of Kaba-he in the seasonal frozen soil area of Xinjiang, the non-absorbing soil permittivity model in different seasons is constructed. Taking the metal pipe as an example, the reflection amplitude data of the metal pipe in different seasons are simulated by gprMax software, and the reflection amplitude data are restored to the same depth by the method of amplitude recovery. The particularity of amplitude recovery from ground penetrating radar (GPR) data in seasonal freezing area is discussed.

title: A QoS-Aware Routing Protocol for High-Speed Optical Networks Using Reinforcement Learning
authors: Shweta Goyal, Tolib Rajabov, Maksadbek Babajanov, Ogabek Solayev, Odilbek Allaberganov, Sudha Shanker Prasad
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: This paper proposes a QoS-aware routing protocol for high-speed optical networks that leverages reinforcement learning (RL) to adapt path selection to dynamic traffic, physical-layer impairments, and service-level objectives. The RL agent observes network state (e.g., residual bandwidth, path length, OSNR margins, and historical blocking) and selects routes that jointly optimize blocking probability, end-to-end latency, and differential delay while respecting wavelength/slot continuity constraints. We design state, action, and reward formulations that capture QoS priorities and implement training/inference with lightweight overhead suitable for online deployment. Simulation results on realistic network topologies show reduced blocking probability, improved tail latency, and enhanced QoS satisfaction compared with shortest-path, fixed-weight, and heuristic baselines.

title: Ethical Considerations of AI-Enabled Education
authors: Jin Zhai, Jihong Xu
abstract: Amid the current digital wave, generative artificial intelligence (AIGC) is rapidly penetrating the education sector with its powerful capabilities and innovative features, triggering a series of transformations in both teaching and learning. Educators have keenly recognized the advantages of this technology, leveraging AIGC as an instructional aid to create dynamic course materials and design diverse teaching activities, thereby significantly enriching classroom presentations. Students, on the other hand, enthusiastically utilize AIGC to enhance learning efficiency — for instance, employing intelligent translation software to overcome language barriers or refining essay content with AI-assisted writing tools. As the frequency of AIGC applications in educational settings continues to rise, profound shifts in pedagogical paradigms have emerged. The traditional binary "teacher-student" structure is transitioning into a ternary "teacher-student-machine" framework, fostering more flexible classroom interactions, personalized learning resource delivery, and greater autonomy and selectivity in learning pathways.

title: Machine Learning Driven Undergraduate Thesis Grade Prediction Supporting Educational Decisions
authors: Xiang Li, Lidan Wang, Shukai Duan, Feng Chen
abstract: The undergraduate thesis is a pivotal component of higher education curricula across all disciplines, directly determining students' graduation eligibility. Its quality serves as a critical indicator of institutional teaching standards. With artificial intelligence profoundly impacting higher education, global institutions are rapidly integrating AI-related courses and applications, making early prediction of thesis quality grades increasingly imperative. This study leverages multidimensional data from engineering students over three consecutive academic years. Feature engineering and SMOTE oversampling techniques were employed to address data imbalance and enhance model performance. The processed dataset was fed into four models for training and testing: Random Forest (RF), Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU), Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP), and Support Vector Machine (SVM). Following hyperparameter optimization via grid search, all models demonstrated strong performance across evaluation metrics including accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score.Notably, the Random Forest(RF) model achieved a prediction accuracy of 87.85%, significantly outperforming comparative models. This research confirms RF's efficacy in forecasting thesis quality grades, providing data-driven decision support for reducing delayed graduation rates and optimizing educational resource allocation. Consequently, it advances practical applications of educational data mining.

title: LiDAR-Guided Adaptive RSSI Filtering: An Approach for Coordination Target Selection in Multi-Robot Systems
authors: Haoyu Wen, Zexi Hua, Yongchuan Tang, Bin Wen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Robotics and Automatic Control (IRAC)
abstract: Efficient selective communication is critical in lowcost multi-robot systems to avoid network congestion and high computational overhead. However, identifying collision-risk neighbors quickly and accurately remains a challenge. We propose a LiDAR-guided adaptive RSSI filtering algorithm for coordinating object selection. To stabilize raw RSSI signals, our method adapts the EWMA filter by integrating LiDAR distance information. This ensures signal stability while enabling a rapid response as robots approach. Furthermore, a dynamic RSSI risk threshold is established, triggering communication only when a neighbor's signal strength indicates it is a coordination object. Experiments show the algorithm's responsiveness is significantly superior to baseline methods, including standard EWMA. Its computational time is comparable to EWMA and much lower than complex Kalman filter-based methods, demonstrating enhanced response capability while maintaining low overhead.

title: An Improved Cloud Drift Optimization Based Two-Layer MPC for Economic Dispatch of Microgrids with Hybrid Energy Storage
authors: Peixin He, Chenyuhao Ma, Daming Zhou, S. M. Muyeen
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: This paper proposes a two-layer Model Predictive Control (MPC) framework integrated with an Improved Cloud Drift Optimization (ICDO) algorithm to address the economic dispatch problem in renewable-energy-powered microgrids with hybrid energy storage systems (HESS). The upper-layer MPC performs long-term economic scheduling with battery degradation cost consideration, while the lower-layer MPC handles short-term power fluctuation suppression and prediction error compensation. To enhance the global optimization capability and computational efficiency of the non-convex upper-layer problem, an ICDO algorithm is introduced, incorporating sinusoidal chaotic mapping initialization, a ring topology strategy, and a multi-layer adaptive parameter mechanism. Simulation results under various electricity price and uncertainty scenarios demonstrate that the proposed method significantly reduces operating costs, mitigates battery degradation, and improves computational performance compared to conventional solvers and other swarm intelligence algorithms.

title: Renewable Energy Absorption Capacity Assessment Method of Power System Based on Fine-Tuning Large Language Model
authors: Ke Li, Junhong Guo, Zongyuan Chen, Tao Yu, Lizhou Jiang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: With the rapid rise in renewable energy penetration, ensuring the secure and efficient integration of large-scale renewable generation has become a critical challenge for contemporary power systems. Accurately and promptly evaluating the renewable energy absorption capacity is essential for the reliable planning, real-time operation, and intelligent control of modern grids. Traditional assessment approaches based on deterministic mathematical models often involve intricate formulations and high computational burdens. On the other hand, methods driven by artificial intelligence frequently struggle to capture the inherent stochasticity and multi-time-scale volatility of renewable sources and loads, thereby compromising the accuracy of their predictions. To this end, this paper proposes a method for evaluating renewable energy absorption capacity of power systems based on fine-tuning large language model to solve the above challenges. First, short-term fluctuations and long-term trends in power grid operation data are extracted based on the bidirectional time convolution network; second, the text description of the power grid operation data is encoded; then, the timing feature encoding vector and the text description encoding vector are spliced, and the pre-trained large language model is input for LoRA fine-tuning to build a nonlinear mapping relationship between the power grid operation data and renewable energy absorption capacity; finally, the calculation simulation and experimental verification are carried out based on a provincial power grid in China. The results show that the method proposed in this paper has higher evaluation accuracy and speed than traditional models.

title: Peak–Valley Reduction and Ramp Suppression via Coordinated Thermal–BESS Control
authors: Shanke Mou, Hao Chen, Nan Yang, Zhendong Wan, Xuanwen Zhu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: This paper proposes an integrated peak-shaving and frequency-regulation framework for a thermal unit assisted by a battery energy storage system (BESS). A joint state-of-charge estimator—forgetting-factor RLS for parameter identification followed by an EKF for state updating—enhances SOC accuracy and availability. Day-Ahead peak shaving is formulated with a weighted objective that minimizes peak–valley spread and BESS energy throughput, solved via an improved Beluga Whale Optimization under power, ramp-rate, and SOC-zoned constraints. For real-time regulation, Swing Door Trending smooths AGC commands for the thermal unit while the BESS rapidly compensates residuals. Case studies on winter/summer typical days demonstrate reduced peak–valley differences, fewer ramping events, bounded energy throughput, and SOC maintained within limits, yielding improved AGC tracking and operational flexibility.

title: Understanding the Amount of Changes Required for Merge Request Acceptance: An Empirical Study
authors: Samah Kansab, Mohammed Sayagh, Francis Bordeleau, Ali Tizghadam
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Software Engineering and Service Science (ICSESS)
abstract: Code review (CR) is essential to software development, helping ensure that new code is properly integrated. However, the CR process often involves significant effort, including code adjustments, responses to reviewers, and continued implementation. While past studies have examined CR delays and iteration counts, few have investigated the effort based on the volume of code changes required—especially in the context of GitLab’s Merge Request (MR) mechanism, which remains underexplored. In this paper, we define and measure CR effort as the amount of code modified after submission, using a dataset of over 23.6k MRs from four GitLab projects. We find that up to 71% of MRs require adjustments post-submission, and 28% of these involve changes to over 200 lines of code. Surprisingly, this effort is not correlated with review time or the number of participants. To better understand and predict CR effort, we train an interpretable machine learning model using metrics across multiple dimensions: text features, code complexity, developer experience, review history, and branching. Our model achieves strong performance (AUC 0.84–0.88) and reveals that complexity, experience, and text features are key predictors. Historical project characteristics also influence current review effort. Our findings highlight the feasibility of using ML to explain and anticipate the effort needed to integrate code changes during review.

title: Model for Distributing Radio Channel Bandwidth among 5G NR Network Slices Considering Traffic Self-Similarity
authors: Ulugbek Amirsaidov, Bairam Turumbetov
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: This paper reviews existing methods for integrating heterogeneous services into New Radio (NR) 5G networks. The principal requirements for these methods include high efficiency in utilizing the NR 5G spectrum and ensuring quality of service for heterogeneous traffic. We propose a model that provides distribution of radio channel bandwidth among eMBB, URLLC, and mMTC slices, considering different network numerologies and traffic self-similarity. This model addresses the challenge of minimizing the total radio channel bandwidth allocated to these slices while considering constraints on the delay times of heterogeneous traffic packets.

title: Anti-Eavesdropping Multicast GAN Steganography for Botnet Stealth Communication
authors: Keru Fu, Sara Khanchi
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: Botnets, networks of compromised devices controlled by malicious actors, pose a growing threat to cybersecurity by enabling large-scale DDoS attacks, data theft, and critical infrastructure disruption. To evade detection, modern botnets increasingly rely on covert communication channels. This paper introduces EAMS-GAN (Encrypted, Authenticated, and Multi-casting Steganography GAN), a novel botnet architecture that combines steganography, deep learning, and error correction to achieve highly stealthy communication. EAMS-GAN offers advanced capabilities, including anti-eavesdropping, sender authentication, and secure multicasting, illustrating the potential sophistication of next-generation botnet operations. Experimental results show that the system achieves 99% payload transmission accuracy and 100% command communication accuracy without degrading image quality. This work is intended solely for cybersecurity research and awareness, aiming to help defenders anticipate and counter evolving threats, not to promote malicious use.

title: A Security-Enhanced Precoding Scheme for RIS-Assisted THz Communication Systems
authors: Mengliang Li, Chenyu Wu, Shuai Han, Weixiao Meng
abstract: Terahertz (THz) communication, a promising 6G candidate boasting ultra-wide bandwidth, confronts critical challenges including severe path loss and the inherent beam splitting effect in wideband scenarios. Reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RIS) offer an effective means to dynamically manipulate wireless channels for performance enhancement. This letter proposes a novel RIS-assisted terahertz physical layer security (PLS) precoding scheme aimed at 6G ultra-high-speed secure communication requirements, providing a core solution to the security transmission challenges in THz broadband scenarios. The scheme precisely resolves the double beam splitting bottleneck caused by the coupling between RIS and THz broadband through beam focusing and shaping technology, achieving directional concentration of signal energy and leakage suppression from a spatial perspective; further innovatively, the artificial noise (AN) is projected into the channel null space of legitimate users, leveraging the ultra-wide bandwidth advantage of THz to construct a full-band interference barrier. In the end, the simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Impact of Torsional Vibration of Brushless Excitation Turbogenerator Shafting on the Parameters of Coaxial Exciter
authors: Yucai Wu, Shuqiong Sun, Yuanyuan Kong, Xinkai Zhu, Minghan Ma
abstract: The low-frequency oscillation of large generators poses great harm to the shaft system. In the case of brushless excitation turbogenerators, the oscillation will affect the coaxial exciter. In this article we focus on the impact of the low-frequency oscillation of large-scale generator shaft system on the coaxial exciter parameters. Starting from the influence of oscillation on the conduction law of the armature winding, the expression of the armature current was derived, and the expression of the armature magnetic field was further extracted to predict the harmonic characteristics in terms of excitation current. Simulation verification was implemented on an 8-pair pole 3-phase brushless exciter, and the experimental verification was completed on a 7-pair pole 3-phase brushless exciter. The research indicates that the specific frequency harmonics in the excitation current of the brushless exciter can be utilized to monitor the torsional vibration of the turbogenerator shaft system.

title: CPAD: Continuous Pre-training for Infrared Images with Advances in Data, Preprocessing, and Paradigm
authors: Tao Zhang, Jinyong Wen, Kun Ding, Yu Xiong, Zeyu Zhang, Yan Wen, Shiming Xiang, Chunhong Pan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Infrared remote sensing imagery has emerged as a critical data source in environmental perception and intelligent monitoring, with significant potential in scenarios requiring robust performance under low-light, nighttime, or complex atmospheric conditions. Improving the perception capability of vision models for infrared images is essential to these applications. However, existing vision models pre-trained on RGB data often underperform in the infrared domain due to the severe distribution shift. To bridge this gap, we systematically investigate self-supervised learning for infrared imagery from three perspectives: data, preprocessing, and pre-training paradigm. This work identifies three core challenges hindering effective infrared pre-training: 1) the lack of large-scale infrared pre-training datasets, 2) the non-iconic characteristic of infrared images, and 3) the scarcity of fine-grained textures. To mitigate the data scarcity, we construct a large and diverse dataset called Multi-Scene Infrared Pre-training (MSIP), consisting of 178,756 images. As for the non-iconic characteristic, a simple yet effective image preprocessing method, Object-Sensitive Random RoI Cropping (OS-RRC), is introduced. To alleviate the negative impact of weak textures on feature learning, we propose a novel pre-training paradigm called Continual Pre-training with ADapter (CPAD), which incorporates adapters to learn domain-specific features while freezing off-the-shelf pre-trained models to retain the general feature extraction capability. Furthermore, to overcome limitations of vanilla adapters in CPAD, we introduce the patchwise-scale adapter equipped with dynamically learnable scale factors, allowing for pre-training once and subsequent application to various tasks. Extensive experiments show that the proposed framework achieves notable performance gains across three representative downstream tasks, validating its effectiveness for infrared image analysis in environmental monitoring and intelligent perception systems.

title: Geometry Aware Entropy Minimization Autofocusing Algorithm for UAV-based SAR
authors: Naomi Petrushevsky, Pietro Grassi, Stefano Tebaldini, Claudio Maria Prati
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) systems deployed on Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) are emerging as a highly promising solution for a wide range of future remote sensing and monitoring applications. The integration of SAR’s well-established capabilities for high-resolution imaging and change detection with the flexibility, maneuverability, and cost-effectiveness of modern UAV platforms unlocks significant potential for innovative sensing missions. However, the practical implementation of SAR on UAVs presents considerable challenges, primarily due to the inherent limitations in UAV flight stability and precise navigation, which degrade image quality. As a result, robust autofocusing techniques are essential to correct motion-induced phase errors and ensure coherent image reconstruction. While numerous autofocusing methods have been proposed in the literature, most are designed under assumptions that do not hold for low-flying UAV platforms. Specifically, conventional algorithms often overlook the strong dependence of the SAR imaging geometry on both azimuth and range positions of the targets, which becomes pronounced at low altitudes. In this study, we introduce a novel autofocusing approach termed Geometry-Aware Entropy Minimization (GAME). The proposed algorithm reconstructs three-dimensional positioning errors by explicitly modeling the spatially variant acquisition geometry along the UAV trajectory. This geometry-aware formulation enables accurate autofocus correction under the challenging conditions associated with low-altitude UAV SAR acquisitions. The effectiveness of the GAME algorithm is demonstrated using real X-band SAR data collected by an octacopter platform, confirming its applicability and performance in practical scenarios.

title: Privacy-Preserving Location-Based Service in Internet of Vehicles via Oblivious Transfer in Zero-Trust Framework
authors: Bo Mi, Zhaoyang Deng, Darong Huang, Yang Li, Zhongmei Li, Changyin Sun
abstract: The dynamism and heterogeneity inherent to the internet of vehicles necessitate its operation within a zero-trust environment. Serving as a vital element in location-based services (LBSs), geographic information is imperative to ensure the proper functioning of navigation, traffic updates, courier service, etc. Location data can potentially reveal extensive personal information of a user, such as social relationships, habits, and health conditions. To alleviate the conflicts amongst privacy, data property, and real-time performance for an LBS in the Internet of Vehicles, a secure point-of-interest information retrieval scheme is presented in this paper. We developed a lightweight fully homomorphic encryption algorithm based on the hardness of the discrete logarithm conjugacy search problem (DLCSP) and implemented it as an oblivious transfer (OT) protocol that not only conceals the query but also safeguards the data assets of the server. The effectiveness of our proposed method was validated experimentally. The results showed that our scheme outperformed state-of-the-art methods in terms of both computation and communication overhead, particularly on the server side. In addition, a simulation-based security validation demonstrated that our scheme is more robust when defined as an OT.

title: Low threshold single mode lasing from suspended membrane photonic crystal surface emitting lasers
authors: Balthazar Temu, Tomas Peach, Tyrone Jones, Shangfeng Liu, Qiang Li
abstract: Low lasing threshold is desirable in photonic integrated circuits and many other applications in order to reduce the power consumption of the lasing device. Double lattice photonic crystal surface emitting laser utilizing constructive interference between the two lattices can be used to realize lower lasing threshold compared to single lattice devices. Here we demonstrate single mode lasing of a double lattice device and compare to its single lattice counterpart. The device is made of a suspended membrane of InP photonic crystal layer on InP substrate. The average lasing threshold values measured for four single and four double lattice devices were about 43 μJ/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> and 20 μJ/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> respectively. This work paves the way to successful realization of low threshold single mode PCSELs for different applications.

title: Retrieval-Augmented Generation for Service Discovery: Chunking Strategies and Benchmarking
authors: Robin D. Pesl, Jerin G. Mathew, Massimo Mecella, Marco Aiello
abstract: Integrating multiple (sub-)systems is essential to create advanced Information Systems. Difficulties mainly arise when integrating dynamic environments, e.g., the integration at design time of not yet existing services. This has been traditionally addressed using a registry that provides the API documentation of the endpoints. Large Language Models (LLMs) have shown to be capable of automatically creating system integrations (e.g., as service composition) based on this documentation but require concise input due to input token limitations, especially regarding comprehensive API descriptions. Currently, it is unknown how best to preprocess these API descriptions. In the present work, we (i) analyze the usage of Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) for endpoint discovery and the chunking, i.e., preprocessing, of state-of-practice OpenAPIs to reduce the input token length while preserving the most relevant information. To further reduce the input token length for the composition prompt and improve endpoint retrieval, we propose (ii) a Discovery Agent that only receives a summary of the most relevant endpoints and retrieves specification details on demand. We evaluate RAG for endpoint discovery using (iii) a proposed novel service discovery benchmark SOCBench-D representing a general setting across numerous domains and the real-world RestBench benchmark, first, for the different chunking possibilities and parameters measuring the endpoint retrieval accuracy. Then, we assess the Discovery Agent using the same test data set. The prototype shows how to successfully employ RAG for endpoint discovery to reduce the token count. Our experiments show that endpoint-based approaches outperform naüve chunking methods for preprocessing. Relying on an agent significantly improves precision while being prone to decrease recall, disclosing the need for further reasoning capabilities.

title: Metamaterial-Based Sensor with Integrated Real-Time Heartbeat and Respiration Monitoring for IoT-Enabled Clinical Applications
authors: Van Linh Pham, Saiful Islam, Young-Hyo Lim, Hyoungsuk Yoo
abstract: Physiological signals such as respiration and heart rate are critical indicators for real-time health monitoring. Although conventional contact-based sensors like electrocardiograms offer high accuracy, they are limited by discomfort, hygiene concerns, and poor long-term usability. Radar-based and wireless RF sensing technologies have emerged as promising non-contact alternatives; however, they face challenges such as environmental interference, line-of-sight constraints, and limited signal selectivity. Additionally, hardware complexity, phase noise, and low signal-to-noise ratio hinder performance in dynamic environments. To address these limitations, this study proposes a novel physiological sensing system based on spoof surface plasmonic (SSP) metamaterial structures. These SSP-based sensors offer a low-profile design, material compatibility, and strong surface wave confinement, along with radiative capabilities for short-range wireless communication. By integrating SSP waveguides with radiative elements, the system enables passive, indirect-contact, and reliable detection of vital signs, providing improved robustness over traditional radar-based solutions. Furthermore, the system supports remote sensing and IoT-based connectivity, enabling seamless integration into healthcare monitoring networks. Experimental validation confirms the system’s potential for unobtrusive health monitoring in clinical settings. This work lays the groundwork for metamaterial-assisted sensing systems in next-generation biomedical applications.

title: Prolonging Tool Life: Learning Skillful Use of General-purpose Tools through Lifespan-guided Reinforcement Learning
authors: Po-Yen Wu, Cheng-Yu Kuo, Yuki Kadokawa, Takamitsu Matsubara
abstract: In inaccessible environments with uncertain task demands, robots often rely on general-purpose tools that lack predefined usage strategies. These tools are not tailored for particular operations, making their longevity highly sensitive to how they are used. This creates a fundamental challenge: how can a robot learn a tool-use policy that both completes the task and prolongs the tool’s lifespan? In this work, we address this challenge by introducing a reinforcement learning (RL) framework that incorporates tool lifespan as a factor during policy optimization. Our framework leverages Finite Element Analysis (FEA) and Miner’s Rule to estimate Remaining Useful Life (RUL) based on accumulated stress, and integrates the RUL into the RL reward to guide policy learning toward lifespan-guided behavior. To handle the fact that RUL can only be estimated after task execution, we introduce an Adaptive Reward Normalization (ARN) mechanism that dynamically adjusts reward scaling based on estimated RULs, ensuring stable learning signals. We validate our method across simulated and real-world tool use tasks, including Object-Moving and Door-Opening with multiple general-purpose tools. The learned policies consistently prolong tool lifespan (up to 8.01× in simulation) and transfer effectively to real-world settings, demonstrating the practical value of learning lifespan-guided tool use strategies.

title: A Three-stack Silicon Wafer Direct Bonding MEMS Tilt Sensor with Less Than 0.005° Angle Repeatability
authors: Shihao Du, Weihong Chu, Tiangi Guo, Jianlin Chen, Jingchuan Zhou, Weinan Chen, Zhihua Luo, Hui Su, Fang Chen
abstract: This paper presented an ultra-high angle resolution MEMS tilt accelerometer with a new sandwich-like structure based on a three-stack silicon wafer direct bonding processes. The scheme is implemented using a system of micromachined single side cantilever spring beam and three-stack silicon structure as a large capacitive sensing mechanism. A proof of concept of a lateral-axis sandwich-like accelerometer with a mechanical sensitivity of 55.0 pF/g (initial capacitor of 160 pF）has been designed, simulated and fabricated, and results from its evaluation are presented in this paper. The electronics interface is based on a new integrated digital (Sigma-Delta Modulation) closed-loop ASIC chip without requiring multiple high-precision ADCs. Experimental results show that the presented sandwich-like MEMS accelerometer exhibits a mechanical sensitivity of 46.5 pF/g with a ±0.05 % FS non-linearity within the ±16° linear range , an average bonding strength of 33.7MPa, a noise floor of 1μg/√Hz , an angle resolution of 0.00057° and a tilt angle repeatability of less than 0.005 °.

title: From Data Mirror to Smart Copilot: A Survey on NextG Semantic Communication for Propelling Digital Twin World into Cognitive Stage
authors: Fang Zhu, Jiayuan Chen, Junjie Wen, Yuye Yang, Changyan Yi, Yun Tie, Peng Zhang, Jun Cai, Dusit Niyato, Mohsen Guizani
abstract: The revolution of information technologies is blur-ring the boundary between physical and virtual worlds, with digital twin (DT) at the forefront of this transformation. Mean-while, DT is evolving from offering simple data mirrors to smart copilots, capable of understanding user’s intents and proactively providing profound insights. This ushers in the pivotal cognitive stage of the DT, where humans or embodied artificial intelligence agents (EAIs) can obtain cognitive perceptions within the DT world. Among various issues, in the cognitive stage, establishing strong interactions between the physical and DT worlds is critical. This paper thus explores the Next-Generation Semantic Communication (NextG-SemCom), well-suited for this issue, to fully enable the DT world with human-like cognitive capabilities. NextG-SemCom is envisioned as a cognitive-native paradigm that leverages Large AI Models (LAMs) as its core engine to perform intent understanding, contextual planning, and intent-oriented generative extraction. NextG-SemCom establishes a closed cognitive loop that shifts communication from data-driven to cognitive-driven, thereby not only reducing the traffic overhead, but also achieving cognitive comprehension of the transmitted information. This paper provides the first survey of the NextG-SemCom driven DT world, focusing on the advancement, trend and vision. We start by tracing the evolution of the DT from the initial virtual mapping stage to the current cognitive stage, and detail the distinguishing features of NextG-SemCom. We then present a holistic framework of cognitive interactions in the DT world, analyzing its core components, including the NextG-SemCom codec and network management, along with its design requirements and challenges. Furthermore, we discuss potential applications across a spectrum of human-human, human-EAI, and EAI-EAI interactive scenarios. Finally, we outline future research directions to provide a roadmap and inspire further studies in this promising field.

title: Demand Biasing and Virtual Bidding Can Lead to Suboptimal Unit Commitment Under Uncertainty
authors: Sunny Chen, Johanna L. Mathieu, Peter Seiler
publish: IEEE Transactions on Energy Markets, Policy and Regulation
abstract: Power system operators currently use deterministic optimization for unit commitment (UC). However, increased uncertainty caused by, e.g., intermittent renewable energy can reduce the social welfare from these UC solutions. To improve deterministic solutions given uncertainty, operators can bias forecasts of uncertain quantities, e.g., wind power production or load. Another option is to use virtual bidders, who are financial participants that arbitrage prices between forward and real-time markets. Alternatively, operators can directly address uncertainty with stochastic optimization, which will provide better solutions if the uncertainty distributions are known. However, stochastic UC is generally not used. The objective of this paper is to compare the social welfare obtained by stochastic UC, deterministic UC with demand biasing, and markets with virtual bidders. We provide examples where deterministic UC cannot recover the stochastic commitment independent of the bias value. We also show an example where virtual bidders neither recover the stochastic optimum nor the deterministic optimum with biasing. Finally, we provide computational examples where we fail to recover the stochastic solution on larger systems. From these results, we conclude that current deterministic methods likely suffer from a performance gap compared to stochastic methods, even under demand biasing and virtual bidding.

title: FIGhost: Fluorescent Ink-based Stealthy and Flexible Backdoor Attacks on Physical Traffic Sign Recognition
authors: Shuai Yuan, Guowen Xu, Hongwei Li, Rui Zhang, Xinyuan Qian, Hangcheng Cao, Qingchuan Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Traffic sign recognition (TSR) systems are crucial for autonomous driving but are vulnerable to backdoor attacks. Existing physical backdoor attacks either lack stealth, provide inflexible attack control, or ignore emerging Vision-Large-Language-Models (VLMs). In this paper, we introduce FIGhost, the first physical-world backdoor attack leveraging fluorescent ink as triggers. Fluorescent triggers are invisible under normal conditions and activated stealthily by ultraviolet light, providing superior stealthiness, flexibility, and untraceability. Inspired by real-world graffiti, we derive realistic trigger shapes and enhance their robustness via an interpolation-based fluorescence simulation algorithm. Furthermore, we develop an automated backdoor sample generation method to support three attack objectives. Extensive evaluations in the physical world demonstrate FIGhost's effectiveness against state-of-the-art detectors and VLMs, maintaining robustness under environmental variations and effectively evading existing defenses.

title: Class Knowledge-Guided Lightweight Network for Salient Object Detection of Strip Steel Surface Defect
authors: Kunye Shen, Xiaofei Zhou, Zhi Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Recent lightweight salient object detection (SOD) models for strip steel surface defect typically adopt classification model as encoder to extract semantic features, followed by task-specific decoder for defect detection. Despite achieving promising results, these models often overlook the potential of leveraging class-level knowledge to enhance detection performance. In this paper, we propose a Class Knowledge-Guided Lightweight Network (CKLNet) for salient object detection of strip steel surface defect. Particularly, CKLNet employs a three-stage training strategy. In the first stage, a general SOD model is trained to perform initial detection of surface defect. Then, the second stage constructs a classification branch built upon the general SOD model to extract defect class knowledge. Embarking on this class knowledge, multiple class-specific decoders are trained in the third stage, where we can generate refined and class-aware defect predictions. Extensive experiments on two datasets demonstrate that CKLNet achieves superior detection performance and generalization capability when compared with the cutting-edge lightweight models, with real-time inference speed of 783 FPS on an RTX 2080Ti GPU. Moreover, unlike existing models that only enable defect localization, our CKLNet further provides accurate defect class identification. The source code is publicly available at https://github.com/Kunye-Shen/CKLNet.

title: Self-Decoupled Dual-Band Dual-Polarized Shared Aperture Base Station Antenna Array
authors: Shiqiang Fu, Haonan Li, Zhixia Xu, Zhongbao Wang, Zhi Ning Chen
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: A self-decoupled, dual-band, dual-polarized, shared aperture antenna array is proposed for base station applications. The slotted patch structure and folded stub loading on the 1.69 2.2 GHz low-band (LB) antenna effectively suppress LB scattering effects while simultaneously generating a partially reflected wave for the 3.3–3.8 GHz high-band (HB) antenna to mitigate coupling between HB elements. Additionally, four circular parasitic elements are arranged around the LB antenna to further reduce coupling among the HB antennas and broaden the LB bandwidth, without requiring additional decoupling layers. A detailed analysis of the decoupling mechanism provided by the slotted patches and folded stubs is conducted. Measurement results confirm that the proposed design achieves excellent decoupling performance, restores the radiation patterns of the HB antennas, achieves an isolation level better than 25 dB, and delivers outstanding performance in both LB and HB frequency bands.

title: When Vehicle Crowd-Sensing Meets Complex Driving: Robust Illegal Roadside Parking Detections
authors: Ruixue Huang, Chaocan Xiang, Yulan Guo
abstract: Illegal roadside parking is highly common in major cities worldwide, leading to traffic congestion & accidents and undermining human safety. Traditional methods for detecting illegal parking rely heavily on active human effort and customized sensors, which are extremely cost-ineffective to cover large-scale cities. To this end, we explore utilizing massive on-road vehicles to collect parking violation-related data (including surrounding videos and driving state information), enabling large-scale and low-cost illegal parking detection. However, the dynamic and unpredictable motion of the sensing and target vehicles, coupled with intricate driving behaviors and traffic conditions, pose great challenges to achieving accurate detection. To address these challenges, we propose $i$Patrol+, a novel robust illegal parking detection system empowered by vehicle crowdsensing, at the heart of which lies a key extension of the Doppler effect from the traditional acoustic scenarios to the vehicle-mounted video scenarios in intricate driving conditions. Specifically, following the methodology of the Doppler effect and leveraging camera imaging theory, we establish a new vehicle speed estimation model via frame-to-frame feature shifts. Furthermore, this model is augmented by a feature re-projection scheme and a driving behavior-aware bias rectification scheme to effectively alleviate the negative effect of intricate driving conditions. We implement $i$Patrol+ on smartphones mounted behind the vehicle windshields and conduct on-road experiments covering 233 $\rm {km}$ of roads in a 125 $\rm {km}^{2}$ urban area. The experimental results demonstrate that $i$Patrol+ identifies illegal parking events with a precision of 86% in intricate driving conditions (e.g., turns/u-turns, lane changes, traffic congestion, and waiting at traffic signals), outperforming five baselines by 17% on average.

title: Load Forecasting of Power System Based on Deep Neural Network and Digital-Twin
authors: Jing Zhao
abstract: With the accelerated development of the global energy Internet and the integration of green and clean energy, the future power grid has posed more strict demands for the accuracy and stability of power load prediction. This paper proposes a novel deep neural network model, TCN-LSTM, that integrates Temporal Convolutional Networks (TCN) and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), and is enhanced by an adaptive attention mechanism and a hybrid loss function (MSE-CE). The main contributions of the research are Architectural Innovation, Training Optimization, and Empirical Validation. A dual-module design leverages TCN to capture long-term dependencies and LSTM to model temporal dynamics, while the attention mechanism dynamically prioritizes critical features, significantly improving feature utilization. Furthermore, the research combines the designed prediction model with a digital twin to construct a dynamic simulation environment for the power system, enabling real-time mapping and predictive feedback on the power grid’s operating status. This enables real-time updates and dynamic optimization of the prediction model, enhancing the adaptive capability of load forecasting. The comparison index data show that, in short-term load forecasting, the average absolute error, average absolute percentage error, and root mean square error of the proposed algorithm in the research are 52.1, 0.0059, and 70.9, respectively. Compared with other algorithms, they are reduced by an average of 30.03, 0.0028, and 26, respectively. In terms of long-term prediction results, the average absolute error, average absolute percentage error, and root mean square error of the proposed algorithm in the research are 57.2, 0.0081, and 80.9, respectively, which are on average reduced by 39.43, 0.0062, and 32.47 compared with other algorithms. These results validate the high accuracy and stability of the proposed method for load forecasting.

title: MTRAG: Multi-Target Referring and Grounding via Hybrid Semantic-Spatial Integration
authors: Yili Ren, Jinyang Du, Xi Liu, Qianxiao Su, Yue Deng, Hongjue Li
abstract: Fine-grained visual referring and grounding are critical for enhancing scene understanding and enabling various real-world vision-language applications. Although recent studies have extended multimodal large language models (MLLMs) to these tasks, they still face significant challenges in fine-grained multi-target scenarios. To address this, we propose MTRAG, a pixel-level multi-target referring and grounding framework that leverages semantic-spatial collaboration. Specifically, we introduce a Channel Extension Mechanism (CEM) that enables a global image encoder to extract global semantics and multi-region representations while retaining background context, without extra region feature extractors. Moreover, we introduce a grounding branch for pixel-level grounding and design a Hybrid Adapter (HA) to fuse semantic features from the MLLM branch with spatial information from the grounding branch, thereby enhancing the semantic-spatial alignment. For training, we meticulously curate MTRAG-D, a dataset comprising single-and multi-target referring and grounding samples derived from existing datasets and newly synthesized free-form multi-target referring instruction-following data. We also present MTR-Bench, a benchmark for systematic evaluation of multi-target referring. Extensive experiments across five core task, including single- and multi-target referring and grounding as well as image-level captioning, show that MTRAG consistently outperforms strong baselines on both multi- and single-target tasks, while maintaining competitive image-level understanding. The code is available at https://github.com/deng-ai-lab/MTRAG.

title: DeepTimeGeo: Trajectory Reconstruction From Sparse Data With Transformer
authors: Shangqing Cao, Jiaman Wu, Aparimit Kasliwal, Baoqi Chen, Giuseppe Perona, Marta C. González
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: The completion of sparse Location-Based Service (LBS) data for modeling urban-scale origin-destination (OD) flow is of great importance to transportation planning applications. Sparse trajectories lack realistic human mobility patterns. Only with completed trajectories one can derive urban-scale OD flow that resembles complete travel diaries as those gathered by surveys or actively collecting phone applications. We present DeepTimeGeo (DTG), a transformer encoder-only model that reconstructs complete trajectories from sparse LBS inputs. We adopt a rank-based representation of locations to preserve individual-level heterogeneity and take a sequence-to-sequence approach to address the issue of gradient back-propagation blockage when it comes to regulating human mobility patterns. We devise human mobility distribution-based loss functions and leverage auxiliary learning to model the dynamics of exploration versus returns in users’ spatial choices. Experimental results show the superiority of DTG in trajectory reconstruction compared to other start-of-the-art generative models for human mobility trajectories. We conducted a case study with LBS data in the city of Coral Gables, Florida. The case study reveals that DTG leads to a reduction of more than 15% (1.35 vs. 1.60), when compared to the state-of-art model, in the cross-entropy loss that measures the deviation from the ground truth departure time distribution. We further demonstrate through SUMO simulation that DTG-generated trip demand captures both morning and evening rush hours, enabled by the more accurate distribution of trip departure time with important implications for traffic estimates.

title: Anomaly Detection for Generic Failure Monitoring in Robotic Assembly, Screwing and Manipulation_supp1-3664647.mp4
authors: Niklas Grambow
abstract: Out-of-distribution states in robot manipulation often lead to unpredictable robot behavior or task failure, limiting success rates and increasing risk of damage. Anomaly detection (AD) can identify deviations from expected patterns in data, which can be used to trigger failsafe behaviors and recovery strategies. Prior work has applied data-driven AD on time series data for specific robotic tasks, however the transferability of an AD approach between different robot control strategies and task types has not been shown. Leveraging time series data, such as force/torque signals, allows to directly capture robot-environment interactions, crucial for manipulation and online failure detection. As robotic tasks can have widely signal characteristics and requirements, AD methods which can be applied in the same way to a wide range of tasks is needed, ideally with good data efficiency. We examine three industrial robotic tasks, robotic cabling, screwing, and sanding, each with multi-modal time series data and several anomalies. Several autoencoderbased methods are compared, and we evaluate the generalization across different robotic tasks and control methods (diffusion policy-, position-, and impedance-controlled). This allows us to validate the integration of AD in complex tasks involving tighter tolerances and variation from both the robot and its environment. Additionally, we evaluate data efficiency, detection latency, and task characteristics which support robust detection. The results indicate reliable detection with AUROC exceeding 0.96 in failures in the cabling and screwing task, such as incorrect or misaligned parts and obstructed targets. In the polishing task, only severe failures were reliably detected, while more subtle failure types remained undetected.
