title: Low-Latency Real-Time Data Storage for Zigbee-Connected Autonomous Surface Vehicles
authors: Shahab Tayeb, Kavan Singh, Reza Alam
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: Near-shore autonomous surface vehicles (ASVs) face challenges of intermittent connectivity, limited bandwidth, and the need for resilient real-time data storage. This paper presents a lightweight, Firebase-powered architecture that integrates ZigBee telemetry, a Python backend, Firestore database, and a Next.js dashboard into a unified cloud-synchronized system. A historical dataset of 42,192 records was migrated with zero loss, validating the reliability of large-scale ingestion. Field experiments measured average write latency of 312 ms and read latency of 410 ms, consistent with prior Firebase benchmarks. The system sustained 99.7% uptime and recovered from induced disconnections in under 3 s using a fault-tolerant batch logging mechanism. These results demonstrate that cloud-synchronized telemetry can be achieved with low latency and high reliability in near-shore ASV deployments, providing a practical foundation for real-time situational awareness and future fleet-scale coordination.

title: Improving the Generalization Performance of YOLO-Based Wildlife Detection Models in Camera Trap Images Using a Hyperparameter Tuning Framework
authors: Mahesh Sharma, Saqib Gulzar, Elizabeth Peterson, Gabriel Cosyleon, Md Islam, Trung Duong
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: Wildlife detection is crucial in minimizing vehicle wildlife collisions, but it is challenging to use camera trap imagery under adverse climate conditions. Wildlife detection is crucial to mitigate wildlife-vehicle collisions and to advance ecological monitoring. Our study has introduced an Adaptive Early Stopping (AES) framework integrated with Bayesian hyperparameter optimization (Optuna). At the same time, YOLO-based models have shown strong performance in real-time object detection with better generalization when trained with AES. A large-scale training data set was constructed from approximately 20,000 camera trap videos covering six wildlife classes (bear, bobcat, coyote, deer, elk, and mountain lion) in varying temporal and climatic conditions using RoboFlow. This proposed method improved the training and detection accuracy of the YOLOv9m, YOLOv10m and YOLOv11m models, achieving mAP@50 scores of 98. 4%, 98. 3%, and 97. 9%, respectively. Model inference was conducted over 19,686 camera-trap videos, yielding high true positive rates and minimal false negatives. Our framework establishes a transferable strategy for enhancing the generalization of YOLO, offering efficient real-time detection under challenging conditions.

title: P-Q Coordinated Control Method for Optical Storage Coupled Inverter with Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Zhenhao Zhang, Honghou Zhang, Lizhong Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: With the wide application of distributed energy, the influence of optical storage coupling system on the stability of electrical power system (EPS) is becoming more and more obvious, and it is the key to realize efficient P-Q coordinated control of inverter. In this article, the method of combining deep reinforcement learning (DRL) is used to construct the corresponding control algorithm model. In this model, the DRL framework is carefully constructed, the state space, action space and reward function are reasonably defined, and an improved algorithm is designed based on deep Q network (DQN) to optimize the control strategy. By building an experimental platform including simulated photovoltaic array, energy storage battery pack and other components, the experimental verification is carried out under various working conditions such as rapid change of light intensity, sudden change of load and fluctuation of grid voltage. The results show that, compared with the traditional fixed strategy control, the inverter based on this algorithm model has fast active power output response and small fluctuation when the light intensity changes. When the load changes suddenly, the reactive power adjustment is accurate and fast; When the grid voltage fluctuates, it can effectively realize the coordinated regulation of P and Q. The control method of integrating DRL can improve the control performance of the optical storage coupled inverter and ensure the system stability and power quality.

title: Artificial Intelligence Ethics Test for University Students: Design Principles, Content Validation, and Pilot Testing
authors: Jiayi Wu, Shuhan Zhang, Guangfeng Wu
abstract: The accelerated evolution of artificial intelligence (AI) has led to its impact extending to all aspects of society, including education. However, university students are increasingly facing ethical challenges in their use of AI technologies. This growing concern highlights the need for robust assessment tools that can accurately measure students’ understanding of AI ethics. Although several studies have examined assessment instruments for AI literacy among university students, few have focused on the development of rigorously validated cognitive tests specifically targeting AI ethics. To address this gap, we developed the AI Ethics Test (AIEt). This study presents test design, content validation procedures, and pilot testing. The test was developed using the Evidence-Centered Design (ECD) framework, and 7 constructs were covered. A rigorous validation process was conducted, including expert reviews and cognitive interviews with students, to ensure content validity. Then, pilot testing was implemented at a public university in southwest China, involving 96 first- and second-year students. Item analysis was carried out, and informed revisions were made to enhance the test validity. AIEt provides an effective and reliable tool for assessing AI ethics, laying the groundwork for future research and practices in AI education at the higher education level.

title: Distributed Multi-View Environment Sensing in Wireless Communication Networks
authors: Xin Tong, Zhaoyang Zhang, Zhaohui Yang, Yu Ge, Henk Wymeersch
abstract: In this paper, we propose a generic distributed multi-view sensing framework to deal with the three crucial challenges, i.e., physics-inspired signal propagation modeling, large-scale region of interest (ROI) pixelation, and distributed sensing architecture and algorithm design, in typical ISAC (integrated sensing and communication)-enabled wireless networks. First, we propose a unique pixel coordinate system with non-uniform and affine pixel division and mapping, which helps to resolve the occlusion effects between pixels and can be well tailored for common computational imaging technology. Second, inspired by Huygens’ principle, we propose a novel integral-form signal propagation model that well captures the overall amplitude and phase effects of the pixels with arbitrary shapes and sizes, thus leading to a greatly reduced quantization error and making it suitable for large-scale scenario sensing. The proposed system model allows free pairing of transmitters and receivers in the network and makes full use of the multi-view observations, further resolving the occlusion problem any individual receiver may encounter in large-scale environment sensing. We then propose a low computational complexity alternating optimization (AO) algorithm, which iteratively performs sparse reconstruction and occlusion detection to obtain accurate sensing results. Finally, the performance of the proposed method is analyzed. Extensive numerical results verify the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Study on the Relationship Between Ground Spectral Sampling Variance and Observation Scale
authors: Yun Zhang, Jun Pan, Lijun Jiang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Geographic Information and Remote Sensing Technology (GIRST)
abstract: To address the issue of spectral data comparability arising from inconsistent observation scales between satellites and the ground, this study systematically analyzes the impact of random variations in sampling views on the representativeness of ground spectral sampling. A simulation site model is constructed from a mathematical perspective, with a circular sampling view defined and the spatial response function considered. Through simulation experiments, the random variations in the size and position of the sampling view are simulated, and the quantitative relationship between the overall variance of the sampling view and the sampling-view size is examined. Meanwhile, based on this relationship, a quantitative relationship between the variance of sampling-view data and the number of sampling points is established, and the simulation experiment results are compared and validated. The results show that the overall variance of the sampling view significantly decreases with increasing sampling-view size and tends to stabilize after reaching a certain scale, reflecting the true spectral characteristics of the surface. The variance of the sample mean is inversely proportional to the number of sampling points, and the simulation experiments agree closely with the fitted model, verifying the universality of the constructed variance model. Under the premise of meeting accuracy requirements, equivalent substitution between sampling-view size and the number of sampling points can be achieved, providing a clear quantitative basis for optimizing ground spectral sampling strategies.

title: An Exploratory Study on Redesigning Learning Activities for Engagement: Addressing Gen Z’s Diverse Needs in Open Distance Learning
authors: Andrew Ang Dun Yu, Enna Ayub
abstract: As learner demographics change, so do the unique needs and expectations of Gen Z in Open Distance Learning (ODL). This exploratory study investigates the decline in student engagement with self-directed online activities during their ODL degree programs. One potential factor is the lack of a structured pedagogical framework to guide novice instructional designers (IDs) in creating inquiry-based online activities that improve engagement with Gen Z learners. Inspired by the Design and Development Research (DDR) approach and guided by the Successive Approximation Model 1 (SAM1) iterative process, this paper covers Phase One of the study, aiming to redesign inquiry-based learning activities rooted in the Community of Inquiry (CoI) framework and scaffolded using the ARCS motivational design model. By integrating social, cognitive, and student-centred design principles, the study aims to contribute to the discourse on effective learning design practices for postgraduate online learners. It also highlights the need for further investigation into instructional design practices to meet the diverse learning needs of digital native students.

title: How High- and Low-Achieving Students Use Generative Artificial Intelligence to Create Educational Videos
authors: Jinfei Zhu, Shi-Ting Chen, Shurui Bai, Sihan Sun, Donn Emmanuel Gonda
abstract: While artificial intelligence (AI) is increasingly integrated into higher education, little is known about how learners effectively utilize generative-AI (Gen-AI) tools and prompting strategies to create multimedia content. This study employs a case study and mixed-methods approach to explore how high- and low-achieving graduate students collaboratively use Gen-AI tools to create educational videos. Using the "Write-Create-Validate" (WCV) framework, we analyzed the AI usage behaviors of 27 students across three video creation assignments. The results show that high-achieving students adopted more structured, goal-oriented, and iterative prompting strategies, whereas low-achieving students tended to use simpler or inconsistent approaches. Statistical analyses confirmed significant differences between the two groups in both performance and AI usage patterns. These findings highlight the importance of prompt quality and refinement in AI-assisted learning. The study offers practical guidance for designing multimedia tasks that incorporate AI and for supporting students, especially those with lower performance, through structured prompting scaffolds.

title: Evaluating AI-Assisted Performance Review Tools: A Framework for Fairness, Efficiency, and Usability
authors: Gaurav Nanda, Parteek Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: Performance reviews are critical in engineering management, yet they remain time-intensive, inconsistent, and vulnerable to bias. With the rise of large language models and multi-system integrations, AI-assisted tools can now aggregate artifacts across GitHub, Slack, Jira, and Google Docs to generate evidence-backed summaries for managers. While anecdotal reports suggest these tools save time and broaden visibility into contributions, no systematic framework currently exists to evaluate their effectiveness. To our knowledge, this is the first framework designed for AI-assisted performance reviews, a managerial task that has received little attention compared to developer-facing AI tools. We propose four evaluation dimensions: efficiency, fairness and coverage, accuracy and trust, and usability and adoption. Each dimension is operationalized through two practical metrics. Our contribution is to establish a research agenda that connects anecdotal reports with systematic measurement and provides both researchers and practitioners with a foundation for responsible adoption of AI in performance management.

title: SAGE-HD: SPaT- and Grade-Aware Deep Reinforcement Learning for Eco-Safe Longitudinal Control of Connected Heavy-Duty Electric Vehicles
authors: Rajan Chaudhary, Nalin Kumar Sharma, Rahul Kala, Sri Niwas Singh
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: Energy efficiency and safety remain critical challenges for heavy-duty electric vehicles (HDEVs) operating in connected intelligent transportation systems (ITS). Roadway grade (slope) and Signal Phase and Timing (SPaT) phase/countdown available using V2I communication are complementary factors that affect eco-driving policies, and the twin factors have not been sufficiently researched simultaneously for Eco-driving. This paper presents SAGE-HD (SPaT and Grade-Aware Deep Reinforcement Learning for Eco-Safe Longitudinal Control of Connected Heavy-Duty EVs). The proposed technique is a legality-aware, SPaT-and grade-aware deep reinforcement learning (DRL) controller for eco-safe longitudinal driving. We use Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) actor-critic policy for learning. We introduce a lightweight safety shield that enforces stop-line legality and powertrain feasibility to make learning easier. Evaluation on a 41.9km corridor with 23 signalized intersections (fixed 40s/20s green/red cycles and shared offsets) uses an identical heavy-duty powertrain and compares against a signal-aware Eco-IDM baseline. The learned policy decreases traction energy from 43.58kWh to 27.52kWh (−36.9%), shortens trip time from 47.55min to 35.57min (−25.2%), and achieves 0/23 red-light violations (baseline 1/23).Results indicate that coupling SPaT scheduling and terrain adaptation with shielded DRL advances both efficiency and stability for HD-EV operation in IoT enabled corridors.

title: Adaptive Current Protection Scheme for Power Grids with Distributed Generation Integration
authors: Shaoan Xu, Xingsheng Wan, Keyan Liu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: Against the background of the large-scale integration of Inverter-Interfaced Distributed Generators (IIDG) into the distribution network, this paper first analyzes the fault output characteristics of IIDG, equivalenting it to a positive-sequence voltage-controlled current source. Then, combined with four fault locations (upstream of the fault point, downstream of the fault point, both upstream and downstream, and adjacent lines), the impact of IIDG on protection is discussed. Taking the three-stage current protection as an example, PSCAD simulations verify that the protection fails to operate correctly. Subsequently, an improved adaptive current protection scheme is proposed based on the composite sequence network. For phase-to-phase short circuits and three-phase short circuits, the settings of Stage I and Stage II are determined respectively. Simulation results show that this scheme can ensure the reliable operation of protection and effectively cover the entire length of the line.

title: Development of a Hardware - Software Complex for Recognizing Objects and Determining the Distance to them Based on a Neural Network Model
authors: Utkir Khamdamov, Bekzod Turgunov, Elmurod Urinov, Baxtiyor Akmuradov
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: This scientific article is devoted to the development of a hardware - software complex for blind people, based on artificial intelligence, which recognizes objects, measures the distance to the recognized object and provides voice notification in uzbek language about the class of the recognized object and the distance to it. In this research paper, a fine-tuned Yolov5s neural network model based on a special dataset, as well as a stereo camera system for measuring the distance to the recognized object, were used to develop such a complex for recognizing objects. This paper also proposes a solution to improve the accuracy of measurements of the stereo camera system in such projects. The developed project of the complex was experimentally tested. An analysis of the obtained test results was carried out.

title: BugBlaze: An Explainable Framework for Detecting Latent Defect Ignitions in Software Systems
authors: Hema Yalamancheli, Nazia Shaik, Nurmyrat Amanmadov, Tarlan Abdullayev, Balajee Asish Brahmandam
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: Contemporary software systems frequently harbor latent defects such as dormant logic errors, untested edge cases, and hidden security flaws that slip past static analysis tools and conventional test suites, undermining both reliability and security. To address this, we introduce BugBlaze, the first comprehensive framework for real time ignition detection of latent defects powered by explainable AI. At the center of BugBlaze is the BlazeCore engine, which integrates a large language model with an attention enhanced graph neural network to jointly represent source code and runtime logs. The framework incorporates several key modules: a TriggerTrace Predictor that anticipates defect-triggering inputs with SHAP based explanations, a CollabGuard Integrator that enriches pull requests with risk scores and natural language justifications, a PatchCraft Assistant that suggests preventive patches supported by XAI reports, and a RiskHeat Visualizer that highlights vulnerable code regions directly in the editor. Complementing these is a ContextMemory Vault that adapts risk profiles based on historical data, and an XAI-Trace Explainer that records LIME-based decision traces for transparency. Deployed through an IgnitionMesh across CI/CD pipelines, VSCode, and Git workflows, BugBlaze cut latent defect incidents by 87% and reduced mean time to detection by 65% across seven large-scale projects totaling 1.2M LOC. We also discuss scalability considerations, integration trade-offs, and future extensions toward adaptive learning in multilingual environments.

title: Generative AI and Knowledge Graph Empowered Digital-Intelligent Collaborative Teaching System
authors: Xiaodong Liu, Xi Xiong, Baolin Lai, Jinyi Liu, Huilin Zhou, Yuhao Wang
abstract: The rapid development of artificial intelligence (AI) and digital transformation is driving higher education to shift from mass education to personalized education. However, current digital and intelligent technologies are primarily applied to teaching without fully exploring their potential. Thus, based on generative AI and knowledge graphs, a digital-intelligent collaborative teaching system is proposed to construct a novel intelligent teaching environment that supports active learning and collaborative teaching. The system focuses on the cultivation of talents in electronic information fields. Specifically, it leverages large models to develop a three-dimensional knowledge graph for professional courses, enabling the recommendation of personalized learning paths for students. Meanwhile, an intelligent formula derivation engine is designed to facilitate human-machine collaborative problem setting and solving, while establishing connections between knowledge and application based on the given problems. Moreover, a wireless communication agent incorporating teacher knowledge base is constructed to provide students with professional companion learning tools. The proposed system implemented over one semester in three classes with 144 students significantly enhances teaching quality and learning effectiveness, earning positive recognition from students. This provides a low-cost, high-efficiency digital-intelligent education model for new engineering education.

title: Real-Time Traffic Monitoring Using AI-Powered IoT Sensor Networks for Smart Cities
authors: Deepa Nikam, Vikrant Chole, Minal Chole, Swapna Lokhande, Santosh Sahu, Jhankar Moolchandani
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: Due to the fast urbanization of the contemporary communities, there is the increasing traffic jams, safety issues, and poor transportation management. The study offers a smart system of monitoring traffic in real-time and being powered by AI-based IoT sensors. The system combines computer vision technology, sensor fusion, and deep learning to receive and process real-time traffic data. The suggested model is also able to better predictive decision-making and helps the urban authorities cope with electrical traffic and mitigate accidents and enhance quick reaction to critical situations. The experiments prove that this model has an accuracy of 92.4 percent in recognizing congestion and the latency of the model is reduced by 28 percent than that of traditional methods.

title: Research on Overcurrent Mechanism and Suppression Strategy of Grid-forming Converters during Fault Recovery Stage
authors: Lin Cheng, Yifei Wang, Qian Yang, Gaoshang Zhao, Shuyu Zhang, Peng Han
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: Virtual impedance technology can effectively prevent grid-forming converters from experiencing overcurrent during faults, yet in the fault recovery stage, the converters may still face the risk of current exceeding limits. Focusing on this issue, this paper thoroughly investigates the mechanism of overcurrent during the fault recovery stage and demonstrates that the increasing of virtual power angle is the dominant cause of overcurrent. Based on this finding, an overcurrent suppression strategy is proposed: by equipping the grid forming control loop with a virtual power angle saturation module, the output current is constrained within a safe range throughout the entire fault stage. Simulations validate the theoretical analysis and confirm the effectiveness of the proposed strategy.

title: The double-sided impact of digital intelligence technology on higher education: Opportunities and challenges
authors: Yue Zhang
abstract: With the rapid development of digital intelligence technology[1], the field of higher education is experiencing unprecedented changes. The purpose of this study is to explore the application of digital intelligence technology in higher education and its opportunities and challenges. Firstly, the paper analyzes the application of digital intelligent technology (such as artificial intelligence, big data, cloud computing, etc. ) in higher education, and emphasizes the positive role in improving teaching quality, optimizing the allocation of educational resources, and expanding the influence of education. It then explores the challenges posed by these technologies, including data security and privacy protection issues, the impact of educational equity, and challenges to traditional educational models. Finally, a series of countermeasures are put forward in order to provide guidance and suggestions for the digital transformation of higher education.

title: New Designs for Voting Networks Based on the Boyer-Moore Majority-Finding Algorithm
authors: Behrooz Parhami
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: Replication and voting is a key redundancy scheme for obtaining highly-reliable computation results from unreliable components. Both hardware voters (voting networks) and software voters (voting algorithms) have been studied for many decades and trade-offs in their designs have been investigated. For voting networks, the circuit complexity grows superlinearly with the number of inputs, making the design of large voters quite challenging, given that failures in the voter hardware tend to be critical. In this paper, we show how to use the linear-cost, logarithmic-parallel-delay Boyer-Moore algorithm to design efficient and scalable voting networks.

title: Research on Multi-Objective Operation Optimization of Mine Area Photovoltaic-Wind-Storage-Hydrogen Systems
authors: Guangqiang Xu, Huiqun Huang, Wenhao Shan, Yongteng Du, Cai Sun, Chunyang Yue, Qingzhao Ma
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: Mining areas as a typical high-energy consumption and high-carbon emission scenario, their energy system green transformation is crucial to the national "dual carbon" strategy. Addressing the limitations of traditional "wind-solar-storage" systems constrained by the short-term energy storage characteristics of batteries, which struggle to meet the continuous energy demands of mining areas, this paper constructs an integrated "solar-wind-storage-hydrogen" energy system. By establishing an optimization model targeting economic efficiency, environmental sustainability, and energy self-sufficiency, and solving it using a decomposition-based multi-objective evolutionary algorithm (MOEA/D), a Pareto optimal solution set characterizing the trade-offs among objectives is obtained. The fuzzy decision-making method is then applied to select the optimal compromise solution. These findings provide an innovative system architecture and scientific decision-making methodology for the green transformation of mining area energy systems, holding significant theoretical value and practical implications for advancing clean and low-carbon development in mining regions.

title: Analysis of Ecological Sensitivity in Kunming City Based on GIS and RS
authors: Yiting Liu, Yue Chang, Dena Yang, Yibo Wang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Geographic Information and Remote Sensing Technology (GIRST)
abstract: Ecosystem sensitivity analysis is of great significance for regional ecological protection and planning, especially in areas like Kunming City, where its unique geographical location and ecological environment require special attention and protective measures. This article uses Kunming City as an example to conduct ecosystem sensitivity analysis, dividing the study area into four sensitivity zones: non-sensitive, low-sensitive, moderately sensitive, and highly sensitive. Based on GIS and RS technologies, the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) is used to establish an evaluation factor system, selecting nine factors such as elevation and slope, determining the weights of each indicator, and performing GIS weighted overlay. The research findings will help guide ecological protection efforts in Kunming City and surrounding regions, providing scientific basis for ecological restoration, urban planning, and land use decisions, promoting sustainable regional development

title: Research on Key Technologies of Single-Sample Self-Learning Fault Detection for Electrical Equipment
authors: Cihai Qin, Yi Qian, Yingying Jiang, Peng Peng, Jie Hu, Yun Yu, Jing Han
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: In response to the practical needs of real-time monitoring of power equipment faults, this paper proposed a single-sample self-learning fault detection technology with the high-resolution, the high-frame-rate and multi-information fusion. Combining with pre-trained deep learning models, multi-source data integration and image segmentation had been achieved through single-sample self-learning, which allowed the model to learn and adjust effectively on the basis of very few samples, thereby realizing high-precision fault feature recognition. At the same time, based on knowledge distillation and analogy learning technology, the multi-core architecture advantages of embedded processors were fully utilized to reasonably allocate processing tasks and improve the computational efficiency of the algorithm, realizing multi-modal data fusion under the condition of limited computing resources. The accuracy and efficiency of power equipment fault detection were not only improved, but also the dependence on a large amount of labeled data was reduced, making the technology more flexible and efficient in practical applications and providing an innovative solution for the intelligent operation and maintenance of power systems.

title: Chaotically Initialized and Adaptively Disturbed Tunicate Swarm Algorithm (CIAD-TSA)
authors: Obaid Ur Rahman, Zirui Zhang, Yajie Gao, Lingling Li, Bingxiang Ji
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: The standard Tunicate Swarm Algorithm (TSA) exhibits limitations in convergence precision and susceptibility to local optima when solving high-dimensional, non-convex power system optimization problems such as wind-solar-thermal energy dispatch. To address these issues, an enhanced TSA algorithm based on a random position disturbance strategy (TSAD) is proposed. Key innovations include: (1) A chaotic mapping strategy for population initialization, expanding solution space coverage; (2) An adaptive guidance coefficient dynamically balancing global exploration and local exploitation; (3) A random position disturbance mechanism maintaining population diversity throughout iterations. Validated on six benchmark functions (unimodal and multi-modal), TSAD achieves significantly superior convergence precision (e.g., down to 10-21)compared to PSO, SSA, CSA, MFO, and standard TSA, particularly excelling in high-dimensional(30D) scenarios. Crucially, TSAD attains these improvements without increasing computational cost, maintaining comparable runtime to TSA. The algorithm's robustness in avoiding local optima and scalability for complex, nonlinear scheduling models underscores its practical value for real-world power system optimization tasks.

title: Generalization-enhanced Channel Estimation through Adaptive Interpolation and Multi-Task Learning–Based Denoising Network
authors: Bolin Wang, Li Chen, Xiaohui Chen, Weidong Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Machine Learning in Communications and Networking
abstract: Accurate CSI estimation with low pilots is desirable for the multiple-input multiple-output orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing (MIMO-OFDM) system. In the existing channel estimation methods, both interpolation and denoising suffer from the problem of generalization. In this paper, we propose an adaptive interpolation and multi-task learning denoising network for generalization-enhanced CSI estimation. First, we model the wireless channel based on Gaussian process (GP) and use Bayesian optimization (BO) to find the optimal parameters of the Mat´ern kernel for interpolation. For each matrix, we can find the most suitable parameters of the kernel to achieve precise interpolation adaptively. Then, we design the multi-task residual network (MT-Net) based on multi-task learning. In MT-Net, shared layers are employed to utilize the relevant information between multiple tasks. And task-specific layers are also designed to extract the characteristics of each task. Compared to single-task learning, MT-Net can achieve information sharing between multiple tasks to enhance the scenario generalization of the model. Simulation results show that when the application scenario changes, our method exhibits a stronger generalization ability compared to other neural network-assisted methods.

title: Multi-View Aligned Clustering Via Sample-Bundled Optimization: Anchor Graph Enhancement and Contrastive Propagation
authors: Shubin Ma, Zhikui Chen, Lin Yuanbo Wu, Liang Zhao
abstract: Multi-view representation is powerful to capture the complex characteristics of real-world data by integrating complementary information from various modalities. However, in many use cases, such as boiler combustion monitoring, factors including sensor sampling frequency, equipment malfunctions, and network delays can lead to temporal asynchrony in data collection. This asynchrony leads misaligned multi-modal data, furthering the difficulty of learning optimal fused representation. To address this misalignment in multi-view data, a body of methods based on autoencoders and non-negative matrix factorization (NMF) have been presented. However, those methods are incapable of jointly exploring the underlying structure inherent in each view as well as the semantic consistency and structural similarity across views. To these ends, we propose a novel sample-bundled optimization for multi-view aligned clustering, which is based on Enhanced Anchor Graph and Contrastive Propagation (termed as EAGCP). We state that there is semantic consistency among intra-class samples (with the same and cross views) and that the global structures across different views demonstrate similarity. By leveraging these associations, we introduce an enhanced anchor graph with learnable sample correlation and a contrastive graph with feature propagation. Specifically, each anchor graphs preserves the semantic relationship among same-view samples, while the contrastive graph propagates feature information across multi-view samples. Experimental results demonstrate the superiority of our method on benchmark datasets by validating its effectiveness in aligning and clustering multi-view data.

title: Auxiliary Innovation-Based Stealthy Attack Strategies Against Distributed State Estimation
authors: Jitao Xing, Dan Ye
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: This article investigates stealthy attack strategies that leverage auxiliary innovations in distributed state estimation. We propose a malicious attacker who exploits both local innovations and auxiliary innovations from neighboring nodes to construct the attack. Under such attacks, the dynamics of the compromised estimation error covariance are derived, and the attacker aims to maximize the trace while maintaining stealthiness. By leveraging singular value decomposition, we derive an analytical solution to the optimal stealthy attack, together with a degraded counterpart that does not exploit auxiliary innovations. Furthermore, to alleviate computational complexity for the attacker, a lower bound of the compromised estimation error covariance trace is established, based on which a numerical solution for a suboptimal stealthy attack is developed. Finally, the theoretical results are verified through simulations on a buoyant air turbine (BAT) model.

title: High-Frequency Characterization and Modeling of Pulse Magnet via High-Precision Impedance Measurement and Neural Network-Based Parameter Identification
authors: Lantao Huang, Ziheng Huang, Zhuobin Liu, Boyu Lin, Huamin Jie, Shaozhe Zhang, Wenqi Wei, Hanshi Zeng, Zhenyu Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Pulsed high magnetic fields (PHMFs) have emerged as essential tools in scientific research. Consequently, the design and analysis of pulsed magnets, as the key to generating PHMFs, have garnered significant research attention. Among them, the circuit model of pulsed magnets is critical for simulating their electromagnetic behavior and predicting the discharge characteristics. In this paper, a high-frequency characterization and modeling method via high-precision impedance measurement and neural network-based parameter identification is proposed. This study eliminates the influence of parasitic parameters and performs de-embedded impedance measurements of the pulsed magnet using a vector network analyzer (VNA) in conjunction with a custom-designed fixture adapter. Based on the measured data, a circuit model of the pulsed magnet was constructed, and the values of individual components in the model were subsequently identified using a neural network. For validation, the proposed circuit model was implemented in a simulation to predict the terminal-voltage variation and discharge behavior of the magnet. The results demonstrate a close agreement between the simulated and experimental voltage data, confirming the high accuracy and strong predictive capability of the model derived using the proposed method. In specific, under broadband square-wave with excitation frequencies of 1 MHz and 2 MHz, the model achieves a time-domain mean absolute errors (MAE) of 0.058/0.038 and a frequency-domain mean absolute relative error (MARE) of 0.066/0.064.

title: Semantic task offloading and resource allocation in UAV-assisted mobile edge computing network for disaster rescue
authors: Sai Liu, Zhenjiang Zhang, Guangjie Han
abstract: In disaster scenario, the damage of ground base stations leads to the interruption of traditional communication. Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) equipped with edge servers becomes the key infrastructure for emergency rescue. However, the UAV communication face strict bandwidth constraints, while aerial image transmission and ground search-rescue tasks both have high data redundancy. Simultaneously processing bidirectional UAV-ground tasks faces the dual pressure of delay and energy consumption. To address these challenges, this paper constructs a UAV-assisted semantic edge computing network. We introduce semantic compression technology to reduce the amount of redundant information in aerial images and search-rescue task data. We minimize the system energy consumption by collaboratively optimizing the task offloading decision, semantic compression ratio, edge computing resource allocation, transmission power, bandwidth allocation, and UAV three-dimensional flight trajectory. We decompose the complex non-convex joint optimization problem into five subproblems and propose an alternating optimization strategy to solve them iteratively. Specifically, we propose a branch and bound algorithm based on continuous relaxation and Lagrangian duality to solve the offloading decision subproblem. To solve the optimal semantic compression ratio, we develop an optimization algorithm based on block coordinate descent. We propose a sequential convex approximation algorithm to solve the power and bandwidth allocation subproblem. Then we design an improved artificial lemming algorithm to plan the UAV 3D flight trajectory. Simulation results show that our proposed scheme can effectively overcome the bandwidth bottleneck, significantly reduce the system energy consumption and guarantee the delay requirement of tasks.

title: DOtA++: Unsupervisely and Collaboratively Detect Objects From Multi-Agent Observations With Multi-Modal Prior Constraints
authors: Qiming Xia, Longhui Zheng, Shijia Zhao, Xun Huang, Hai Wu, Chenglu Wen, Cheng Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Enhancing perception performance via multi-agent collaboration has gained increasing attention in the field of autonomous driving. However, as the number of agents grows, the manual annotation required for training collaborative detectors increases significantly. To tackle this problem, we introduce an unsupervised method that learns to Detect Objects from Multi-Agent LiDAR scans, named DOtA, without using labels from external. DOtA first generates preliminary labels by an initial detector, which is trained by internally shared information of collaborative agents. DOtA then optimizes these preliminary labels by utilizing the physical rule constraints derived from the surrounding area of the object. Building on DOtA, we further propose DOtA++, an enhanced version that improves performance by leveraging composite prior constraints. Beyond physical rule constraints, DOtA++ further uses image data as an auxiliary modality to introduce multi-agent observation consistency constraints, boosting object classification, while also incorporating point cloud geometric distribution constraints to improve structural description. Extensive experiments on widely-used benchmarks demonstrate that DOtA and DOtA++ effectively perceive potential objects in the scene without manual annotations. In particular, DOtA++ shows 10.7% mAP improvement over traditional unsupervised methods on V2X-R dataset. Our code is available at https://github.com/xmuqimingxia/DOtAv2.

title: A Robust Inversion Method for Cross-Sectional River Surface Flow Velocity with Zonal Adaptive Multi-Angle Pairing Using UHF Streamflow Radar
authors: Qing Zhou, Zhicheng Qian, Depeng Wang, Chuanwei Ding, Heng Zhao, Hong Hong, Xiaohua Zhu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: This paper proposes a Zonal Adaptive Multi-Angle Pairing Robust Inversion (ZAMPRI) method to address the challenge of limited accuracy in retrieving cross-sectional surface flow velocity using Ultra-High Frequency (UHF) streamflow radar in complex riverine environments. Building upon the conventional Teague method, ZAMPRI incorporates longitudinal cross-section partitioning, adaptive estimation of the main flow direction, robust pre-screening based on the Median Absolute Deviation (MAD), and a multi-angle pairing-weighted fusion mechanism, which enables stable retrieval of cross-sectional surface flow velocity under complex conditions such as flow direction deviation, boundary interference, and data gaps. Simulation experiments demonstrate that under noisy, data-gapped conditions, ZAMPRI significantly reduces the MAE and RMSE of the retrieved cross-sectional surface flow velocity compared to the traditional Teague method, thereby exhibiting enhanced robustness. Multi-scale validation (single survey and long-term time series) using field data from the Yangtze River further shows that the cross-sectional surface flow velocity retrieved by ZAMPRI achieves a correlation coefficient exceeding 0.9 with measurements from a horizontal acoustic doppler current profiler, demonstrating stable reflection of true cross-sectional flow velocity variations under diverse hydrological and noise conditions. This study provides a highly accurate, generalizable new approach for estimating river cross-sectional flow velocity and discharge using monostatic UHF streamflow radar.

title: Fusing multi-sensor data to generate a highly integrated global solar-induced chlorophyll fluorescence (FSIF) time series
authors: Yuchen Wang, Xiaobin Guan, Liangyun Liu, Yao Zhang, Xing Li, Huanfeng Shen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Satellite solar-induced chlorophyll fluorescence (SIF) provides a new opportunity to quantify vegetation photosynthesis at large scales, but individual satellite observations are usually constrained by their respective limitations regarding spatial continuity or temporal coverage. Although various reconstructed SIF products have already been generated, their spatiotemporal variability remains highly dependent on selected explanatory variables, and complementary information from multiple sensors has not been fully exploited. Here, we developed a multi-source SIF fusion framework to integrate the respective strengths of the Global Ozone Monitoring Experiment-2 (GOME-2), Orbiting Carbon Observatory-2 (OCO-2), and TROPOspheric Monitoring Instrument (TROPOMI) products, to generate a Fusion-based global continuous SIF time series with high quality (FSIF). Specifically, a statistical spatiotemporal fusion (STF) approach is first employed to preliminarily merge the spatial resolution and timespan advantages across GOME-2 and TROPOMI SIF observations, and followed by a Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LightGBM) model to extract the information from auxiliary data and OCO-2 SIF. FSIF covers the full period observed by the three sensors from 2008 to 2022, with a 0.05-degree and 8-day resolution. The spatial distribution of FSIF is consistent with TROPOMI SIF (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>=0.91, p<0.001), primarily attributable to the STF process, which effectively constrains spatial patterns and value ranges. Fusion with OCO-2 observations further enhances the relationship between FSIF and the Eddy Covariance (EC)-based gross primary productivity (GPP) with an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> difference of 0.09, which benefits from the superiority of OCO-2 SIF in GPP representation. Extensive factorial experiments also declare the importance of fusing each sensor and the significance of coupling STF- machine learning (ML) models.

title: STaR-PM: An Interpretable Spatiotemporal Transfer Learning Framework for PM Retrieval Using Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks_supp1-3664648.docx
authors: Bin Chen
abstract: Accurate monitoring of ground-level PM2.5 is essential for air quality management, yet sparse in-situ observations limit large-scale surveillance. Although satellite-based retrieval has become indispensable, existing methods often struggle to simultaneously achieve high resolution, high accuracy, and physical interpretability under spatiotemporally heterogeneous conditions. To address these challenges, we propose STaR-PM, an interpretable spatiotemporal adaptive framework for PM2.5 retrieval. The core of STaR-PM is an attention-augmented improved Kolmogorov–Arnold Network (iKAN), which represents the input–output relationship through variable-wise spline-based nonlinear response functions. This structure enables direct inspection of feature-specific effects and reveals regime-dependent, physically interpretable relationships between satellite observations, meteorological drivers, and PM2.5 concentrations. To enhance robustness and generalization across regions and seasons, spatiotemporal transfer learning is integrated, allowing shared low-level representations to adapt to diverse spatiotemporal regimes. STaR-PM achieves superior performance, with an R2 of 0.89 at 1-hour/0.05◦ resolution and 0.84 at 10-minute/0.02◦ resolution, outperforming multiple baseline models. Sensitivity analyses further demonstrate stable behavior under extreme pollution levels, varying cloud conditions, and across daytime and nighttime illumination regimes. Interpretability analyses based on iKAN response functions and interaction diagnostics identify key physical drivers, and elucidate their regime-dependent impacts on PM2.5. Overall, STaR-PM effectively reconciles accuracy, resolution, generalization, and interpretability, providing a practical and physically grounded solution for large-scale, near-real-time air quality monitoring. Our source codes are available at https://github.com/HaoMingxiang/STaR-PM.

title: Shattering Latency Boundaries: An LSTM–RCM Driven Smith Predictor for Path Tracking Control Under Time Delay
authors: Seokki Lee, Junmin Park, Munyu Kim, Joono Cheong
abstract: Time-varying communication delays fundamentally limit the performance of networked control systems in robotic applications. Classical Smith predictors can compensate for constant delays but degrade under nonlinear dynamics and stochastic variations. This article presents a predictive delay-compensation framework that embeds a long short-term memory (LSTM) dynamics model and a sparse variational Gaussian process (SVGP) residual corrector referred to as a residual correction model (RCM) within a Smith predictor architecture, bridging classical control with data-driven modeling. The LSTM forecasts delay-free state evolution, while the SVGP refines these predictions by modeling structured residuals with quantified uncertainty. The approach was validated on a mobile robot teleoperation platform executing straight, circular, and mixed trajectories under round-trip delays of up to 1 s. Across all tests, the LSTM–RCM Smith predictor achieved lower lateral and heading errors than a pure pursuit controller without delay compensation, the conventional Smith predictor, and an enhanced Smith predictor with <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{H}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-filter compensation, demonstrating its robustness and accuracy under stochastic network delays.

title: Artificial Intelligence Startups: An Empirical Study of Business Model Innovation in Digital Entrepreneurship
authors: Marcel Werle, Alexander Michael Brem
abstract: Prevailing digital innovation theory assumes fast go to-market, rapid, and near-frictionless scaling of Software as a Service ventures. However, Artificial Intelligence (AI) ventures developing data-dependent solutions in Business to Business (B2B) niche markets tend to deviate from these assumptions. Drawing on a comparative multiple case study, we investigate how data dependency affects Business Model Innovation processes and trajectories in AI ventures. We contrast the early stage business model experimentation of three AI digital ventures with that of three non-AI digital ventures operating in B2B niche markets. Our data corpus comprises 11 semi-structured interviews with 119 pages of transcripts, and is complemented by informal interviews and archival data. Our analysis followed a transparent, process-oriented coding approach. The findings reveal three recurring limitations on business model experimentation from data-dependent solutions - data availability, epistemic predictability, and data path-dependency – which condition how Business Model Innovation inputs are acquired, experimentation unfolds, and how scaling trajectories emerge. The venture AI ventures in our sample deviated from classical Software as a Service scaling patterns, instead relying on service-intensive launch strategies and staged automation to build a data corpus for AI training and expansion. By specifying data dependency as a structural constraint on business model experimentation and growth, this study refines core assumptions in digital innovation and BMI literature. It provides process-level explanations for slower and staged growth trajectories in AI ventures.

title: Green Federated Learning via Carbon-Aware Client and Time Slot Scheduling
authors: Daniel Richards Arputharaj, Charlotte Rodriguez, Angelo Rodio, Giovanni Neglia
publish: 2025 33rd International Symposium on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Computer and Telecommunication Systems (MASCOTS)
abstract: Training large-scale machine learning models incurs substantial carbon emissions. Federated Learning (FL), by distributing computation across geographically dispersed clients, offers a natural framework to leverage regional and temporal variations in Carbon Intensity (CI). This paper investigates how to reduce emissions in FL through carbon-aware client selection and training scheduling. We first quantify the emission savings of a carbon-aware scheduling policy that leverages slack time-permitting a modest extension of the training duration so that clients can defer local training rounds to lower-carbon periods. We then examine the performance trade-offs of such scheduling which stem from statistical heterogeneity among clients, selection bias in participation, and temporal correlation in model updates. To leverage these trade-offs, we construct a carbon-aware scheduler that integrates slack time, $\alpha$-fair carbon allocation, and a global fine-tuning phase. Experiments on realworld CI data show that our scheduler outperforms slackagnostic baselines, achieving higher model accuracy across a wide range of carbon budgets, with especially strong gains under tight carbon constraints.

title: B5G/6G Cyber Security Testbed
authors: Alessandro Carrega, Franco Davoli, Ramin Rabbani
publish: 2025 33rd International Symposium on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Computer and Telecommunication Systems (MASCOTS)
abstract: The evolution of mobile communication technologies to Beyond 5G (B5G) and Sixth-Generation (6 G) introduces significant advancements but also new cybersecurity vulnerabilities. This paper details the National Inter-university Consortium for Telecommunications (CNIT) National Laboratory of Smart and Secure Networks (S2N) testbed in Genoa, Italy, a state-of-the-art facility for research and development in B5G/6G technologies with a focus on cybersecurity. The testbed’s modular architecture, including isolated “islands” and advanced HardWare/SoftWare (HW/SW), enables the simulation and analysis of cyber threats like Application Programming Interface (API) exposure, and Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks. It supports the testing of security measures, including Artificial Intelligence (AI)/Machine Learning (ML)-based solutions, and facilitates comprehensive vulnerability assessments and penetration testing for next-generation networks.

title: LoRa-Assisted Edge Analytics Framework for Long-Range Environmental Monitoring Using ESP32 Clusters
authors: Doniyor Yakhshibaev, Arziev Ali Tileubaevich, Raghu Raja Sharma, Alimbayeva Asalbonu, Arzieva Jamila Tileubaevna
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: The energy-efficient, scalable, and low-latency nature of long-range environmental monitoring needs resource-constrained operation of scalable and competent communication architectures. In this paper, the authors suggest a LoRa-assisted edge analytics platform with clustered ESP32 network nodes to obtain and process real-time environmental data. The suggested architecture will combine local edge intelligence with longrange LoRa communication in order to minimize the backhaul traffic and enhance system responsiveness. Delay and energy consumption and throughput mathematical models are obtained and the performance is assessed experimentally using representative simulation graphs. Findings show that the latency, power efficiency and scale of networking are greatly enhanced over monitoring solutions based on clouds.
