title: FPZNet: Fuzzy Perception Zero-Shot Learning for Infrared and Visible Image Fusion
authors: Sheng Wang, Boxun Han, Linzhe Yang, Kexin Chen, Guodong Sun, Fu Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Human cognitive systems excel at making approximate decisions in complex and uncertain environments, a capability particularly evident in visual perception. This inherent fuzzy decision-making ability has profound implications for multimodal image fusion, where the scarcity of ground-truth data for infrared and visible light integration presents a fundamental challenge for traditional deep learning approaches. Here we introduce a zero-shot transformer architecture that mirrors human cognitive flexibility by implementing fuzzy decision-making mechanisms for pixel-level fusion weight determination. Our approach circumvents the limitations of conventional pretraining requirements through a sparse attention mechanism that selectively preserves only 15-20% of the most salient cross-modal interactions, effectively filtering out redundancy and noise. To address the computational challenges of high-resolution data, we incorporate low-rank approximation techniques that reduce the complexity from quadratic to linear, capturing over 95% of cross-modal information using a projection dimension of merely 128. The method demonstrates remarkable stability across multiple benchmark datasets, achieving a peak signal-to-noise ratio of 65.904 dB under diverse environmental conditions. Our findings challenge the prevailing assumption that dense attention patterns are essential for effective feature integration, revealing instead that multimodal fusion inherently operates in a low-dimensional space. This biomimetic approach to zero-shot learning not only advances our understanding of cross-modal feature interactions but also provides a more generalizable framework for real-world applications where ground-truth data is scarce.

title: Situation-Aware Hybrid Sensing and Position Control for UAV-Assisted ISAC Systems
authors: Ling Lyu, Qirui Luo, Yanpeng Dai, Nan Cheng, Cailian Chen, Xinping Guan, Xuemin Shen
abstract: The high flexibility and controllable mobility of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) make it possible to construct the line-of-sight transmission link between devices in plant and the remote center, where the channel state condition heavily depends on the position of UAV. In this work, integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) is adopted to simultaneously perform position awareness and data transmission with limited radio resources. In particular, a situation-aware hybrid sensing pattern is proposed to reduce energy consumption and the interference of sensing to communication. In this hybrid pattern, the sensing function is activated on demand based on the channel state condition that is heavily affected by the position of UAV. Besides, the position control of UAV is performed based on the sensing result to further improve the transmission rate. Then, a joint optimization problem of beamforming design and power allocation is formulated to maximize energy efficiency. To solve this mixed integer nonlinear problem, the original problem is decomposed into subproblems in Phase I and Phase II. Finally, the golden-section based Dinkelbach algorithm and the penalty based approximation algorithm are proposed to solve the Phase I subproblem with the fractional objective function and rank-one constraints. Moreover, a quadratic transform enabled joint design of remote center beamforming and UAV transmit power is proposed to solve the Phase II subproblem. Simulation results verify that the proposed UAV-assisted integration of sensing, communication, and control approach outperforms compared approaches regarding data volume and energy efficiency.

title: Closed-Box Unlearning for Large Language Model-Enabled Internet of Everything
authors: Zhiqiang Xie, Yijing Lin, Zhipeng Gao, Jiacheng Wang, Haifeng Sun, Dusit Niyato
abstract: The Internet of Everything (IoE) represents a paradigm shift from device-centric connectivity to intelligence-centric ecosystem. To enable autonomous decision-making in dynamic environments, large language models (LLMs) have been integrated into IoE, leveraging the Model Context Protocol (MCP) to collect cross-device data for fine-tuning and transforming human natural language intents into structured tool calls that generate executable device instruction sequences. However, the massive data streams continuously generated in IoE environments often contain sensitive user privacy information, outdated low-quality data, and potentially malicious content, which can severely compromise the performance and trustworthiness of LLM-enabled IoE. Recently, LLM unlearning techniques have emerged as essential mechanisms for removing the influence of problematic data while preserving the model’s performance on retain data. However, existing unlearning approaches typically require full or partial access to the target LLM, which does not align with real-world IoE scenarios where only API access is available. To bridge this gap, we propose a closed-box unlearning framework for LLM-enabled IoE, without updating the target LLM parameters or accessing its internal logits. Our method employs a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG)-enhanced dual-auxiliary architecture for forget-data detection, enabling dynamic selection of IoE response models to prevent leakage of forgotten data while maintaining optimal performance for legitimate queries. Comprehensive experimental evaluations on the TOFU dataset across multiple forgetting ratios demonstrate that our approach achieves superior unlearning effectiveness while preserving LLM utility.

title: Continuous learning method for incremental fault class identification of control valves based on weighted supervised contrastive knowledge distillation
authors: Yan Shi, Yanjie Li, Jun Ma, Ce Wang, Jiayi Ma, Lei Li, Xiangkai Shen, Yixuan Wang, Zhibo Sun, Yushan Ma
abstract: Data-driven methods have achieved high accuracy in diagnosing control valve faults. However, Incremental Learning (IL) methods for step signal fault diagnosis of control valves remain insufficient. First, the distinct characteristics of various step-response signals lead to data imbalance, which makes it difficult for models to extract discriminative features from step-fault data. Second, the arrival of a novel fault class necessitates full retraining and incurs prohibitive computational overhead. Finally, as the number of fault classes increases, the model tends to bias toward newly added fault classes and may suffer from catastrophic forgetting of previously learned ones. These issues collectively degrade the performance of incremental fault diagnosis models. To solve these problems, this paper proposes an incremental fault diagnosis model based on Weighted Supervised Contrastive Knowledge Distillation (WSCKD), which extends the classical Incremental Classifier And Representation Learning (ICARL) framework in three key ways. First, supervised contrastive learning (SCL) is weighted to enhance representation learning for step-response signals. In addition, a new preferred example selection method, Greedy Diversity Sampling (GDS), is proposed to limit computational overhead and is combined with knowledge distillation to mitigate catastrophic forgetting. Furthermore, a Balanced Bagging Classifier (BBC) alleviates the adverse effects of class imbalance. Extensive simulation experiments were conducted on a control valve system. Experimental results demonstrate that the WSCKD method outperforms existing approaches, achieving average incremental accuracies of 94.32% for 5 fault classes.

title: Multi-Dimensional Histogram Modification Framework for Reversible Data Hiding in JPEG Images
authors: Kaiyue Hou, Cheng Zeng, Xiaoyi Zhou, Dahao Fu, Xin Liao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Reversible data hiding in JPEG images is critical for secure multimedia applications, while, existing histogram modification schemes are confined to fixed 1D or 2D dimensions. These methods fail to adapt to the characteristics of cover images and the demands of embedded data, resulting in suboptimal trade-offs among embedding capacity, image quality, and file size. To address these issues, this study proposes a Multi-Dimensional Histogram Modification Framework that advances histograms from "fixed dimension" to "variable dimension" and extends them to high-dimensional structures. Our key contributions are as follows: first, we propose an adaptive dimension selection strategy that dynamically determines the optimal histogram dimension by evaluating the capacity and distortion for each cover image and embedding task; second, we develop a high-dimensional histogram construction method that combines AC coefficients with absolute values of 1 and 2 at the same frequency to enhance the utilization of coefficient correlation; third, we design an optimized mapping algorithm that searches for the optimal mapping matrix to minimize both distortion and file expansion. Experimental results show that the proposed method outperforms existing 1D and 2D histogram modification schemes. On average, it increases the embedding capacity by 5000 bits, improves the image quality by 0.2 dB, and reduces the file size by 4000 bits.

title: Deep Learning-driven Ensemble Learning for Solar PV Faults Detection Under Low Irradiance Condition
authors: Harun Ismail, Shun-Feng Su
publish: IEEE Transactions on Device and Materials Reliability
abstract: Solar photovoltaic (PV) system has become one of the most prevalent renewable energy sources, offering numerous benefits. However, such PV failures are inevitable due to circuit issues or environmental changes. This study proposes a low irradiance PV faults detection approach based on deep learning-driven ensemble learning (ELDL). Random forest, gradient boosting, and AdaBoost are ensembled as base learners while deep neural network (DNN) is used as final decision-making of meta learning. Both internal and external features are covered as they all affect the PV performance. Double dimensionality reductions of principal component analysis and linear discriminant analysis are applied sequentially to gain representative feature extraction. Different tuning strategies are adopted: 1). Hyperopt for base learners; and 2). Optuna for DNN. Hyperopt helps gain more conditional search spaces, which become difficult due to complex, different base learners in ensemble learning. As such, Hyperopt provides versatility in search spaces. Optuna gives strong generalization of DNN in optimizing hyperparameters. The proposed ELDL method is not only validated with metrics but also with a robustness test of noise injection. The results show that the ELDL method is superior to other benchmarking models.

title: On the Reliability of Complementary Field Effect Transistor: Unveiling the Role of Grain Granularities and Random Fluctuations
authors: Sandeep Kumar, Deven H Pati, Sunil Rathore, Ankit Dixit, Naveen Kumar, Vihar Georgiev, S. Dasgupta, Navjeet Bagga
publish: IEEE Transactions on Device and Materials Reliability
abstract: This study presents a comprehensive statistical reliability analysis of monolithic Complementary Field Effect Transistors (CFETs), focusing on the impact of process-induced variations. The analysis highlights key sources of variability, including Metal Gate Granularity (MGG), Poly Grain Granularity (PGG), Random Dopant Fluctuation (RDF), and Line Edge Roughness (LER). In smaller geometries, the gate metal (or poly-gate) grain granularities play a significant role in threshold voltage (V<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sub>) variations, raising severe reliability concerns. Through calibrated statistical TCAD simulations, the ON current (I<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ON</sub>) variation of 2.82 μA (2.85 μA) is observed in the nFET (pFET) side of CFET, due to MGG for experimentally reported 5 nm grain size. In advanced technologies like high bandwidth memory (HBM), the gate is made of polysilicon that suffers from the PGG in sub-3 nm node devices. The observed coefficient-of-variance (CV) of pFET (2.19) is higher than nFET (1.45), which shows higher variability in pFET due to poly grain size variations. Further, the process-induced RDF and LER significantly alter the V<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sub>. Random numbers are generated by doping atoms in the Voronoi volume of each vertex to quantify the undoped and doped channels to statistically analyze the RDF. In contrast to a doped channel with σV<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sub> of 9 mV (7 mV) for nFET (pFET), the undoped scenario yields a default standard deviation (σV<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sub>) of 2 mV. To characterize LER, correlation length (Λ) is a prime factor; as Λ approaches the sheet width, CV increases by 24.32% (37.22%) in nFET (pFET). Thus, the results underscore the need for stringent control over grain morphology, doping precision, and edge definition to ensure reliable CFET performance.

title: Neural Network Augmented PID Control for Variable Center of Mass Autonomous Underwater Vehicle Trajectory Tracking
authors: Shreya Baronia, Aadi Dahake, Kevin He
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Robotics and Automatic Control (IRAC)
abstract: Autonomous Underwater Vehicles (AUVs) often manipulate payload or deploy mechanisms such as grippers in order to fulfill missions, possibly resulting in shifts in the center of mass (CoM) that significantly degrade the controller’s performance. Reliance on fixed-gain controllers is inadequate for real-time missions with unpredictable disturbances, including dynamic ocean environments. This paper addresses the response of an AUV as it is subjected to a change in the CoM while following predefined trajectories under realistic environmental conditions. A direct adaptive recurrent neural network is used to compute a compensation term that is added to a Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) controller, improving its ability to respond to CoM disturbances and environmental perturbations. For comparison, a gain-scheduled PID controller using predefined gains selected by angular velocity is also implemented. MATLAB simulations incorporating full 6 degrees of freedom AUV dynamics and an environmental model demonstrate that the addition of an adaptive neural network term to a standard PID controller had a lower average tracking error after a CoM change and in dynamic conditions when compared to a gain-scheduled PID controller, improving robustness in uncertain situations.

title: Capisa: A Case-Augmented AI System for Personalized U.S. College Admissions Planning
authors: Xing Ran Liao, Xin Steven, Ping Nie, Zheng Li
abstract: In recent years, demand for personalized and scalable U.S. college admission services is growing rapidly. In response to this, A large number of American college admission agencies have emerged. However, The majority of those American college admission agencies rely on templates, and their college admission guidance lacks personalization, is costly, and relies on manual labor. Accordingly, this paper propose Capisa (College, AI, Path, Initiative, Success, Aspiration), an AI-driven college admissions guidance platform that systematically integrates structured student profile data — including academic records, standardized test scores, extracurricular experiences, and personal inclination—with curated historical admissions cases, and leverages prompt engineering techniques with the ChatGPT-4o-mini model via the OpenRouter API, generating highly personalized, comprehensive planning reports for high school students targeting U.S. universities.

title: Secure Arduino-Based LiFi Communication for IoT Sensor Networks
authors: Vishal Jain, Danish Ather, Abu Bakar Abdul Hamid, Raghu Raja Sharma, Gulnoza Talipova, Golnoosh Manteghi
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: Light Fidelity (LiFi) has turned into a promising substitute to the radio-frequency communication in Internet of Things (IoT) sensor networks providing a high spatial reuse, electromagnetic immunity, and natural spatial confinement. This paper provides the design, implementation, and performance analysis of a secure LiFi-based Arduino communication platform in low power internet sensor networks. The system proposed incorporates a simple LED transmitter and receiver based on a photodiode with the resource-friendliness of Arduino platforms. An integrated security model that integrates physical containment, frame authentication and light weight encryption is presented. To measure throughput, latency and reliability, analytical modeling, prototype configuration and simulationbased evaluation are implemented. Findings show that it is possible to use Arduino in the process of getting secure LiFi communication, which can support indoor IoT applications without much compromise on performance and increased confidentiality.

title: Secure and Reusable Memory Protection for AVR Microcontrollers Using an External Tamper-Detection Countermeasure
authors: Kanwalinderjit Kaur, Atharva R. Koli
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: This paper presents a novel hardware-based countermeasure for securing memory in AVR microcontrollers against physical tampering. The system integrates a secondary AVR device that continuously monitors the target's UART RX/TX pins for unauthorized serial communication activity and triggers a fast 30-ms backup-and-wipe routine upon detection, followed by bootloader restoration for reusability. This response includes a backup of application firmware using a logger to a Wi-Fi enabled SD card and a secure memory wipe, followed by automatic bootloader restoration, thereby preserving device reusability. Unlike traditional self-destruct mechanisms that render devices permanently inoperable, this solution balances data protection with operational recovery. Implemented using off-the-shelf components and standard communication protocols (UART, SPI), the system offers an accessible, low-cost approach to embedded hardware security. Experimental results show consistent triggering within 30 milliseconds, an average backup duration of 26.8 s, and an erase latency of 33 ms, validating applicability in critical environments such as industrial controllers, automotive ECUs, and offline embedded systems.

title: Energy-Aware Optical-Wireless Convergence for 6G-Enabled Smart Cities
authors: Saef Thallal, Ali Imam Abidi, Dr. Sukhwant Kaur, Ravi Kant Prasad, Shilpa Pahwa, Vinay Kumar
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: The convergence of optical and wireless networks is a cornerstone in enabling 6G-driven smart cities, where massive connectivity, ultra-reliable communication, and sustainable operations are required. Optical backhaul provides high-capacity links, while wireless access ensures ubiquitous mobility and flexibility. However, the integration of these two domains raises challenges in energy efficiency, particularly under dense urban traffic and heterogeneous service demands. This paper proposes an energy-aware optical-wireless convergence framework that minimizes overall power consumption while preserving Quality of Service (QoS). An analytical energy model is created that represents transmission and processing costs and techniques applied to minimize the energy per transmitted bit. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed model achieves up to 38% energy savings compared to conventional designs, while maintaining comparable throughput and lower latency. The results provide an emphasis on the energy-conscious opticalwireless (EC) integration as one of the key enablers to the realization of sustainable, 6G-enabled smart city infrastructures.

title: Virtual Inertial Response and Frequency Regulation Control Method for Combined Systems of Renewable Energy and Hybrid Energy Storage
authors: Wenxin Guo, Ruifeng Zhao, Yumin Li, Jiangang Lu, Huijuan Tan, Shiming Li
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: As the penetration of renewable energy continues to rise and conventional synchronous generators are progressively retired, the decline in system inertia and the shortage of primary frequency-regulation capability have become increasingly prominent. Renewable-energy-driven hydrogen-production systems, whose electrolyzes feature fast and controllable electrochemical processes, offer a promising avenue for providing virtual inertia support and ancillary frequency regulation. To address the transient non-linearity and multi-physics coupling characteristics of electrolyzers, this paper proposes a virtual-inertia response and frequency-regulation control method for renewable-energy-based hydrogen-production systems that explicitly accounts for electrolyzer dynamic characteristics. First, a high-fidelity electrolyzer–hydrogen-production model is developed on the basis of electrochemical kinetics, thermodynamic equilibrium, and gas–liquid mass-transfer coupling, furnishing a rigorous platform for control-strategy design. Second, within a virtual synchronous generator (VSG) framework, a hierarchical coordinated-control scheme is implemented: a dynamic-inertia compensation loop collaborates with an adaptive power–frequency (P–f) regulation module to achieve rapid, coordinated virtual-inertia support and primary-frequency response. Third, to mitigate power fluctuations caused by electrolyzer operating constraints, an energy-conservation-based dynamic-matching mechanism is formulated between hydrogen-production capacity and grid frequency-regulation demand, thereby ensuring safe and economic system operation. Finally, time-domain simulations on a modified IEEE 30-bus test system demonstrate that the proposed method significantly enhances key frequency metrics—including maximum deviation and settling time—while surpassing benchmark strategies in both hydrogen-production efficiency and regulation economics. The results provide effective technical support for boosting grid inertia, improving frequency stability, and enabling high-efficiency green-hydrogen utilization under high renewable-energy penetration.

title: A Real-Time Camera Processing Pipeline for Blindspot Detection and Correction in Autonomous Vehicles with AI
authors: Harkirat Hattar, Akhil Singamneni
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: Cameras in self-driving cars often fail to deliver clear vision when affected by weather, dirt, or scratches, creating blind spots that threaten safety. Basic corrections can clean up images but struggle when conditions change quickly or when lens damage persists. This paper introduces a live processing system that addresses these issues by combining environmental correction, blindspot detection, and object recognition into one pipeline. Each frame is first corrected for weather effects, then divided into regions analyzed for sharpness, contrast, and edges. AI techniques, including LSTMs, help the system learn patterns over time and distinguish between temporary disturbances and true blindspots. Confirmed blindspots are repaired instantly before frames reach the object detector. In testing, the system identified blindspots with an 89.6% accuracy, recalled more than 82% of true defects, and improved detection confidence across degraded video. By processing input live and adapting as conditions shift, the system strengthens perception and makes autonomous vehicles more reliable in everyday driving.

title: Bridging Policy and Practice: Advancing Equitable Transmission Development in New Jersey and Multi-State Power Systems
authors: Hilda Afeku-Amenyo, Samuel Grant Quansah, Pankaj Lal, Winston Akai Nettey
publish: 2025 New Jersey Future Energy Transmission Conference (NJFET)
abstract: As New Jersey advances toward 100% clean energy by 2035, transmission infrastructure upgrade is critical, not merely for reliability and renewable integration, but also for achieving an equitable energy transition [1]. In this paper, we consider how current transmission planning processes are aligned with the Energy Master Plan and Environmental Justice Law, requiring serious engagement with communities and resilience investments in overburdened communities [2], [3]. Using a systematic examination of regulatory filings, planning studies, and geospatial data from 2020–2025, we find that while equity is expressly codified in state policy, it is consistently absent from infrastructure siting decisions, benefit distribution, and public engagement processes. Regional transmission planning programs, adopted to deliver interregional reliability and efficient cost allocation across multi-state service territories, many times lack mechanisms to incorporate localized equity considerations, misaligning state mandates at the policy level and on-the-ground outcomes [4]. We identify actionable pathways to bridge this gap, including using equity-informed planning criteria, enhanced community benefit arrangements, and enhanced coordination across statewide agencies, regional grid entities, and local actors. These findings though applicable to New Jersey also provide information for other states navigating energy transition, social equity, and system reliability in multi-state power systems.

title: Decentralized Trust Engine - Blockchain Technology Drives Paradigm Shift in Education Certificate Authentication
authors: Shujuan Li, Wenjing He
abstract: The traditional education certificate certification system is mired in multiple challenges, including centralized monopolies, low efficiency, high costs, susceptibility to forgery, poor interoperability, and information silos, which hinder global talent mobility and the development of lifelong learning. This paper presents the core argument that blockchain, as a "decentralized trust engine," is driving the transformation of the certification paradigm from "institutional trust" to "algorithmic trust." Through technical deconstruction and ecological modeling, it reveals its disruptive value. This paradigm breaks down data silos, transforms informal learning outcomes into verifiable assets on the blockchain, and drives the evolution of educational certification from a "diploma-centric" to a "competency-centric" model. It systematically addresses the current issues of efficiency, cost, and counterfeiting in certification systems, thereby establishing a trustworthy infrastructure for global talent mobility.

title: A Visualized Bibliometric Analysis of Game-Based Learning in Education
authors: Xulun Xiao, Nana Chen, Yuyan Ren
abstract: With the advancement of increasingly growing science, technology, and research methodologies, game-based education has witnessed profound and widespread application in the field of education. Therefore, it is of great significance to conduct scientific and systematic research on it. This study, based on 1,012 literature items from Web of Science, employs CiteSpace for visualized bibliometric analysis. By examining the volume of published literature, country distribution, institutional collaboration networks, and keyword clustering, it aims to unveil the research hotspots and distribution patterns in this field over the past 15 years. The research findings reveal that the research focus of game-based education has approximately gone through four transformational stages: concentrating on students’ psychological mechanisms; emphasizing the computational and model-based practical applications within the educational field; conducting research on the concrete application in educational scenarios; analyzing demographic characteristics and focusing on active learning. Meanwhile, the research priorities and trends of different countries and institutions regarding game-based education reflect diversity and pluralism. This study is expected to offer theoretical support for future research and promote the innovative development of game-based learning in education.

title: Research on UAV Path Planning Algorithms Based on Satellite Network
authors: Liang Liu, Sheng Wang, Chensong Liu, Hongyu Zhang, Danyang Chen
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Software Engineering and Service Science (ICSESS)
abstract: With the rapid development of satellite networks, these systems not only extend the communication range of UAV but also provide reliable environmental information to enhance path planning capabilities for complex missions, such as power facility inspection, emergency reconnaissance and so on. By providing environmental information to drones via satellite networks, the overall flight routes and mission efficiency of UAV are enhanced. However, the poor performance of traditional UAV path planning algorithms has become a key constraint to UAV mission execution. To address the limitations of the traditional ant colony algorithm, including its weak global search capability and slow convergence speed, an improved ant colony algorithm is proposed. First, the algorithm utilizes environmental information provided by satellites, and a multi-scale domain hopping mechanism is introduced to expand the search scope of the algorithm and enhance its search capability in densely obstructed areas. Second, an elite reinforcement strategy is employed to accelerate the algorithm’s convergence toward optimal paths while ensuring the stability of the convergence curve. Compared with the traditional ant colony algorithm, the improved ant colony algorithm reduces the average path length by 12.6%, 21.6%, 26.7%, and 30.1% on 40×40, 60×60, 80×80, and 100×100 grid maps, respectively, while requiring fewer iterations to achieve convergence. The improved ant colony algorithm demonstrates higher search efficiency compared to the traditional ant colony algorithm, achieving better path planning results and faster convergence, making it better suited to the low-latency and high-stability requirements of satellite-based environments.

title: The pose control algorithm of bionic robotic fish based on fuzzy adaptive cascade PID
authors: Gang Wang, Yaohui Pan, Simin Ding, Jun Yu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Robotics and Automatic Control (IRAC)
abstract: This study tackles the challenges of using fixed inner-loop parameters in the cascade PID controller for bionic robotic fish, particularly in the complex underwater environment and the difficulty of tuning these parameters. To overcome these limitations, a fuzzy adaptive cascade PID algorithm is introduced, which dynamically adjusts the inner-loop control parameters in real-time, improving the pose control. Both simulation and experimental evaluations were performed using the URWPGSim2D platform and a multi-robot underwater cooperative system. The simulation results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm outperforms both time-varying feedback and cascade PID controls, enabling the robotic fish to reach the target pose faster and with less error. In physical trials, the robotic fish achieved the target pose in 12.8 seconds, with a pose error of (-2px, 3px, -0.045rad), validating the algorithm's efficiency and its ability to meet the performance requirements.

title: A Review of the Application of AI Technology in the Consumption of Renewable Energy and the Coordinated Dispatching of Source-Grid-Load-Storage
authors: Zhe Zheng, Wenpeng Cui, Yu Liu, Yong Liu, Qiwei Zang, Yulu Cai
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: Driven by the global energy transition and the strategic goals of "carbon peaking and carbon neutrality," renewable energy has been integrated into power systems on a large scale due to its clean and low-carbon characteristics. However, the intermittency and volatility of renewable generation have posed significant challenges to its consumption, becoming a major bottleneck in the energy transition. As a key mechanism for integrating multiple links, source–grid–load–storage (SGLS) coordinated scheduling, combined with the advantages of artificial intelligence (AI) in big data processing and dynamic optimization, provides an important pathway to address this issue. This paper focuses on the applications of AI in renewable energy forecasting and SGLS coordinated scheduling. Starting from the core concepts of renewable energy microgrids and SGLS coordination, it reviews three theoretical foundations: renewable energy integration, coordinated optimization, and intelligent algorithms. Subsequently, it systematically surveys the current applications of AI in renewable energy forecasting and SGLS optimization and scheduling, followed by an in-depth analysis of key challenges, including covariate shift under extreme scenarios, bottlenecks in multi-source heterogeneous data integration, conflicts of interest among multiple stakeholders, and data privacy protection. Finally, the paper proposes future directions such as the integration of AI with digital twins, the application of spatiotemporal graph technologies, blockchain, and multi-agent reinforcement learning, aiming to provide theoretical insights and practical implications for AI-driven renewable energy integration and intelligent power system scheduling.

title: Improving General-Purpose LLM Models for Power Cable Tasks Using Structured Context Engineering
authors: Tong Wu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: With the rapid development of large language models (LLMs), their performance on general tasks has approached human-level capabilities. However, challenges remain in applying these models to specific professional domains, such as insufficient domain knowledge and limited problem comprehension. This paper proposes a knowledge enhancement method based on context engineering. Using DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-32B as the experimental subject, the method embeds fault cases, textbook knowledge, and real-world problem descriptions from the field of power cables into the context in a structured manner. This significantly improves the model’s performance in the domain. Experimental results show that, compared with AI systems that do not employ context engineering, the proposed method achieves a notable increase in accuracy across multiple professional question sets. The study demonstrates that combining context engineering with high-quality data can rapidly and effectively enhance a general-purpose language model's domain knowledge and problem-solving capabilities without fine-tuning of the model.

title: An Optimal Scheduling Strategy for Virtual Power Plant Participating in Peak Regulation Considering Industrial Load Production Processes
authors: Jin Mao, Liang Yin, Fang Wang, Xiaoli Wang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: High-energy-consuming industrial loads in multi-process industries such as glass factories have considerable flexible adjustment potential, but their enthusiasm for participating in grid peak shaving is low due to production characteristics. As an aggregator of distributed resources, virtual power plant (VPP) can coordinate resources to participate in trading in energy and peak shaving markets. To address this, an optimal scheduling strategy for VPP peak shaving considering industrial load production processes is proposed: constructing a trading framework for VPP to participate in the two markets, establishing an energy-peak shaving response model for glass factory loads to tap adjustment potential, analyzing and modeling their typical production processes using the state-task network (STN) method, and then building an optimal VPP scheduling model to enhance loads’ enthusiasm for demand response (DR) while ensuring normal production in glass factories. Case simulations show that the model can fully exploit load potential and actively participate in DR under the premise of ensuring safe production and plans of industrial enterprises, with VPP revenue increased by 8.16% and peak shaving and valley filling volume improved by 23.73%.

title: LSTM Neural Network Based Ramping Demand Forecasting Algorithm for Power Systems
authors: Yuanyuan Lou, Jian Chen, Chenxi Wu, Kai Li
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: Under China's "dual carbon" goals, renewable energy development has significantly increased system ramping demand complexity, posing challenges for power system forecasting. This paper proposes a multi-source decomposition modeling approach that decomposes complex ramping demand into three independent components: load changes, wind fluctuations, and solar intermittency, providing a novel theoretical framework for new power systems. A multi-branch LSTM neural network with dynamic attention fusion mechanism is employed to achieve specialized modeling and adaptive optimization for different component characteristics. Case analysis using East China power grid data demonstrates superior performance with 7.52% MAPE for short-term forecasting, achieving 18.5% improvement over traditional methods. The proposed method provides an effective solution for ramping demand prediction in renewable-dominated power systems.

title: Artificial Intelligence-driven deep learning system design for college students
authors: Xiangfei Zhao, Jihong Xu
abstract: College students generally tend to engage in superficial learning, with low levels of deep learning, facing issues such as insufficient motivation and difficulty in accessing resources. To address this, an AI-driven deep learning system is designed. Through learner profiles, personalized paths, adaptive resources, and dynamic feedback mechanisms, the system breaks through the limitations of existing systems. Following the closed-loop logic of "learning emotion perception - dynamic adaptation - intelligent intervention" and integrating multi-source data, it aims to enhance the depth and efficiency of learning, cultivate core competencies, and provide a technical path to solve the problem of superficial learning.

title: AI-Driven Fault Detection and Localization in Optical Fiber Networks
authors: Ambuj Kumar Agarwal, Kajal Saluja, KM Anjli, Nitin Rakesh, Shreyas Rajendra Hole
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: The existing telecommunication has had to heavily rely on the optical fiber networks which have large scale formed the backbone of the entire communication network of the world. These networks have however common effects of being impaired by a mixture of impairments that reduce performance; fiber cuts, signal attenuation and connector losses. The conventional fault management systems such as manual supervision and threshold-based monitoring among others are limited by their capability to work and cannot be applied adequately on largescale networks. To address the challenges, the new literature has recommended the use of the techniques of artificial intelligence (AI) in fault detection and localization in optical fiber systems.In this regard, machine learning (ML models) and deep learning (DL models) offered a chance to broaden the diagnostic process capabilities because of the opportunity to discover defects in the form of an automated solution, capable and precise in realtime. Experimental testing involving hardware proves that AIbased systems outperform traditional solutions in terms of both accuracy in detecting the adverse situations, and, reduce the mean time to recover (MTTR). In addition, the models are highly scaled hence making them particularly suited to deploy the next generation optical communication infrastructures. Overall, the use of AI-based fault management systems can ensure the network reliability is improved, the disruptions into the provided services are minimized, and the efficiency of the provided work is simplified in the modern models of telecommunication.

title: Design and Implementation of Relay Protection for 380V Station AC Power System
authors: Chunyun She, Jianwei Cao, Guangpu Zhang, Bo Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: At present, the 380V AC power supply system of substations generally lacks independent microcomputer-based protection for the incoming and outgoing feeders, relying instead on electronic trip units to perform protection functions. Although this approach simplifies wiring, the large measurement error of electronic trip units makes it difficult to achieve proper grading coordination between the inlet line and feeder line protections. When a fault occurs in an outgoing feeder, it often results in a cascading trip, causing a voltage loss across the entire 380V bus section. Moreover, locating the fault point is difficult, which severely affects the reliability of substation power supply. This paper proposes a highly integrated microcomputer-based protection device that can realize the protection functions for both incoming and outgoing lines within a single unit. This design saves panel installation space while providing high protection setting accuracy and low time-delay error, thus resolving the grading coordination problem between inlet line and feeder protections. In addition, a bus protection scheme with a blocking mechanism is adopted. It operates independently of external signals, featuring simple and reliable logic, and ensures rapid protection response in the event of bus faults.

title: Multiscale Modeling and Electrochemical Validation of PEM Electrolyzer-Coupled Hybrid Energy Storage Systems
authors: Haotian MA, Shangfeng DU, Georgios Nikiforidis
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: This paper presents a multiscale modeling and electrochemical validation framework for a decentralized hybrid energy storage system (HESS) integrating a proton exchange membrane (PEM) water electrolyzer, lithium-ion battery, supercapacitor, and photovoltaic (PV) generation. The proposed system enables autonomous energy management by dynamically coordinating short and long-term storage based on real-world environmental and load data.At the component level, the PEM electrolyzer is modeled using thermodynamic and kinetic equations, capturing reversible electrochemical potential, activation, ohmic, and concentration losses under varying temperature and pressure. The lithiumion battery and supercapacitor are represented via dynamic and equivalent-circuit models, respectively, with hierarchical control logic ensuring fast transient response and long-term resilience.One-year simulations at 15-minute resolution demonstrate the system achieves near-complete off-grid operation with grid interaction below 2%. The electrolyzer operates at 87% thermal efficiency at 2 A/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> and maintains hydrogen purity above 99.2%. The supercapacitor absorbs 5 kW load transients within 50ms, preserving battery state-of-charge between 20% and 80% and preventing degradation. Control transitions remain stable with voltage overshoot below 3%.Sensitivity analysis shows that a ±10°C stack temperature variation leads to only ±2.5% efficiency change, and moderate pressure increase improves hydrogen compression efficiency by 5% without electrical losses. These results validate the system’s technical feasibility and operational robustness. Future work will incorporate degradation modeling, techno-economic analysis, and hardware-in-the-loop validation to support real-world deployment in residential microgrids and data centers.

title: Hybrid RF/Free-Space Optical Links with RL-Based Adaptive Modulation for 6G Backhaul
authors: Jhankar Moolchandani, Santosh Sahu, Vikrant Chole, Minal Chole, Swapna Lokhande, Deepa Nikam
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: The rising requirements of 6G (sixth generation) wireless networks of ultra-reliable, low-latency, high-capacity backhaul require innovative communication systems beyond the conventional radio frequency (RF) systems. Hybrid Free-Space optical (FSO) and RF connections have complementary benefits which integrate fiber-like information communication speeds and resistance to atmospheric degradation. In this paper, the adaptive modulation framework based on reinforcement learning (RL) is introduced as a solution to the problem of improving spectral efficiency and reliability of links operating in dynamic atmospheric conditions in hybrid RF/FSO systems. By using the proposed scheme, the FSO high-capacity and RF resilience are intelligently traded with the adaptive switching and modulation scheme, the proposed scheme results in a cost-effective, reliable, and high-throughput backhaul that is compatible with the nextgeneration 6G networks.

title: Lightweight and Acceleration Optimization of YOLOv12 for Efficient Object Detection
authors: Yan Liu, Guosen Lyu, Shaopeng Wei, Guan Yue, Renyuan Qi, Lean Weng, Yajing Tong, Wenlong Zhao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Robotics and Automatic Control (IRAC)
abstract: In recent years, the growing demand for precision management have driven a growing need for robust and efficient object detection models in tasks such as crop monitoring, yield estimation, and field condition analysis. Targets in these scenarios are often small, diverse in appearance, and embedded in complex backgrounds, which places strict requirements on both detection robustness and real-time performance. Meanwhile, practical deployments typically run on resource-constrained edge platforms such as field sensor terminals or UAV-mounted devices, making model lightweighting and inference efficiency critical. To improve inference speed and structural compactness under these constraints, this study integrates a depthwise separable wavelet convolution module, termed WTConv2d, into the YOLOv12 framework to alleviate parameter redundancy during receptive field expansion. WTConv2d effectively enlarges the receptive field while preserving a compact model architecture. In addition, the original YOLOv12 detection head is replaced with the proposed v10Detect, which removes the dependence on non-maximum suppression and further accelerates inference. Experiments on a challenging agricultural image dataset demonstrate that the proposed method achieves approximately a 94.1% improvement in inference speed while maintaining comparable detection accuracy, indicating a favorable trade-off between efficiency and performance for lightweight edge deployment.

title: Optimal Configuration of Distributed Generation Considering Line Vulnerability in Distribution Networks
authors: Yangjun Zhou, Chenying Yi, Wei Zhang, Juntao Pan, Ke Zhou, Weixiang Huang, Like Gao, Shan Li, Yuanchao Zhou, Ling Li
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: Driven by the dual-carbon goals, the increasing penetration of distributed generations (DGs) enhances the flexibility and reliability of distribution networks. However, existing DG configuration studies mainly focus on ensuring the power supply to critical loads and improving system reliability, while often neglecting line vulnerability. To address this gap, this paper proposes a comprehensive line vulnerability assessment model integrating both structural and state perspectives. The line betweenness index and voltage stability index are fused using Dempster–Shafer evidence theory to accurately identify vulnerable lines. On this basis, a DG optimization configuration model considering line vulnerability is developed, which jointly optimizes DG siting and sizing. Simulation results verify that the proposed method effectively enhances system resilience and operational efficiency, achieving secure and optimal DG deployment.

title: Enhancing Learning Outcomes: Development of a Blended Sports Biomechanics Course
authors: Guoying Zhang, YifangFan YifangFan
abstract: Sport biomechanics has emerged as a pivotal field bridging the gap between sports science and Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) education. With the advancement of educational technology and the growing demands of sports science pedagogy, the limitations of traditional biomechanics teaching models in terms of practical integration and personalized learning have become increasingly evident. Blended learning has been proven to effectively enhance teaching outcomes. This study aims to elucidate the development process and student evaluations of a blended Sports Biomechanics course open for undergraduate students and the general public. By integrating online resources with offline components, a 32-credit-hour Sports Biomechanics course was designed. The pass rates were 97.7% for students majoring in sports and 86.5% for general education students A survey was conducted among 463 students who completed the course between 2022-2024, reporting an overall course satisfaction rate of 88.61%. The blended course significantly improved learning efficiency and outcomes, as evidenced by positive student feedback. The success of this blended Sports Biomechanics course, which has been accredited as a National First-Class Undergraduate Course in China, exemplifies its substantial applicability and potential for wider implementation. It is viable to use educational technologies such as the internet and virtual simulation to promote the learning of innovative methods in sports biomechanics and sports rehabilitation engineering.

title: RCNet: Reliable Co-Training Network for Weakly Supervised Change Detection
authors: Zhi-Hui You, Si-Bao Chen, Chris H. Q. Ding, Li-Li Huang, Jia-Xin Wang, Jin Tang, Bin Luo
abstract: Fully supervised change detection (CD) methods in remote sensing (RS) perform well but depend on costly and time-consuming pixel-level annotations, which are impractical to obtain at scale. Therefore, it is essential to develop annotation-efficient alternatives that can narrow the performance gap with fully supervised methods. To this end, we propose a novel weakly supervised CD framework, named RCNet, which employs dual networks to implement reliable co-training using image-level annotations. Our framework is grounded in multi-view learning of co-training and the localization ability of class activation mapping (CAM). In our approach, two sub-nets with the same architecture perform image-level change classification and pixel-level segmentation from different views. Although CAM roughly localizes changes, ambiguity and noise in its pseudo labels may cause confirmation bias, limiting performance. Our approach mitigates this bias by introducing a feature discrepancy loss to enable cross-supervision between two sub-nets. Meanwhile, CAM tends to highlight a single object, but RS images commonly contain many dense and small changed objects with complexity, resulting in decreased reliability of pseudo labels. Therefore, we present an IoU-based reliable pseudo label screening (RPLS) strategy, which minimizes the likelihood of changed areas being misidentified as unchanged, enhancing the reliability of changed information obtained. Besides, to further improve boundary fineness and internal integrity of changed areas, we incorporate an additional strong perturbation branch for each sub-net and develop a consistency regularization loss. Extensive experiments on three challenging RS image CD datasets demonstrate that our RCNet achieves competitive performance with image-level labels. The source code is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/Youzhihui/RCNet</uri>.

title: Prototype-based Asymmetric Hierarchical Matching for Text-Video Retrieval
authors: Donglin Zhang, Zheng Rao, Xiao-Jun Wu
abstract: In recent years, CLIP-based text-video retrieval has made significant progress. Most existing text-video retrieval methods usually directly align global video-level and sentence-level features without establishing intrinsic connections between different modalities. Furthermore, due to the asymmetry between visual and textual information, the symmetrical modeling also has inherent limitations that may affect the search performance. To mitigate these problems, we propose an asymmetric hierarchical text-video retrieval framework based on clustering prototypes. Specifically, beyond the commonly used global features, we generate video instance prototypes using clustering algorithms and derive video object prototypes from video patch tokens. The text instance prototypes can be obtained by the developed Text Prototype Generation module (TPG). Besides, the Joint-Interaction Module (JIM) and the coarse-grained instance alignment scheme are proposed to coordinate different modalities. Furthermore, the cross-correlation matrix among instances is proposed, which can further reduce the heterogeneity between video and text modalities. Extensive experiments on several datasets (including MSRVTT, and MSVD) demonstrate that our method outperforms some existing state-of-the-art methods. The source code is available at: <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/rzheng77/PAHM-text-video-retrieval</uri>.

title: Anonymous Task Assignment and Worker Payment in Mobile Crowdsensing
authors: Tyler Nicewarner, Ali Allami, Dan Lin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Emerging Topics in Computing
abstract: Ensuring efficient task assignment and secure payment in mobile crowdsensing while preserving worker location privacy remains a challenging problem. Existing solutions either rely on expensive encryption schemes, employ blockchain-based verification that incurs high computational and gas costs, or use differential privacy techniques that degrade spatial accuracy. This paper introduces the Privacy-preserving Task Assignment and Payment (PTAP) framework, a lightweight solution built upon secure multi-party computation (SMPC). PTAP employs additive secret sharing and a challenge-response mechanism across three semi-honest servers to achieve anonymous task allocation and payment without blockchain or zero-knowledge proofs. The framework guarantees full unlinkability between worker identities, task locations, and payment records while maintaining accurate location-based assignment and supporting traceability for dispute resolution. Experimental evaluation using the MP-SPDZ framework demonstrates scalability to over 1.5 million workers and 7 million payment tokens. The average end-to-end completion time is approximately 35.4 seconds, with zero gas cost. Compared to the state-of-the-art AVeCQ system [15], which requires about 13 minutes and 37 MWei per transaction on the Goerli network for only 1,024 users. The results confirm PTAP's efficiency, scalability, and strong privacy guarantees for large-scale mobile crowdsensing deployments.

title: A High-Dynamic-Range BroadBand MMIC GaN Mixer for Microwave Conversion TX/RX
authors: J.L. Jimenez-Martin, V. Gonzalez-Posadas, D. Espinosa-Adams, A. Prieto-Poyatos, E. Oreja-Gigorro, J. Montero-De-Paz, J.J. Sanchez-Martinez, W. Hernandez
abstract: This paper presents a wideband, high-performance monolithic microwave integrated circuit (MMIC) mixer fabricated in a 150-nm Gallium Nitride (GaN) technology from the UMS Foundry. The design addresses the inherently high local oscillator (LO) drive requirement by integrating a dedicated driver amplifier with a field-effect transistor (FET) ring mixer core. The compact MMIC, measuring 3.9 x 3 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, implements a novel dual-core architecture: an up-converter (transmit mode) with a differential radio frequency (RF) port for improved spurious rejection, common-mode noise immunity, and balanced drive capability; and a down-converter (receive mode) with an integrated balun providing a single-ended RF interface, thereby simplifying integration with low-noise components while reducing power consumption and die area. Measured results demonstrate excellent performance over a 2.5–21 GHz RF bandwidth (3:1 octave ratio), with conversion loss below 10 dB across a DC to 6 GHz intermediate frequency (IF) range. The circuit achieves port isolation greater than 30 dB and a noise figure below 10 dB. Owing to its complete high-drive mixer core and GaN’s inherent robustness, the proposed solution is particularly suited for high-performance and high-reliability systems requiring stringent integration and power-handling capability.

title: Evaluation of Relay Functionality in LoRaWAN: Energy Consumption Trade-offs and Oscillator Accuracy
authors: Ygor Kupas, Jean Michel de Souza Sant’Ana, Jamil Farhat, Samuel Baraldi Mafra, Richard Demo Souza
abstract: Long Range Wide Area Network (LoRaWAN) deployments are limited by the protocol’s native star topology. In obstructed environments, such as underground, dense urban, or industrial sites, coverage can be unreliable, causing data loss. Adding gateways improves coverage but is often cost-prohibitive. To address this, the LoRa Alliance introduced the relay functionality. This paper analyzes the energy impact on relays and end-devices using Time-on-Air (ToA)-based estimates, comparing LoRaWAN relay performance with the Long Preamble method and emphasizing trade-offs and oscillator accuracy. Our analysis reveals that the tolerance of the crystal oscillator plays a major role in the end device’s energy consumption. Specifically, using a 10 PPM crystal instead of a 40 PPM crystal, the standardized mode provides a 29% energy reduction for SF7 values compared to the Long Preamble approach for a one-hour link periodicity.

title: Assessing the Representation of Suicidal Ideation in Social Media Datasets Relative to Suicide Notes
authors: Merve Kavut, Amina Dzafic, Ulya Bayram
abstract: Clinical records are inaccessible due to legal restrictions, and genuine suicide notes are scarce, limiting the availability of verified suicidal expression data. Consequently, most Natural Language Processing (NLP) studies rely on widely accessible social media datasets containing expert annotations or heuristic labels. However, it remains unclear how expressions of suicidal ideation in these datasets relate to the ideation in genuine suicide notes. In this study, we address this gap by comparing manually annotated social media datasets in English and Turkish, as well as automatically labeled English datasets, directly against genuine suicide notes using a combination of linguistic and statistical analyses, classification models, and zero shot embedding-based representations. Results show that expert labeled social media data exhibit limited overlap with suicide notes across both languages while remaining distinguishable, whereas automatically labeled data diverge substantially from the notes in all analyses. These findings indicate that the annotation method critically shapes the signals learned by the computational models and that social media data capture different stages or forms of ideation than those in suicide notes. Overall, our findings emphasize the importance of careful dataset evaluation and caution against misinterpreting model performance in suicide risk detection research, given the shared objective: supporting global suicide prevention efforts.

title: Medium-Frequency Oscillation Analysis and Single-Parameter Feedback Suppression for Full-Size Converter-Based Variable-Speed Pumped Storage and Renewable Energy Combined System
authors: Qi Zhang, Junliang Liu, Xiaoming Zou, Chengmao Du, Xiong Du, Bing Chen
abstract: The coordinated operation of the full-size converter-based variable-speed pumped storage unit (FSC-VSPSU) and renewable energy station can help smooth the power fluctuations and improve the renewable energy utilization. However, this combined system may encounter instability problem such as medium-frequency oscillation in practical application. The impedance-based analysis method is commonly used for addressing such instability problems. Nevertheless, existing research lacks an impedance model of FSC-VSPSU and does not fully conduct the stability analysis of the system. Hence, this paper develops the impedance model for FSC-VSPSU. By integrating it with the impedance model of renewable energy units, an equivalent impedance model of the entire system is derived. The system stability is then analyzed using the impedance-based analysis method. To address the instability issues, a suppression method based on a single feedback parameter k is proposed for FSC-VSPSU. This method reshapes the equivalent impedance with minimal complexity, eliminating the need for filters that typically degrade dynamic response performance in existing solutions. Simulation and experimental results are presented to validate the effectiveness of the established impedance model and the proposed control strategy.

title: Design of Multiple Supplementary Controllers for Embedded HVDC Links Using a Model-Free Adaptive Control Approach
authors: Vitor Antunes, Antonio F. Da C. Aquino, Aguinaldo S. E Silva
abstract: Power system stability is a fundamental requirement for ensuring reliable and secure operation of interconnected grids. Disturbances such as short circuits or generator trips can initiate or amplify electromechanical oscillations, which, if not properly damped, can compromise system integrity. In this paper, a data-driven approach known as Model-Free Adaptive Control (MFAC) is applied to the design of Power Oscillation Damping (POD) controllers for mitigating inter-area oscillation modes in large-scale power systems. Unlike traditional model-based techniques, the MFAC method does not require a mathematical model of the system, relying solely on real-time input–output data to adaptively adjust the control signal. This makes the controller particularly suitable for systems with significant nonlinearities and uncertain operating conditions. The proposed POD controllers are implemented as supplementary controllers on embedded High Voltage Direct Current (HVDC) links. Their performance is validated through two case studies: a test system composed of two HVDC links and eight synchronous generators, and a full-scale model of the Brazilian Interconnected Power System (BIPS). In both cases, the MFAC approach is applied to design POD controllers in multiple HVDC links, and the performance is compared with that of POD designs based on traditional techniques. In all evaluated scenarios, the MFAC controllers exhibit effective and efficient damping of inter-area oscillation modes. Additionally, the controllers demonstrate robust performance under large variations in power system operation.

title: A Review on Air Pollution Prediction Using Artificial Intelligence
authors: G Jai Kumaran, Senthilkumar Mohan
abstract: Air pollution has become a risk to the ecosystem in recent years, raising health concerns. To take precautionary steps against air pollution, policymakers require precise pollution forecasts achieved through advanced techniques. This paper conducted an extensive literature review of machine learning and deep learning models used for air pollution forecasting. The literature review consisted of 60 studies, each of which focused on indoor and outdoor air pollution forecast models. In comparison, hybrid and ensemble models emerged as prominent models across multiple regions using datasets collected from monitoring stations, satellites, and sensors. A few articles included interpretable models to evaluate the correlation between the target feature and the features used for model predictions through Explainable Artificial Intelligence techniques. This study offers a comparative discussion and further enhancements to existing studies, which can help improve performance and interpretability. The use of deep learning models was highlighted for their consistent performance in spatiotemporal modelling, along with various suggestions for future enhancements.

title: A Multi-band Low–supply–voltage 16–QAM Transmitter Based on a Digital Fractional–N PLL with TDC Calibration for Capsule Endoscopy
authors: Daehyeon Kwon, Donghyun Youn, Sohmyung Ha, Minkyu Je
publish: IEEE Transactions on Biomedical Circuits and Systems
abstract: This paper presents a highly digital transmitter capable of multi-band 16-QAM modulation for capsule endoscopy, which requires a high data rate with high energy efficiency and relatively high output power to meet receiver sensitivity specifications. A counter-assisted digital phase-locked loop (CDPLL) is utilized for generating clocks across multiple bands with low noise, resulting in good error vector magnitude (EVM) performance. The EVM generated by the CDPLL is better than 1% by using the proposed time-to-digital converter (TDC) calibration. A digital power amplifier with high power efficiency helps reduce the power consumption of the entire endoscopy capsule system, powered by a battery with limited capacity. Fabricated in a 180-nm CMOS process, the transmitter achieves a maximum data rate of 40 Mbps using 16-QAM modulation. At a 1.1-V supply, it achieves a 0.27/0.26-nJ/bit efficiency with a data rate of 40 MHz, and the measured EVM is 3.24/3.7% while delivering a -5-dBm output power within a 10-MHz narrow bandwidth at 435/415 MHz for the wireless medical capsule endoscopy band in Europe and the biomedical band in China, respectively. The corresponding figure of merit is 0.86/0.82 nJ/bit/mW in each band.

title: Efficient Exploration for Quadruped Robots Using Graph Neural Networks with Global Attention
authors: Kai Wu, Mingyang Shi, Haoyi Zhang
abstract: Autonomous exploration in an unknown environment is a critical task for quadruped robot applications. Traditional approaches based on stacked decision rules often suffer from inefficiency due to the greedy behavior. In this work, we propose a hybrid architecture that jointly employs a graph neural network (GNN) and a multi-head self-attention mechanism within a reinforcement learning (RL) framework to address myopic decision-making across spatial and temporal dimensions. The environment is represented as a topological graph, where the GNN enables the agent to learn the spatial structure of the map by leveraging topological relations. Meanwhile, the multi-head self-attention mechanism (MHSA) captures global dependencies among subregions at different positions, enabling the robot to reason over long-range spatial relationships. The RL framework further mitigates temporal greediness by encouraging policy learning from accumulated experience, which equips the robot with the ability to reason about the spatial structure of unseen areas and strike a balance between exploiting known regions and exploring unknown ones. The proposed approach was validated in publicly available simulation environments. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach significantly reduces redundant exploration and shortens the overall planned trajectory length.

title: Improving the Accuracy of the VIE-SWG Scheme With the Use of a Strict Boundary Condition
authors: Ali Deng, Yifei Zhang, Zhiqiang Zhu, Xikui Liu, Qigang Zhu, Bingzhong Ren, Liming Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: For calculation of internal field distribution in and electromagnetic scattering from dielectric objects, it is shown that the conventional solution scheme for volume integral equation (VIE) using the Schaubert-Wilton-Glisson (SWG) basis functions by Method of Moments (MoM) suffers from the accuracy problem，especially for high permittivity cases. The analysis shows that this problem is resulted from the use of the half SWG basis functions directly for the boundary elements without any additional restrictions for normal continuity condition. Based on this analysis, a divergence free condition is applied in boundary elements for the electric flux density vector which results in a revised version of the VIE-SWG (VIE-SWG-R) scheme. Numerical results show that the revised version is accurate not only for low but also for high permittivity cases. More importantly, it is much more accurate than the conventional VIE-SWG scheme when the mesh size varies between λr/8 and λr/15 with λr being the wavelength in a dielectric body, particularly for high permittivity cases. Besides, the VIE-SWG-R scheme results in fewer numbers of unknowns than the conventional scheme for the same discretization. Additionally, this revised solution scheme can be implemented by a minor modification of the conventional VIE-SWG scheme.

title: Federated TrustChain: Blockchain-Enhanced LLM Training and Unlearning
authors: Xuhan Zuo, Minghao Wang, Tianqing Zhu, Lefeng Zhang, Dayong Ye, Shui Yu, Wanlei Zhou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: The development of Large Language Models (LLMs) faces a significant challenge: the exhaustion of publicly available fresh data. This is because training an LLM requires a large demand for new data. Federated learning emerges as a promising solution, enabling collaborative model to contribute their private data to LLM global model. However, integrating federated learning with LLMs introduces new challenges, including the lack of transparency and the need for effective unlearning mechanisms. Transparency is essential to ensuring trust and fairness among participants, while accountability is crucial for deterring malicious behaviour and enabling corrective actions when necessary. To address these challenges, we propose a novel blockchain-based federated learning framework for LLMs that enhances transparency, accountability, and unlearning capabilities. Our framework leverages blockchain technology to create a tamper- proof record of each model's contributions and introduces an innovative unlearning function that seamlessly integrates with the federated learning mechanism. We investigate the impact of Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) hyperparameters on unlearning performance and integrate Hyperledger Fabric to ensure the security, transparency, and verifiability of the unlearning process. Through comprehensive experiments and analysis, we showcase the effectiveness of our proposed framework in achieving highly effective unlearning in LLMs trained using federated learning. Our findings highlight the feasibility of integrating blockchain technology into federated learning frameworks for LLM.

title: Optimal Stabilization of Periodic Orbits: A Symplectic Geometry Approach
authors: Fabian Beck, Noboru Sakamoto
abstract: In this contribution, the optimal stabilization problem of periodic orbits is studied via invariant manifold theory and symplectic geometry. The stable manifold theory for the optimal point stabilization case is generalized to the case of periodic orbit stabilization, where a normally hyperbolic invariant manifold (NHIM) plays the role of a hyperbolic equilibrium point. A sufficient condition for the existence of an NHIM of an extended Hamiltonian system is derived in terms of a periodic Riccati differential equation. It is shown that the problem of optimal orbit stabilization has a solution if a linearized periodic system is stabilizable and detectable. A moving orthogonal coordinate system is employed along the periodic orbit, which is a natural framework for orbital stabilization and linearization along the orbit. Two illustrative examples are presented: the first involves stabilizing a spring-mass oscillator at a target energy level, and the second addresses an orbit transfer problem for a satellite-a classic scenario in orbital mechanics. In both cases, we show that the proposed nonlinear feedback controller outperforms traditional linear control.
