title: The Strategic Role of Cross-Border Online Early Education in Advancing AI and Computational Skills: A Case Study of a Romanian University and Rural regions in R.Moldova
authors: Irina Mocrac Groza, Anatolie Mocrac
abstract: University rankings are gaining importance worldwide. While the top-ranked universities are the subject of numerous academic publications, very little literature is available on universities in the lower two-thirds of the ranking list. [1] Babeș-Bolyai University (UBB), placed 801–1000 in the 2025 THE Computer Science ranking with an international outlook score of 28.6(March 2025), highlights deficiencies in current evaluation frameworks. This study proposes the introduction of a Peripheral Outlook Index for better capturing university engagement with peripheral schools in computer science (CS). The next research phase proposes an option how to expand UBB’s global academic presence and foster early computational competencies among rural dual Moldo-Romanian citizens, via XREDUNordiclab, a virtual educational platform. A new, promising research field in education consists of acquainting children with Machine Learning (ML) to foster this much-needed shift from traditional rule-driven thinking to ML-based data-driven thinking. [2] The framework establishes priorities for independent curricular development, emphasizing zero-coding, digital citizenship, and foundational artificial intelligence competencies. Scant if any attention has been paid to ML in computing education [2] for international online classes. We introduce a proposed model, the computer science talent development model (CSTDM), for finding and developing talents in computer science in K–12 settings [3] across Romania, the Republic of Moldova, and Finland. Results gained from a virtual, English-language international classroom suggest that strong motivational engagement can mitigate initial technical limitations, enabling children to comprehend and apply foundational ZeroCode Science concepts. This article starts by introducing the theoretical, pedagogical framework for learning by collaborative design. Then, it presents the research methodology, research setting, and the empirical work and analysis.[4] Research implications and future research directions within the K-12 context are also discussed.[5] The recent findings underscore the transformative potential of virtual, motivation-centered, cross-border pedagogical ecosystems in developing equitable, AI-literate educational pipelines.

title: The Impact of Interdisciplinary Learning on Students' Higher-Order Thinking Development: meta-analysis based on 22 Quasi-experiments Domestic and Foreign Based on 2000-2025
authors: Jing Wen, Yan Song, Lei Cao
abstract: The new curriculum standards of the Ministry of Education require that interdisciplinary learning and strengthening the collaborative education function of the curriculum, but its actual effectiveness in promoting the development of students' higher-order thinking is still controversial. Through meta-analysis of 22 domestic and international quasi-experimental studies (total sample size N=2183), this study found that interdisciplinary learning exerts a moderate-to-high and statistically significant positive effect on promoting students' higher-order thinking, but a relatively limited effect on innovative creativity and problem-solving ability. In addition, this effect was influenced by a number of moderating variables: in terms of teaching modes, blended and contextualised teaching had a significant effect; in terms of educational stages, the strongest effect was found at the primary school level; regarding course types, the stronger effect was found in the natural sciences and medical courses; and for the degree of integration between education and technology, the best effect was found at the "substitution" and "redefinition" levels; concerning the degree of embodiment, the medium degree of embodiment had a greater impact; and in terms of achievement measurement tools, the use of domain-based measurement tools was the most effective. Looking ahead to the future, teachers should cultivate students' higher-order thinking in a targeted manner based on the characteristics of their academic subjects, flexibly design interdisciplinary activities according to their cognitive development stages, strengthen teacher training and technological empowerment, reasonably use generative artificial intelligence (GAI) to construct a new mode of human-machine collaborative teaching, and adopt multi-dimensional evaluation tools that focus on student differences to dynamically monitor and promote students' higher-order thinking development.

title: Enhancing Mixed Reality Accessibility for Color Vision Impaired Users
authors: Haseeb Ali Khan, Sitara Afzal, Kyungjin Han, Jong Weon Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: Mixed Reality (MR) technology creates immersive experiences in entertainment, games, and education. However, some individuals, like those with Color Vision Deficiencies (CVD), may not fully enjoy these experiences. CVD is a condition that affects a significant portion of the population, particularly men. People with CVD often encounter color-related challenges in their daily lives. To address this challenge, we present a novel MR application specifically for individuals with CVD. Our goal is to assist color-blind users in interacting with colored objects efficiently while experiencing MR scenarios by providing them with textual information about the objects they interact with, as well as real-time communication with other users. The system offers two modes, Virtual Environment and Augmented Environment, with multiplayer functionality for real-time communication and guidance. Key technical components include color and object detection, text augmentation upon keyword detection, and synchronization of the scenes for effective interaction and communication between multiple users. We evaluate our system’s effectiveness and usability, aiming to enhance accessibility in MR environments for color-blind users.

title: Research on Layered Reactive Power Coordinated Control of Photovoltaic Energy Storage
authors: Jianyue Man, Bingfeng Yu, Guangjun Hao, Yuxin Li
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: The large-scale integration of photovoltaic (PV) grid-connected generation poses new challenges to voltage stability in distribution networks. To address voltage limit violations caused by PV integration, this paper proposes a layered PV–energy storage coordinated reactive-power control strategy. First, a voltage-state awareness score is constructed by fusing voltage deviation, rate of change, and short-window magnitude, and the voltage state is classified into four levels-"normal, slight violation, moderate violation, severe violation"-to enable early, quantitative perception of over-limit risk. Then, resources are coordinated in layers according to the score: under slight violations, the remaining reactive power of PV inverters at violating nodes is prioritized; if the violation persists or worsens, multi-point PV reactive power is coordinated based on "residual capacity and electrical distance"; in severe-violation scenarios, active-power support from energy storage is superimposed (modulated by SOC weighting and power/cycling constraints), forming a closed-loop control of "local priority-system-wide coordination-storage backstop." Daylong time-series simulations on the IEEE 33-node low-voltage distribution network show that, compared with traditional droop control, the proposed strategy more effectively suppresses peak-period overvoltage within the acceptable voltage band and reduces the maximum deviation at feeder ends, significantly improving system-wide voltage compliance and overall enhancing voltage quality and operational stability of the distribution network.

title: Beyond the Algorithm: A Holistic Pedagogy for Cultivating General Education in the AI Era of Language Education
authors: Xin Wang, Shudong Wang
abstract: The integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) into language education has marked a paradigm shift, offering unprecedented efficiency and personalization. However, this technology-driven approach risks overlooking the cultivation of crucial humanistic growth, such as intrinsic motivation, emotional resilience, and the ability to formulate insightful questions. This paper addresses this pedagogical gap. Drawing upon over 20 years of pedagogical practice in beginner-level Chinese language classes at a Japanese university, this study proposes a series of "counter-intuitive," human-centered teaching strategies. These strategies are not designed to oppose technology but to build a complementary relationship with it. This paper argues that by focusing on igniting curiosity, building psychological safety, fostering empathy, and valuing the process of inquiry, educators can nurture the aspects of holistic development that AI cannot replace. We conclude that this synergy between technology and humanism is the key to realizing true General Education and holistic education in the AI era.

title: Research on high-precision real-time simulation modeling method of TNPC three-level inverter based on ABM
authors: Zehui Wang, Guochu Chen
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: T-type neutral clamp (TNPC) three-level inverters have gained widespread attention in medium to high power applications due to their excellent efficiency and performance. However, its complex switching state and real-time control strategy pose challenges to the computational efficiency and accuracy of the simulation model. In this paper, a high-precision real-time simulation method combining algorithmic modeling (ABM) and average switching modeling (ATMT) is proposed. By constructing switch state coding and interlocking logic, the precise abstraction of the switching behavior of TNPC inverter is realized. In the open-loop experiment, the system compares three methods: pure SimPower Systems modeling, ABM+ATMT modeling and ABM+SimPower hybrid modeling, and the results show that the total harmonic distortion (THD) of the output voltage is less than 3.1% in the whole working condition range of modulation ratio 0.6 to 1.0, which is significantly better than the comparison method, while maintaining excellent fundamental amplitude reproduction accuracy. In the closed-loop experiment, the VF control strategy is used to verify that the proposed ABM model and the physical Simscape model have a high degree of consistency between the power grid voltage and the inverter current waveform (fundamental amplitude deviation <0.1%, THD deviation <0.03%). This study provides an effective solution for efficient and high-precision real-time simulation of three-level inverters.

title: AI-Augmented Photonic Integrated Circuits for High-Capacity Optical Interconnects
authors: Vinod Joshi, Ashwini Kumar, Lalit Kumar Tyagi, Sudeep Varshney, Mridul Gupta, Baker Karim
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: This paper presents an AI-augmented photonic integrated circuit (PIC) architecture designed to enhance high-capacity optical interconnects. The integration of artificial intelligence enables adaptive optimization of channel allocation, thermal tuning, and nonlinear compensation in silicon photonic devices. Simulation results demonstrate significant improvements in spectral efficiency, energy efficiency, and biterror rate (BER) compared to conventional PICs. The proposed solution highlights the synergy between photonics and AI in future exascale computing and data center networks.

title: Design and Development of an Arduino–GSM Based Wireless Telemetry System for Water Monitoring Applications
authors: Abdusamat Ubaydillayev, Ferdavs Isakulovich Kushnazarov, Mansurbek Marufov, Dilsora Saidxodjayeva, Nodirbek Madiboev Jamolidinovich
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: Efficient monitoring of water resources is essential for sustainable agriculture, urban water management, and hydrological safety. Conventional manual monitoring approaches are labor-intensive, error-prone, and unsuitable for remote or distributed environments. This paper presents the design and development of a low-cost Arduino–GSM based wireless telemetry system for real-time water monitoring applications. The proposed system integrates water level and flow sensors with an Arduino microcontroller and a GSM communication module to enable continuous data acquisition and remote transmission. Sensor data are processed locally and transmitted to a monitoring station via Short Message Service (SMS) or packet-based GSM communication. Experimental evaluation demonstrates reliable data delivery, acceptable latency, and low power consumption, making the system suitable for deployment in remote and resource-constrained environments.

title: Study on hyperspectral inversion model of Cr content based on soil in yugan county
authors: Ziheng Zhao, Qixiang Nie, Xiaoming Zhang, Liangchuan Qiu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Geographic Information and Remote Sensing Technology (GIRST)
abstract: The extraction methods of characteristic bands and the selection of inversion models for hyperspectral inversion of soil heavy metal pollution are key factors affecting inversion accuracy. How to optimize their combination to improve inversion accuracy is a pressing challenge that needs to be addressed. In a typical heavy metal-polluted area of Yugan County, 130 soil samples were collected. The Cr content was measured using the ICP-AES (Inductively Coupled Plasma-Atomic Emission Spectroscopy) method, and their hyperspectral information was collected in the laboratory using the FieldSpec4 Hi-ResNG spectrometer from ASD. Spectral preprocessing employed a combination of Savitzky-Golay smoothing (SG), multiplicative scatter correction (MSC), and first-order differential (FD) transformation to mitigate the effects of soil scattering and noise. Three algorithms—competitive adaptive reweighted sampling CARS), Pearson correlation coefficient (PCC), and genetic algorithm (GA)—were selected to extract characteristic bands. Three inversion models—random forest regression (RFR), partial least squares regression (PLSR), and XGBoost regression—were chosen to establish the relationship between the characteristic bands and Cr content.By comparing the inversion results of soil Cr content under different combinations of characteristic band extraction methods and inversion models, it was found that the CARS and PCC methods significantly improved the predictive performance of the PLSR, XGBoost, and RFR models. The combination of SG+MSC+FD+CARS+RFR extracted 84 characteristic bands located at 350–500 nm, 1600–1850 nm, and 2100–2500 nm. After modeling, the validation results showed a coefficient of determination (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) of 0.75, root mean square error (RMSE) of 6.74 μg/g, mean absolute error (MAE) of 5.37 μg/g, and mean relative error (MRE) of 7.35%, indicating excellent performance in predicting soil Cr content. Subsequent experiments explore the inversion model of soil heavy metal content based on spectral data extracted from ZY1-02D hyperspectral images, with an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.84 for the training set and an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.36 for the test set.Taking hyperspectral inversion of soil Cr pollution as an example, this study determined the optimal model by comparing the inversion accuracy of different combinations of characteristic band extraction methods and inversion models, providing a modeling approach for small-sample inversion of soil heavy metal pollution.

title: A Hybrid 3D-DenseNet+ISSC Framework with Expert-Informed Post-Processing for Multimodal Urban Land Cover Classification
authors: Ahmad Alkhatatbih, Dalila Megherbi
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Geographic Information and Remote Sensing Technology (GIRST)
abstract: The classification of Urban land cover of multimodal Airborne imagery is still challenging due to spectral similarity, spatial adjacency, and structural ambiguity among urban classes. We extend the multimodal 3D-DenseNet+ISSC late-fusion framework with a rule-based post-processing module, getting inspired by the Data Fusion Contest (DFC) 2018 winners. We tested our model on the Houston IEEE GRSS 2018 DFC dataset, experimental results demonstrated that the proposed approach enhances the Overall Accuracy (OA) from 74.39% to 83.44% and Average Accuracy (AA) from 66.82% to 74.18%, outperforming the DFC 2018 national challenge winners, while highlighting the enduring value of domain-informed post-processing, even when leveraging advanced deep multimodal fusion architectures, and highlight the importance of integrating learned and rule-based corrections for robust urban scene classification.

title: ML-based Resource Dimensioning for 5G Core NFs
authors: Fetahi Wuhib, Carla Mouradian
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: Efficient resource dimensioning is critical in the dynamic NFV landscape, particularly in complex 5G core (5GC) deployments. We propose a Deep Neural Network (DNN)-based solution that automatically generates NF resource configurations to meet SLA targets while optimizing infrastructure use. Since the available data maps configurations to KPIs, direct training in the reverse direction (KPIs to configurations) is infeasible. We address this with inverse input reconstruction. A second challenge arises because multiple valid configurations can satisfy the same KPI, which we solve by designing a loss function that balances inference accuracy with aggregate resource usage. Finally, since collecting sufficient experimental data is prohibitively slow (30– 60 minutes per sample), we design and implement a 5GC simulator to generate representative datasets. We evaluate our solution in this setting and show that it enables accurate and efficient configuration generation, demonstrating its feasibility for complex NFV services.

title: The Impact of Generative Artificial Intelligence on Learning Outcomes of College Students: A Meta-Analysis Based on Instructional Design
authors: Ping Yin, Yalin Yin, Ying Zhang, Yixiao Zhang
abstract: The rapid iteration of generative artificial intelligence has provided a technological driver for innovation in higher education. However, there is still controversy among researchers regarding whether generative artificial intelligence can improve college students' learning outcomes, and it is unclear how generative artificial intelligence can be effectively integrated into instructional design. Therefore, this study systematically analyzed 32 relevant experimental or quasi-experimental studies from the instructional design perspective using the meta-analysis approach. The results showed that the teaching application of generative artificial intelligence had a moderately positive impact on the learning outcomes of college students. It has shown certain positive effects under different teaching content, teaching resources, teaching modes and teaching evaluation. Moreover, the learning organization form, teaching period and sample size had a significant moderating effect on the learning outcomes of generative artificial intelligence. Based on this, the study put forward some suggestions on the integration of generative artificial intelligence into teaching, in order to provide reference for educators to further practice.

title: Research on the Entropy-Weight TOPSIS Model for Performance Assessment under the Classification Evaluation System of University Teachers
authors: Changyu Xu, Qingwei Meng
abstract: The study investigates the performance assessment of teachers under the classified evaluation system in higher education institutions, exemplifying College D in Shanghai as the research objectives. An evaluation method on the basis of the entropy-weighted TOPSIS model is proposed and applied. This method calculates the weights of evaluation indicators with the tool of information entropy and assesses teacher performance comprehensively through the TOPSIS model. The results of empirical experiments show that the model effectively captures differentiation among teachers across various indicators and is particularly sensitive to those with high variability. Additionally, the increase of the sample size refines the rationality of the assessment outcomes. The model demonstrates strong adaptability for evaluating teachers in different fields, inclusive of teaching, scientific research and public services, providing a valuable reference for the classified assessment of teachers in higher education institutions.

title: Graph Signal Prediction using Learned Laplacian with Application to Weather Data
authors: Christopher Duran, Jing Guo
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: As interest in Graph Signal Processing (GSP) continues to grow, the complexity of its practical implementations also surges. While many previous studies on GSP have relied on prior knowledge of the underlying graph topology, this assumption often fails, as the network topology of real data is almost always unknown. This paper proposes the use of a novel graph learning algorithm to draw on the relationship between graph regressors and signal smoothness to predict missing signals based on weather data. Using this algorithm, our aim is to identify similarities or dependencies in the data more accurately, thereby estimating climate behavior hidden within their network structures. The outcome of this study will be to improve predictive capabilities in graph signal prediction from learned graph topology.

title: Multi-dimensional quantitative extraction of road cracks using RKDPT
authors: Jishi Sun, Weidong Song, Shangyu Sun, Jinhe Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Geographic Information and Remote Sensing Technology (GIRST)
abstract: Aiming at the issues in road crack detection, such as heavy reliance on supervised algorithms, insufficient extraction accuracy, and weak detail characterization capability, this study proposes the RKDPT algorithm for road crack detection using high-density laser point cloud data. The method achieves precise extraction of three-dimensional crack coordinates and quantification of multi-dimensional attribute information. The preprocessing pipeline adopts grid partitioning and standardization to enhance crack feature distinctiveness. The RANSAC plane fitting algorithm is employed to extract candidate crack points. By integrating local neighborhood point density and Euclidean distance, outlier removal is performed via PCA to eliminate noise and obtain the final crack points. The TIN algorithm is utilized to construct crack boundary polygons and skeleton points, based on which attributes such as direction, length, width, and depth are quantified. Experimental results show that, compared with three different methods, the proposed approach achieves F1-score and IoU of 77.32% and 63.06%, respectively, reaching accuracy levels comparable to the baseline PointNet++ model in deep learning. Comparative results indicate that the accuracy for longitudinal cracks in length, width, and depth reaches 91.63%, 87.88%, and 94.02%, respectively, while for transverse cracks, it reaches 88.50%, 84.66%, and 93.51%, verifying the accuracy of the proposed crack detection and quantification algorithm.

title: RAG-X-Driven Construction of an Intelligent Platform for Teaching Assistance in Higher Education
authors: Shuai He, Liming Liu, Jinghui Ma, Yu Lu
abstract: This study developed a RAG-X workflow based on RAG technology and constructed a teaching support platform suitable for intelligent education in universities. Currently, AI teaching support platforms are plagued by issues such as fragmented functions and frequent hallucinations. Based on RAG-X technology, this project has developed a teaching support platform that includes a large language model specialized in economics and management, an intelligent question generator, personal knowledge bases, and "YOU Intelligence". The actual effectiveness of the platform was evaluated using quantitative analysis methods. The research found that the intelligent education support platform developed in this project has significantly improved the teaching and learning experiences of teachers and students in four dimensions: functional satisfaction, ease of use, perceived learning/teaching effectiveness, and future willingness to use.

title: A Distributed Link Precoding Method Based on Reciprocity
authors: Xiaodong Zhang, Guibo Zhu
abstract: Issues in flight tests—such as high aircraft taxiing speeds, drastic channel variations, significant challenges in acquiring channel state information (CSI) for frequency division duplexing (FDD) systems, and the resultant severe degradation of transmission rates in existing cooperative precoding—are hereby addressed. A distributed link precoding method based on reciprocity is proposed. First, CSI reconstruction is performed using partial reciprocity. Leveraging the correlation among CSI obtained at different locations, reciprocity parameters are extracted for prediction. These predicted parameters are then used to replace their corresponding counterparts in the feedback CSI, thereby achieving channel correction. When channel correlation is weak, the conjugate beamforming (CB)-based precoding algorithm is adopted; when channel correlation is strong, the zero-forcing (ZF)-based precoding algorithm is employed. This approach enables the maximum utilization of diversity gain and multiplexing gain. Simulation results show that the proposed method can achieve accurate prediction of CSI, and after precoding with the accurate CSI, higher throughput can be obtained, which improves the offloading rate of aircraft test data.

title: Low-Power Silicon Photonics for Edge-Enabled Telecommunications Systems
authors: Neha Belwal, Gouri Shankar Mishra, Ravi Kalra, Ahmad Alzaidi, Vivek Dhiyani, Vandana Aggarwal
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: Silicon Photonic is fast becoming one of the leading technologies of low-power, high-speed communication in edge device telecommunications systems. In this paper, an analysis will be provided of the recent developments in silicon-based photonic devices and integration approaches with a focus on the effect of this technology in facilitating energy-efficient optical interconnects in next-generation edge infrastructures. There is a proposal of architecture of low-power digit photonic circuit design and performance in edge computing, which is simulated with analysis.

title: DetectLLM: A Multimodal Fusion Approach for Detecting LLM-Generated Text
authors: Rajat Soni, Rajiv Misra, Supratik Mukopadhyay
abstract: Large language models (LLM) are increasingly being able to generate human-like text. Delineating between AI-generated and human-authored content is essential for academic integrity, journalism, cybersecurity, and digital forensics. State-of-the-art detectors often rely on superficial linguistic patterns or watermarking approaches. Not only such detectors ae unreliable, one can easily evade such detectors by paraphrasing, fine-tuning, or using model ensemble techniques. This paper presents DetectLLM, a novel multi-modal detection framework leveraging a combination of fine-grained linguistic analysis and deep contextual embeddings to identify LLM-generated text across various domains and model types.DetectLLM presents a hybrid setup that merges a transformer-based discriminator trained on a varied dataset of human and LLM-authored texts. It also includes a metadata-aware classifier that picks up on temporal, stylistic, and structural signals. We also include a contrastive learning module to distinguish LLM textual fingerprints from human writing styles, even in adversarial or obfuscated environments.Our method outperforms state-of-the-art LLM output detectors across multiple benchmarks, for content generated by GPT, Claude, LLaMA, and open-source fine-tuned models. Our approach achieves an F1-score of 88.9%, outperforming state-of-the-art AI generated detectors such as DetectGPT (86.2%) and the OpenAI Text Classifier (82.1%), while maintaining robustness and generalizability across languages and domains.

title: Scalable Continuous Testing Framework
authors: Abhirup Chatterjee
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Software Engineering and Service Science (ICSESS)
abstract: In modern software delivery, continuous testing is a critical enabler of rapid and reliable deployments, yet long-running integration tests often create bottlenecks in CI/CD pipelines. This paper introduces SCTF (Scalable Continuous Testing Framework), a Jenkins-based solution built with Groovy that dynamically generates pipeline stages at runtime to optimize test execution. Unlike fixed pipelines, SCTF uses YAML-based configuration to easily set how many stages to run, how they’re arranged, and whether they run in parallel, sequence, or a mix—depending on each service’s testing needs. By grouping Cucumber features or scenarios and distributing them across configurable stages for parallel execution, overall test time can be reduced from several hours to under 30 minutes, accelerating feedback and production deployment readiness.Beyond dynamic orchestration, SCTF integrates advanced capabilities including stage-wise log preservation, consolidated Cucumber report generation, error log extraction, and automated Confluence uploads for enhanced traceability. It further supports rollback mechanisms which can be configured under certain condition, shell command execution, and real-time notifications through Slack and email, ensuring resilience and transparency across the delivery pipeline. By providing scalability, adaptability, and efficiency, SCTF enhances the robustness of Jenkins pipelines, enabling faster and more reliable production releases while strengthening the overall continuous testing lifecycle.

title: Economic Optimal Dispatch Method for Low-Voltage Distribution System Based on AOE Control Technology
authors: Di Huang, Junjie Huang, Bin Zhou, Liangrong Xu, Faxian Wu, Weimin Lu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: The development of new electricity system has led to the aggregation and coordinated control of an increasing number of source-load resources, making the structure of distribution networks more complex. As a result, the computational burden and latency of traditional centralized control methods have risen significantly. Against this background, this paper proposes an economic dispatch technique for low-voltage distribution substations based on AOE (Activity on Edge) control technology. First, an event-driven control architecture based on AOE theory is designed to enable rapid deployment of edge computing services. Second, an economic optimal dispatch model for low-voltage distribution substations is established using AOE-based modeling. Finally, a Simulink-Based simulation is conducted to compare the proposed edge-based distributed control method with a conventional cloud-based centralized control approach. The results demonstrate that the proposed AOE-based edge control technology effectively reduces communication latency and meets the operational requirements of practical power grid applications.

title: Area-Efficient Heterogeneous MRAM for High-Performing AI Acceleration
authors: Sohan Salahuddin Mugdho, Kshemal K. Gupte, Md. Shahedul Hasan, Cheng Wang
abstract: Modern Artificial Intelligence (AI) workloads have become increasingly complex and memory-intensive, posing a significant challenge to computational efficiency. One promising solution is to address the notorious von-Neumann memory wall bottleneck by enabling high-density memory to reduce the off-chip data movement. Spin Transfer Torque Magnetic Random Access Memory (STT-MRAM) has recently emerged as a promising non-volatile memory (NVM) technology. Compared to Complementary Metal-Oxide-Semiconductor (CMOS)-based Static Random Access Memory (SRAM), MRAM achieves higher density while providing the desirable access speed and endurance for on-chip memory. However, the scaling of the standard STT-MRAM cell is hindered by the access transistor, which needs to be large to supply sufficient write currents for accurate STT-driven switching. In this work, we propose a heterogeneous MRAM architecture based on area-efficient and error-aware MRAM cell design. We exploit the insight that pre-trained DNN models have high heterogeneity in the error resiliency at the bit-level granularity. A comprehensive device-circuit-algorithm co-optimization framework is developed to harness a significant improvement in the on-chip density of MRAM, leading to substantial mitigation of the von Neumann bottleneck while narrowing the gap in write energy between MRAM and SRAM. Our evaluations of the co-designed MRAM-based AI inference engine demonstrate an optimal trade-off between bit error and efficiency. Compared to the SRAM baseline, we achieve up to 4.7x and 2.43x improvement in the efficiency of memory access energy and system-level energy, respectively, while preserving near-lossless inference accuracy.

title: Measurement-Based High-Altitude UAV Air-to-Ground Channel Characterization and Modeling for Different Flight Maneuvers at 28 GHz
authors: Yixiao Tong, Yuning Yu, José Rodríguez-Piñeiro, Jingxiang Hong, Guangzheng Jing, Fan Yu, Shunqin Xie, Xuefeng Yin
abstract: As one of the components of the Low Altitude Platforms (LAPs) and High Altitude Platforms (HAPs) for Non-Terrestrial Networks (NTNs), Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) have become a key player for future six-generation (6G) networks. Understanding the Air-to-Ground (A2G) propagation channels is essential to enable reliable wireless communication systems between Ground Stations (GSs) and UAVs. In particular, due to the scarcity of available bandwidth, higher frequency bands, such as millimeter wave (mmWave), are essential. However, in previous studies, most of the high-altitude and highspeed UAV channel models in mmWave bands are solely based on simulations. To fill the gap, in this paper, A2G channels have been evaluated by means of a fixed-wing UAV measurement campaign considering three different heights (1500 m, 2000 m, 2400 m) and two different maneuvers, namely cruising and turning, in a rural scenario at Ka-band (28 GHz) and with 420MHz bandwidth. The multipath components (MPCs) are extracted by the space-alternating generalized expectation-maximization (SAGE) algorithm and used as the basis for developing a complete stochastic channel model. This model explicitly characterizes key parameters, including Path Loss (PL) with its exponent, Rician K-factor, Root-Mean-Square Delay Spread (RMS-DS), and Root- Mean-Square Doppler Frequency Spread (RMS-DFS) for different flight altitudes and aircraft attitudes. Due to large bandwidth considered, the increased delay resolution allowed us to provide through analyses of the exhibited propagation effects, such as the MPCs caused by the airframe. Furthermore, the models specifically include the effects of the attitude characteristics for each flight maneuver. For example, the PL model incorporated correction factors related to the changing flight attitude of the aircraft. As a result, the provided models constitute a complete framework for the simulation and evaluation of high-altitude and high-speed A2G channels, which are of utmost importance for the design and deployment of 6G NTN systems.

title: Millimeter-Wave Phased Array Antenna with High Gain, Low Grating Lobes, and Fewer Phase Shifters via Overlapped Large-Sized Elements
authors: Zhicheng Huang, Shaowei Liao, Haoshen Zhu, Quan Xue
abstract: This paper presents a millimeter-wave (mmWave) phased array antenna (PAA) design that reduces the required number of phase shifters while achieving high gain and low grating lobes for both horizontal (HP) and vertical polarization (VP) arrays. The design leverages a novel approach using overlapped large-sized elements (LSEs), each comprising a driven subelement with multiple passive and parasitic subelements, all implemented as patches. By configuring the LSEs with tailored aperture fields that approximate a sinc function distribution, the array achieves a flat-top active element pattern (AEP), effectively reducing scan loss and suppressing grating lobes. To demonstrate, 24-GHz 1×5-element HP and VP linear PAAs with λ0 element spacing are developed, which further form 1-D scanning 4×5-element HP and VP planar PAAs, respectively, fed by just five phase-shifted ports. The measurements show that the HP/VP array achieves a peak gain of 22 dBi/21.7 dBi with a scanning range of ±20°/±18°, scan loss below 2 dB/1.2 dB, and grating lobes below −10 dB. This design provides a cost-effective and simple structural solution for limited field-of-view applications requiring high performance and low grating lobes, with potential scalability for future mmWave vehicle systems.

title: Fano-Like Resonances in Coupled Sagnac Interferometers Formed by a Self-Coupled Waveguide
authors: Hamed Arianfard, Tim Weiss, Yang Yang, Joshua Bader, Stefania Castelletto, Alberto Peruzzo
abstract: We demonstrate Fano- like resonances in silicon-on-insulator (SOI) nanowire-based coupled Sagnac interferometers (SIs) formed by a self-coupled waveguide. By adjusting the reflectivity of the two SIs and coupling strength between them, we tailor coherent mode interference to achieve high-performance optical analogues of Fano resonance. The device is theoretically analyzed and experimentally fabricated on a SOI platform. Theoretical analysis predicts periodic Fano- like resonances with a high extinction ratio and a steep slope rate, arising from strong coherent optical mode interference within a compact resonator comprising two SIs and a connected feedback waveguide. Experimental results align with the theoretical model, validating the expected resonance behavior and confirming the effectiveness of the design. These findings underscore the potential of compact coupled SIs for generating Fano- like resonances, enabling broader applications in integrated photonics.

title: Research and Application of a Time Series Data Prediction Model Based on Dense Residual Networks and Long Short-Term Memory Networks
authors: Aizhen Ren
abstract: This study proposes a hybrid deep learning model, termed Dense Residual Long Short-Term Memory (DRLSTM), for financial time series forecasting. The architecture integrates residual connections to stabilize gradient flow and dense connectivity to enhance feature reuse, combined with the memory and gating mechanisms of LSTM to improve long-term dependency modeling. Real-world datasets from the SSE Composite Index, NASDAQ, and Hang Seng Index are employed, where training samples are constructed using a sliding window approach, normalized with Z-score, and hyperparameters optimized via grid search. Experimental evaluations show that DRLSTM provides more accurate and robust predictions than representative benchmark models. The results suggest that DRLSTM can serve as a practical component of financial decision support systems and other expert applications requiring reliable time series forecasting.

title: Analysis and Comparative Study of a Novel Stator-Permanent-Magnet Axial-Flux Counter-Rotating Hybrid-Excitation Machine
authors: Chenxi Xia, Yaojing Feng, Jiangtao Yang, Shoudao Huang
abstract: This paper proposes a novel stator-permanent-magnet axial-flux counter-rotating hybrid-excitation machine (SPM-AFCRHEM) for unbalanced-load operation of counter-rotating propeller (CRP) systems, and investigates three topologies with different stator configurations. By utilizing U-shaped permanent magnets (UPMs) and field-regulation windings to achieve magnetic decoupling and field-regulation capability. Firstly, the field-regulation principle of SPM-AFCRHEMs are analyzed. The working harmonics and their respective torque contributions are calculated and evaluated by establishing the magnetomotive force (MMF)-permeance model. Subsequently, the torque performance of SPM-AFCRHEMs with different pole-slot combinations is compared under unified winding layout principles, and the risk of negative-sequence back-electromotive force (EMF) caused by stator yoke magnetic saturation is discussed. Finally, the machines are comprehensively evaluated through comparative studies of no-load characteristics, load performance, and field-regulation time constants. A prototype of the top-performing configuration is fabricated and experimentally validated, demonstrating that the proposed SPM-AFCRHEM represents a competitive solution for direct-drive CRP systems.

title: External Disturbances Compensation for LiDAR-Inertial Odometry Under Vibration Conditions on Quadruped Robot
authors: Quoc Hung Hoang, Gon-Woo Kim
abstract: This paper presents a new tightly coupled LiDAR-inertial odometry (LIO) scheme for a quadruped robot operating under fluctuating conditions. By proposing external disturbance modeling, the profile of unknown disturbances and noise on the IMU is effectively characterized using the time delay estimation (TDE) technique. Simultaneously, the IMU orientation and the TDE-based uncertainty model are jointly updated through an Error-State Kalman Filter (ESKF) using a measurement model derived from LiDAR odometry (LO). Thereafter, the output of the ESKF is employed to mitigate vibration effects in the IMU preintegration factor, thereby enhancing the precision and stability of inertial motion estimation. Furthermore, the refined IMU preintegration pose is leveraged to correct LiDAR distortion and improve the accuracy of LO. As a result, the proposed approach achieves optimal performance, smooth trajectories, and enhanced robustness against uncertainties. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed LIO is evaluated through real-time experiments on a quadruped robot across different scenarios.

title: Fast Synthesis of Breast Monostatic Microwave Response for Massive Dataset Generation
authors: Raquel A. Martins, João M. Felício, Jorge R. Costa, Carlos A. Fernandes
publish: IEEE Journal of Electromagnetics, RF and Microwaves in Medicine and Biology
abstract: Microwave (MW) technology has been researched for the past decades as a promising technique for breast cancer detection. However, its value for the medical community compared to existing techniques is still undetermined. One of the reasons is the lack of large enough representative datasets of MW signals for evaluation and improvement of the developed signal processing algorithms. To overcome this, we present a fast hybrid method combining geometrical optics, physical optics and full-wave analysis that can model the direct problem, allowing us to create digital twins of experimental microwave monostatic setups, for fast generation of large representative datasets. For validation purposes, a digital twin of our in-house experimental dry microwave setup was implemented – MWSensing – and made openly available to the interested community. We have tested the model against experimental results in the 2-5 GHz range for cylindrical, elliptical and anthropomorphic, homogeneous and heterogeneous breasts phantoms, with a tumor placed inside, in different positions. We show that the MW signals obtained from MWSensing and from the experimental setup are of the same nature and provide similar imaging results. With this framework, it becomes possible to build a large dataset of MW signals, quickly and efficiently, enabling users to evaluate firsthand their algorithms before moving on to more advanced test stages.

title: Measurement and simulation of the magnetic levitation characteristics of passive no-insulation coils
authors: James G. Storey, Elliott Sazo, Luke Porteous, Konstantinos Bouloukakis, Mohammad Siamaki, Rodney A. Badcock
abstract: The use of no-insulation coils in high-temperature superconductor levitation bearings has the potential to produce bulk-like characteristics without the associated size, quality and mechanical limitations of bulk material. Here we performed levitation force measurements on passive (open-circuit) dry wound and solder-impregnated REBCO no-insulation coils to investigate the effect of varying turn-to-turn resistivity. Finite element simulations employing a rotated anisotropic resistivity tensor successfully reproduced the observed behaviour, validating this approach. Low turn-to-turn resistivity facilitates the circulation of a net azimuthal current, which enhances levitation force but decays with time due to resistive dissipation. This work lays the groundwork for future research on active (powered) coils to fully realise the potential of no-insulation coils in superconducting bearings.

title: Reed-Muller Error-Correction Code Encoder for SFQ-to-CMOS Interface Circuits
authors: Yerzhan Mustafa, Berker Peköz, Selçuk Köse
abstract: Data transmission from superconducting digital electronics such as single flux quantum (SFQ) logic to semiconductor (CMOS) circuits is subject to bit errors due to, e.g., flux trapping, process parameter variations (PPV), and fabrication defects. In this paper, a lightweight hardware-efficient error-correction code encoder is designed and analyzed. Particularly, a Reed-Muller code RM(1,3) encoder is implemented with SFQ digital logic. The proposed RM(1,3) encoder converts a 4-bit message into an 8-bit codeword and can detect and correct up to 3- and 1-bit errors, respectively. This encoder circuit is designed using MIT-LL SFQ5ee process and SuperTools/ColdFlux RSFQ cell library. A simulation framework integrating JoSIM simulator and MATLAB script for automated data collection and analysis, is proposed to study the performance of RM(1,3) encoder. The proposed encoder improves the probability of having no bit errors by 6.7% as compared to an encoder-less design under <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\pm$</tex-math></inline-formula>20% PPV. With <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\pm$</tex-math></inline-formula>15% and lower PPV, the proposed encoder could correct all errors with at least 99.1% probability. The impact of fabrication defects such as open circuit faults on the encoder circuit is also studied using the proposed framework.

title: Resilient Synchronization of Multi-Leader MASs under Random Link Failure Constraints
authors: Ke Tang, Kaibo Shi, Jin Yang, Shuai Li, Ming Zhu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: This paper investigates the resilient synchronization problem of multi-agent systems (MASs) with multiple leaders under random link failure constraints (RLFCs). Firstly, in order to overcome the vulnerability on communication links of single-leader MASs, a model of MAS with multiple leaders under RLFCs is established. Secondly, to address the design problem of resilient control, a distributed leader state observer is introduced. Then, the distributed leader state observer with adaptive capability is designed to resolve the unpredictable states of the leaders under RLFCs. Thirdly, to obtain a reliable PI controller with high performance, stochastic stability criteria are derived via the algebraic Riccati equation and an appropriate Lyapunov-Krasovskii function (LKF). Finally, a simulation based on actual F-16 flight results is given to demonstrate the feasibility of the proposed control strategy.

title: A Quaternary Interpretation of Quantum Dynamics (QIQD) Dialogic Computer
authors: Pravir Malik, Ken Hilton
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: In this paper, we introduce the QIQD Dialogic Computer, a new computational paradigm grounded in the Quaternary Interpretation of Quantum Dynamics (QIQD). The QIQD Dialogic Computer operates through a law suite that enforces property neutrality, bounded entanglement, hardware binding, and entropy authority. Computation proceeds via a dialogic interface that translates natural language requests into lawful operations, and a structural engine that mutates state only under lawful conditions. Seeds, defined as unique four-tuples (K, Pr, Po, H), provide the basic carriers of information, while typed entanglement across strata (p/o/n/m) encodes structural correlations. An Operator Surface of verbs ensures all interactions remain auditable and compliant. We demonstrate the system through a case study: the lawful execution of a Room-Temperature Superconductor (RTS) algorithm. This experiment shows measurable coherence improvement (coherence_C from 0.57 to 0.61) while maintaining high min-entropy (0.89) and safe disclosure ratios (commuting_ratio = 1.0). The QIQD Dialogic Computer thus establishes a structurally lawful, assurance-embedded foundation for quantum-assured computation, with implications for cryptography, materials discovery, and complex system modeling.

title: SFCF-YOLO: An Improved YOLO Architecture with Spatial-Focus Cross-Fusion Mechanism for Insulator Defect Detection
authors: Guyu Zhang, Xiwen Jiang, Xiaohang Wen, Xiaopeng Wei, Yujue Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Robotics and Automatic Control (IRAC)
abstract: Accurate detection of insulator defects is essential for maintaining the safety of power transmission systems, yet images captured by unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) often contain small, low-contrast defects that challenge existing lightweight detectors. To address this limitation, we propose SFCF-YOLO, an enhanced YOLOv10n-based framework equipped with a Spatial–Focus Cross-Fusion (SFCF) module that improves spatial detail preservation and multi-scale feature interaction. The module integrates FocusCalib attention and cross-branch fusion to more effectively highlight subtle defect cues with minimal computational overhead. Experiments on the UPID dataset show that SFCF-YOLO improves mAP50 and mAP50–95 by 2.1% and 2.3%, respectively, over YOLOv10n, delivering higher accuracy and sensitivity while maintaining real-time performance.

title: Prescribed-Performance Visual Servo Control of a Mobile Manipulator Under Safety Constraints
authors: Weibing Li, Qinyun Liao, Chengzhu Li, Zhichao Huang, Mingyue Cui, Yehui Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Robotics and Automatic Control (IRAC)
abstract: Conventional methods for image-based visual servo control of mobile manipulators rarely consider necessary safety constraints, such as field-of-view and joint-limit constraints. To tackle such a problem, this paper proposes a quadratic programming-based prescribed-performance control scheme, aiming at achieving IBVS of mobile manipulators under field-of-view and joint-limit constraints. A holistic kinematic model is developed by treating the mobile base and manipulator as an integrated system to enhance motion coordination. A control scheme combining a prescribed-performance controller and a quadratic programming-based control framework is designed to achieve fast convergence in visual servoing tasks while maintaining field-of-view and joint-limit constraints. Comprehensive simulative and physical experiments of a two-wheeled mobile manipulator have been conducted to validate the effectiveness and efficacy of the proposed control scheme.

title: EV Charging Scheduling in Residential Areas: A Multi-Objective Approach Based on MOIPSO
authors: YueJun Li, Bin Duan, Yi Kuang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: To address the peak load overlapping phenomenon caused by the highly concentrated EV charging in residential areas, this study proposes an orderly charging strategy based on an improved multi-objective particle swarm optimization (MOIPSO) algorithm. A multi-objective optimization model is established to minimize the total system load variance, reduce user costs, and maximize charging volume, while considering EV battery aging costs and system power constraints. Simulation results demonstrate that, compared to the NSGA-II and MOPSO algorithms, the proposed algorithm significantly improves the diversity and convergence of the Pareto solutions through the introduction of dynamic inertia weights and elite crossover and mutation strategies. Moreover, compared to unordered charging, the proposed orderly strategy increases the average off-grid SOC by 3.3%, reduces the total cost by 29%, decreases the load peak by 28.4%, lowers the peak-valley difference rate by 39.3%, and reduces the load variance by 87.2%.

title: Current Status and Challenges of the Application of Artificial Intelligence Technology in the Emotion Management of College Students
authors: Jia-Hao Li, Yuan Sun
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) technology has brought new solutions for college students' emotion management, showing great potential for application. This paper comprehensively summarizes the current situation and challenges of AI technology in college students' emotional management. In terms of specific applications, AI chatbots provide personalized support to college students instantly by simulating human conversations, effectively relieving their psychological stress. Psychological AI Tess has significantly improved the depression and anxiety symptoms of college students by providing interventions such as cognitive behavioral therapy. However, the application of AI in this field also faces many challenges, including the risk of data privacy leakage, technical limitations, and ethical controversies. In the future, there is an urgent need to build an interdisciplinary collaboration mechanism, optimize the data security framework, and strengthen long-term tracking studies to verify the sustainability of AI interventions, so as to ensure the effectiveness and safety of AI technology in college students' emotion management and fully utilize its potential to promote college students' mental health and emotional development.

title: Bridging the Gap: A Cyber-Physical-Geospatial Framework for Modernizing Power Engineering Education in Support of Clean Energy Transitions
authors: Winston Akai Nettey, Samuel Grant Quansah, Hilda Afeku-Amenyo
publish: 2025 New Jersey Future Energy Transmission Conference (NJFET)
abstract: New Jersey’s objective of achieving a clean energy goal by 2035 has exposed a critical workforce gap: a shortage of power engineers who combine traditional grid knowledge with modern competencies in cybersecurity and geospatial analytics. This study investigates the misalignment between current power engineering curricula at New Jersey institutions, including NJIT, Rowan University, and Rutgers, and the evolving skill demands of employers such as PSEG, PJM, and offshore wind developers. Through a comparative analysis of course catalogs, ABET learning outcomes, and 60 industry job postings (2023–2025), we identify significant gaps in training related to industrial control systems (ICS) security, spatial risk visualization, and data-driven grid decision-making. In response, we propose a modular, open-access educational framework that embeds cyber resilience labs and GIS-based grid dashboards into existing power systems courses. Developed in consultation with NJIT’s Power Systems Engineering Center and informed by the NSF IUCRC GOWIND Center’s workforce goals, this model enables students to analyze real-world scenarios, such as mapping substation vulnerabilities or simulating cyber-physical disruptions, using freely available tools like QGIS and open-source SCADA testbeds. The framework supports the New Jersey Energy Master Plan’s call for a skilled, diverse clean energy workforce and offers a scalable template for university-industry partnerships across the PJM region. By modernizing engineering education at the intersection of power, cyber, and place, this work ensures New Jersey’s talent pipeline keeps pace with its grid transformation.

title: A Review on the Simulation Evaluation of Inertia Modeling for Grid-forming Power Electronic Devices
authors: Hang Liu, Fangqun Liao, Xinran Sun, Peiran Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: This article reviews the research on inertia simulation and evaluation of grid-connected power electronic devices. With the integration of new energy sources leading to a decrease in system inertia, the issue of frequency stability has become prominent. The article introduces the generalized inertia theory, inertia evaluation methods and testing systems, analyzes the mechanism by which grid-connected devices achieve adjustable inertia support through control, and points out the existing problems of identification accuracy and standardization, providing a reference for the stable control of new power systems.

title: Fault attacks against UOV-based signatures
authors: Sven Bauer, Fabrizio De Santis, Kristjane Koleci
publish: 2025 Workshop on Fault Detection and Tolerance in Cryptography (FDTC)
abstract: The Unbalanced Oil and Vinegar (UOV) construction is the foundation of several post-quantum digital signature algorithms currently under consideration in NIST’s standardization process for additional post-quantum digital signature schemes. This paper introduces new single fault injection attacks against the signing procedure of deterministic variants of signature schemes based on the UOV construction. We show how these attacks can be applied to attack MAYO and PROV, two signature schemes submitted to the NIST call for additional post-quantum signature schemes. The attacks are demonstrated with reference implementations that run on an ARM Cortex-M4 processor. Our attacks do not require precise triggering or precise fault injection capabilities. Any type of fault in large portions of the code has the potential to result in successful key recovery. We demonstrate our attacks with very cheap equipment and simple clock glitching techniques, enabling the recovery of the secret key with either two faulty signatures or one correct signature and one faulty signature in the case of MAYO and one correct signature and two faulty signatures in case of PROV. The fact that our attacks do not require precise fault injection capabilities and can be successful with only a few signatures makes them particularly powerful, hence harmful for the implementation security of post-quantum digital signature schemes.

title: A Study of the Effect of Peer Assessment on Collaborative Problem-Solving Skills in Synchronous Online Discussions
authors: Zhonghua Wang, Wenna Li, Xintong Zhang, Mengyuan Wang
abstract: Collaborative problem solving is a key competency indispensable for 21st century talents which involves time management, associative thinking and interdependent social cognitive processes. In this study, we explored the mechanism of peer assessment, constructed a discussion-driven online synchronous collaborative problem-solving framework, and conducted a semester-long quasi-experimental pedagogical study. By collecting synchronous online discussion data from participants during the peer assessment process, lagged sequence analysis and content analysis techniques were used for in-depth mining and analysis. The results of the study show that peer assessment activities have a positive effect on enhancing learners' collaborative problem-solving ability, while the process is characterized by complexity and dynamic fluctuation, and there are significant differences in problem solving ability among different performance groups, reflecting that collaborative problem solving ability is directly or indirectly associated with the quality of learning outcomes.

title: Carbonized Channel Identification Algorithm Based on HSV Color Space Complement and Markov Random Field Optimization
authors: Yuling Liu, Yong Li, Guanghua Wang, Yafei Qin, Jin Yang, Li Zhang, Xue Li, Xiaohan Ma
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: Accurate identification of carbonized channels on lightning arrester surfaces is crucial for power equipment assessment. This study proposes an algorithm integrating HSV color space complement extraction and region growing, enhanced by Markov Random Field (MRF) optimization for improved segmentation precision. Initially, lightning arrester surface images are converted to HSV, and the saturation (S) component's complement is used to boost carbonized area contrast. An automated region growing algorithm then performs preliminary segmentation. To refine these results and ensure boundary coherence, an MRF model minimizes an energy function via an efficient Graph Cut algorithm, yielding optimal binary segmentation. Finally, morphological filtering based on area, aspect ratio, and circularity precisely localizes and identifies carbonized channels. Experimental results confirm the algorithm's effectiveness in identifying surface carbonized channels, providing a robust tool for fault diagnosis.

title: Proof-at-the-Edge: zk-SNARKs for Privacy-Preserving Wearable IoT Health Monitoring
authors: Alexander Banks, Ali Jalooli
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: Healthcare IoT systems must balance the need for continuous monitoring with strong guarantees of privacy and trust. We present ProofHealth, a zero-knowledge proof–based framework that shifts verification to the edge by generating zk-SNARKs on smartphones. In this design, wearable data is encrypted and accompanied by proofs that ensure only valid submissions are admitted to cloud storage, even on untrusted networks. We implement and evaluate ProofHealth under varying batch sizes, measuring latency, throughput, and proof size. Results show batching significantly improves per-sample efficiency while proof sizes remain constant at sub-kilobyte scale, enabling lightweight communication suitable for constrained devices. This demonstrates the practicality of proof-at-the-edge healthcare monitoring and establishes ProofHealth as a novel approach to secure and privacy-preserving health data collection.

title: Design of a Training System for Preservice Teachers' Intelligent Teaching Language Skills
authors: Xiuci Xu, Yue Zhou
abstract: Traditional teaching language skills training for preservice teachers has limitations such as subjectivity, delayed feedback, and heavy reliance on resources. This paper applies speech recognition analysis technology and generative large language model technology to construct a ubiquitous intelligent teaching language skills training system that solves the above problems. It includes a four-layer architecture consisting of a display layer, user layer, business layer, and data layer, and aims to provide preservice teachers with a ubiquitous, intelligent teaching language skills training system to help them better master teaching language skills and lay a solid foundation for their future careers.

title: Research on earthquake mitigation technology for power lines under multi-scenario severe meteorological conditions
authors: Guangtai Pan, Xiaomeng Yin, Enjun Zhong, Wen Zhang, Liangxing Zhan, Huiping Li
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Geographic Information and Remote Sensing Technology (GIRST)
abstract: Under global climate change, extreme weather events have triggered frequent ice-related failures on high-voltage transmission lines, causing economic losses and threatening grid safety, necessitating online ice monitoring. However, existing weight-based ice layer calculation methods suffer from complexity, limited applicability, and significant result discrepancies. This paper focuses on optimizing online ice monitoring models for transmission lines. By analyzing existing theoretical models and simplifying calculations based on the total suspension load change before conductor icing, the proposed model offers straightforward computation, easy implementation with limited monitoring resources, and demonstrated good generalizability and engineering applicability.

title: Theoretical Modeling and Verification of Self-Powered Units
authors: Hao Ding, Jin Wu, Nan Wu, Haibo Yue, Changlei Xiao, Xueyan Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: To address the requirements of realizing passive self-power supply function and miniaturization for hybrid current-limiting fuses, a passive power supply scheme is designed where the triggering device does not require external power supply. Firstly, an equivalent circuit model of the passive self-power supply unit is constructed, which converts the complex electricmagnetic field-circuit coupling problem into a single circuit problem, simplifying the model and calculation process. The calculation methods for key parameters in the circuit model are derived, and experiments are conducted to verify the accuracy of the model. Experimental results show that under two different current rise rates, the induced electromotive force (EMF) of the iron-core coil is in good agreement with the theoretical calculation results, which verifies the accuracy of the equivalent circuit model. This model has certain applicability and can be used to guide the multi-parameter optimization analysis and design of the passive self-power supply unit. In addition, the power supply voltage of the triggering device in this passive triggering scheme is directly obtained from the fault current; the larger the fault current, the more sufficient the voltage obtained by the system. This ensures that the system has an absolutely reliable power supply in extreme situations where protection is most needed, thereby improving the reliability and safety of the hybrid current-limiting fuse.

title: Entanglement Distribution in Quantum Optical Networks Using Multimode Photonic Circuits
authors: Farrukh Hamroyev, Raykhan Razakova, Muzaffar Shojonov, Izzatbek Nafasov, Odilbek Matsapayev, Manik Rakhra
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: Future quantum networks depend on reliable distribution of entanglement between distant nodes to power device-independent cryptography, blind quantum computing, and distributed sensing. Integrated photonics offers a scalable, phase-stable route to interconnects, yet long-distance rates are limited by fiber loss and the probabilistic nature of Bell-state measurements (BSMs). We present a system model and performance analysis for multimode photonic circuits that exploit time-, frequency-, and path-multiplexing to raise the success probability over lossy links. Closedform expressions are derived for single-shot success, end-to-end rate with Μ parallel modes, and fidelity under multi-pair noise, dark counts, and imperfect indistinguishability. We outline a practical architecture combining SPDC sources, integrated ( de)multiplexers, MMIs, thermo-optic phase shifters, and SNSPD arrays. Using representative device parameters and standard fiber attenuation, we simulate rate-distance trade-offs and quantify multiplexing gains. Moderate multiplexing (e.g., Μ = 16) delivers >10× higher rate at 50km without sacrificing fidelity, offering design guidance and a reproducible LaTeX/ PGFPlots workflow.

title: Study on Dual-Time-Scale Mid-to-Long-Term Spot Electricity Procurement Optimization Model Considering Inter-Provincial Channel Constraints
authors: Ying Fan, Pengfei Zhang, Na Wang, Yuxin Chen, Huan Zhou, Gaiping Sun
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: To address cost control and power supply stability challenges posed by the diversity of grid agency electricity procurement resources, and the limitations of existing single procurement modes (poor adaptability, intra-provincial resource constraints), this paper develops a monthly-hourly dual-time-scale mid-to-long-term spot optimization model. First, variables are unified by time scale: intra-provincial mid-to-long-term procurement and renewable energy procurement are set as monthly variables, while inter-provincial mid-to-long-term procurement and spot procurement are hourly variables, with scale connection via aggregation and equalization. Then, aiming to minimize total procurement cost, multi-space resource allocation is achieved by incorporating special constraints of three inter-provincial channels. Simulations with full-year 2024 load and electricity price data, verified against a control group, show the model effectively connects mid-to-long-term and spot markets, ensures full renewable energy consumption and power supply stability, and cuts procurement cost significantly compared to the control group, achieving cost optimization.

title: Multi-dimensional Feature-Fusion-Based Cooling and Heating Load Identification Model for Distribution Substations
authors: Bingbing Lu, Fan Yang, Jun Liu, Jiashuai Li, Gaiping Sun, Ziqi Ye
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: To overcome the key limitations of conventional cooling/heating load identification in distribution substations— namely, the insufficient characterization of temperature-response lags and the low dimensionality of features—this paper presents a multi-feature fusion model. First, a dynamic thermal-response event detector is built. It employs a sliding-window standard-deviation algorithm to capture abrupt temperature events and verifies load-response characteristics with Pearson correlation, extracting spatio-temporally coupled features. Second, a high-dimensional feature set covering load spectral entropy, period sensitivity, and lagged correlations is designed. Third, an improved LightGBM classifier is proposed: SMOTE is used to oversample cooling and heating loads to 80 % of the normal-load size, while principal-component analysis retains components explaining 95 % of the variance. Finally, a seasonal-priority strategy combined with a confidence-tier mechanism is established; samples whose predicted probabilities fall between 0.4 and 0.6 are manually reviewed to resolve classification conflicts. Validation on 1,133 actual substations shows the method achieves 92.3 % accuracy and an F1-score of 0.87 for cooling and heating load classification.

title: Research on Multi-Scale Feature Extraction and Fusion Algorithm for Change Detection in Time-Series High-Resolution Remote Sensing Images
authors: Yuan Zhang, Wenbo Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Geographic Information and Remote Sensing Technology (GIRST)
abstract: Aiming at the problems of insufficient utilization of multi-scale features and lack of adaptability of fusion strategy in high-resolution remote sensing image change detection, a multi-scale feature extraction algorithm based on adaptive fusion was proposed. A hierarchical Siamese encoder is used to extract feature representations of different resolutions from dual-temporal images, and a learnable difference calculation module is used to quantify the change information of each scale. An adaptive fusion mechanism based on global context awareness is introduced to dynamically adjust the contribution weight of each scale feature. Experiments on the public change detection dataset verify the advantages of the adaptive fusion strategy compared with the fixed weight fusion in terms of detection accuracy and boundary accuracy. Ablation experiments prove the effectiveness of multi-scale feature extraction and adaptive weight adjustment. The research provides a new technical path for remote sensing image change detection, which can be applied to urban expansion monitoring, disaster loss assessment and other fields.

title: Safety Evaluation of Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning Algorithms Applied to Industrial Robot Arms
authors: Brook Abegaz, Isabel Gliniecki
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: This paper considers three data sets from industrial robotic arms and implements artificial intelligence machine learning algorithms to detect anomalies in the operation. The robot arm operational data was used for validation and verification, with anomalies either partitioned from that data or added manually for training purposes. The implementation could reveal where and when anomalies exist in the industrial operation and indicate if the system is safe to operate or not. This research can also indicate which artificial intelligence and machine learning algorithms were the most accurate to evaluate the safe operation of the industrial system. For two of the data sets, the Subspace K-Nearest Neighbors was the most accurate. For the other, a Fine Gaussian Support Vector Machine was the most accurate. The approach could be extended to evaluating methods and algorithms applied to other types of systems in the future.

title: An Adaptive Model Predictive Load Frequency Control Strategy for Low-Inertia Power Systems
authors: Hayato Nagaosa, Yutaka Sasaki, Helin Yang, Yoshifumi Zoka, Naoto Yorino, Ahmed Bedawy, Weichao Wang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: As renewable energies (REs) are rapidly penetrating existing power systems, maintaining frequency stability has become increasingly difficult. Load frequency control (LFC) operations are very important under these circumstances. Classical PI controllers are widely used as LFC controllers; however, the system operator must retune the parameters whenever system configurations are changed. To address this issue, the authors have developed an adaptive model predictive LFC (AMPC-LFC) to improve the frequency stability by using an automatic parameter update. This paper proposes a modified AMPC-LFC for power systems with high penetration of wind turbine (WT) power generation in an interconnected two-area network. An extended Kalman filter (EKF) is applied to AMPC-LFC to estimate the parameters of the simplified internal model in real time. Furthermore, a high voltage direct current (HVDC) transmission system with inertia emulation control (INEC) can reduce frequency deviations caused by WT and load changes. Simulation results show that the HVDC-AC hybrid transmission system can improve frequency control performance by up to 56% compared to AC-only systems. Additionally, when AMPC is compared with PI controllers and particle swarm optimization (PSO)-tuned adaptive PI controllers, AMPC can reduce frequency deviation for each controller by up to 64% and 44% respectively.

title: Research on Seismic Optimum Design of Oil-Paper Capacitive Bushing
authors: Guanghu Xu, Dangdong He, Yingbin Shi, Qingchuan Zhang, Xiaodong Chen
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: In ultra-high voltage (UHV) power transmission, bushings are the most earthquake-vulnerable transformer components. This study optimized 1000kV oil-paper capacitive bushings: using response spectrum method for dynamic analysis, adopting rigid brackets (71Hz, meeting IEC 61463—2016/IEEE 693—2005), and improving key parts (e.g., thickening pressure balancing ring plates, adding shaft seals/nylon sleeves, optimizing flange holes, and applying equal-stress design to porcelain).Two shaking table tests (2×0.3g in Chongqing, 2×0.4g in Tongji) were conducted: white noise measured modal parameters, time-history/artificial waves excited responses, and strain/accelerometers monitored data; electrical parameters (tanδ, capacitance) were tested pre-post. Results: Bushing natural frequency and electrical parameters barely changed; table/code response spectra met tolerance; max porcelain stress was 16.13MPa (safety factor 2.79, 2×0.3g) and 23.3MPa (1.93, 2×0.4g), exceeding 1.67. The bushing outperforms foreign products in seismic performance (2×0.4g vs. 2×0.3g) and bending load, verifying optimization effectiveness.
