title: Analytical Characterization and Efficient Simulation of Batched Arrivals in the Kafka Broker
authors: András Horváth, Marco Paolieri, Benedetta Picano, Enrico Vicario
publish: 2025 33rd International Symposium on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Computer and Telecommunication Systems (MASCOTS)
abstract: Apache Kafka is a key component in event-driven and microservice architectures relying on distributed publishsubscribe messaging for scalable and fault-tolerant streaming of real-time data. To reduce distribution overhead, messages are buffered and dispatched to the broker when either a maximum batch size N is reached or a timeout T expires, enabling control on the trade-off between high throughput and low latency. However, this trade-off has been explored only through empirical studies, referred to specific system deployments and not suited for runtime adaptation to variable workload conditions. We provide an analytical characterization of the arrival process induced by Kafka batching policy under Poisson arrivals. The analysis develops on the observation that the time for buffering a full batch and the size of a batch dispatched at expiration of the timeout follow truncated Erlang and Poisson distributions, respectively. Leveraging this insight, we derive closed forms for quantities that characterize the arrival process, and we propose a method for efficient simulation of the process embedded at dispatching times. To support practical implementation, we evaluate solutions for drawing samples from an Erlang distribution provided by NumPy, PyTorch, and R, and we also propose a novel approach based on rejection sampling with proposal function in the family of Kumaraswamy distributions with automated optimization of parameters with respect to the number of phases. Numerical experimentation shows that: (i) aggregated simulation enabled by the analytical formulation is insensitive to the value of the batch size, and it definitely outperforms fine-grained simulation of individual message arrivals; (ii) the best efficiency is obtained with the NumPy implementation of Erlang, with promising results of the novel approach based on Kumaraswamy, which achieves results comparable to PyTorch and better than $\mathbf{R}$.

title: Beamforming Through Encapsulation Layers: Efficient Time-of-Flight Modeling for High-Resolution Ultrasound Imaging
authors: Mélanie Audoin, Ali Salari, Rune Sixten Grass, Kitty Steenberg, Kasper Fløng Pedersen, Lasse Thurmann Jørgensen, Erik Vilain Thomsen, Jørgen Arendt Jensen
abstract: Medical ultrasound probes commonly employ a polymer encapsulation over the transducer for electrical protection and acoustic impedance matching. However, the speed of sound mismatch between the encapsulant and biological tissue can introduce Time Of Flight (TOF) errors that degrade beamforming coherence. This article presents a beamforming method that includes the encapsulating layer in the TOF calculation to improve image quality. Two TOF approximations, Direct Path (DP) and Normal Path (NP), are evaluated in terms of accuracy and computational cost. These are compared against the Homogeneous Direct Path (HDP) model, which neglects the encapsulant, and the exact Snell’s law Path (SP), computed using ray-tracing. Simulations and experiments are performed on a silicone encapsulated Row-Column Addressed (RCA) Capacitive Micromachined Ultrasound Transducer (CMUT) probe as a case study. DP and NP increased the processing time by only 1.2 × compared to HDP, while SP increased it by 46 ×. The measured standard deviation of the TOF error was reduced from 0.10 λ (HDP) to 0.06 λ (DP), and 0.05 λ (SP), ensuring high inter-channel coherence. Lateral resolution increased up to +47%, and contrast was enhanced by ≥ +2.1 dB using DP and SP models compared to HDP. The DP approximation achieved near-SP image quality, while maintaining HDP-level computational efficiency. The validity domain of NP and DP for any transducer was generalized using a critical F-number α. Overall, the proposed approximations provide a computationally efficient means to enhance resolution and contrast, establishing a practical solution for high-resolution realtime imaging.

title: Deep-Q-Network in Multiview Ensemble Learning to Predict Anti-diabetic Peptide and Diabetic Types
authors: Aditya Kumar, Deepak Singh
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Biology and Bioinformatics
abstract: Diabetes mellitus disease has become a significant human health concern globally, causing cardiovascular complications, kidney disease, cerebrovascular accidents, etc. In humans, bioactive molecules, specifically Antidiabetic peptides (ADPs), target <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\beta$</tex-math></inline-formula> or <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$T$</tex-math></inline-formula>-cells to regulate insulin production, making them potential alternatives for diabetes therapy. Recently, several computational ensemble methods have been investigated to predict ADPs. Notwithstanding progress in ensemble techniques, finding optimal solutions for predicting ADPs requires continuous effort for improvement. Therefore, the current study proposed a novel Deep-Q-Network (DQN)-based Reinforcement learning (RL) approach for optimizing a multiview ensemble to predict anti-diabetic peptides and diabetic types. Initially, to obtain the multiview, diverse feature encodings were employed, which were then systematically categorized into three heterogeneous groups based on the information sources and information-extracting techniques. Each group is considered as a view, and these views are based on sequence, physicochemical properties with sequence composition, and evolutionary information. Next, the proposed ensemble is constructed with 36 branch classifiers derived from 6 convolutional neural networks(CNNs). A reinforcement learning technique is employed to optimize the ensemble search space of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2^{36}-1$</tex-math></inline-formula>, made by thirty-six branch CNNs and three views. The DQN approach encodes 36-bit binary strings to find the optimal ensemble. The optimal ensemble with an ideal view-classifier pair enhances antidiabetic prediction efficacy. It surpasses existing state-of-the-art with a classification accuracy of 96.37%, a matthews correlation coefficient of 0.870, and an area under the curve of 0.983 on the standard ADPs dataset. Lastly, the performance of the proposed ensemble is considered to be its efficacy in peptide antidiabetic activity prediction.

title: LoAPE: A Load-Aware and Power-Elastic Platform for Green Serverless Computing
authors: Hanfei Geng, Yuanchun Li, Jichao Leng, Feng Zhao, Yunxin Liu
abstract: Energy efficiency in serverless computing has remained under-explored despite its growing adoption. To fill this gap, we propose LoAPE, a load-aware and power-elastic serverless platform. Unlike existing methods limited to CPU core frequency scaling or density-based consolidation, LoAPE leverages c-states and uncore frequency scaling, which offer greater energy benefits but pose deployment challenges. Uncore changes affect the performance of all co-located functions, and cstates require sustained idle periods for effective energy savings. LoAPE’s insight is to strategically exploit function elasticity. By creating idle intervals across cores and servers, it enables aggressive c-state activation and uncore frequency reduction. To achieve this goal, LoAPE adopts topology-aware instance scheduling and eviction, which scale the number of active servers along with serverless functions. Within servers, LoAPE proactively manages active cores based on incoming loads. Our evaluations demonstrate that LoAPE delivers a 3.02× improvement in cluster energy reduction compared to frequency-scaling frameworks and extends savings by 1.17× over state-of-the-art density-aware schedulers, while meeting performance requirements.

title: Characterization of precipitation-induced radon progeny deposition events using a city-scale sensor network
authors: S. Das, N. Abgrall, M.S. Bandstra, R.J. Cooper, Y. Kim, E. Rofors, R. Sankaran, S. Shahkarami
abstract: Networks of radiation detectors provide a platform for real-time radioactive source detection and identification in urban environments. Detection algorithms in these systems must adapt to naturally-occurring changes in background, which requires well-characterized relationships between precipitation events and their corresponding radiological signature.We present a quantitative and qualitative description of rain-induced radon progeny deposition events occurring in Chicago from September 2023 through February 2024. We measure ambient gamma radiation levels, precipitation rate, temperature, pressure and relative humidity in a network of sensor nodes. For each identified precipitation period, we decompose spectra into static- and radon-associated components as defined by a non-negative matrix factorization (NMF) algorithm. We find a consistent powerlaw relationship between a precipitation-dependent peak of the radon progeny proxy (RPP) and the peak strength of radon-associated NMF component for most precipitation events. We conduct a case study of a rainfall period with abnormally high levels of implied radon progeny concentration and describe its temporal and spatial evolution. We hypothesize this phenomenon is due to the air mass path that intersects a uranium-rich region of Wyoming. Finally, we cluster precipitation events into three distinct categories. One category roughly corresponds to events with deep low-pressure systems and high relative radon concentration, while another is characteristic of light stratiform rain with slightly higher temperatures and intermediate relative radon concentration. The third category appears to contain weak-gradient or lake breeze convection showers with intermittent precipitation and low relative radon concentration. These findings suggest that radiological anomaly detection could be improved by training unique background models corresponding to each category of meteorological event.

title: Characterization of Sub-20nm FinFET-based AI Chips under Single-Event Effects
authors: Shuanglin Feng, Bin Liang, Ming Tao, Jiaofen Yang, Yaqing Chi, Jianjun Chen, Deng Luo, Guofang Yu, Guotai Qiao, Xun Wang, Hengzhu Liu
abstract: Single-event experiments were conducted on four typical CNN architectures currently prevalent in the aerospace field: Yolov5s, Ssd, ResNet50, and Vgg16. During heavy ion testing, Single-Event Functional Interrupt (SEFI) phenomena were observed in all architectures. Among them, the Ssd architecture experienced more severe SEFI compared to the other three. Additionally, Single-Event Upset(SEU) phenomena were observed only in Yolov5s.To further investigate, pulsed laser experiments were carried out. The results showed that both Yolov5s and Ssd exhibited more severe SEFI, and SEU phenomena were detected in these two models. In contrast, the other two models only displayed SEFI without any SEU phenomena.By analyzing the differences in network layers and resource utilization among the four CNN architectures, potential reasons for these variations were summarized. This study provides a reference and insights for future in-depth research in this field, offering fault analysis and insights for the next generation of radiation-hardened AI chips.

title: Transient Stability Analysis of Parallel Grid-Following and Grid-Forming Inverters With the Current Limiting Mode
authors: Qianchao Liao, Zhenbin Huang, Xia Chen, Jinyu Wen, Yin Chen
abstract: With the integration of renewable energy into power grids, hybrid parallel systems comprising both grid-following and grid-forming (GFM) inverters have become increasingly common. However, the transient stability and control strategies of such systems under current limiting mode remain unclear. To address this issue, this article investigates the transient stability of both types of inverters operating under current limiting conditions during faults. First, a new modeling and analysis method is proposed and used to delineate the angle stability region. Second, the instability mechanisms of the two inverters are analyzed under different grid voltage sags and system parameters. Furthermore, the impact of the current control angles of both inverters on system stability is examined, leading to the proposal of a transient current limiting strategy that balances system transient stability with the desaturation capability of the GFM inverter. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed control strategy is validated through comparative simulations and experiments against existing current limiting methods.

title: Minimizing the Cost of UAV-Assisted Marine Mobile Edge Computing System Based on Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Siyang Xu, Ze Fan, Zijian Zhou, Qiuyu Lu, Biao Zhang, Yu Wang, Xin Song
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management
abstract: To enable compute-intensive and delay-sensitive maritime services, unmanned surface vessels (USVs) can offload tasks to mobile edge computing (MEC) servers mounted on unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs). However, jointly minimizing energy consumption and latency is challenging due to the strong coupling between communication, computation, and mobility under stringent quality-of-service (QoS) requirements. To capture this trade-off, we formulate a weighted energy–delay minimization problem that jointly optimizes one-to-one UAV–USV scheduling, task partitioning, and UAV trajectory. The resulting problem is particularly difficult due to a hybrid discrete–continuous decision space and strong temporal coupling under stringent feasibility constraints. To address this mixed-integer nonconvex optimization problem, we reformulate it as a Markov decision process (MDP) and develop a constraint-aware OU–TD3 algorithm that integrates differentiable scheduling relaxation, feasibility-aware action mapping, and adaptive OU–Gaussian mixed exploration for stable learning in high-dimensional continuous control. We further extend the formulation and solution to a cooperative multi-UAV MEC setting with signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR)-coupled interference and coordination constraints. Extensive simulations with statistical evaluation demonstrate stable convergence and up to 54.2% cost reduction over baseline schemes, while maintaining robustness under realistic maritime disturbances.

title: Intent-based Network in Online Resource Allocation with Machine-learned Prediction
authors: Minxi Feng, Haotian Wu, Shahid Mumtaz, Jiaming Pei
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management
abstract: The development of Internet-of-Things (IoT) services demands intelligent and adaptive mechanisms for online resource allocation under dynamic and uncertain environments. Intent-Based Networking (IBN) has emerged as a promising paradigm to align system behavior with high-level user intents. However, realizing intent-aware allocation in real time remains challenging due to uncertain resource availability and incomplete future information. This paper presents a modular framework that integrates semantic intent parsing, machine-learned resource prediction, and robust online decision-making. We propose IBN-ONMP, an IBN-based online resource allocation algorithm that leverages machine-learned predictions and adapts safety margins based on feedback to ensure feasibility and performance under uncertainty. We formally define the problem, establish theoretical guarantees including regret and competitive ratio bounds, and validate the approach on real-world and simulated datasets. Experimental results demonstrate that IBN-ONMP achieves high utility and robust performance across varying prediction error levels, which is consistent with theoretical analysis.

title: GradCloak: Gradient Obfuscation for Privacy-Preserving Distributed Learning as a Service
authors: Wenqi Wei, Tiansheng Huang, Sihao Hu, Xinxin Fan, Rui Zhang, Jingya Zhou, Ling Liu
abstract: Gradient leakage attacks pose a significant privacy threat in distributed learning-as-a-service APIs. Existing literature on gradient leakage defense relies on gradient perturbation for preventing privacy leakage. However, determining where and how much to perturb the gradient offers different capabilities for preventing gradient leakage. This paper presents GradCloak, a principled approach to guiding gradient perturbation with theoretical robustness bounds in federated learning as a service, aiming to find the minimum required noise for simultaneously achieving privacy protection, competitive accuracy, and preventing gradient leakage attacks. The paper is organized into three major components. First, we formulate the gradient leakage threats and their adverse effect. We categorize the attack into two broad types: leakage during local training and leakage before global aggregation. Second, we investigate different gradient perturbation approaches. We analyze and compare these gradient perturbation methods, which are performed at the federated server, with those performed at the participating client(s). Third, we introduce three robustness properties of robust perturbation against gradient leakage threats, formulated by the anonymization bound for training data robustness, the perturbation bound for gradient robustness, and the distribution robustness bound for perturbed gradients. We conduct extensive evaluations on eight benchmark datasets to demonstrate that specific settings of gradient perturbation exist that best balance privacy, accuracy, and leakage prevention. Code is available at https://github.com/git-disl/GradCloak.

title: An Odd-Even Column Major Order Approach for Optimal Shade Dispersion Over the Solar PV Arrays
authors: B.S.S. Santosh, Gadiraju Harish Kumar Varma, Diwaker Pathak, Gourav Verma, Venugopal Reddy Barry, Sanjeevikumar Padmanaban
abstract: Partial shading significantly affects the performance and efficiency of photovoltaic (PV) arrays, leading to mismatch losses (MLs) and reduced energy output. This research proposes a novel odd-even column major order reconfiguration strategy to mitigate these challenges and optimize the performance of the total-cross-tied (TCT) PV array. The proposed method focuses on redistributing the shade by rearranging the PV modules while preserving TCT electrical connections, minimizing MLs, and enhancing the power generation. The proposed strategy is evaluated through extensive simulations and experimental validation on a 6 × 6 PV array under various shading scenarios using key performance indices such as global maximum power point, ML, power enhancement (PE), fill factor, and efficiency. Results demonstrate a significant improvement across all indices, with up to 19.86% PE, ML reduction to 1.46%, and a maximum efficiency of 16.96%. Therefore, the proposed method presents an effective solution to shading-induced challenges in PV arrays, promoting sustainable energy generation and advancing the adoption of solar power in diverse environmental conditions.

title: Spectrum Sensing for Cognitive Radio Using Laplacian Kernel Correlator in the Presence of Laplacian Noise_supp1-3664612.pdf
authors: Weichao Xu
abstract: This paper proposes the Laplacian kernel correlator (LKC) to address the limitations of current spectrum sensing techniques in the presence of Laplacian noise interference. The proposed method enhances robustness against impulsive noise by employing a Laplacian kernel function to mitigate outliers deviating from the sample median of received signals. We derive closed-form expressions for the mean and variance of LKC, and further establish explicit expressions for the false alarm probability and detection probability. Performance analyses are further conducted in terms of receiver operating characteristic (ROC) and area under the ROC curve. Monte Carlo simulations not only verified the correctness of the established theoretical results, but also demonstrated the superiority of LKC over other commonly used methods in terms of detection probability under Laplacian noise.

title: Tropical Cyclone Detection and Tracking Using Spatial-Temporal Characteristics of Regional Wind Speed from CYGNSS: Proof of Concept and Assessment
authors: Xiangchao Ma, Dongkai Yang, Feng Wang, Weichen Sun, Chuanrui Tan, Jie Li, Mengjie Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Reliable data for global rapid coverage and short-period detection of tropical cyclones (TCs) are scarce. CYGNSS captures GNSS signals reflected from the Earth’s surface, delivering high-revisit global observations. This study presents a proof-of-concept evaluation of CYGNSS’s capability for global TC detection and tracking. A machine learning-based algorithm is introduced, which extracts wind speed features through regional segmentation. Using comparative analysis, statistics that effectively distinguish TC from non-TC samples were selected, while the spatiotemporal correlation of TC motion was incorporated for detection and tracking. This method addresses challenges including the irregular spatial sampling of CYGNSS data and the class imbalance between TC and non-TC samples. For daily time-slots, the method achieves a probability of detection (POD) of 82% with a false alarm rate (FAR) of 12% for tropical storm (TS) level TC detection. For hurricane-level TCs, the POD increases to 83% while the FAR decreases to 9%. The tracked TS-level tracks show a cosine similarity of 92.0% with IBTrACS reference paths. For semi-daily time-slots, the method attains a POD of 75% with a FAR of 8% for TS-level detection, while for hurricane-level TCs, the POD reaches 79% with a FAR reduced to 3%. The cosine similarity between tracked TS-level tracks and IBTrACS references reaches 93.1%. However, the limited quality of irregular point observations and the challenges in observing the fine-scale structure of TCs with CYGNSS data continue to constrain its capability for global TC detection with short revisit periods. Further refinement of the constellation’s design and antenna performance, integrated with complementary remote sensing systems, is essential to enhance the TC monitoring capability.

title: A Novel Self-supervised Learning based on Masked Signal Modeling for Multimodal Physiological Emotion Recognition
authors: Xin Wan, Yongxiong Wang, Zhe Wang, Benke Liu
abstract: Multimodal physiological emotion recognition is an essential and challenging field of human-computer interaction (HCI). However, the collection of labelled physiological signals is difficult and expensive, especially for electroencephalogram (EEG). To address above issue, we propose a novel self-supervised learning (SSL) method, named the Masked-signal Modeling based Self-supervised Learning (MMSL), to train model using numerous unlabelled physiological signal datasets. To capture robust and effective general representations, masked-signal modeling (MSM) is applied to pretrain within each modality through reconstructing EEG and electrocardiogram (ECG) signals by masking a certain proportion of signal. The pretrained signal encoder is then transferred to the SSL phase. In the SSL phase, representation alignment (RA) and cross-modal transformer (CMT) module are designed to capture effective representations without manual labeling through several signal transformations. A multimodal tensor fusion (MTF) technique is then used to integrate abundant multimodal information for transformation recognition. To verify the effectiveness of the proposed method, the pretrained modules are either frozen or fine-tuned for emotion recognition on the AMIGOS dataset. Experimental results demonstrate that our method achieves superior performance in arousal and valence levels compared to recent studies. Furthermore, several visualized results illustrate that the proposed method is capable of recognizing emotion states.

title: TinySplat: Feedforward Approach for Generating Compact 3D Scene Representation
authors: Zetian Song, Jiaye Fu, Jiaqi Zhang, Xiaohan Lu, Chuanmin Jia, Siwei Ma, Wen Gao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: The recent development of feedforward 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) presents a new paradigm to reconstruct 3D scenes. Using neural networks trained on large-scale multi-view datasets, it can directly infer 3DGS representations from sparse input views. Although the feedforward approach achieves high reconstruction speed, it still suffers from the substantial storage cost of 3D Gaussians. Existing 3DGS compression methods relying on scene-wise optimization are not applicable due to architectural incompatibilities. To overcome this limitation, we propose TinySplat, a complete feedforward approach for generating compact 3D scene representations. Built upon standard feedforward 3DGS methods, TinySplat integrates a training-free compression framework that systematically eliminates key sources of redundancy. Specifically, we introduce View-Projection Transformation (VPT) to reduce geometric redundancy by projecting geometric parameters into a more compact space. We further present Visibility-Aware Basis Reduction (VABR), which mitigates perceptual redundancy by aligning feature energy along dominant viewing directions via basis transformation. Lastly, spatial redundancy is addressed through an off-the-shelf video codec. Comprehensive experimental results on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate that TinySplat achieves over 100× compression for 3D Gaussian data generated by feedforward methods. Compared to the state-of-the-art compression approach, we achieve comparable quality with only 6% of the storage size. Meanwhile, our compression framework requires only 25% of the encoding time and 1% of the decoding time.

title: A Framework for Semantic Annotation of Russian-Language Tables Using Deep Learning
authors: Igor V. Bychkov, Nikita O. Dorodnykh, Kirill V. Tobola, Aleksandr Yu. Yurin
abstract: Structured tabular data remains a cornerstone of information representation, serving critical roles in knowledge sharing, analytical workflows, and cross-domain interoperability. Despite their ubiquity, automated interpretation of tables is hindered by their inherent structural diversity, including non-standard formats, context-dependent semantics, and language-specific nuances. While recent advancements in pretrained language models have contributed to advances in table understanding, existing research is mainly focused on English-oriented datasets, resulting in under-explored low-resource languages such as Russian. To bridge this gap, we introduce RuTaBERT, a deep learning framework for semantic column annotation of Russian tables using transformer-based multilingual models. Our framework maps tabular data to semantic type labels from DBpedia, addressing linguistic features through domain-adaptive fine-tuning. The training utilizes a curated dataset of 3.2 million columns derived from the Russian Wikipedia corpus, preprocessed to reduce noise and lexical ambiguity. For this purpose, we develop a new LoReTA framework for automating the preparation of tabular data, including their automatic labeling based on table headers, which is suitable for various languages. RuTaBERT integrates context-enriched table linearization and a contrastive pre-training strategy to handle linguistic specificity and data sparsity. Experimental evaluations demonstrate RuTaBERT’s advantage, achieving a high Micro F1 score of 97.4% on an established benchmark, far surpassing baselines while demonstrating robustness on rare semantic types and computational efficiency. By transcending language barriers, RuTaBERT unlocks opportunities for knowledge graph enrichment, data integration, and automated analytics in low-resource language contexts.

title: Integrating Machine Learning and Image-Based Damage Quantification to Predict Self-Healing Performance of Asphalt Mixtures
authors: Merve Ozkan, Mert Atakan, Kürşat Yildiz
abstract: This study presents a machine-learning framework that predicts a fracture-based healing index of asphalt mixtures by explicitly incorporating image-quantified fracture-surface damage modes (adhesive, cohesive, aggregate). Damage types were quantified through digital image processing. Two datasets were employed: one with specimens broken at –20 °C and another with variable temperatures (–20 °C to 20 °C). Eight feature sets were developed to isolate key factors, and multiple ML models were tested. Results showed that breaking temperature is the most dominant factor influencing healing, though its strong correlation can create spurious relationships that mask the effects of mixture properties. When temperature was fixed, aggregate damage consistently emerged as the most reliable predictor, with the best performance achieved by Support Vector Regressor (R² = 0.856 at –20 °C). Bitumen content showed gradation-dependent effects: in porous mixtures, higher binder reduced aggregate damage, while in dense mixtures the effect was negligible. Regardless of gradation, higher binder content enhanced healing by improving crack filling and binder flow. Air voids also showed contrasting effects: healing decreased with higher voids in dense mixtures, but moderate voids in porous mixtures facilitated binder redistribution and improved healing. Among the algorithms, Support Vector Regressor achieved the highest predictive accuracy, followed by Gradient Boosting, while Linear Regression underperformed, reflecting the nonlinear nature of healing. Feature selection with Recursive Feature Elimination and Cross-Validation (RFECV) improved efficiency with minor accuracy loss, though excluding aggregate damage reduced reliability. Sensitivity analyses confirmed that breaking temperature dominated predictions at variable conditions, while at fixed temperature, volumetric properties and cohesive damage became more influential. These findings demonstrate the potential of ML to capture complex healing mechanisms and support mix design strategies tailored to gradation type and service temperature.

title: Improving Sign Language-Gloss Translations with Pretrained Models
authors: Shuo Chen, Yan Wang
abstract: Sign language gloss-to-text translation is a crucial task for enhancing communication and accessibility for the deaf community. However, the scarcity of annotated sign language data poses significant challenges for developing effective translation models. In this paper, we propose leveraging pretrainedxian language models to improve gloss-to-text translation performance. While intuitively one might assume bilingual translation objectives (e.g., En-De) suit this task, our extensive empirical analysis yields a counter-intuitive but critical key finding: the gloss-to-text task functions fundamentally as a monolingual constraint generation task rather than a cross-lingual translation task. Consequently, models pretrained with denoising auto-encoding objectives (e.g., mBART) significantly outperform those with translation objectives. Based on this insight, we propose to utilize large-scale multilingual pretrained models in our main experiments on three widely-used benchmarks (PHOENIX-2014T, ASLG-PC12, and CSL-Daily). Experimental results demonstrate the superiority of our approach, which consistently benchmarks against and outperforms existing state-of-the-art models. Specifically, our method achieves absolute improvements of +4.37 BLEU on Phoenix2014T and +15.18 BLEU on CSL-Daily compared to strong baselines. We also discuss limitations, such as copying behavior and model robustness, which warrant further investigation. Our findings suggest that denoising auto-encoding pretrained models hold promise for advancing gloss-to-text translation and have the potential to greatly benefit the deaf community.

title: A 2.2- μ W Keyword Spotting System With Filterbank Learning and Attention-Aware Soft-Threshold Denoising in 28-nm CMOS
authors: Cai Li, Ziming Wang, Zhihao Yan, Lishuo Deng, Junyi Qian, Weiwei Shan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems I: Regular Papers
abstract: Keyword spotting (KWS) is crucial for speech interactions in mobile devices, yet its widespread adoption is constrained by the trade-off between low power and high accuracy in diverse noisy environments. Here, we present an ultra-low-power and robust KWS chip to address this challenge through architecture and circuit co-optimization. First, a learnable Mel filter bank is proposed and co-designed with a group-based time-multiplexed architecture to perform adaptive spectral reshaping in a log-Mel feature extractor, reducing the downstream network computations by 25.8% while preserving feature representation capability. Second, a broadcasted residual network (BC-ResNet) is designed to support both KWS and speaker verification (SV) classification tasks, which reduces additions by 43.5% and parameters by 5% compared to a lightweight depthwise separable CNN (DSCNN). Third, an attention-aware soft-threshold denoising strategy is developed to dynamically filter noisy features, yielding up to a 5.8% increase in accuracy over the baseline without denoising at 0dB signal-to-noise ratio (SNR). Finally, a multiplier-less processing element (PE) array combined with stacked-transistor-based ultra-low-leakage custom memory is designed, reducing hardware area by 31.3% and leakage power by 20.4%. Fabricated in a 28nm CMOS process, the proposed 12-class KWS chip consumes only <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2.2\mu $</tex-math> </inline-formula>W at 0.42V supply. It achieves 87.6%-93.5% accuracy on GSCD across 0dB to 20dB SNR levels, demonstrating high robustness for diverse scenarios.

title: RAMACoDrive: A RealTime Asynchronous Framework for Cooperative Perception With Realistic V2X Communication
authors: Shunyao Zhang, Yingfeng Cai, Chengzhi Gao, Caizhen He, Hai Wang, Long Chen
abstract: Recent advances in cooperative driving have garnered significant attention, as it is believed to have greater potential than single-vehicle systems in complex environments. However, gaps in current research frameworks impede its further development. Dataset-based frameworks provide a limited perspective, failing to capture the dynamic, asynchronous, and interactive complexities of the real world. Simulation-based frameworks often employ synchronous implementation and oversimplified communication models, impeding meaningful real-time performance evaluation in asynchronous environments. To this end, we propose RAMACoDrive, a novel real-time asynchronous framework for cooperative perception research. RAMACoDrive implements complete process separation, allowing agents and their internal components to operate asynchronously and independently. It uniquely integrates hardware-in-the-loop V2X communication using an external device for realistic data forwarding. Furthermore, RAMACoDrive incorporates an asynchronous online evaluation method with real-time performance metrics, enabling comprehensive evaluation beyond mere accuracy. Through experiments centered on cooperative 3D object detection, we demonstrate its effectiveness in revealing the impact of real-world asynchronous effects and communication constraints. RAMACoDrive provides a valuable and realistic testbed for cooperative perception algorithms and helps to advance the deployment of practical applications. The code will be released on our GitHub repository.

title: 280 μW MICS/MedRadio CMOS Receiver Front-End for In-Vivo Biomedical Implants
authors: Gyuwon Kim, Chiyoung Ha, Yeongjun Jo, Hyun-Moon Park, Kwangseok Choi, Sungho Lee, Junghwan Han
abstract: This study presents an ultra-low power radio frequency receiver (RX) front-end implemented in complementary metal-oxide-semiconductor (CMOS) technology, designed for operation within the 401–406 MHz Medical Implant Communications Service (MICS) and Medical Device Radiocommunications Service (MedRadio) bands. The proposed direct-conversion RX front-end architecture incorporates a transconductance-boosted current-reuse low-noise amplifier with a feedforward capacitive-coupling technique, in-phase and quadrature complementary current-bleeding downconversion mixers with body voltage control, a two-stage passive-type polyphase filter and local oscillator buffers for quadrature LO signal generation, and output buffers. These techniques collectively enhance the overall RX front-end gain and power efficiency under constrained current consumption. Fabricated in a 65-nm CMOS technology, the implemented RX front-end occupies an active area of 0.16 mm2 (0.64 mm × 0.25 mm), excluding bonding pads. The design achieves input return losses (S11s) better than –10 dB, a conversion gain of 32.3 dB, a noise figure below 4.1 dB, an input 1-dB compression point greater than –35.5 dBm, and an input-referred third-order intercept point greater than –25.5 dBm across the targeted MICS/MedRadio band. The RX front-end draws a current of approximately 280 μA from a 1 V nominal supply.

title: Differentiable Obstacle Avoidance Framework for Robot Safety_supp1-3664595.mp4
authors: Louis Ferdinand Nicodemus Fernandez
abstract: Obstacle avoidance is a fundamental requirement for safe and reliable robot operation. Due to the lack of techniques capable of efficiently and accurately computing volumetric distances and their derivatives, many obstacle avoidance frameworks neglect the volumetric characteristics of objects by using points or spheres as the choice of object representation. To overcome this, an optimisation-based method is used in this paper to accurately compute the minimum distance between convex shapes. In order to enable integration with gradient-based obstacle avoidance algorithms, a method that calculates the gradient of the minimum distance is introduced. This information is incorporated into a Quadratic Program to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach for online obstacle avoidance. In contrast to methods that rely on closed-form expressions, the proposed framework leverages optimisation to simultaneously compute pairwise distances between multiple convex shapes. Simulation results, averaged over 1000 runs, demonstrate that the proposed approach completes tasks more accurately and consistently, improving trajectory tracking accuracy by up to 35% compared to the state-of-the-art baseline. The proposed framework is further validated on a physical robot system, confirming its practical applicability and robustness on real hardware.

title: A Comparative Study of the Effects of Human and AI-Generated Pedagogical Agent in Instructional Videos on Learning Effectiveness
authors: Qingtang Liu, Changyan Guo, Ruiqiu Ye, Yunfan Zuo
abstract: In recent years, instructional videos have been widely used in education. However, the traditional way of recording and producing instructional videos has the disadvantages of being labor-intensive, consuming and costly. The rise of generative artificial Intelligence (GAI) and lip-synthesis technology has greatly reduced the burden of teachers recording videos repeatedly. However, the characters synthesized by GAI tools still have unnatural expressions. For this purpose, the study aims to investigate the differences in the effectiveness of human instructors as well as AI-generated instructors in promoting students' learning performance, social presence, cognitive load, and the uncanny valley, and to compare the performances of different pedagogical agents made in different ways in instructional applications. The study results showed that the AI- generated and the human pedagogical agents are equally effective in promoting students' cognitive progress, retention, and transfer. Furthermore, the AI-generated agents did not create more cognitive load for the students. Meanwhile, the differences between pedagogical agents synthesized by different generative tools have no significant impact on learners’ learning.

title: Research on Control Instruction Flow Anomaly Detection and Behavior Modeling Technology in Energy Industry Internet Applications
authors: Xiaojie Shen, Haohui Su, Zhang Xuan, Lvjun Zheng, Hua Liao
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: With the advancement of digital transformation in the energy industry, the importance of control instruction flow in the industrial internet is becoming increasingly prominent. Due to the complexity of the systems and the massive amount of data, traditional anomaly detection methods face challenges in handling dynamic time-series data, especially in the case of scarce labeled data. To address this issue, this paper proposes a time-series modeling and anomaly detection method based on Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks. By combining the time-series modeling capability of LSTM, self-supervised learning mechanism behavior modeling, and attention mechanisms, this paper effectively improves the detection accuracy of anomalous behaviors in complex time-series data. In experiments, the model achieved anomaly detection in the energy industry control instruction flow through self-supervised learning and performed well in various scenarios, including equipment failures, operational errors, and communication interruptions. The experimental results show that the LSTM model achieves an accuracy of 0.93, a recall rate of 0.91, and an F1 score of 0.92 in equipment fault detection. In comparison with traditional methods, the F1 score of the LSTM model is, on average, 27% higher. Through experimental validation, the proposed method demonstrates high accuracy and robustness, meeting the real-time anomaly detection requirements in the energy industry internet environment.

title: Human–AI Collaboration Pipeline for Thematic Analysis: Example of VR-Supported Pulmonary Rehabilitation
authors: Yunbing Bai, Aileen S Gabriel, Joseph Finkelstein
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: Thematic analysis of qualitative interviews is a time-consuming iterative process aimed at summarizing content of multiple interviews. Large Language Models (LLM) have been shown to be effective in summarizing textual content. We used results of a previously completed thematic analysis of qualitative interviews of patients who provided feedback on VR-supported pulmonary rehabilitation for comparison with the results of LLM-assisted thematic analysis. Pulmonary rehabilitation (PR) improves outcomes in COPD but remains underused; virtual-reality (VR)–enabled, home-based models may expand access and engagement. We evaluated a modular human–AI pipeline for thematic analysis of qualitative interviews with nine patients introduced to a VR PR app, assessing how closely LLM–generated themes align with human analysis. A three-agent workflow produced layered codebooks and themes; Sentence-T5-XXL embeddings and cosine similarity quantified theme proximity. Mean cosine similarity between matched human and LLM themes was consistently high. Overall, the engineered pipeline approximates human thematic structure while offering tunable granularity, with a recurring tendency for LLMs to over-abstract pragmatic details.

title: Design of Industrial Robot Automation Production Unit Integrating Machine Vision
authors: Ruxia Di, Haige Li, Zhenhua Xu, Ping Tang, Lili Wang, Xiaohong Li, Gang Wen, Ruqi Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Robotics and Automatic Control (IRAC)
abstract: The design and simulation of an automated production unit were undertaken in a laboratory setting, founded on the machining specifics of the CK45B CNC lathe and the technological process for shaft-type components. This production unit upgrades and modifies the existing lathe by adding a hydraulic system to control the chuck, and a pneumatic system to control the movement of the protective door and tailstock. The system utilizes a DOBOT CR5 collaborative robot combined with machine vision to achieve automatic loading and unloading of workpieces, and transfers workpieces between processes through a conveyor mechanism. The entire device is controlled by a PLC, and signal interaction between the machine tool and the robot is achieved through I/O allocation of the machine tool, robot, and PLC, as well as program writing. Experimental results demonstrate that this production unit can effectively replace manual loading and unloading operations. By integrating a machine vision module, the robot achieves accurate positioning of shaft workpieces, advancing the automation of the machining process. The overall system operational efficiency surpasses that of manual operation.

title: Design and Implementation of an Intelligent Alarm System for Pumped-Storage Power Stations
authors: Xiaojian Wang, Yangyang Yu, Mingjie Xie, Yaoting Cui
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: As a key component of the computer-based monitoring architecture of pumped-storage power stations, an intelligent alarm system provides crucial technical support for operators to supervise the plant efficiently. With the rapid development of artificial-intelligence technology, machine-learning methods have been intensively studied and deployed in many fields, and their remarkable performance has strongly promoted innovation and engineering application of intelligent hydropower technology. Addressing the need for efficient alarm-information processing in the operation management of pumped-storage plants, this paper proposes a systematic design framework and application strategy that introduces machine-learning techniques into an intelligent alarm system, following the international alarm-management standard ANSI-ISA-18.2-2016. Experimental results demonstrate that the adoption of machine-learning algorithms can effectively improve the validity and practicality of production-data alarm management in pumped-storage power stations.

title: Systematic Exploration of LinuxPTP Configuration in Multi-Hop Networks Using SARB
authors: Tim Brockmann, Michael Rethfeldt, Benjamin Beichler, Frank Golatowski, Christian Haubelt
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: Accurate clock synchronization in multi-hop networks is critical yet difficult to evaluate without disturbing the protocol under test. Building on the Sequence-Aligned Reference Broadcasts (SARB) method, this paper presents a systematic study of Precision Time Protocol (PTP) in an 8-hop line-topology testbed. The study sweeps delay estimation mechanism (end-to-end vs. peer-to-peer), synchronization intervals, and clock servo types. At the eighth hop, residual percentiles, median absolute deviation, and a success-ratio after robust outlier cleaning are assessed. For consistent comparison, an 8-Hop Residual (8HR) index is defined as a composite score normalized to a per-servo reference configuration. Results show that synchronization quality is dominated by servo design and parameter tuning, while the difference between end-to-end and peer-to-peer is marginal in boundary-clock chains where both effectively measure one-hop delays. Within this setting, PI servos perform best with end-to-end at a short synchronization interval, and linear-regression servos perform best with peer-to-peer at a moderate synchronization interval.

title: A Dual-channel Millimeter-wave Radar System Designed for High-precision Mileage Measurement
authors: Xiaoyu Ni, Guangbo Wang, Yu Zheng, Shuchao Xie, Peilan Fan, Xiudong Hong, Jian Guo
abstract: In response to the precise measurement requirements of the traveling distance of vehicles, a high-precision odometer is designed and developed in this article. The system adopts a dual-channel radar speed measurement based on Janus configuration, uses commercial 77GHz radar chips, and combines a waveguide feed network to significantly reduce feed loss. Onboard top-fed waveguide microstrip conversion is applied to increase the integration of the feed network and provide a certain sealing, improving the reliability of the radar system. Horn antennas are used for rapid design verification. Finally, the antenna, RF circuit board and FPGA development board were integrated. Under the condition that the speed measurement range is limited by the current test platform, the preliminary test results show that the measurement error for the speed range of 3–14km/h is 0.55%–3.5%.

title: Optimization of a Shared Energy Storage and Multi-Microgrid System Based on a Bi-level Hybrid Game Framework
authors: Haojing Wang, Yu Zhang, Yuqing Zhao, Chen Fang, Yuanhui Chen, Yaojie Sun, Yu Wang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: Reasonable pricing and efficient operation optimization of shared energy storage in energy systems are crucial to improving the level of new energy consumption and enhancing the overall economy of the system. Therefore, it is necessary to optimize the pricing and operation of multi-microgrid shared energy storage based on third-party investment. The hybrid game is used to model the two-layer energy sharing. The upper model is the energy sharing of shared energy storage and microgrid alliance, which is modeled and optimized by master-slave game, and solved by dichotomy. The lower layer is the power sharing between microgrids, which is modeled and optimized by cooperative game, and solved by alternating direction multiplier method (ADMM). The example verifies that the proposed hybrid game framework reduces the overall cost of the microgrid alliance by 18.91 % and carbon emissions by 24.3 %.

title: Blockchain-Enabled Innovation in Digital Governance and Learning Assessment Systems for Higher Education
authors: Jianxun Guo, Meng Xu
abstract: The ongoing digital transformation in higher education exposes traditional assessment systems to challenges of data security, limited oversight, and rigid evaluation models. Blockchain technology, with its core features of decentralization, immutability, and smart contracts, provides new pathways for upgrading digital governance and assessment frameworks. This study proposes a six-layer dynamic assessment architecture, integrating essential modules such as the learning record chain, dynamic assessment engine, incentive governance, and security/privacy subsystems. The architecture supports comprehensive, multi-agent, and context-aware evaluation and data management. The paper details the system’s platform architecture, data structure, and incentive/security mechanisms, focusing on consortium blockchain-driven collaborative governance and automated assessment via smart contracts. By analyzing case studies and practical bottlenecks, it identifies key challenges in standard alignment, institutional integration, and cross-sector collaboration. The paper offers targeted recommendations for system design, intelligence optimization, incentives, and privacy. Empirical evidence confirms that blockchain-based assessment platforms significantly advance the scientific and collaborative quality of academic evaluation, contributing a robust foundation for digital and multidimensional learning assessment reform in higher education.

title: Transient Fault Analysis of Renewable Energy DC Collection and Transmission System with High-Voltage DC-DC Converters
authors: Dazhen Xu, Zhibo Zhang, Zhiguang Lin, Jianjun Ma, Miao Zhu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: This paper develops a transient fault current calculation method for renewable energy DC collection and transmission system. Fault transient equivalent circuits are established for critical power electronic devices and the whole system under typical fault locations. System matrix differential equations are formulated to enable accurate current computation. Comparison with MATLAB/Simulink simulations validates the effectiveness of the purposed method.

title: Resilient Optical Communication Architectures for Space-Terrestrial Integration
authors: Santosh S. Saraf, Taqy Aleobahaey, Subrata Sahana, Rajeev Kumar, Irfan Khan, Sukhwant Kaur
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: The rapid convergence of satellite and terrestrial communication infrastructures has created a strong demand for resilient optical communication architectures. Space-terrestrial integration promises global coverage, ultra-high-capacity links, and lowlatency connectivity; however, it faces critical challenges including atmospheric turbulence, pointing errors, orbital dynamics, and intermittent link blockages. To address these issues, this paper proposes a fault-tolerant and energy-efficient hybrid architecture that leverages free-space optical (FSO) links, optical ground stations, and terrestrial fiber backbones. It includes adaptive modulation, fault protection through redundancy, and cross-layer allocation of resources to provide the high reliability in dynamic conditions in its architecture. Simulation and analytical models show that this design realizes considerable gains in the link availability, outage probability and energy efficiency relative to traditional FSO and satellite-only systems. These results show how resilient optical integration strategies can be used to serve next generation communication networks of space exploration, global broadband connectivity, and intelligent infrastructures of the earth.

title: Blocky-Based Programming Environment for Developing Cross-Platform Mobile Applications
authors: S. R. Bopitiya, P. D. M. Sumanasekara, T. M. T. C. Tennakoon, N. Kodagoda
abstract: This paper introduces MiniBlocks, a child-friendly blocky-based programming environment focused on designing and deploying cross-platform mobile applications. MiniBlocks distinguishes itself through three core innovations: (1) a child-friendly UI designer featuring accessible widgets tailored to young learners; (2) an integrated debugger within the logic block designer, offering real-time feedback and step-by-step execution; and (3) cross-platform compilation and deployment pipelines for generating native Android and iOS packages. The paper begins with a literature review of 18 relevant studies and industry reports (2018–2024) on no-code and block-based platforms in K–12 education. Results show that MiniBlocks increases engagement and eases the learning curve compared to existing tools while filling a major gap in cross-platform application generation. Building on these foundations, the study further positions MiniBlocks as an end-to-end learning ecosystem that bridges early computational thinking pedagogy with real-world software engineering practices. We present a mixed-methods evaluation involving 72 participants aged 7–15 and 15 instructors, in which learners produced fully deployable apps that ran on both Android and iOS devices within a single 90-minute classroom session, an outcome unattainable with comparator platforms such as Scratch, MIT App Inventor, or Glide. MiniBlocks’ serverless build pipeline, implemented through GitHub Actions and containerized Flutter toolchains also achieved an average 38 % decrease in compilation latency compared with conventional CI/CD workflows. These findings underscore MiniBlocks’ potential not only as a teaching aid but as a scalable blueprint for future no-code solutions that aspire to deliver authentic, device-ready outcomes for novice programmers. By uniting child-centric design principles with industrial-grade deployment architecture, MiniBlocks charts a compelling path toward democratizing mobile-app creation for the next generation of digital innovators.

title: Research on the Construction of Photovoltaic Power Station Operation and Maintenance Scenarios Based on MR Mixed Reality Technology
authors: Jingwei Zheng, Feng Xu, Xianjun Tan, Weikang Wang, Qi Ni
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: With the continuous expansion of photovoltaic (PV) power station scales, traditional operation and maintenance (O&M) methods face severe challenges in terms of efficiency, accuracy, and safety. This paper presents an innovative solution for PV power station O&M scenarios based on mixed reality (MR) technology. By establishing a comprehensive knowledge base platform, modeling the power system environment using Unity3D, and leveraging virtual-real fusion simulation technology, the solution achieves intelligent and visualized O&M tasks. Research results show that MR technology significantly improves inspection efficiency (by 60%), reduces defect handling time (by 40%), and increases diagnostic accuracy (to 92%), while achieving system stability with 99.97% availability. This solution not only optimizes resource utilization but also reduces O&M costs through remote collaboration and real-time data interaction, providing technical support for the sustainable development of PV power stations.

title: Design and Simulation of WDM-PON for Scalable Urban Optical Access Networks
authors: Leyla Ziyodulloyeva, Khushnud Azizjanov, Ogabek Solayev, Jushkinbek Yuldoshev, Odilbek Matsapayev, Sudha Shanker Prasad
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: This paper presents the design and simulation of a wavelength division multiplexed passive optical network (WDM-PON) architecture tailored for scalable urban access. We outline wavelength planning, power budgeting, component selection, and dynamic split configurations suitable for dense metropolitan deployments. A simulation workflow (e.g., OptiSystem/MATLAB—replace with your tool) evaluates bit error rate (BER), optical signal-to-noise ratio (OSNR), and reach under varying split ratios, fiber lengths, and amplifier placements. Findings indicate that split rates can be increased multiple times with an optimal strategy on wavelength allocation and amplification, without compromising the target BER, which allows supporting multi-gigabit rates per customer with scalability to future.

title: Robotic Control Policies Using Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: George James, Trung Duong
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) has emerged as a powerful approach for developing control policies for complex robotic systems. This research investigates the application of DRL, specifically Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) and Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (DDPG) algorithms from the Stable Baselines3 (SB3) library, to train simulated robots within the PyBullet physics engine. A review of existing literature describes key advancements and challenges in DRL for robotic control, including issues of sample efficiency, sim-to-real transfer, and stability. The experimental component of this study focuses on training robotic agents for manipulation tasks, examining the impact of network architecture, reward shaping, and training hyperparameters on performance outcomes. Results demonstrate that with appropriate environment design and hyperparameter tuning, DRL agents can achieve robust and generalizable control policies. Future work will extend to physical hardware implementation and further exploration of advanced DRL methods such as model-based approaches. This paper aims to contribute to the growing body of evidence supporting the viability of DRL for real-world robotics applications.

title: Parametric Estimation of Photonic Crystal Fiber Using Machine Learning
authors: Priyankkumar Gadliwala, Nishant Kumar, Akhilesh Tiwari
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: A fairly recent product is Photonic Crystal Fibers (PCFs) that have gained much popularity in recent years due to its distinctive optical properties and applications in telecommunications, sensing, and nonlinear optics. The optical properties, such as effective refractive index (Neff), effective mode area (Aeff), dispersion and confinement loss, of these nanoparticles, remain difficult and time-consuming to predict using the traditional simulation tools alone. This thesis proposes a machine learningrelated model to determine optical characteristics of PCFs effectively through core refractive index, all cladding rings, pitch, and the wavelength as structural parameters. The different types of regression models applied/ used encompassed the Artificial Neural Networks (ANN), Support Vector Regression (SVR), Random Forest Regression (RFR) and K-Nearest Neighbours Regression (KNNR). With high R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> scores and low error rates across all target properties, the SVR model outperformed the others. The article presents an excellent alternative to traditional numerical approaches by showing that predicting the characteristics of a single PCF within a short time and with a low cost is possible and accurate with the help of a Machine Learning model. Besides, it predetermines the new research into the field of photonic design automation and machine learning integration.

title: Power Electronic Transformer Supporting Flexible Interconnection in Distribution Networks and Its Control Strategy
authors: Youzhuo Zheng, Di Weng, Pengzhu Liu, Jiangfeng Yan, Hongyu Zuo, Zongchen He
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: To address the urgent needs of distribution networks for flexible regulation and reliable power supply under high penetration of renewable energy integration, this paper investigates a Power Electronic Transformer (PET) supporting flexible interconnection in distribution networks and its control strategy. Focusing on the Cascaded H-Bridge (CHB) PET, a hierarchical control strategy is proposed: the input/output stages employ positive and negative sequence decoupling control to adapt to grid unbalance; inter-phase voltage balancing is achieved with low complexity by injecting negative-sequence currents; intraphase submodule voltage balancing is realized through modulation wave compensation; the isolation stage Dual Active Bridge (DAB) accomplishes energy transfer and secondary-side voltage balancing via phase-shift angle control. Finally, experiments on a 10kV/2MVA prototype validate that the proposed scheme provides an effective technical approach for enhancing the operational stability and power regulation capability of flexible interconnected distribution networks.

title: Digital Practice and Innovation of Flipped Classroom in Smart Auditing Courses
authors: Hao Wu, Zhenjiao Gu
abstract: With the development of big data and artificial intelligence technology, intelligent audit has become the core direction of the audit field, and the traditional audit teaching is facing challenges. This study takes the intelligent audit course as the object, constructs a three-dimensional teaching model based on education digitization, and explores the application path of flipped classroom. Develop resource matrix combined with intelligent platform to transmit knowledge before class, use virtual and real integration teaching method and problem-oriented learning to strengthen students' ability in class, rely on AI algorithm to push tasks and organize real audit project practice of enterprises after class. The empirical results show that this model can improve students' ability, shorten the post adaptation period of graduates, and achieve high satisfaction of enterprises. The research also puts forward optimization strategies to provide reference for the innovation of intelligent audit education paradigm.

title: Research on Point Cloud Map Construction Method of Large Scene Based on Multi-sensor Fusion
authors: Lufeng Zhang, Xuan Sun, Bo Chen, Changsheng Ai
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Geographic Information and Remote Sensing Technology (GIRST)
abstract: When laser SLAM is used to construct point cloud map, because of the complexity of large scene environment, the data of single sensor is affected by noise and error, which easily leads to poor loop effect and drift in Z axis direction of point cloud map. In order to make up for the deficiency of single sensor, multi-sensor information is fused to build map and position. High frequency IMU information is added to right the factor cloud distortion of lidar and decrease the amassed error. In addition, GNSS data is introduced to provide absolute pose reference and correct the accumulated error of point cloud map, so as to improve the loop effect. The Z-axis absolute position is constrained directly by GNSS elevation data, and the Z-axis drift is corrected. Compared with single laser mapping odometer and multi-sensor fusion mapping odometer, absolute trajectory error (APE) analysis is done to verify the optimization effect of this study on loop effect and Z-axis drift. The point cloud map is repositioned, and the precision of point cloud map is verified by drawing positioning odometer and satellite odometer with EVO tool. This study can effectively improve the loop effect of point cloud map and correct the drift in Z axis direction.

title: Kinetic Control Detection In Video Via HAVOK Forcing For Low Resource Usage
authors: Amit Bhatia
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: Videos capture high dimensional data that provide valuable information for downstream analysis. In low bandwidth environments, it is useful to focus attention on a set of key frames which capture the desired change, and only send those frames around that change for downstream processing. In this paper we focus on the KITTI dataset where a ground vehicle navigates through an urban road environment and the focus is on finding frames where the vehicle makes a turn. This could be useful in a scenario where an analyst is trying to figure out if the vehicle made a turn at the correct intersection, which is plausible during training and validation of an autonomous vehicle. If the system only transmits the frames around these turns, it requires lower bandwidth to transmit data and lower analyst time to process the change. We model the system in a Dynamic Mode Decomposition (DMD) construct which approximates linear representations of non-linear dynamics. We use a low dimension input feature to extract "turn detection" as a "forcing function" applied to the system, using the Hankel Alternative View of Koopman (HAVOK) analysis. Using delay embedding and Koopman theory this decomposes chaotic dynamics into a linear model using the leading delay coordinates and a forcing function using the low energy delay coordinates. Since vehicle kinematics is not necessarily a well-defined periodic function, the regenerated dynamics is noisy, but the forcing function can be used to extract frames where the vehicle makes turns. Our contributions are: (1) We apply HAVOK analysis to vehicle kinematics, (2) We link vehicle turns with the forcing function of the model, (3) We show that both the peaks and valleys of the filtered absolute value of the forcing function provide candidate locations for kinetic change detection.

title: A Multi-layer QFD Model For Quantitatively Evaluating Cognitive Factors In Project-Based Teaching Of Industrial Engineering
authors: Yixuan Guo, Leran Chen, Dong Lu, Yongsheng Ma
abstract: As project-based learning (PBL) becomes increasingly integrated into industrial engineering curricula, it raises critical challenges in effectively evaluating students’ cognitive engagement and progression. Traditional assessment frameworks often fall short in offering the structure, precision, and actionable insights needed for pedagogical improvement. This paper introduces a novel quantitative model inspired by the Quality Function Deployment (QFD) methodology, widely utilized in product development, to address this gap. The proposed framework systematically organizes cognitive indicators and employs expert judgment and weighting analysis to evaluate key dimensions such as project complexity, risk perception, resource dependency, and collaborative cognition. Findings suggest that the model enhances the objectivity and practicality of cognitive assessments and supports informed instructional design and project management decisions. This work contributes both a theoretical foundation and a practical toolset for advancing the standardization and intelligent optimization of project-based engineering education.

title: AI-driven Culturally Responsive Educational Technology: Based on the Empowerment of Distance Education and the Reconstruction of Inclusive Learning
authors: Xingwang Li, Yongpeng Hu
abstract: This article is based on the data from the UNESCO 2024 Global Education Monitoring Report, which indicates that 73% of multi-ethnic countries face issues of insufficient cultural representation in curricula. It systematically elaborates on the theoretical framework of Culturally Responsive Educational Technology (CRET). By analyzing the SBAC assessment standard system developed by the Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium in the United States, and examining typical cases such as the bilingual teaching platform in China's "Three Regions and Three Prefectures" (Tibet, Tibetan areas in four provinces, the southern Xinjiang four prefectures, Sichuan's Liangshan Prefecture, Yunnan's Nujiang Prefecture, Gansu's Linxia Prefecture, and the production and construction corps located in the southern Xinjiang four prefectures), as well as conducting a comparative study of educational technology policies across 28 countries, this paper proposes a CRET three-dimensional model that includes cultural adaptation algorithms, multimodal resource libraries, and intelligent diagnostic systems. Research shows that classrooms adopting CRET can increase minority students' participation by 41% and improve knowledge retention by 33%. These groundbreaking advancements not only validate the feasibility of technology-enabled culturally responsive teaching but also establish a technological pathway to address the phenomenon of "cultural poverty in education", providing a replicable solution for global digital education governance. The future educational ecosystem will be a collaborative intelligent system between humans and machines, preserving the advancement of technology while guarding the unique creativity and empathy inherent to humanity.

title: The Sociotechnical Imaginaries of AI in Future School Punishment
authors: Ziyue Wei
abstract: As an important component of school education management, the rationality and effectiveness of educational punishment have always been a focus of attention in the education and social sectors. With the rapid development of artificial intelligence technology, the application of AI in the field of education is gradually extending from auxiliary teaching to deeper management decision-making. This article is based on the theory of sociotechnical imaginaries, exploring the potential application of AI technology in the future school educational punishment system and the profound changes it may bring.

title: Stability Analysis of Hybrid Intersatellite Communication Links in Low-Orbit LEO Systems
authors: Dilmurod Davronbekov
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: The paper examines a comprehensive methodology for assessing the reliability and stability of hybrid inter-satellite communication links in low-orbit satellite systems. An integral resilience metric is introduced that takes into account channel availability, delay percentile, specific energy per bit and inter-site ratio. Analytical models of energy budgets for radio-frequency, laser, and hybrid channels are developed. A dual terminal architecture and an algorithm for adaptive switching between laser and radio channels based on threshold and predictive models are described. A comparative analysis showed that the hybrid architecture provides an optimal balance between high throughput and resilience, reducing the risk of cascading failures in dense low-orbit satellite constellations.

title: A Survey and Prospects of Source Code Processing Techniques Based on Large Language Models
authors: Lei Wang, Zhuoying Yang
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Software Engineering and Service Science (ICSESS)
abstract: Source code processing is a core research domain in software engineering. In recent years, the emergence of large language models (LLMs) — such as the BERT series, GPT series, LLaMA series, DeepSeek series, T5, and their variants tailored for source code—has introduced novel technical approaches to this field. Numerous scholars, both domestic and international, have devoted significant efforts to the study of LLM-based source code processing techniques, resulting in a wealth of fruitful research outcomes. To further advance the theoretical and practical development of this domain, this paper conducts a comprehensive review and presents future prospects. Centered on two primary methodological categories—prompt-based source code processing and fine-tuned task-specific models—the study systematically organizes and summarizes the current state of research and recent achievements in LLM-based source code processing. On this basis, it further identifies the key challenges and pressing issues in the field. Finally, it outlines promising research directions and potential solutions. This work offers a thorough and systematic overview of the development, latest progress, and future trends of source code processing technologies powered by LLMs, providing valuable references and guidance for future research endeavors.

title: Synthetic Blood Data Generation for Fair Machine Learning

authors: Xiangming Li, Hua Chu, Chengyu Feng, Jianan Li, Yangtao Zhou, Qingshan Li, Wanqiang Yang
