title: On the Convergence Club Nature of Competitiveness and Efficiency across Firms by Technological Complexity and Size
authors: Francisco Javier Santos-Arteaga, Raquel Marín, Madjid Tavana, Debora Di Caprio
abstract: Digitalization strategies emerge through interactions among producers, consumers, and institutions across value chains, leading to gains in productivity, the introduction of new patents, and innovations in products and processes. Dynamic Capabilities theory extends the static resource-based view of the firm by incorporating learning and innovation in evolving environments. Its collaborative extension has recently been introduced to analyze the behavior of corporate dynamics within evolving ecosystems shaped by Information and Communication Technologies and firms' digitalization strategies. However, empirical evaluations of how digital value chains influence firm level productivity and innovation remain limited, relying on static efficiency evaluation frameworks. We apply a dynamic Slacks-Based Data Envelopment Analysis model to a panel of 1,369 Spanish manufacturing firms progressing through the emergence and consolidation phases of digitalization that have characterized the early decades of the twenty-first century. We examine how efficiency and competitiveness evolve, finding that larger firms and those in more complex technological sectors show more varied behavior but lower inefficiency. The findings offer implications for theory, best practices, and digitalization policies. The robustness of our analysis has been validated by demonstrating substantial differences between the patterns obtained under the standard static and our dynamic evaluation environments.

title: A Density-based Clustering Approach for Pilot Assignment in Scalable Cell-Free Massive MIMO
authors: Suheel Rehman, G. R. Begh, Omkar Singh
abstract: Cell-free massive multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) is a promising wireless architecture for next-generation networks, but its performance is still strongly affected by pilot contamination, especially in dense and mobile user environments. In this work, we introduce a two-stage pilot assignment framework that leverages structured clustering, systematic refinement, and a channel estimation model that accounts for hardware impairments. In the first stage, we generate a warm-start pilot assignment using an interference-aware hybrid density-based hierarchical clustering method, which groups users based on both spatial proximity and mutual interference. In the second stage, this initial solution is refined using a Tabu Search algorithm whose search space is pruned by a lightweight learning-based mechanism, allowing faster and more effective optimization. In addition, we extend the study to user mobility and evaluate the spectral efficiency of the proposed design under dynamic network conditions. Simulation results confirm that the proposed pilot assignment framework consistently outperforms state-of-the-art pilot assignment schemes under both static and mobile scenarios.

title: Differential Evolution Algorithm Based on Spatial Partition Perturbation Mechanism
authors: Liangliang Sun, Zhenghao Song, Ge Guo, Natalja Matsveichuk, Yuri Sotskov
abstract: Differential Evolution (DE) algorithm, as a state-of-the-art population-based stochastic optimizer for continuous non-convex search spaces, can adaptively balance exploration and exploitation through difference vectors among individuals. However, as iterations proceed, population diversity diminishes, leading to reduced exploration capability and susceptibility to local optima, especially in multimodal or complex landscapes. To address this limitation, this paper proposes a Differential Evolution Based on Spatial Partition Perturbation Mechanism (SPMDE). The application of KD-Tree enables SPMDE to dynamically manage population distribution, update stagnant individuals, and maintain diversity, thereby strengthening its global search capability in the evolutionary process. CEC2017 benchmark problems is used to evaluate the overall performance of SPMDE. Experimental results indicate that SPMDE achieves highly competitive optimization performance when compared to both state-of-the-art DE variants and enhanced versions of classic evolutionary algorithms.

title: Conductive Sensing Jamming Layers for Resistive Sensing of Layer Jamming Brakes_supp3-3657963.mp4
authors: Hugo Rodrigue
abstract: Layer jamming brakes exhibit variable stiffness with vacuum pressure, allowing them to restrict relative motion between two points. These devices hold significant potential for wearable applications due to their lightweight nature and ability to generate substantial linear tension for load transfer or selective movement restriction. However, the challenge of integrating displacement sensors within their structure has not yet been solved. In this article, we introduce a layer jamming system with resistive sensing jamming layers. The proposed mechanism leverages the relative motion of internal overlapping sensing jamming layers to produce a variation in resistance which can inform the user about their relative displacement while also producing frictional forces. This sensing approach is inherently synergistic with the mechanism of the device as it simultaneously generates friction and enables real-time displacement measurement without altering the shape of the device. The proposed device can generate a tensile force of up to 1017 N, can sense displacements over the entire range of operation of jamming layer brakes (up to 82% displacement) with a gauge factor of 1.15 and a linearity error within 1%. We demonstrate its application as a wearable device with a controllable braking point algorithm and as an upper-arm support system.

title: Voltage Control for Nonlinear DC Microgrids via a Fully Actuated System Approach
authors: Yi Yu, Chao Deng, Rongni Yang, Mohammad Shahidehpour, Chi Yung Chung
abstract: Except for purely resistive loads, DC microgrids (MGs) interfaced with boost or buck converters typically feed multistage power converters via a common bus. A notable class within this framework is the tightly regulated point-of-load (POL) converter, which behaves as a constant power load (CPL) within its control bandwidth. Considering the challenges posed by the negative incremental impedance characteristics of CPLs on MG stability, this article establishes a second-order fully actuated (SOFA) model for nonlinear MGs incorporating CPLs and proposes a fully actuated (FA) voltage regulator based on a disturbance estimator. The proposed approach accounts for both known and unknown CPL scenarios, including load variations that are not previously identified. Furthermore, a closed-loop MG system with FA control under parameter perturbation is analyzed based on singular perturbation theory. In this study, the first-order under-actuated MG system containing CPLs is transformed into an SOFA system by means of techniques such as state transformation, system dimension reduction, and system order augmentation. Compared to the existing methods, the proposed FA controller, based on this system model, features a straightforward and easy-to-implement structure, which makes the parameterized design of the controller possible. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed method for achieving voltage tracking as well as system stability is confirmed through abundant experimental cases conducted on a built hardware MG platform.

title: Illumination-Guided Grouped Attention and Masked Progressive Denoising for Low-Light Image Enhancement
authors: Hui Da, Yuzhen Niu, Liuxiang Qiu, Fusheng Li, Tiesong Zhao, Yuzhong Chen
abstract: Existing Transformer- or Mamba-based low-light image enhancement (LLIE) methods can capture long-range dependencies in images and achieve global degradation restoration, but suffer from insufficient detail recovery. Besides, these methods do not consider the different illumination levels in various regions or enhance the regional illumination accordingly. Furthermore, existing denoising methods often overfit to single noise distribution and type, showing poor generalization to the noises in low-light images. To address these issues, we propose an Illumination-guided Grouped Attention (IGA) module and a Masked Progressive Denoising (MPD) module for low-light image enhancement. The IGA module first improves the local feature representation through detail recovery operations, and then iteratively groups the image representation based on the illumination levels and conducts grouped attention to achieve both fine detail recovery and adaptive regional illumination optimization. The MPD module explores correlations within and among regions to enhance the texture and structure representations from a local to global perspective, thus achieving both local and global denoising and well denoising generalization capability. Extensive quantitative and qualitative experiments on eight datasets demonstrate that our proposed method outperforms the existing state-of-the-art low-light image enhancement methods. Furthermore, plugging our proposed IGA and MPD modules into existing Transformer- or Mamba-based LLIE methods can significantly improve their performance, further demonstrating the modules' ability to address the common issues in such methods.

title: Filtering of Q(t) Measurement Data for Estimating Leakage Current
authors: Ryota Kitani, Shinya Iwata, Tomoka Tsuya, Hiroaki Uehara, Tatsuki Okamoto
abstract: Q(t) measurement has been developed as a diagnostic technique for electrical insulators in DC applications, and is widely used to compare the relative properties of polymeric samples under high voltage; however, its conventional usage is limited to analyzing the charge amount compared to the space charge phenomenon. Conversely, Q(t) measurement can also serve as a diagnostic tool for leakage current through insulation materials because of its relatively high precision; hence, this study focuses on utilizing this method as an online abnormal detector. However, first, noisy data resulting from variable circumstances remains a challenge, even when simple low-pass filters are applied. This study ensures noise reduction by assuming an ordinary differential equation model and applying Kalman filters/Rauch–Tung–Striebel (RTS) smoothers to the experimental data of a polyimide sheet sample. Filtering/smoothing reduces the noise level to less than 1/900 of the simple first-difference data when an RTS smoother is applied, according to the comparison method that utilizes linearly-approximated data. Then, fixed-lag smoothers are applied, generally obtaining more smoothed data than that of the Kalman filter. Through the filtered results and Kalman filters’ property as an adaptive low-pass filter, a direction for filter designing is proposed, which depends on ‘process noise to the 2nd power’ / ‘observation noise.’ The filtering/evaluation/designing methods utilized in this study are beneficial for more precise diagnoses and are expected to provide a foundation for online leakage current detection.

title: Why do Elementary School Students Choose Educational Tablet? --Case-based narrative research
authors: Yurou Wang, Wentao Wu
abstract: As smart learning devices become widespread, elementary students are key users, yet the market faces issues like functional exaggeration, inadequate standards, and ethical concerns, necessitating research into their adoption motivations and usage impacts. This study examines why primary students choose educational tablets, using a narrative case method centered on one pupil. Interview data were analyzed with grounded theory. Findings show that initial selection is driven by scenario-based educational needs and family investment rationality, while continued use depends on behavioral incentive loops and emotional human-computer connections. Balancing technological empowerment and control remains a key challenge. Design should integrate functional suitability, behavioral motivation, and ethical control. A developmentally appropriate educational ecosystem requires home-school collaboration, enhanced industry standards, and improved digital literacy for children.

title: Forstering AI Literacy Through Teacher-and Studentbuilt AI Agents in an EAP Course: An Exploration Study
authors: Qing Wen
abstract: In English for Academic Purposes (EAP) courses developed for engineering students, employability is a popular theme. To address the challenges posed by Generative AI to employability, this study explores how both the teacher and the students can build AI agents to facilitate the development of L2 job interview skills. AI Interest Group (AIG) (N=12) used and built AI agents with teacher guidance, Group A (N=14) used AI informally, and Group B (N=11) did not use AI in preparation for an L2 job interview. Mixed methods were used to examine students’ job interview performance and anxiety change, their perceived benefits and the relevance of AI literacy incorporation in an EAP course. One-way ANOVA analysis showed no significant difference in performance scores between the AIG group and the other two, but a significant difference between Groups A and B. Mixed ANOVA analysis showed a significant drop in anxiety levels across all groups, with a notably larger decrease among the AIG students. Thematic analysis from the interview data endorsed AI’s role in scaffolding, explaining the drop in anxiety level. All AIG students successfully built AI agents. They perceived this incorporation to be extremely relevant and expressed a strong need for AI literacy development. The study implies it is possible and might also be necessary to incorporate AI literacy development in EAP courses. Future research could explore larger sample sizes and examine more controlled teaching and learning practices once institutional policies have matured.

title: Hysteresis Control with Variable Coefficients Based on a Physics-Mechanism-Data Hybrid Modeling Approach
authors: Weijie Tang, Fan Yang, Bingcheng Zhou, Tao He, Xiaoyan Sun, Zhilei Qiu, Gaiping Sun
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: Pure data-driven modeling approaches for transformer districts suffer from limitations in data quality and availability, and their outputs often lack physical interpretability, which hinders their practical application in guiding specific grid control and renovation measures. On the other hand, purely physical modeling and simulation methods heavily depend on accurate grid topology and component parameters. To address these issues, this paper proposes a variable coefficient droop control strategy based on a hybrid physical mechanism–data-driven modeling approach, which simultaneously considers load analysis and physical modeling. Using k-means clustering, loads are classified and active power characteristic curves are extracted. These load profiles are then incorporated into the photovoltaic (PV) inverter control model. Based on real-time voltage variations, the droop control coefficient is dynamically adjusted, thereby improving voltage control performance in the transformer district.

title: Design and Development of a Virtual Reality Game for Cultural Heritage Education of Qiqiao Festival
authors: Jue Huang, Xinyi Xie, Chaoguang Wang
abstract: Intangible Cultural Heritage (ICH) education faces challenges such as declining awareness among youth and the endangerment of traditional skills. This study presents an immersive virtual reality (VR) educational game as an innovative method for integrating digital technology with cultural heritage education. The project is grounded in the Qiqiao Festival of Zhucun, Guangzhou, and draws on both fieldwork and literature analysis to reconstruct the cultural significance of traditional crafts. Using Unreal Engine 5 and virtual technology, the research creates a multisensory game world based on a Lingnan folk setting and designs seven game quests where core folkloric elements of the Qiqiao Festival become gamified learning units. The integration of gamification and VR enhances cultural immersion and engagement, while gamified tasks and feedback mechanisms promote cultural knowledge acquisition. The study demonstrates that goal-driven and feedback-informed gamified systems can improve youth participation in cultural heritage education, offering a natural integration of cultural knowledge with engaging game play.

title: Optimization Strategy for Backflow Power in Dual Active Bridge Converters Using Fuzzy Adaptive Sliding Mode Control
authors: Kai Wang, Ying Jiang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: Aiming to address the issue of backflow power in DAB converters and to minimize the backflow power, this paper proposes an optimized control strategy based on EPS control. The proposed approach involves analyzing the operating principles of the DAB and applying the KKT conditions to transform constraints into constraint functions. A Lagrange polynomial function is then established to determine the extremum, thereby deriving the optimal solution for circulating power minimization. In addition, SMC is introduced to enhance the system’s disturbance rejection capability. To mitigate the chattering issue inherent in conventional SMC, fuzzy adaptive control mechanism is incorporated to dynamically adjust the sliding mode controller parameters, thereby reducing chattering and improving system accuracy and performance. Simulation results validate the effectiveness of the proposed optimization control strategy.

title: Integrated Photonic Biosensors for Real-Time Soil Nutrient and Crop Health Analysis
authors: Aliev Ravshan Maratovich, Vivek Veeraiah, Mamatha G, Ankur Gupta, Dharmesh Dhabliya, Shahanawaj Ahamad
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: In sustainable agriculture, agricultural systems using sensing mechanisms to provide high frequency in-situ data on soil and plant nutrients and condition are becoming a necessity. In this article, we would present the universal photonic biosensing system that is designed based on silicon nitride (SiN) ring resonators and MachZehnder interferometers (MZI) together with microfluidics, low-powered edge computing, and cloud analytics. The system will attempt to determine the level of nitrate, phosphate, and potassium (NPK) ions and proxies of crop stress in quicker measurements to allow closing the loop of irrigation and bringing together of the fertilization procedure. With experience of the optical spectroscopy, thermal and electro-optical remote sensing and field-scale estimation of soil moisture, our scheme possesses a lower latency than couple of pure remote, and better limit-of-detection (LOD) than couple of pure remote methodological tools. We outline device physics, models including calibration and an edge to cloud data pipeline. Field-informed case study indicates sub-10ms edge case-inference latency and sub- SI 0.5 mg/L nitrate LOD with a good R2 calibration. We address the complementary ideas with UAV/aerial surveillance, AI-oriented disease diagnosis, and intelligent-ag models.

title: Global Ocean Three-Dimensional Temperature Field Prediction Based on RG-Transformer and RF
authors: Ke Yi, Peng Chen, Dian Wang, Xiunan Li
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Geographic Information and Remote Sensing Technology (GIRST)
abstract: The accurate inversion and spatiotemporal prediction of the global ocean three-dimensional temperature field are core technical challenges in understanding global climate change and maintaining marine ecological balance. In existing studies, there are limitations in the accuracy of three-dimensional temperature field inversion. This study proposes a two-step integration framework of "sea surface temperature prediction - three-dimensional temperature field inversion": First, an innovative RG-Transformer model is used to predict the sea surface temperature at future moments based on historical sea surface temperature data, which addresses the issues of error accumulation and poor adaptability to spherical space in traditional models. Subsequently, the predicted sea surface temperature is used as input, combined with a Random Forest model trained on the Argo dataset, to invert the subsurface three-dimensional temperature field at a depth of 0-200 m for the corresponding moment. The experimental results show that this integrated framework achieves high-precision prediction and inversion in global ocean regions. For short-term (2-month) sea surface temperature prediction, the RMSE is as low as 0.33°C, and the average error of the corresponding three-dimensional temperature field inversion layer is 0.51°C, representing an accuracy improvement of approximately 48% compared to traditional methods. The method proposed in this study effectively solves the difficulties in ocean temperature field prediction and provides comprehensive spatiotemporal data support for research on changes in ocean heat content and the dynamic distribution of fishery resources.

title: Downscaling of surface air temperature over Milan metropolitan area for Urban Heat Island analysis
authors: Davide Parmeggiani, Sofia Costanzini, Dražen Skoković, Francesca Despini, Grazia Ghermandi, José Antonio Sobrino, Sergio Teggi
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Geographic Information and Remote Sensing Technology (GIRST)
abstract: Urban Heat Island (UHI) is a global warming phenomenon that affects a large number of people around the world. Studying this phenomenon requires accurate measurements of climatological variables, particularly air temperature at 2 meters (T2m) on the urban scale. To improve spatial resolution of T2m ERA5 data from 0.1° to 0.05°, we implemented a deep learning approach using a Super Resolution Deep Residual Neural Network (SRDRN) and compared its performance with the traditional LOcalized Constructed Analog (LOCA) downscaling method and bilinear interpolation. Our results demonstrate that SRDRN achieved greater performance metrics (RMSE = 0.9°C, R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.95) than LOCA (RMSE = 3.8°C, R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.27) and bilinear (RMSE = 1.9°C, R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.61) approaches, validating the benefit of deep learning for temperature downscaling applications and subsequent urban analysis. Future work will focus on achieving finer spatial resolution (0.01°) by incorporating additional auxiliary variables to improve model performance.

title: Research on International Comparison of Measurement Standards for High Voltage and Heavy Current
authors: Yang Xue, Hao Chen, Bin Zheng
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: With the transformation of the global energy structure and the rapid development of smart grid technology, the informatization and automation levels of power systems are increasingly improving. For the international comparison of high voltage and high current standards, a star or loop (petal) method is adopted. The pilot laboratory calibrates the traveling standard against the national measurement standard and provides the uncertainty, using the calibration value of the traveling standard as the reference value. Domestic and international laboratories use their respective standard setups, test equipment, and measurement methods to complete tests on the same traveling standard used for comparison. During the comparison process, stability checks are required both when leaving and returning to the high voltage metrology station, and short-term stability is quantified. Provided no abnormalities in sample stability are detected, the same sample is used throughout the entire measurement comparison plan for circulation. Each time the sample returns to a laboratory, the laboratory must perform one stability check (n=10), until all participants have completed their tests. Through the precise calibration of the traveling standard by the pilot laboratory, multiple rounds of stability checks, and a unified data evaluation method, the international comparison of high voltage and high current standards was successfully completed, effectively enhancing the international applicability in the field of high voltage and high current metrology.

title: Efficient Deep Learning Network for Device Orientation-independent Human Activity Recognition Based on Gyroscope Smartphone Data
authors: Sakorn Mekruksavanich, Anuchit Jitpattanakul
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Software Engineering and Service Science (ICSESS)
abstract: This study presents an orientation-independent deep learning framework for smartphone-based human activity recognition (HAR) using gyroscope sensor data. Conventional deep learning models often experience substantial performance degradation when device orientation varies, a common occurrence in real-world usage. To address this limitation, we propose a compact CNN-BiGRU architecture designed to learn orientation-invariant motion representations directly from raw gyroscope signals. The model integrates convolutional layers for local pattern extraction with bidirectional gated recurrent units that capture temporal dependencies, enabling robust recognition of motion dynamics rather than orientation-specific values. The framework is evaluated on the RL-HAR dataset, which contains four activity classes—active, driving, inactive, and walking—recorded under multiple device orientations from 19 participants with diverse demographic characteristics. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms state-of-the-art baselines while maintaining computational efficiency suitable for mobile deployment. The CNN-BiGRU network achieves 94.26% accuracy (±0.47%) and a 93.39% F1-score (±0.47%), representing roughly a 5% improvement over the strongest baseline model. With only 1.2 million parameters and an inference time of approximately 3.2 milliseconds per sample, the model delivers precise and orientation-invariant activity classification with minimal misclassification across all activity categories. These findings highlight the potential of lightweight hybrid architectures for reliable real-world HAR applications.

title: Effect of Current Limiting Parameters on tanδ Calculation in the PDC Method
authors: Weiming He, Xuan Qiu, Jiayu Mai, Yang Cheng, Qin Zhang, Han Chen, Rilang Liu, Aopan Deng
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: To clarify the impact of current-limiting parameters on dielectric loss calculations for XLPE cables during PDC testing, this paper investigates the response patterns of cables of varying lengths through extended theoretical analysis of the Debye model and experimental validation. Results indicate: For short cables measured in the laboratory, the small geometric capacitance results in an RC circuit time constant of milliseconds due to the current-limiting resistor and capacitor. The polarization voltage approximates an ideal step response, eliminating the need to delay the fitting start time. Simulation calculations for a 1km field cable indicate that reaching 99% of the set polarization voltage requires 0.86–0.98 seconds. A 4-second delay in fitting the start time is necessary for parameter convergence, and overall dielectric loss values are significantly higher, with a maximum deviation of 9.84×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">–5</sup> at 0.1 Hz. Short cables in laboratory settings can be handled conventionally, whereas long field cables require determining the voltage stabilization time before optimizing the fitting strategy to ensure dielectric loss calculation accuracy.

title: A Dual-Channel Framework for Churn Risk Stratification and Intelligent Recall Using XGBoost Prediction and User Profiling
authors: Shuhui Li, Siyu Zhang, Jinhe Yu, Yi Qian, Hang Song, Na Lv
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: Aiming at the issues of insufficiently refined churn risk stratification and the suboptimal alignment between recall strategies and user preferences in the potential churn user prediction and recall for the State Grid online platform, this paper constructs a dual-path churn risk stratification and intelligent recall strategy model that integrates XGBoost prediction with user profiling. Based on the dual-path ensemble learning model, a churn risk prediction pathway—with Boruta-XGBoost at its core and driven by Bayesian optimization—has been constructed. This approach accomplishes a multi-level stratification of user churn risk into "high, medium, and low" tiers, and further achieves adaptive threshold adjustment through a PID-based dynamic control mechanism. On the other hand, a churn user profiling pathway is constructed by jointly employing three metrics—the Pearson correlation coefficient, Spearman's rank correlation coefficient, and analysis of variance (ANOVA)—thereby modeling the behavioral patterns and demand preferences of potential churn users. Finally, a two-dimensional matrix mapping is employed to achieve the cross-integration of risk prediction and user profiling. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves a churn user prediction accuracy of 0.9384, an F1-score of 0.8413, and a maximum AUC value of 0.8861, thereby enabling precise prediction of State Grid online platform user churn and effective matching of recall strategies.

title: Transformer Network–Based Reliability Assessment for Distribution Networks with Large-Scale Distributed Energy
authors: Yangjun Zhou, Yuanchao Zhou, Wei Zhang, Like Gao, Chenying Yi, Weixiang Huang, Ling Li, Shan Li
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: This study addresses the temporal variability and uncertainty of wind and solar outputs that, when integrated at scale into distribution networks, can cause supply–demand imbalances, power-quality deterioration, and reduced reliability. A Transformer-Based reliability assessment method is developed for distribution networks with large-scale distributed energy: first, an improved minimal-path approach is formulated for networks containing distributed resources; when upstream component failures trigger outages in areas with distributed generation, those areas shift to islanded operation, prioritizing the restoration of essential loads within the island. Subsequently, a Transformer-Based procedure is introduced to determine reliability-index intervals by reframing prediction as a classification task, effectively mitigating the non-smooth behavior of the indices. The method’s effectiveness is demonstrated on the IEEE RBTS 6-node system (feeder 4). The proposed approach enables real-time monitoring and early warning of operational risks in distribution networks.

title: Optimal Design of Axial Flux Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motor
authors: Yuxin Feng, Zhongcui Miao
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: Aiming at the problem of insufficient torque performance of the stator coreless axial flux permanent magnet synchronous motor, a new motor structure combining a novel hexagonal winding and Halbach array magnetic pole structure is proposed from the perspective of motor structure. Firstly, the characteristics of different windings are compared, and then a new hexagonal winding structure is proposed, and its influence on motor copper loss and torque is analyzed. Then, the electromagnetic performance such as magnetic field distribution, air-gap flux density, no-load back electromotive force, electromagnetic torque and torque ripple of the traditional surface-mounted and Halbach array structures is analyzed. To further enhance the motor’s torque performance, the finite element method was employed to analyze how the main magnetic pole angle affects this performance. The analysis resulted in the determination of the main magnetic pole angle that delivers the optimal comprehensive torque performance.

title: AI-Enhanced API Gateway: A Unified Framework for Security and Performance for Next Generation Microservices
authors: Karan Kumar Ratra, Dhruv Kumar, Deepika Verma, Hemant Burman
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: As AI-driven applications continue to scale, the reliance on microservices architecture has become critical for achieving modularity, agility, and high availability. API gateways serve as the primary interface for managing microservices communication by handling authentication, authorization, rate limiting, and traffic routing. However, traditional API gateways are increasingly inadequate in the face of evolving cybersecurity threats and unpredictable, high-throughput API traffic generated by AI workloads. Static configurations, lack of contextual awareness, and limited adaptability expose systems to security vulnerabilities and performance bottlenecks.This paper proposes an AI-enhanced API Gateway architecture that introduces intelligent security and performance features using advanced machine learning models. Key innovations include zero-trust security enforcement, machine learning-based anomaly detection, adaptive rate limiting, and predictive load balancing. AI algorithms such as LSTM networks, Isolation Forests, Gaussian Mixture Models, and Deep Q-Networks are integrated into the gateway to detect malicious traffic patterns, dynamically adjust request thresholds, and efficiently route traffic based on historical and real-time metrics. The AI-powered API Gateway concept discussed in this paper offers a future-ready, scalable solution for securing and optimizing communication in complex AI microservices environments, enabling organizations to adapt quickly to evolving operational and security demands.

title: Sequential Restoration Model for Active Distribution System with Dynamic Islanding
authors: Jiyuan Tang, Kaigui Xie, Chunyan Li, Chenghuang Wu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: This paper presents a sequential restoration model aimed at minimizing system recovery costs following multiple faults in an active distribution network (ADN). Unlike conventional methods that rely on pre-identified fault-based islands, the proposed scheme introduces a dynamic islanding strategy in which the number and boundaries of islands can evolve through merging during the repair process. This enhances flexibility and resilience by reducing reliance on isolated microgrids. In addition, the model jointly optimizes repair crew routing and system restoration by tracking the maintenance status of each component over discrete time intervals, ensuring proper coordination between repair activities, network reconfiguration, and island merging. In this way, the proposed approach achieves a stepwise restoration process that further improves recovery efficiency. The effectiveness of the proposed model is verified through case studies on the IEEE 33-bus system.

title: Stability control of DC grid DAB converter based on improved nonsingular terminal sliding mode control
authors: Yuexin Jiang, Dazhi Wang, Liang Tong, Yanqi Jiang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy Internet and Power Systems (ICEIPS)
abstract: To solve the problem of slow dynamic response of dual-active-bridge DC-DC converter under disturbance, an improved sliding mode control strategy based on nonsingular terminal sliding mode with integrator is proposed in this paper. By analyzing the operation principle of dual active bridge under single phase-shift modulation, the order reduction model of dual active bridge is established, and the integrator is added to the non- singular terminal sliding mode surface to reduce the voltage overshoot and improve the dynamic performance of the converter on the premise of retaining its dynamic fast response characteristics. The simulation model of double active bridge is built, and the comparative experiments verify that the improved control proposed in this paper can keep the output stable, improve the dynamic response speed and reduce the overshoot under the conditions of input voltage disturbance, load disturbance and output voltage variation, and verify the feasibility of optimizing the anti-disturbance ability of the control strategy.

title: Design of a Cost-Effective Receiver Front-End Module with High Image-Rejection Ratio
authors: Ruihao Xun, Zexi Zhu, Longfei Li, Zhiqiang Yu, Jianyi Zhou
abstract: To meet the demand for high spectral purity in modern communication systems, this paper presents a novel and cost-effective receiver front-end architecture that achieves high image rejection at the board level. The proposed design employs a synergistic filtering approach, where a notch filter is integrated within the low-noise amplifier (LNA) for targeted suppression of the image frequency, followed by a band-reject filter for broader stopband attenuation. A single-balanced mixer is subsequently used for down-conversion, significantly reducing overall system complexity. A prototype was fabricated on an RO4350B printed circuit board (PCB), targeting a radio frequency (RF) band of 3.0–3.5 GHz with an intermediate frequency (IF) range of 250–750 MHz. The results demonstrate an image-rejection ratio (IRR) exceeding 32 dB across the operational band, a conversion gain of 6 dB, and a noise figure (NF) of 2 dB. These results validate the proposed architecture as an effective and practical solution for achieving high image rejection in receiver front-ends while maintaining low cost and complexity.

title: Research on the Construction and Application of Evaluation Index System for Equipment’s Digital Textbook in Military Academy
authors: Yuan Jiang, Li Lu
abstract: As an important tool for the cultivation of skilled talents, digital textbooks reflect the advanced technological capabilities and practical skills of equipment manufacturers, serving as the foundational resource for equipment-related instruction in military academies. This paper establishes five level-I indicators and twenty level-II indicators for equipment digital textbooks. These indicators are further informed by the analysis of digital textbook development needs, as well as interview data from frontline teachers. In accordance with expert feedback, certain indicators are refined to construct a comprehensive evaluation index system for equipment digital textbooks. Finally, the Analytic Hierarchy Process is applied to calculate the weight values of each constituent indicator based on questionnaire responses, resulting in an evaluation index system for new forms of digital textbooks that reflects the relative importance of each component.

title: Deployment of IoT Technologies for Phase Balancing in Low-Voltage Power Distribution
authors: Aship Chaudhary, Samundra Gurung, Rabindra Maharjan, Priyanshu Rouniyar, Sashank Shrestha, Yubraj Chimoriya
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Smart Power &amp; Internet Energy Systems (SPIES)
abstract: Voltage Unbalance (VU) is a significant power quality issue in low-voltage (LV) distribution feeders, particularly when voltage drops approach allowable limits and residential loads are unequally distributed across the three phases. The increasing penetration of single-phase rooftop solar photovoltaic (PV) systems further worsens this problem by introducing asymmetrical power injection, leading to greater per-phase loading variation and increased VU. High levels of VU can increase network losses and cause malfunctions or premature failure of three-phase equipment, such as induction motors. To mitigate this, a distributed intelligent load transfer scheme is proposed to dynamically reduce VU by redistributing residential loads among phases. A central controller installed at the distribution transformer monitors power consumption in each house using Internet of Things (IoT) technology and determines optimal load transfers. These transfers are executed via static transfer switches with a three-phase input and a single-phase output, installed at each residence to allow flexible phase reassignment. A short pi-model distribution line with unbalanced loading conditions is developed in MATLAB/Simulink to simulate the proposed scheme. The simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the approach in reducing voltage unbalance and improving the overall performance of the feeder.

title: Barriers to Integrating Low-Power IoT in Engineering Education: A Survey of the Literature
authors: V. Sanchez Padilla, Albert Espinal, Jose Cordova-Garcia, Lisa Schibelius
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Information Technology, Electronics and Mobile Communication Conference (IEMCON)
abstract: Low-power Internet of Things (IoT) technologies are becoming increasingly important in engineering education as a tool to help students connect theory to real applications. However, many institutions face barriers that slow down their adoption in courses and labs. This paper reviews recent studies to understand these barriers and organizes them into three groups: technical, organizational, and curricular/pedagogical. Technical barriers include energy management, scalability, and integration issues. Organizational barriers are related to cost, planning, and the need for trained staff. Curricular and pedagogical barriers include gaps in student readiness, limited lab time, and platform choices that depend on budget. By detailing these barriers with practical examples, this paper aims to help educators and academic leaders develop more effective strategies to adopt low-power IoT in engineering programs.

title: Tool for On-Demand Virtual Courses Generation using Content Curation and Artificial Intelligence
authors: Alvaro Fernández Del Carpio, Carlos Mamani Anccasi, Abel Aragón Alvarado, Luis Mamani Arosquipa
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Software Engineering and Service Science (ICSESS)
abstract: The continuous production of tutorial videos on the internet about several topics provides a rich source of educational material that should be leveraged effectively. This generates a need for tools that enable easy access to educational content for learners interested in self-directed study. This paper introduces an innovative tool for dynamically creating an on-demand course. It addresses challenges such as information overload and content organization by using YouTube's extensive video library combined with the advanced processing and generation capabilities of Large Language Models (LLMs) and content curation techniques. The functions of the tool enable, firstly search and selection of YouTube videos based on user prompts. Then, the Gemini-2.5-flash model analyzes the selected videos and metadata to generate a coherent course structure and complementary material. Finally, a crucial LLM-assisted content curation phase refines and structures the content, seeking to align with the subjects of each section. This approach provides a personalized learning path, optimizing accessibility by obtaining targeted material from YouTube videos for effective learning. Initial evaluations demonstrated partial results of the tool to produce structured course content that meets learners’ needs. Although with initial results, this tool can establish a promising direction for democratizing access to personalized learning.

title: A Photonics-Enabled Framework for Intelligent Variable Traffic Sign Recognition and Anomaly Detection
authors: Ryum-Duck Oh, Mirjalol Fayzullaev, Shokhjakhon Abdufattokhov
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: Variable Message Signs (VMS) and Variable Speed Limits (VSL) are two of the most important parts on evolving Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS) for supply drivers with dynamical traffic information in real time nowadays. Having accurate sign detections is crucial to road safety regulations. But such dynamic interfaces can be corrupted by occasional hardware failure, environmental conditions and data transmission errors, which, if not detected in time, can make serious trouble for the driver. The changes in the environment i.e. day and night lighting, unfavourable weather, change in the camera distance or quality make it quite a challenging task to identify anomalies in these road signs in real time. This paper introduces the photonics-enhanced deep learning system which is reliable in detecting anomalies in Variable Traffic Signs. The methodology relies on the CCTV videos collected over 2.5 years, a diversity of conditions including lighting, distance, and the design of signs, and annotated with thousands of samples. The suggested pipeline transfers the images through the CMOS-built sensors and optical transmission links, integrates YOLOv8 to detect the objects, OpenCV to pre-process the images, and Optical Character Recognition (OCR) to detect and analyze Variable Traffic Signs. Anomalies are identified by comparing the received text and numeric values to logical consistency, format and semantic completeness. Intended to be used as real-time roadside VMS and VSL applications, the system is proven in experiments that the system is capable of providing a lightweight yet scalable solution to automated sign surveillance, which reinforces the management of road safety.

title: Simulation Comparison Between Nonlinear GNN and ZNN for Online Complex Sylvester Equation Solving
authors: Zhiguo Tan, Yunong Zhang, Yilin Wu, Qian Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Robotics and Automatic Control (IRAC)
abstract: As a follow-up to our prior work [1], in this paper, the fixed-time nonlinear gradient neural network (GNN) model proposed therein for solving the real Sylvester equation is extended to address the complex Sylvester equation. Furthermore, the corresponding nonlinear zeroing neural network (ZNN) model employing the same modified sign-bi-power function is introduced for comparative analysis. Simulation-based comparisons between these two models are conducted to illustrate their effectiveness and fixed-time convergence performance in solving the complex Sylvester equation. In addition, the impact of parameters of the modified sign-bi-power function on the convergence performance of the two models is also exhibited through simulation experiments.

title: GIS-Integrated Semi-Supervised U-Net for Automated Spatiotemporal Detection and Visualization of Land Encroachment in Protected Areas Using Remote Sensing Imagery
authors: Binghui Li
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Geographic Information and Remote Sensing Technology (GIRST)
abstract: With such illegal land use activities as gradually increasing within the restricted protected areas of the United States, it is urgent to carry out the efficient monitoring and management support for encroachment through remote sensing images and intelligent analysis. In this work, we develop a Semi- supervised Enhanced U-Net (SS-EU-Net) for remote sensing images in this article, with an ability to identify land encroachment areas, as well as to visualize spatially and analyze its time evolution behavior by means of the geographic information system (GIS). Inherited from the conventional U-Net, the model introduces two critical improvements: first, the method integrates self-supervised pre-training scheme and pseudo-label generation mechanism to improve the feature learning capability of the model on the unlabeled satellite images. Multi-scale attention fusion module was proposed to greatly enhance the segmentation performance on complex edge of ground objects. The model takes a remote sensing image with geographical coordinates as an input and then generates a pixel-level mask of encroachment based on GIS layer through coordinate registration, which accomplishes the refined monitoring for the temporal and spatial variations of encroachment as well as helps for the decision support. Experimental results demonstrate that SS-EU-Net enhances the IoU and F1 by 5.3% and 4.7% in remote sensing image data set of typical protected areas in USA than existing methods.

title: Emerging Fiber-Optic Sensing Technologies for Climate-Resilient Smart Agriculture
authors: Aliev Marat Muhamedovich, Vivek Veeraiah, Mamatha G, Ankur Gupta, Dharmesh Dhabliya, Shahanawaj Ahamad
publish: 2025 Optical Communication, Photonics, Telecommunications, and Intelligent Machine Applications (OPTIMA)
abstract: Climate variability exacerbates spatiotemporal uncertainty in soil moisture, plant water status and micro climate and pose a problem in the scheduling of irrigation and maximization of inputs at the farm scale. Although solutions using IoT and vision offer useful decision support signals, they are limited with regards to spatial continuity, electromagnetic interference, and long-term stability. In this paper, the authors review emerging fiber-optic sensing technologies participants fiber Bragg gratings (FBGs), distributed temperature sensing (DTS), distributed acoustic sensing (DAS), and interferometric schemes and suggest to combine edge–cloud analytics with them to create climateresilient smart agriculture. We combine the experience acquired with smart irrigation, greenhouse AI, and optical/photogrammetric monitoring and position fiber sensing into a virtuous cycle of reliable high-granularity measurements. A reference architecture is suggested to merge fiber, environmental, and vision signals providing resilient control in stressful climate conditions, coupled with region knowledge.

title: TOF characterization of new MAPD-3NM-II SIPM
authors: A. X. Pinto, F. Ahmadov, P. M. M. Correia, G. Ahamadov, Z. Sadygov, A. Sadygov, M. Holik, O. Pavlas, P. Kučera, O. Urban, E. D. Bosne, J. F. C. A. Veloso, S. Lyubchyk, F. Mamedov, A. L. M. Silva
abstract: Silicon Photomultipliers (SiPMs) have become an integral part of time-of-flight positron emission tomography (TOF-PET) scanners in recent years. Their excellent photodetection efficiency and fast decay time are essential in state-of-the-art timing resolutions, which have enabled improvements in image quality for TOF-PET. However, most SiPMs share a common architecture: an array of single avalanche photodiodes. This design has a limitation: each pixel requires its own quenching resistor and conductive connections, creating inactive regions that reduce the effective detection area. In this paper we explored a new type of SiPMs called the Micropixel Avalanche Photodiodes (MAPD) for the purposes of TOF-PET. These devices utilize buried pixel technology, which minimizes detector dead zones and achieves an almost 100 % fill factor. We evaluated their noise characteristics, energy resolution, and coincidence timing resolution (CTR). Our findings indicate that although the MAPD-3NM-II devices exhibit higher dark count rates, notable optical cross-talk, and a narrower overvoltage range compared to the reference Hamamatsu S14160-3015PS SiPMs, they offer superior energy resolution—improving up to 17 % at 511 keV—while maintaining competitive timing performance at the same overvoltage. In particular, with 3.8×3.8×4 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> LYSO crystals, the MAPD-3NM-II achieved a CTR of 336 ± 12 ps, a 5% improvement compared to Hamamatsu at the same overvoltage. Despite operating only up to 4.5 V, the MAPD-3NM-II demonstrates strong potential for TOF-PET applications, especially in scenarios prioritizing energy resolution. Further structural optimizations to reduce cross-talk and expand the operable voltage range could make this technology a competitive alternative to established SiPM architectures.

title: A CNN-LSTM-Attention Model for Fatigue State Assessment of Helicopter Rotor Using FBG Sensors
authors: Yiqun Zhang, Yumin Zhang, Lianqing Zhu, Chaofan Deng, Mingxin Yu
abstract: Accurate fatigue state assessment of helicopter rotors is essential for structural health monitoring, enabling early identification of degradation and improved operational safety. However, existing fatigue assessment methods often suffer from insufficient nonlinear modeling capability, heavy reliance on simulated data, and limited treatment of temporal dynamics and long-range dependencies across the fatigue assessment. To address these limitations, we propose an optimized hybrid 1D CNN-LSTM-Attention model for fatigue state assessment from fiber Bragg grating strain measurements. A full life-cycle strain-fatigue dataset is established through ground calibration and dynamic flapping fatigue experiments on a full-scale GFRP rotor beam instrumented with multiple FBG channels. The proposed architecture extracts local temporal patterns using 1D CNN, captures long-range dependencies using LSTM, and emphasizes fatigue-critical segments via attention-based reweighting. Experimental results under six-fold leave-one-sensor-out evaluation achieve 95.25% accuracy, 95.52% precision, 95.51% recall, and a 95.50% F1 score, outperforming conventional machine-learning baselines. Ablation studies further verify the contributions of each module. Additional evaluations under sensor-wise and section-wise holdout provide quantitative evidence of robustness to spatial variability within the same rotor-beam design under the tested conditions.

title: Spectre-Fed: Evolving Federated Edge Intelligence from FedEdge-ID to Robust-Private IoT Intrusion Detection via Hybrid Adversarial Training
authors: Saeed Ullah, Junsheng Wu, Mian Muhammad Kamal, Mohammed K. Alzaylaee, Mohammad Alibakhshikenari
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: The growing number of Internet of Things (IoT) devices requires decentralized Edge Intelligence solutions. As the current FL-based IDS systems are decentralized solutions for privacy protection, face two major problems: (1) network traffic manipulation through adversarial evasion attacks (2) privacy threats from gradient-based inference attacks and (3) server-side Robustness issue. The current methods which use Differential Privacy (DP) or adversarial training result in 5-15% accuracy reduction which makes them unsuitable for deployment. The key novelty of our work is the integration of a novel dual-defense framework that uniquely reconciles the conflict between differential privacy noise and adversarial gradient requirements, effectively eliminating the conventional ”accuracy tax” along with server-side Robust Aggregation. Our research develops an enhanced two-stage federated system which is robust and protects privacy while delivering secure IoT edge intelligence solutions. The core system FedEdge-ID provides 99.73% detection performance across different edge devices. Spectre-Fed enhances the FedEdge-ID framework via three key defenses: (1) Hybrid Loss Adversarial Training (α=0.5) to fortify decision boundaries against evasion, (2) Gradient-Guided Adaptive Privacy with decreasing noise injection (σ0=0.0005, γ =0.95) for secure gradient updates, and (3) Robust Trimmed Mean Aggregation to counter Byzantine poisoning. Experiments demonstrate that Spectre-Fed’s client-side (Layer 1) defense achieves 99.72% clean accuracy with only a 0.01% utility loss versus the non-private baseline. It shows strong adversarial resilience, retaining 99.34% accuracy against FGSM attacks (ϵ =0.01), a mere 0.38% degradation from the clean state. When integrated with server-side Robust Aggregation (Layer 2), the system sustains 99.59% accuracy even under active label-flipping attacks from 20% of clients, while preserving high utility compared to the baseline. The system achieves optimal privacy-utility balance through its formal privacy protection and its ability to resist adversarial attacks which makes it suitable for zero-trust IoT systems.

title: Autonomous Weeding Robots: Coordinating Locomotion and Manipulation via Long Short-Term Memory-Proximal Policy Optimization Reinforcement Learning
authors: Shunzheng Ma, Ruijiao Li, Shuojie Cong, Xi Nie, Rezwan Al Islam Khan, Chengjia Yu, Wenju Zhou, Huosheng Hu, Hongbin Fang, Huiliang Shang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: Autonomous weeding robots offer significant potential for reducing labor and environmental costs in precision agriculture. However, most systems decouple chassis locomotion from manipulator control, limiting efficiency in unstructured environments. We present LSTM-PPO-Weeding, an end-to-end framework unifying mobility and manipulation via memory-augmented reinforcement learning (RL). A high-speed region of interest (ROI) filter abstracts camera input into three-dimensional weed/crop poses, enabling the system to focus solely on task-relevant features. To mitigate challenges arising from occlusion and partial observability, we integrate long short-term memory (LSTM) into the proximal policy optimization (PPO) algorithm, establishing the proposed LSTM-PPO framework. The agent learns coordinated actions through a custom reward function balancing speed and precision. Experiments in simulation and real-world greenhouse settings show that LSTM-PPO-Weeding improves throughput while maintaining high accuracy. Compared to baseline methods, our approach reduces average weeding time by up to 74% with minimal loss in success rate, demonstrating its robustness for agricultural mobile manipulation.

title: A Reward Cooperative Distribution and Tracing Mechanism-Enabled MARL Algorithm for Adaptive Routing in SDN-Enabled UASNs
authors: Zhenyu Wang, Chuan Lin, Guangjie Han, Guan Wang, Difei Jia, Yating Zhang, Shengbo Wang
abstract: Underwater Acoustic Sensor Networks (UASNs) have garnered considerable attention in recent years due to their widespread applications in both industrial and civilian domains, such as ocean exploration and environmental monitoring. This paper introduces an intelligent Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning (MARL) algorithm to determine routing in UASNs with dynamic underwater environments adaptively. Initially, we model ocean currents and acoustic signal loss in underwater communication to perform the real-world characteristics of underwater routing. Based on software-defined networking (SDN) principles, we redefine the architecture of UASNs and propose an Adaptive Routing scheme for Software-Defined UASNs (ARSDU). Leveraging ARSDU, we propose the Reward Cooperative Distribution and Tracing Mechanism-enabled Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning (RCDTM-MARL) algorithm to optimize routing decisions. The proposed RCDTM-MARL algorithm enhances the convergence speed of MARL by decomposing the reward function into independent-reward and interactive-reward, while incorporating an experience replay buffer to further accelerate convergence. Ultimately, the adaptive routing decision algorithm, based on RCDTM-MARL, adaptively determines the optimal routing path for UASNs. The evaluation results demonstrate that the proposed routing scheme outperforms recent research approaches, achieving superior underwater data routing decisions on multiple key performance metrics.

title: Event-Enhanced Hand Behavior Modeling: Toward Robust Dexterous Hand Motion Transfer
authors: Shaochen Wang, Kang Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Biometrics, Behavior, and Identity Science
abstract: Transferring human hand skills to robots is critical for biometric behavior analysis and human-robot interaction. Existing methods primarily rely on RGB cameras, which suffer from motion blur and overexposure conditions, limiting their applicability in real-world scenarios. To address this, we propose a novel framework that synergistically combines event cameras (bio-inspired sensors with high dynamic range and low latency) with RGB data, enabling robust hand imitation through spatiotemporal synchronization. Our approach leverages the complementary strengths of event streams (capturing fast motion details) and RGB images (providing texture and edge information), effectively mitigating challenges like overexposure and motion blur. Furthermore, we contribute a large-scale synthetic event dataset tailored for dexterous hand analysis, supporting future research in biometric behavior modeling and dexterous motion transfer. Experiments demonstrate improvements over RGB-only methods, particularly in overexposure and fast motion scenarios, with enhanced accuracy and stability in both synthetic and real-world evaluations. This work bridges the gap between bio-inspired sensing, behavioral biometrics, and robots.

title: RIS-Assisted 5G and Beyond Communications in Tunnel Environments: Performance Analysis and Optimization
authors: Abdellah Chehri, Mourad Nedil, Rachid Saadane
abstract: This study investigates the transformative potential of Reconfigurable Intelligent Surface (RIS)-assisted fifth-generation (5G) and beyond, Beyond 5G (B5G), wireless communication systems in the uniquely challenging context of underground mine galleries and other confined environments, such as subway systems, road tunnels, and underground urban complexes. These environments—characterized by severe signal attenuation, complex geometries, and limited line-of-sight (LoS) conditions—demand innovative solutions to ensure reliable connectivity for safety-critical operations and autonomous systems. We evaluate the performance of four distinct RIS phase optimization strategies: Random Phase Assignment, Greedy Algorithm, Semidefinite Relaxation (SDR), and Deep Q-Network (DQN). Using detailed simulations at a 28 GHz carrier frequency, we assess key performance indicators including signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), bit error rate (BER), channel capacity, outage probability, and energy efficiency across varying tunnel distances. The results demonstrate that RIS-enabled intelligent phase control significantly enhances communication robustness and efficiency in subterranean environments, with the DQN-based approach achieving superior SNR gains while maintaining computational tractability. These findings underscore the strategic importance of RIS in advancing resilient, high-performance wireless infrastructures for underground mining and other confined industrial settings.

title: IRS Aided Federated Learning: Multiple Access and Fundamental Tradeoff
authors: Guangji Chen, Jun Li, Yuanhao Cui, Qingqing Wu, Yiyang Ni, Meng Hua, Shihang Lu
abstract: This paper investigates an intelligent reflecting surface (IRS) aided wireless federated learning (FL) system, where an access point (AP) coordinates multiple edge devices to train a machine leaning model without sharing their own raw data. During the training process, we exploit the joint channel recon figuration via IRS and resource allocation design to reduce the latency of a FL task. Particularly, we propose three transmission protocols for assisting the local model uploading from multiple devices to an AP, namely IRS aided time division multiple access (I-TDMA), IRS aided frequency division multiple access (I-FDMA), and IRS aided non-orthogonal multiple access (I NOMA), to investigate the impact of IRS on the multiple access for FL. Under the three protocols, we minimize the per-round latency subject to a given training loss by jointly optimizing the device scheduling, IRS phase-shifts, and communication computation resource allocation. For the associated problem under I-TDMA, an efficient algorithm is proposed to solve it optimally by exploiting its intrinsic structure, whereas the high quality solutions of the problems under I-FDMA and I-NOMA are obtained by invoking a successive convex approximation (SCA) based approach. Then, we further develop a theoretical framework for the performance comparison of the proposed three transmission protocols. Sufficient conditions for ensuring that I-TDMA outperforms I-NOMA and those of its opposite are unveiled, which is fundamentally different from that NOMA always outperforms TDMA in the system without IRS. Simulation results validate our theoretical findings and also demonstrate the usefulness of IRS for enhancing the fundamental tradeoff between the learning latency and learning accuracy.

title: BER Analysis and Optimization for Continuous RIS-Enabled NOMA
authors: Mahmoud AlaaEldin, Amy S. Inwood, Peter J. Smith, Michail Matthaiou
abstract: This letter investigates a novel uplink (UL) system that integrates power-domain non-orthogonal multiple access (PD-NOMA) with a continuous reconfigurable intelligent surface (CRIS). We analyze the effective CRIS-assisted channels under spatially correlated fading to accurately approximate the characteristic function of the cascaded channel. This allows the derivation of an expression for the bit error rate (BER), a key performance metric for UL PD-NOMA. We further utilize the derived BER expressions to introduce a joint optimization frame-work that minimizes the average BER via UL power allocation and dynamic RIS partitioning among the users. The analytical results are validated by simulations, and show that the proposed optimization scheme eliminates the BER floors that are associated with UL NOMA. The results also confirm the superiority of the optimized CRIS-NOMA scheme over conventional orthogonal multiple access (OMA) and non-optimized UL NOMA schemes.

title: Improved Isolation Forest-Based Anomaly Detection for Cooperative Spectrum Sensing Against SSDF Attack in CWSNs
authors: Yunlong Li, Jun Wu, Jiabao Yu, Zhiguang Yang, Mingkun Su, Yanrong Zhai, Xu Bai, Xiaorong Xu, Jianrong Bao
abstract: Cognitive radio (CR) technology aims to address spectrum scarcity by allowing sensor nodes (SNs) to detect and opportunistically access channels that are not utilized by primary users (PUs), thereby improving spectrum utilization. By applying cooperative spectrum sensing (CSS), CR improves spectrum detection accuracy, but also introduces security risks such as spectrum sensing data falsification (SSDF) attack. This letter proposes a defense strategy based on the improved isolation forest (IIF) for detecting malicious sensor nodes (MSNs) in cognitive wireless sensor networks (CWSNs). We analyze the distinct behavior patterns of the two types of SNs, and detect MSNs by isolating data points. Furthermore, we present an enhanced version of the traditional isolation forest to address its limitations. Finally, comparative experiments confirm the superiority of the proposed approach over six other anomaly detection algorithms, demonstrating the effectiveness of the improvements.

title: Comparing V-Nova LCEVC SDK with Practical Open-Source Video Codecs
authors: María Valera, Rafael Rodríguez-Sánchez, Pedro Cuenca, Gabriel Cebrián-Márquez, Antonio Jesus Diaz-Honrubia, David Garc´ıa-Lucas
abstract: This paper presents a comparative evaluation of the V-Nova LCEVC SDK against several practical open-source video encoders, namely SVT-AV1, XEVE, VVenC, x265, and x264. We analyze the trade-offs between the compression efficiency and encoder/decoder runtime of these encoders for high-resolution (UHD and HD) 10-bit consumer applications under a random access configuration. Rate–distortion behavior is assessed using Video Multimethod Assessment Fusion (VMAF, and VMAF-NEG) and Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR), while computational cost is measured through the encoder/decoder runtime. We also analyze the impact of LCEVC’s enhancement layer in terms of both bitrate increase and rate–distortion improvement. The results show that V-Nova LCEVC SDK delivers notable reductions in encoding time with respect to its base codecs, highlighting its suitability as a low-complexity enhancement layer. By comparison, VVenC exhibits a strong compression performance at the expense of high complexity, XEVE also displays considerable encoding times, and SVT-AV1 offers a more balanced compromise between efficiency and computational requirements.

title: A Labriform-Inspired Multi-Stable Soft Robotic Swimmer_supp2-3662591.mp4
authors: Yitong Zhou
abstract: Pectoral-fin-based (labriform) swimming combines high-speed propulsion with agile maneuverability through rigid-flexible fin partitioning. Inspired by this principle, we present a multi-stable soft robotic swimmer composed of two wedge-shaped bistable actuators integrated with fin-like rigid-flexible morphologies. The bistable actuators generate large, rapid deformations for thrust production, while the compliant fin membranes enable drag-reducing feathering during recovery. An analytical model is developed to predict the shape of bistable actuators and is validated experimentally with a minimum prediction accuracy of 97.74%. Computational fluid dynamics (CFD) analysis reveals that bistable switching induces vortex dipole ejection, contributing to thrust generation. The proposed robot attains a maximum speed of 17.53 <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\text{cm.s}^{-1}$</tex-math></inline-formula> (1.10 <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\text{BL.s}^{-1}$</tex-math></inline-formula>), a turning radius of 0.58 per body length, and a turning speed of 31.51<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$^\circ$</tex-math></inline-formula>/s, highlighting our design in shaping both swimming speed and maneuverability. By integrating bistable actuation with bio-inspired fin morphologies, this work offers a principled design strategy for achieving fast and maneuverable swimming in robotic systems.

title: Attack Detection for Cyber-Physical Systems Based on Causal Representation
authors: Liang Cao, Youqing Wang, Yan Qin, Yankai Cao, Bhushan Gopaluni, Richard D. Braatz
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: Cyber-physical systems (CPSs) are increasingly vulnerable to sophisticated cyber-attacks due to their growing complexity and connectivity. Current detection approaches face significant challenges in distinguishing stealthy attacks from normal operational variations, as adversaries can craft attacks that preserve statistical correlations while disrupting physical processes. To address this critical gap, we propose a novel causal representation learning (CRL) framework that leverages intrinsic physical invariants for robust attack detection in industrial CPS. We develop two complementary methodologies, unsupervised secure causal feature extraction (USCFE) and supervised secure causal feature extraction (SSCFE), which extract low-dimensional causal features resilient to adversarial manipulation. Furthermore, theoretical guarantees on detection probability bounds and false alarm control are provided. Experimental validation shows that proposed methods outperform both traditional statistical methods and contemporary deep learning approaches, thus significantly advancing CPS security.

title: Knowledge Transferred DRL-Based Adversary for Cyberattacks on Active Distribution Network Volt-Var Control Agents: When and How
authors: Xuekuan Chen, Yujian Ye, Xiang-Peng Xie, Ziqing Zhu, Jianxiong Hu, Dezhi Xu, Goran Strbac
abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL)-based volt-var control (VVC) in active distribution networks (ADNs) is prone to cyberattacks; malicious attackers can design adversarial attacks to tamper with the real-time measurements and bypass the bad data detection (BDD) mechanism, causing voltage limit violations. Previous work in this area predominantly focuses on designing suitable attack vectors, assuming unlimited attacker resources and neglecting the BDD mechanism. To this end, a new objective as a function of attack timing is designed to maximize the frequency of voltage violation of ADNs with the fewest number of attacks. Furthermore, perturbation set transformation is implemented on the attack vectors to bypass the BDD, ensuring the stealthiness of the attack. For solving the attack optimization with complex constraints, this article reformulates the adversarial attack on DRL-based VVC agents as a hybrid-action state-adversarial Markov decision process (MDP) and proposes a novel knowledge transferred DRL-based adversary to launch strategically timed (when) and stealthy (how) adversarial attacks. Case studies are conducted to verify that the strategically timed adversarial samples generated by the adversary significantly impact the voltage regulation capability of VVC agents while ensuring stealthiness against the BDD mechanism, through benchmarking against existing baseline adversarial attack methods.
